speaker: doctor
text: What brings you back into the clinic today, miss?

speaker: patient
text: I came in for a refill of my blood pressure medicine.

speaker: doctor
text: It looks like Doctor Kumar followed up with you last time regarding your hypertension, osteoarthritis, osteoporosis, hypothyroidism, allergic rhinitis and kidney stones.  Have you noticed any changes or do you have any concerns regarding these issues?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you had any fever or chills, cough, congestion, nausea, vomiting, chest pain, chest pressure?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Great. Also, for our records, how old are you and what race do you identify yourself as?

speaker: patient
text: I am seventy six years old and identify as a white female.

speaker: doctor
text: How're you feeling today?

speaker: patient
text: Terrible. I'm having the worst headache of my life.

speaker: doctor
text: I'm so sorry. Well you are only twenty five, so let's hope this is the last of the worst. Let's see how we can best help you. When did it start?

speaker: patient
text: Around eleven in the morning.

speaker: doctor
text: Today?

speaker: patient
text: Um no yesterday. July thirty first.

speaker: doctor
text: July thirty first O eight. Got it. Did it come on suddenly?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you having any symptoms with it, such as blurry vision, light sensitivity, dizziness, lightheadedness, or nausea?

speaker: patient
text: I'm having blurry vision and lightheadedness.  I also can't seem to write well. It looks so messy. I am naturally right handed but my writing looks like I am trying with my left.

speaker: doctor
text: How would you describe the lightheadedness?

speaker: patient
text: Like there are blind spots.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay. How about any vomiting?

speaker: patient
text: Um no. I feel like my face is pretty swollen though. I don't know if it's related to the headache but it started around the same time.

speaker: doctor
text: Here in the E R, we'll do a thorough exam and eval to make sure nothing serious is going on. While we're waiting for your C T results, I'm going to order a migraine cocktail and some Morphine.

speaker: patient
text: Thank. Will the nurse be in soon?

speaker: doctor
text: Yes, she'll be right in as soon as the order is placed. It shouldn't be more than a few minutes. If it takes longer, then please ring the call bell.

speaker: doctor
text: Hello, miss. What is the reason for your visit today?

speaker: patient
text: I think I have some warts on my back end where the poop comes out.

speaker: doctor
text: I see. When did you start noticing them?

speaker: patient
text: I think like three to four weeks ago.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you feel any pain or discomfort?

speaker: patient
text: It itches a little, but I haven't felt any pain yet. Is this normal for a twenty two year old?

speaker: doctor
text: I'll have to take a look, but you'll be fine. Are there any other symptoms that you are aware of?

speaker: patient
text: Nope. Just the warts and itchiness.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you taking any over the counter medicines?

speaker: patient
text: No, only the ones which were prescribed.

speaker: doctor
text: No alternative medicine, naturopathy or anything?

speaker: patient
text: No, only whatever is here in this prescription.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay let me take a look...so you were prescribed Salmeterol inhaler-

speaker: patient
text: On as needed basis.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay and the other one is Fluticasone inhaler, which is-

speaker: patient
text: Which is a nasal inhaler.

speaker: doctor
text: Right.

speaker: doctor
text: Hi, how are you?

speaker: patient
text: I burned my hand.

speaker: doctor
text: Oh, I am sorry. Wow!

speaker: patient
text: Yeah.

speaker: doctor
text: Is it only right arm?

speaker: patient
text: Yes.

speaker: doctor
text: How's your asthma since you started using your inhaler again?

speaker: patient
text: Much better. I don't know why I didn't take it with me everywhere I went.

speaker: doctor
text: It's important to carry it with you, especially during times where you're exercising or walking more than usual.

speaker: patient
text: Yeah. I think I've learned my lesson.

speaker: doctor
text: Besides asthma, do you have any other medical problems?

speaker: doctor
text: Do you smoke?

speaker: patient
text: No, I quit before I had my daughter.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you currently pregnant?

speaker: patient
text: No, I'm not.

speaker: doctor
text: Did you have any complications with the birth of your daughter?

speaker: patient
text: I actually had a C section.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you had any other surgeries in the past?

speaker: patient
text: I got my appendix out a few years ago.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any other issues, like high blood pressure or heart disease?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have diabetes?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Are there any problems with the lungs, thyroid, kidney, or bladder?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: So, how long ago did you hurt your lower back?

speaker: patient
text: It was about four or five years ago now, when I was in a car crash.

speaker: doctor
text: What kind of treatments were recommended?

speaker: patient
text: They didn't recommend P T, and I didn't really have any increased back pain after the accident.

speaker: doctor
text: Any know drug allergies?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Hi there, sir! How are you today?

speaker: patient
text: Hello! I am good.

speaker: doctor
text: I would like to start with your family medical history today. What do you know about their medical history?

speaker: patient
text: My mother and father both had heart disease. Well, my mother had complication from her heart disease and that is how she passed.  My father was only in his forty's when he died.

speaker: doctor
text: I am so sorry the hear that.

speaker: patient
text: Thank you. I have two brothers, one whom I don't speak to very much anymore. I don't know if he has any health problems. My other brother is healthy with no issues. Both my uncles on my mother's side had polio, I think.

speaker: doctor
text: Tell me more about your uncles with polio. They both had polio?

speaker: patient
text: One of them had to wear crutches due to how bad his leg deformans were and then the other had leg deformities in only one leg.  I am fairly certain that they had polio.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you know of any other family member with neurological conditions?

speaker: patient
text: No. None that I know of.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any children?

speaker: patient
text: Yes. I have one child.

speaker: doctor
text: Is your child healthy and well?

speaker: patient
text: Yes.

speaker: doctor
text: Can you tell me about any diseases that run in your family?

speaker: patient
text: Sure, my brother has a prostate cancer.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, brother.

speaker: patient
text: My father had brain cancer.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, dad.

speaker: patient
text: Then on both sides of my family there are many heart related issues.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

speaker: patient
text: And my brother and sister both have diabetes.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

speaker: patient
text: Yes, that's it.

speaker: doctor
text: Good afternoon, ma'am. Welcome to A B C D General Hospital. Before we begin, I just need to confirm some background information on you.

speaker: patient
text: Good afternoon, doctor. Absolutely, that's no problem.

speaker: doctor
text: First, how old are you?

speaker: patient
text: I'm nineteen, sir.

speaker: doctor
text: Good, and your chart says you identify as Caucasian. Is that correct?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, sir, that's correct.

speaker: doctor
text: Great, what seems to be problem today, ma'am?

speaker: patient
text: I've had this bunion on my foot for such a long time.

speaker: doctor
text: How long has this bunion been present?

speaker: patient
text: At this point, um, I don't even remember how long it's been.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any other conditions that I should be aware of?

speaker: patient
text: Actually, yes. I have a history of, um, Charcot Marie tooth disease.

speaker: doctor
text: That's good to know, thank you.

speaker: patient
text: I would like to have surgery to cut this bunion off, I can't take it anymore.

speaker: doctor
text: I hear someone has a birthday coming up, how old are you turning, ma'am?

speaker: patient
text: I'll be ninety later this month, doctor.

speaker: doctor
text: You're here for a follow up not very long after your first visit. What seems to be the problem today?

speaker: patient
text: Well, actually, my high blood pressure and right arm symptoms are basically gone.

speaker: doctor
text: Great, I saw your blood pressure reading for today, and it's much better. Are you taking the higher dose of Mavik we recommended?

speaker: patient
text: No, I'm not taking that right now.

speaker: doctor
text: How did you tolerate the higher dose?

speaker: patient
text: I didn't feel well at all, so I just went back to the old dose.

speaker: doctor
text: That was one M G per day, correct?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, doctor. I do think I could have some white coat high blood pressure. Doctors' offices make me nervous.

speaker: doctor
text: That does happen. Here, try this sample of Tarka, please.

speaker: patient
text: What is this for, doctor?

speaker: doctor
text: Well, since you're taking the Mavik plus verapamil, you can switch over to Tarka, which is the combined version of the two drugs.

speaker: patient
text: I can't take these, doctor. They're too big.

speaker: doctor
text: Good, so back to that right arm, how is that doing today?

speaker: patient
text: Well, that pain is basically gone now, I think it had to do with that muscle problem back in my right shoulder blade.

speaker: doctor
text: Did you have x rays taken today?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, the tech brought me back right before you came in.

speaker: doctor
text: Good, I have the images right here.

speaker: patient
text: What do they show, doctor?

speaker: doctor
text: Well, these x rays of the neck and right shoulder show some degenerative changes, and possibly some kind of rotator cuff injury.

speaker: patient
text: What makes you think there's an injury?

speaker: doctor
text: Well, look right here. The humeral head is pretty high in the glenoid in the right shoulder, but do you have any pain here?

speaker: patient
text: No, none.

speaker: doctor
text: Then we won't worry about it.

speaker: patient
text: I am having this stomach pain though, doctor.

speaker: doctor
text: How has this pain developed and progressed recently?

speaker: patient
text: Well, it's improved somewhat with me not taking Aleve anymore.

speaker: doctor
text: What medicines are you taking right now, then?

speaker: patient
text: Right know, I'm just taking Tylenol as needed. That seems to be enough for me.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you think this could be acid reflux, or heartburn?

speaker: patient
text: No, but I take Tums, um, three times a day, and Mylanta at night. Oh yeah, I have these sores in my mouth, can you take a look?

speaker: doctor
text: I see. How long have you worn dentures?

speaker: patient
text: Oh I couldn't even tell you, it's been many, many years.

speaker: doctor
text: Do they come and go, the sores?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, one will come, then it'll heal up, then another.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, we'll keep an eye on it.

speaker: patient
text: And doctor, since I've been taking the Lexapro, I have some tremors on basically my whole body, at least the upper body, like my torso and arms.

speaker: doctor
text: It's hard to tell if you have a tremor today, ma'am, but do you think the Lexapro is helping otherwise?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, we think so.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you talking any medications?

speaker: patient
text: No, I don't believe in meds.

speaker: doctor
text: Oh really, let me check your list.

speaker: patient
text: Yeah never.

speaker: doctor
text: Wow amazing.

speaker: doctor
text: Any past medical history?

speaker: doctor
text: Let me see if I can find it in her records.

speaker: doctor
text: Does she see a neurologist?

speaker: doctor
text: Yes, if you could find out that'd be great.

speaker: doctor
text: How old are you?

speaker: patient
text: I am forty four.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you right handed or left handed?

speaker: patient
text: I'm right handed.

speaker: doctor
text: Tell me what happened.

speaker: patient
text: I don't know. I woke up over this numbness on my left side of the body. I remember it was on July twenty nineth.

speaker: doctor
text: Was there any sensation like having pins and needles? Was there any weakness? Is there any change in your visual or mental status? Were you able to walk?

speaker: patient
text: I was able to walk and there was no weakness or any other thing you mentioned.

speaker: doctor
text: When did you first start noticing these symptoms?

speaker: patient
text: There was nothing around Independence Day. It all started after that. At first, I felt that my right hand is very clumsy, and it is kind of stiff. Then I noticed leaning towards the right when walking. It was strange. Happened around July seventh.

speaker: doctor
text: Did you recently have any cold or flu like symptoms?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Were diagnosed with a thing called multiple sclerosis?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Did you ever have a feeling where you felt like there's an electric is going up or down your spine?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: How about any fatigue or pain? Any frequency in your urination? Any urgency in that?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: You had a heart surgery, right?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, that is right.

speaker: doctor
text: Pacemaker?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, they did that.

speaker: doctor
text: What else? What other surgeries?

speaker: patient
text: I have had a hysterectomy.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

speaker: patient
text: Yeah.

speaker: doctor
text: How old are you, young boy?

speaker: patient
text: I am twenty nine.

speaker: doctor
text: And you got right side shoulder pain? Is this something new?

speaker: patient
text: Yes. That is right.

speaker: doctor
text: What were you doing when this happened?

speaker: patient
text: I think I was picking up a stack of cardboard, then putting it down on the ground and twisting to the right side. And sometimes I was throwing them a little bit as well.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, and how far you were lifting them or bending?

speaker: patient
text: Around here, till waist level.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

speaker: patient
text: I heard a pop and since then there is pain in this area. I can't lift heavy items. Basically I have no strength.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay. And this all started from June thirty two thousand and four?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, that's right. The pain is in the lateral part of the back of my shoulder.

speaker: doctor
text: How did you lose your arm if I may ask?

speaker: patient
text: Motorcycle accident.

speaker: doctor
text: When did the nausea and vomiting start?

speaker: patient
text: About a few hours ago. I can't seem to stomach anything.

speaker: doctor
text: How many episodes of vomiting have you had?

speaker: patient
text: At least four.

speaker: doctor
text: Any abdominal pain, fever, chill, or other symptoms?

speaker: patient
text: Just nausea and vomiting. It's been so terrible.

speaker: doctor
text: I'll order you some Zofran to help bring the nausea to bay. One moment while I put the order in.

speaker: doctor
text: Good afternoon, ma'am.

speaker: patient
text: Good afternoon, doctor.

speaker: doctor
text: Is this your assistant, ma'am?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, she helps me out all day.

speaker: doctor
text: Great, do you have your food diary sheets?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, can you give them to her, please?

speaker: doctor
text: Thank you. What are you doing for exercise?

speaker: patient
text: Um, right now, I walk around at the mall to get my steps in every day.

speaker: doctor
text: Is he currently taking any medication?

speaker: doctor
text: Hello, sir. I see your last visit was on July two thousand and seven. What was the reason for that visit?

speaker: patient
text: My asthma was acting up, and it felt like I couldn't breathe.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have a history of asthma?

speaker: patient
text: Not that I know of, but I know I always get this really bad cough where I cough up some nasty phlegm.

speaker: doctor
text: I see. I'm looking at your report and it says you have a history of pneumonia.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you know about any medical traits in your family?

speaker: patient
text: No, everyone in my family is quite healthy. I'm not aware of any medical problems.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you sexually active?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I am with my boyfriend.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you take any drugs or alcohol or smoke?

speaker: patient
text: No, none of them.

speaker: doctor
text: Any past medical history?

speaker: patient
text: Um there were a couple times where I noticed my blood pressure was high but that's improved as of late.

speaker: doctor
text: When did these episodes occur?

speaker: patient
text: About a year ago.

speaker: doctor
text: Did you follow up with your previous doctor?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, my old doctor knows.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay then. Let's see. Have you been checking your own blood pressure as a result?

speaker: patient
text: No not really.

speaker: doctor
text: It looks like your blood pressure was normal today, which is a good sign.

speaker: patient
text: Great.

speaker: doctor
text: Hm any allergies to medications?

speaker: patient
text: None that I know of.

speaker: doctor
text: And it looks like you have gained about fourteen pounds since last year. Any new diet changes or stressors?

speaker: patient
text: I lost my job last January and it took a pretty big toll on me.

speaker: doctor
text: I'm sorry to hear that. How have you been coping?

speaker: patient
text: I'm doing better now but I need to watch what I eat. I tend to eat a lot more when I'm stressed. It's something I'm working on.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you allergic to anything?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I am allergic to Penicillin.

speaker: doctor
text: Any other drugs that you could be allergic to?

speaker: patient
text: Nope that is all.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: Poor renal sufficiency, possibly due to dehydration or diabetic nephropathy. She also has high blood pressure and low blood sugar as a result of missing meals regularly.

speaker: patient
text: Doc what are you going to diagnose me as?

speaker: doctor
text: We are looking at blood born pathogen exposure secondary to needlestick.

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I was also thinking around contamination.

speaker: doctor
text: Correct. About two days ago. I believe it was a head on collision.

speaker: doctor
text: Any allergies I should know about?

speaker: patient
text: Nope, no allergies for me.

speaker: doctor
text: Hello sir. Let me first start by asking your age. How old are you?

speaker: patient
text: I'm twenty four.

speaker: doctor
text: So, what brought you here? How can I help you?

speaker: patient
text: I was out for fishing this weekend, I think I got into some poison ivy and I have these rashes all over my chest, legs, arms and also some are on my back.

speaker: doctor
text: You seem so confident of it being poison ivy has it happened before?

speaker: patient
text: Oh yes, it has happened several times before. It usually takes some time to get over. Last time I was here Doctor Blackman gave me a steroid injection.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, let me check my records. It looks like he gave you eighty milligrams of depomedrol. How was it last time after the injection?

speaker: patient
text: It worked fine. It did take us some time to get rid of it.

speaker: doctor
text: Did you take any medicine or anything else this time?

speaker: patient
text: I took over the counter Benadryl. Also, I'm applying cortisone cream on the rashes.

speaker: doctor
text: Did they help you?

speaker: patient
text: I saw a little bit of improvement. But this weekend it seemed to have been worst.

speaker: doctor
text: No worries, let's set you up for another injection.

speaker: doctor
text: You had mentioned that cancer runs in your family. What type of cancer?

speaker: patient
text: Skin cancer.

speaker: doctor
text: Any other health problems in the family?

speaker: patient
text: High blood pressure.

speaker: doctor
text: Hi, what brings you here today?

speaker: patient
text: I feel this lump on the upper side of my breast.

speaker: doctor
text: Both sides?

speaker: patient
text: No, only on the left side.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you feel it deep inside or on the outer side?

speaker: patient
text: Only on the outer side.

speaker: doctor
text: I understand that you are new to the clinic. Welcome.

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I am new here. I have lived in Arizona for the last four years. I am from Maine. That is where I grow up and most of my family still lives there.

speaker: doctor
text: What line of work are you in?

speaker: patient
text: I am a homemaker. I used to clean house, a while back.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have children?

speaker: patient
text: I have two children but only one of them is still with us. My oldest son passed away from ulcerative colitis complications three years ago.

speaker: doctor
text: I am so sorry to hear that!

speaker: doctor
text: You okay there?

speaker: patient
text: Uh yeah, sorry. I'm just trying to adjust the stretcher.

speaker: doctor
text: Want some help?

speaker: patient
text: No, thank you. I think I got it.

speaker: doctor
text: So how're you doing?

speaker: patient
text: Fine, but I have this weird lump in my chest.

speaker: doctor
text: When did you first notice it?

speaker: patient
text: It's been there for a while. I'd say almost half a year.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you seen anyone for it?

speaker: patient
text: No, not until now.

speaker: doctor
text: Is it causing you pain? And has it changed in size at all?

speaker: patient
text: Not really. It's just noticeable when I run my fingers over it.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you spotted any swelling or redness to the area? Any drainage?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: I see. Okay. Let me take a look and then I'll have you walk down the hall to get an Xray so we can see what's going on.

speaker: doctor
text: Hello, so you are here for follow up today.

speaker: patient
text: Yes, very much.

speaker: doctor
text: I will ask you some regular questions, okay?

speaker: patient
text: Sure.

speaker: doctor
text: Any pain in urination?

speaker: patient
text: Nope.

speaker: doctor
text: Any fever or chills?

speaker: patient
text: Neither of them.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you noticed any blood while urinating? Any blood in your urine?

speaker: patient
text: Nope. I do leak, especially when I'm changing my positions like from sitting to standing so I do feel there is some involuntary urination. It's more like a urge. I'm loading data in like every one hour in the morning, especially when I take that Lasix.

speaker: doctor
text: Does it taper off in the afternoon or night?

speaker: patient
text: It tapers off in the afternoon. And by the night I don't do not feel anything.

speaker: doctor
text: Any leakage in the night?

speaker: patient
text: Nope.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you apply a lot of force to urinate?

speaker: patient
text: Nope.

speaker: doctor
text: How about this stream? Is it good or less? Are you emptying well? And what about the bowel movement?

speaker: patient
text: The stream is good. It does feel like all is out in one go. I do not have any kind of bowel issues. I'm using my vaginal cream. Sometimes I feel difficulty in doing so because I feel that there is still something coming out from the vagina and I'm afraid that there might be a prolapse.

speaker: doctor
text: Don't worry, I will look into it.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you lost weight?

speaker: patient
text: No, I haven't, you can ask my daughter.

speaker: doctor
text: How about anything like fever, nausea, vomiting, pain?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: And as we discussed you have problem talking and comprehending.

speaker: patient
text: Yes.

speaker: doctor
text: And you get urine infections too?

speaker: patient
text: Yes.

speaker: doctor
text: And as discussed, your drainage is similar to past episodes when you had such infection?

speaker: patient
text: Yes.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you use tobacco products? Cigarettes, chewing tobacco or vaping?

speaker: patient
text: I used to smoke a pack a day.  I quit that awful habit in nineteen eighty five.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you work?

speaker: patient
text: I am retired.

speaker: doctor
text: Wonderful. Is your husband retired with you?

speaker: patient
text: Yes. We both are. I cannot imagine working a full time job at seventy six years old.

speaker: doctor
text: Hi there, how are you?

speaker: patient
text: I am okay.

speaker: doctor
text: So, I see you turned eighty-eight yesterday, happy birthday!

speaker: patient
text: Thank you!

speaker: doctor
text: And you are referred by Doctor X, he is your primary physician, right?

speaker: patient
text: Correct! I am also seeing Doctor Y for my leukemia.

speaker: doctor
text: Hm he mentioned that it's chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

speaker: patient
text: Yes.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: And you are also seeing Doctor Z for your heart related problems.

speaker: patient
text: That is correct.

speaker: doctor
text: So, tell me what is happening with you?

speaker: patient
text: For the past one week I am having this increased shortness of breath and having difficulty breathing from past few nights while sleeping.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

speaker: patient
text: And this morning I was having difficulty catching my breath. I am also having wheezing since morning.

speaker: doctor
text: Let me examine you, can you come forward and sit-up here? Any chest discomfort or acute chest pain or anything of that sort? Any pain of the left arm?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Any dizziness, feeling like fainting or light headedness or losing control?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Well, I don't think there is any sign of cardiovascular accident or heart attack, so that's that. You do have mild peripheral edema. We need to treat that.

speaker: patient
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: Ready to go home?

speaker: patient
text: I just can't wait.

speaker: doctor
text: Sure. I can understand.

speaker: patient
text: Bye Doctor.

speaker: doctor
text: Yes. See you soon.

speaker: doctor
text: Hello, sir. How are you today? Can you confirm your age?

speaker: patient
text: Fifty eight. I feel like my balance is off, and I've been feeling tired and weak.

speaker: doctor
text: How long have you been experiencing this?

speaker: patient
text: It's been going on for six to eight weeks.

speaker: doctor
text: I see. Did you feel any other symptoms?

speaker: patient
text: I haven't, but this might not be related. I had pneumonia ten days before this all started.

speaker: doctor
text: Interesting. Did you take any medication for that?

speaker: patient
text: I did, but I don't know how to pronounce it. I wrote it down for you to read. Here it is.

speaker: doctor
text: Let me take a look. I see you took a full course of amoxicillin, right?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, that's right.

speaker: doctor
text: How did you feel after you finished the antibiotics?

speaker: patient
text: Terrible. I felt like I couldn't control my body. My balance got even worse, and I felt even more tired and weak.

speaker: doctor
text: Oh, wow. Do you know why your balance and coordination worsened?

speaker: patient
text: I did fall recently, but I know for a fact my balance was off before my fall.

speaker: doctor
text: How high were you when you fell?

speaker: patient
text: I think I was three or five feet high when I fell.

speaker: doctor
text: Did you fall on your back?

speaker: patient
text: No, I fell on my feet. Just kidding, I fell on my back.

speaker: doctor
text: Funny. Did anything hurt after your fall?

speaker: patient
text: Not really, but I've been having some back pain in my lower and mid back.

speaker: doctor
text: Did you always have that pain?

speaker: patient
text: No, I haven't. It comes and goes.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you done anything to treat it?

speaker: patient
text: I started to see a chiropractor like five days ago. He adjusts my neck and lower back.

speaker: doctor
text: I see. Did you start having problems with your balance after this?

speaker: patient
text: No. I was still having problems with that before I saw the chiropractor.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay. So, it wasn't the result of the adjustments. Is there anything else that may have caused it?

speaker: patient
text: I was taking this other medicine for ten days, but I don't remember what it was for. Here is the name of the medication. I wrote it on another paper.

speaker: doctor
text: It looks like you took Cipro. This is usually used to treat a U T I. Were you aware you had a U T I?

speaker: patient
text: Oh, yeah. I forgot about that. I thought I had one, so I went to another doctor to get some medication.

speaker: doctor
text: I see. I have one more question. Do you have any trouble controlling your bowel movements or attempting to go to the bathroom?

speaker: patient
text: Nope. I feel like I'm able to go to the bathroom whenever I want.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you had any illnesses in the past?

speaker: patient
text: Nope.

speaker: doctor
text: Anything that is worth mentioning?

speaker: patient
text: Nope.

speaker: doctor
text: Sure?

speaker: patient
text: Yes.

speaker: doctor
text: Good afternoon, sir. My nurse tells me you're twenty eight years old, is that correct?

speaker: patient
text: Good morning, doctor. Yes, that's correct.

speaker: doctor
text: So, what happened?

speaker: patient
text: Well, I punched a wall about three days ago.

speaker: doctor
text: Which hand is it?

speaker: patient
text: It's my right hand.

speaker: doctor
text: Is this your dominant hand?

speaker: patient
text: Unfortunately, yes, it is.

speaker: doctor
text: Where does it hurt?

speaker: patient
text: Um, it's right here on the outside of my hand.

speaker: doctor
text: What kind of treatments have you had?

speaker: patient
text: I went to the E D, and they pushed some of the joints in my hand back, and they put me in a splint, so I've been wearing that ever since.

speaker: doctor
text: How is your pain today?

speaker: patient
text: Compared to when it started, it's much better today.

speaker: doctor
text: How would you describe your pain today?

speaker: patient
text: Today, I'd say it's minimal pain.

speaker: doctor
text: Good, do you have any numbness or tingling today?

speaker: patient
text: No, thankfully not.

speaker: doctor
text: Hello there, how are you?

speaker: patient
text: I am good, thank you.

speaker: doctor
text: He is my colleague Doctor Mason, and he will be assisting me today and taking down notes.

speaker: patient
text: Hello.

speaker: doctor
text: Is it okay with you if he can join us?

speaker: patient
text: Sure, no problem.

speaker: doctor
text: Great, thank you

speaker: doctor
text: Doctor Mason can you take down the notes.

speaker: doctor
text: Patient looks well developed and well nourished. He is alert with not acute distress.

speaker: doctor
text: Patient had a head injury, but he is fully conscious. G C S is fifty and nontoxic.

speaker: doctor
text: Anyone sick in your family?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: How about anyone with the same disorders?

speaker: patient
text: No, I don't know.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay don't you worry.

speaker: doctor
text: How did the patient do on the activity test?

speaker: doctor
text: How old was he when he were first evaluated in the other hospital?

speaker: doctor
text: Which hospital was that again?

speaker: doctor
text: So what exactly happened?

speaker: doctor
text: Did the intensity change?

speaker: doctor
text: How long were they in the duration?

speaker: doctor
text: Was there any other associated disorder or anything?

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have major illnesses in the family like diabetes or high B P?

speaker: patient
text: No nothing. No major illnesses.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

speaker: patient
text: Yes.

speaker: doctor
text: Good morning, sir.

speaker: patient
text: Good morning, doctor.

speaker: doctor
text: I just need some background information before we begin today.

speaker: patient
text: Sure.

speaker: doctor
text: Good, have you ever had surgery, sir?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, actually I've had it on my knee, a nose job, and, um, carotid sinus surgery.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you still working?

speaker: patient
text: No, I am retired now. I used to work for the U S postal service as an electronic technician but took retirement one year earlier due to my disability.

speaker: doctor
text: Ah okay. And who is in your family?

speaker: patient
text: Well, I stay with my wife and daughter in our apartment.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay. Do you smoke?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: How about alcohol?

speaker: patient
text: I use to drink occasionally, that too very rare, but after my symptoms stated I stopped completely.

speaker: doctor
text: Any use of recreational or illegal drugs?

speaker: patient
text: Nope.

speaker: doctor
text: Did you travel anywhere recently?

speaker: patient
text: No, it's been really long since I traveled anywhere.

speaker: doctor
text: Good afternoon, how are you today?

speaker: patient
text: I am good Doctor, thanks for asking.

speaker: doctor
text: This is my colleague Doctor White, and she will be taking the notes. Is it okay if she joins us?

speaker: patient
text: Oh sure, no problem.

speaker: doctor
text: Thank you.

speaker: patient
text: Nice to meet you too.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, can you breathe in and out for me? Deep breaths please.

speaker: patient
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay breath sounds are clear. Lung function looks good. Symmetrical rise and fall in chest as patient breathes. I am going to palpate your chest, it's just a routine exam.

speaker: patient
text: Sure.

speaker: doctor
text: Doctor White can you make a note, no egophony or tactile fremitus.

speaker: doctor
text: Where do you live?

speaker: patient
text: I live in a board and care. It is a nice small care home with some very nice and supportive people. It is just next to the Safeway on Village Drive.

speaker: doctor
text: Nice. It looks like you love living there.

speaker: patient
text: Oh yes. I feel very relaxed there.

speaker: doctor
text: Did you consume alcohol in any way?

speaker: patient
text: No Sir.

speaker: doctor
text: Any tobacco consumption?

speaker: patient
text: Never in my life.

speaker: doctor
text: Did you ever try any kind of illicit drugs? Any I V drugs?

speaker: patient
text: No. I have always kept myself away from all those things.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you had any surgeries in the past?

speaker: patient
text: Actually, yes, I had my gallbladder removed in nineteen ninety two.

speaker: doctor
text: Great, any other surgeries? Think back a little further?

speaker: patient
text: Oh yeah, I had my appendix out in nineteen eighty eight.

speaker: doctor
text: How are feeling now after the treatment?

speaker: patient
text: I am feeling pretty fair, improving slowly.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay?

speaker: patient
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: Sir? Can you hear me? Are you Mister Smith's wife?

speaker: doctor
text: How old is he? Can you tell me a little bit of how your husband's condition has come to this point? His level of consciousness is concerning.

speaker: doctor
text: It looks like your husband was admitted to the emergency room the night before.  How did these injuries to his face happen?

speaker: doctor
text: The Adult Protective Services said they found your husband in the home barley conscious. How long had he been that way?

speaker: doctor
text: Do you know what other medications your husband has taken other than the Xanax?

speaker: doctor
text: How have you been feeling? Is the Wellbutrin keeping your mood stabilized?

speaker: patient
text: I have been feeling good. The Wellbutrin is working well for me.

speaker: doctor
text: It is important to not consume any alcohol or recreational drugs while taking Wellbutrin.

speaker: patient
text: I don't drink or do drugs.

speaker: doctor
text: Tell me a little bit about your family history.

speaker: patient
text: My dad and grandpa both had type two diabetes. My son is struggling with type one diabetes at the moment.

speaker: doctor
text: I'm sorry to hear that. Does anyone in your family have heart problems?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: How about cancer?

speaker: patient
text: Two of my cousins had breast cancer.

speaker: doctor
text: Where do you work, miss?

speaker: patient
text: Well, you see, I am a civil engineer. Right now, due to pandemic like everyone else I am working from home.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you working full time or is your disability affecting that?

speaker: patient
text: No, I can only work on half time. This disability does not let me work full time. I need to go to physical therapy quite frequently on and off and I also have a baby who consumes a lot of my time.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you smoke or drink?

speaker: patient
text: No, I've never done any of them.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you know any familiar diseases in your family?

speaker: patient
text: Do you mean like B P, high sugar?

speaker: doctor
text: Yes.

speaker: patient
text: No, no one in my family has anything like that.

speaker: doctor
text: Great.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you had any anxiety attacks lately?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you felt depressed or had any mood swing problems?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Any phobias?

speaker: patient
text: No, not really.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have a history of mental illness or psychological disease?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Hello sir. How are you doing today? You still look a little uncomfortable. Is there still pain?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah. Still a good amount of pain. I did not take my pain medication this morning though. Not sure if that will make a huge difference.

speaker: doctor
text: That is possibly why you are still in pain. How is movement? Can you get out of the house and get around?

speaker: patient
text: Yes. I am quite happy that I can do my daily activities. I can get up with minimal assistance and do many activities out of the house. I think I am gaining muscle from moving around more too.

speaker: doctor
text: How is the home exercise program going?

speaker: patient
text: I am loving pool therapy. I really feel like that is helping. I do the home exercises sometimes twice a day. I really want to get back to normal.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you had any surgeries in the past?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I had knee surgery.

speaker: doctor
text: Which knee?

speaker: patient
text: Right.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you sexually active?

speaker: patient
text: Yes.

speaker: doctor
text: How many partners do you have?

speaker: patient
text: Just one.

speaker: doctor
text: Is this a monogamous relationship?

speaker: patient
text: Yes.

speaker: doctor
text: What gender is you partner?

speaker: patient
text: He is a male. We have been together for three years. He is H I V positive.

speaker: doctor
text: I remember you mentioned that you had one operation done in the past.

speaker: patient
text: I had a lymph node biopsy back in September of O three.

speaker: doctor
text: Did it come back negative?

speaker: patient
text: Fortunately, yes.

speaker: doctor
text: It looks like you have an extensive medical history.

speaker: patient
text: I blame my heart. It's caused me the most trouble. I had coronary artery bypass surgery in twenty ten along with an angioplasty.

speaker: doctor
text: I'm sorry that your heart has been giving you so much trouble. I'm happy that you're here with us today and taking the right measures to keep yourself healthy.

speaker: patient
text: Oh, and I forgot to mention that I've had prostate biopsies in the past.

speaker: doctor
text: When did you have the biopsies done?

speaker: patient
text: Last year.

speaker: doctor
text: Did they come back negative?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, fortunately. I guess my prostate isn't as troublesome as my heart.

speaker: doctor
text: I understand.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any medical problems?

speaker: patient
text: Let's see. I have diabetes, high blood pressure, high cholesterol, and osteoporosis.

speaker: doctor
text: And any surgeries?

speaker: patient
text: Several.

speaker: doctor
text: Which ones?

speaker: patient
text: I had my tonsils taken out when I was a kid. I also had my uterus removed along with my ovaries and fallopian tubes. The list goes on. I had my appendix removed and two or three of my parathyroids taken out. Despite getting some of my parathyroids removed, I still have borderline high calcium levels according to my endocrinologist.

speaker: doctor
text: Did you experience any complications during or after surgery?

speaker: patient
text: No. I forgot to mention that I had two carpel tunnel releases as well.

speaker: doctor
text: What is your family medical history?

speaker: patient
text: My mother passed away from complications with Huntington Disease. She was diagnosed and had been having treatments at U I H C. My grandmother and two of my aunts also passed away from Huntington as well.

speaker: doctor
text: I am so sorry. Do you have siblings?

speaker: patient
text: Yes! I have one sister. She is thirty eight. She has a lot of metal issues. She has attempted suicide two times.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you close with her?

speaker: patient
text: No. Not really.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you married?

speaker: patient
text: Yes.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have children?

speaker: patient
text: Yes. We have two adopted kids.

speaker: doctor
text: Any medical problems on your mom or dad's side?

speaker: patient
text: My dad has lupus and his brother has Addison's disease. High blood pressure also runs in the family.

speaker: doctor
text: Is your dad being treated for lupus?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, he follows up with his rheumatologist pretty regularly.

speaker: doctor
text: I will do a quick exam on you.

speaker: patient
text: What kind of exam?

speaker: doctor
text: I'm just checking for lymph nodes. Whenever there is an infection those guys are the first ones to be noticed with swelling.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, so let's first check your neck area. It looks good. I don't feel any inflamed lymph node. Your armpits look good too and the last place to check is your groin area. It is all good. No sign of infection.

speaker: doctor
text: What are some medications you are on?

speaker: patient
text: I am on pain pills.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you know their names?

speaker: patient
text: Yes. Oxycontin and Vicodin.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay that helps.

speaker: doctor
text: I am looking at the list of your medication.

speaker: patient
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: All I can see is Risperdal and Invega.

speaker: patient
text: I think that is correct.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you not taking anything else?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I take some multivitamins, but do I need to mention it?

speaker: doctor
text: Yes, you should. We need to know everything.

speaker: patient
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: Good morning, ma'am.

speaker: patient
text: Oh, good morning, doctor.

speaker: doctor
text: Please, tell me about your living situation.

speaker: patient
text: Well, right now, I live at home with my kids and my dad.

speaker: doctor
text: I see here that you're not able to go up the stairs well, can you tell me more about that?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I can't use the stairs without holding the rail the entire time.

speaker: doctor
text: Holding the rail makes navigating the stairs easier?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, but I still move very slow.

speaker: doctor
text: I see. Do you smoke?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I smoke about a pack to a pack and a half a day.

speaker: doctor
text: What about exercise? Do you workout?

speaker: patient
text: No, I don't regularly workout, I've never been good at it.

speaker: patient
text: My physician did a blood test. My potassium is high. He recommended me to meet you.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay. I did not get the blood report yet. I am waiting for your doctor's office to send it to me. Is it only your potassium that is elevated?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, that's what they told me.

speaker: doctor
text: I am sorry! He does have multiple trauma due to the accident, and he will require aftercare.

speaker: doctor
text: So, what is your family's living situation at home?

speaker: doctor
text: May I assume that you are his biological parents?

speaker: doctor
text: Great, does he have any siblings?

speaker: doctor
text: What grade is he in?

speaker: doctor
text: Great, and is he doing well in school?

speaker: doctor
text: Good afternoon, what gender do you identify with?

speaker: patient
text: Thank you for asking, I identify as a female.

speaker: doctor
text: Thank you. Do you know of any chronic illnesses?

speaker: patient
text: No, but can you give me some examples of what you mean?

speaker: doctor
text: Well, high blood pressure, osteoarthritis, diabetes, depression, anything like that ring any bells?

speaker: patient
text: Oh, no, I don't have anything like that.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any major medical conditions that I should know about?

speaker: patient
text: What, like cancer?

speaker: doctor
text: It doesn't have to be that serious, but is there anything you take medicine for?

speaker: patient
text: Oh, I have allergies and asthma.

speaker: doctor
text: Can you tell me something about your mom and dad?  Like any diseases they have had?

speaker: patient
text: Sure, my dad died of heart attack when he was sixty five and my mom died of stroke when she was seventy.

speaker: doctor
text: How's about siblings, miss? Any health issues?

speaker: patient
text: No, my brother is healthy.

speaker: doctor
text: Does anyone in your family suffer from any health problems?

speaker: patient
text: No one comes to mind.

speaker: doctor
text: Great.

speaker: doctor
text: Tell me, what's going on?

speaker: patient
text: And I feel the right side is drooping.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, let me look at it.

speaker: doctor
text: My chart here says that you're eighty three years old, is that correct, ma'am?

speaker: patient
text: Yes doctor, that's correct, I just had my birthday.

speaker: doctor
text: Happy belated birthday! How have you been doing since your last visit?

speaker: patient
text: Well, my cancer hasn't needed phlebotomies for several months now, which is good.

speaker: doctor
text: That's great, you have been treated for polycythemia vera, correct?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, that's the one.

speaker: doctor
text: I also see you're unassisted today, which is also great.

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, having some independence is nice.

speaker: doctor
text: So, do you have any family history of cancer?

speaker: patient
text: Well, yes, but I can't remember who had what kind.

speaker: doctor
text: Still, that's helpful, thank you. What about heart disease?

speaker: patient
text: That too, there's some history of heart disease, but I can't remember who.

speaker: doctor
text: As far as you know, are there any major health conditions that you know about?

speaker: patient
text: What do you mean by that?

speaker: doctor
text: Anything like cancer, or arthritis, do those sound familiar?

speaker: patient
text: Oh, um, no nothing like that.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any medical history that we should be aware of?

speaker: patient
text: I have type two diabetes. My numbers always come high.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, anything else?

speaker: patient
text: I also have high cholesterol.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: Hello. How are you feeling today?

speaker: patient
text: Great. I'm just here for my yearly physical.

speaker: doctor
text: Oh, good. I see your past medical history is missing. Do you, by chance, know if you've had any health related problems before?

speaker: patient
text: Uhm. Let me check my notes on my phone. I knew this question would pop up, but I always forget. Oh, perfect. You can take a look at them.

speaker: doctor
text: Thank you. I just want to verify the information with you. You had asthma, nasal inflammation, and some abnormal growth on you neck, correct?

speaker: patient
text: If it's on there, then it's true. I usually don't remember these kinds of things. My wife is usually here with me. She knows all about my health.

speaker: doctor
text: How's the little one doing?

speaker: doctor
text: How long was your pregnancy?

speaker: doctor
text: Was your delivery normal or C section?

speaker: doctor
text: How much did she weigh?

speaker: doctor
text: Tell me what's the issue?

speaker: doctor
text: What else did you notice?

speaker: doctor
text: It looks like she's having some food intolerance.

speaker: doctor
text: What medications are you taking right now?

speaker: patient
text: I am taking Advair and Allegra.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay is it helping you?

speaker: patient
text: I don't know, I am not sure the Allegra is helping. But I do take them regularly.

speaker: doctor
text: But is it like better than Claritin?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I think so.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay that's good.

speaker: patient
text: Shall I continue?

speaker: doctor
text: Anybody sick in family?

speaker: patient
text: No one.

speaker: doctor
text: How about any illnesses that run in your family?

speaker: patient
text: No, everyone is healthy.

speaker: doctor
text: Hi again! How has your acne been since you started the spironolactone?

speaker: patient
text: It has been improving.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you experienced any increased thirst, mood changes or unusual fatigue?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Well, I don't think you need any restraints as you are doing fine. I do want to make sure you have a chair and bed monitor since you have a history of multiple falls. They can help detect fall.

speaker: patient
text: I don't want that, I will manage.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you sure?

speaker: patient
text: Yes!

speaker: doctor
text: Do you know when was the last time you got a tetanus shot?

speaker: patient
text: No I don't remember.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: Hi there! How are you today?

speaker: patient
text: Hi! I am good.

speaker: doctor
text: Welcome in!

speaker: patient
text: Thank you.

speaker: doctor
text: Lets start with a little social history. Are you a tobacco or alcohol user?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you married? Do you have children?

speaker: patient
text: I am not married but I do have a two year old son.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you currently see a gynecologist?

speaker: patient
text: Yes. She is in Bartow.

speaker: doctor
text: Great.

speaker: doctor
text: Tell me about your family medical history.

speaker: patient
text: My family is pretty healthy. I don't know of any health problems.

speaker: doctor
text: Welcome in.

speaker: patient
text: Thank you.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you smoke?

speaker: patient
text: No, I don't. Smoking is gross.

speaker: doctor
text: I agree. Do you drink alcohol?

speaker: patient
text: Yes.

speaker: doctor
text: How much do you drink per day or week?

speaker: patient
text: When I get off work usually have a glass of wine. I don't ever have more then one glass.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: The nurse applied antibiotic ointment and a bandage to your foot. Did she go over how to change the bandage at home?

speaker: patient
text: Yes.

speaker: doctor
text: Hello. Before we begin, I need you to confirm some information for me.

speaker: patient
text: What kind of information?

speaker: doctor
text: About your family. Do you know if you have certain medical conditions that run in your family?

speaker: patient
text: Nope. My family is very healthy.

speaker: doctor
text: How about any breathing issues or asthma?

speaker: patient
text: Actually, I have a history of asthma.

speaker: doctor
text: Oh okay, and was it severe or mild?

speaker: patient
text: Well, it was not severe but still remarkable.

speaker: doctor
text: Hm, alright.  Anything else?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I also struggled with a serious acne problem.

speaker: doctor
text: Got it.

speaker: doctor
text: How's she doing?

speaker: doctor
text: Aw and why's that?

speaker: doctor
text: Does she happen to snore at night?

speaker: doctor
text: Hm.

speaker: doctor
text: Lemme take a look. Have you applied anything to the area?

speaker: doctor
text: Why are you holding your face?

speaker: patient
text: Ah! Have pain in my tooth.

speaker: doctor
text: Oh, how bad is it?

speaker: patient
text: Oh, awfully bad.

speaker: doctor
text: I am so sorry.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you had similar symptoms before?

speaker: patient
text: No never like this.

speaker: doctor
text: Any other complaints you have had in the past?

speaker: patient
text: Just some knee pain issues.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, so chronic knee pain.

speaker: patient
text: Yes.

speaker: doctor
text: Can you tell me about any cancers in your family?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, my sister has ovarian cancer, and my father has liver cancer.

speaker: doctor
text: Oh I am so sorry.

speaker: patient
text: That is okay.

speaker: doctor
text: Any heart conditions?

speaker: patient
text: My mom and dad both have heart disease. My dad has diabetes too.

speaker: doctor
text: Can you tell me what problems you have had in the past. Or what medical issues are currently going on?

speaker: patient
text: You mean my heart problem and things?

speaker: doctor
text: Yes.

speaker: patient
text: Okay, I have hypertension and kidney problems since many years.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

speaker: patient
text: I get frequent urinary infections.

speaker: doctor
text: Your urine creatinine is normal.

speaker: patient
text: Okay. I also have severe aortic stenosis.

speaker: doctor
text: Does anyone else in your family have aneurysm problem?

speaker: patient
text: Well, my grandmother had it. She actually passed away due to brain aneurysm.

speaker: doctor
text: Oh, okay.

speaker: doctor
text: What is wrong with your back honey?

speaker: patient
text: Oh, it all started off with a little pimple on the buttock.  I was soaking it at home with hot water and stuff, but it did not improve. I hope this is not cancer. I am only twenty four.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay what exactly are you experiencing?

speaker: patient
text: I have pain.

speaker: doctor
text: So you came to the hospital on the first and they did an I and D in E D?

speaker: patient
text: Yes I was admitted to the hospitalist service with high blood sugars. My African American father was so scared.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay sugars high. Do you know the number? How high?

speaker: patient
text: No, I do not know that but they found positive bacteria or some sort of thing in my blood culture.

speaker: doctor
text: So today we are evaluating you for surgery?

speaker: patient
text: Yes.

speaker: doctor
text: Hi there! I have the results from your ultrasound. You have kidney stones in the ureter close to the bladder.

speaker: patient
text: Oh no.

speaker: doctor
text: This explains the pain you have been having on your left side. Are you still experiencing nausea and vomiting?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I have been.

speaker: doctor
text: I would like to set you up with a consult with a consult with a surgeon.

speaker: patient
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: Any known drug allergies?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Your daughter had an exposure to the ant bait but we are not sure if she actually ingested any of it. Poison Control confirmed that even if she did ingest the small amount that she was found with, it is likely nontoxic. Do you have any questions?

speaker: doctor
text: Hello, sir. How are you today?

speaker: patient
text: I am alright. I am here for a check up since I am feeling kind of dizzy lately.

speaker: doctor
text: That is not good. How long has this been happening?

speaker: patient
text: A few months. This happened to my sister too. I think she is still dealing with it.

speaker: doctor
text: Is there any other family medical history I should know about? Migraines or cancer?

speaker: patient
text: No. Not that I know of. The rest of my family seems pretty healthy.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you know anyone in your family whose had cancer?

speaker: patient
text: No one that I know.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay so your blood report is back and the cardiac enzyme we were looking for are negative.

speaker: patient
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: Your blood urea nitrogen, also known as B U N, is within normal limits and hydrogen is stable. Creatinine is also within the normal range.

speaker: patient
text: Great!

speaker: doctor
text: Are you on any medications?

speaker: patient
text: No, not taking any medications.

speaker: doctor
text: Hi, how are you doing today?

speaker: patient
text: I've been better. Thank you.

speaker: doctor
text: So, you are here for your follow up right? Remind me how often are you coming here?

speaker: patient
text: That's right. I'm coming around between a month or two.

speaker: doctor
text: Yeah, it's every four to eight weeks.

speaker: patient
text: I'm not taking any medicine now. I just wanted to let you know.

speaker: doctor
text: Yeah, I can see it in your record. It says that you are off of all the immunosuppression. So, just let me check. It says here that you do have mild chronic G V H D. It is not that bad that I should be worried about any therapy or anything else. How long ago did you get that transplant?

speaker: patient
text: I think it was around four and a half years ago. I'm feeling much better after that. I do have complaints of blood in my stool. But after you sent me to that doctor, that gastro doctor, I feel good. I know they said that they removed something, but I'm not sure, but after that it has been improved a lot.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, let me see in my chart. You had some rectal bleeding issues because of which I referred you to the gastroenterologist. A complete endoscopy was performed, which was both on the upper and the lower side. There was no evidence of ulcers or any other abnormality. That's  good news, right?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I agree. That was a relief.

speaker: doctor
text: They did find some polyps and they removed it. They turned out to be benign, so nothing to worry about there.

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I remember this said they removed something, but I forgot the name.

speaker: doctor
text: Is there any other issue that I can help you with?

speaker: patient
text: I don't know. I feel a lot of fatigue and like I'm not able to do things like I used to do before. I get tired very easily. I don't know if it is related to something or not, but things have been weird. I'm not able to do even the minor things like I lift two boxes and I'm done for the day. Is it something that I should be worried about?

speaker: doctor
text: It looks like you have a mild iron deficiency. I will work on that with you, don't worry.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you feeling any pain?

speaker: patient
text: No, I feel great.

speaker: doctor
text: Is there any other medical issue that we should be worried about?

speaker: patient
text: No, it feels like I'm young again. I'm able to do all my activities.

speaker: doctor
text: Thank you for coming in to see us at A B C D General Hospital today.

speaker: patient
text: I wish I wasn't here right now.

speaker: doctor
text: I understand, before we begin, how old are you?

speaker: patient
text: I'm seventy seven years young.

speaker: doctor
text: Which race, and gender do you identify with?

speaker: patient
text: I'm an African American woman.

speaker: doctor
text: What's seems to be causing you pain today?

speaker: patient
text: I've had this bunion on my foot for as long as I can remember.

speaker: doctor
text: Is the pain worsening?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, it is so painful, I've tried to avoid surgery for so long, but I want this bunion gone.

speaker: doctor
text: How have you managed this bunion in the past?

speaker: patient
text: I've used antiinflammatories, rested, changed my activities, I've done everything, but this pain is getting worse and worse.  I need it gone.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have diabetes or blood pressure problems?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I have hypertension but no diabetes.

speaker: doctor
text: Alright.

speaker: doctor
text: How are you dealing with your pain now?

speaker: patient
text: Oh no, I have no issues with my pain. Today I'm here for a different cause. I'm having this weakness all around on my left side, especially in my arm. I feel like I cannot lift anything like even a glass of water. It's hard for me to lift it up. I'm not able to walk properly, let alone the balancing and everything else. It's just that my whole left side seems to be weak.

speaker: doctor
text: Did you have any medical disorders previously, sir?

speaker: patient
text: I have diabetes. Also, I was quite overweight.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you taking any medications for that?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I was still taking something called Zyprexa, but I stopped it after my last regular weight check. Also, I never took anything for diabetes. I also have chronic bronchitis for… I don't know… many years.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you smoke?

speaker: patient
text: Oh yes, I am a smoker.

speaker: doctor
text: How many cigarettes do you take in a day?

speaker: patient
text: Maybe up to sixty a day.

speaker: doctor
text: Lets talk about your ears. Any continuous ringing or thumping noises you may hear?

speaker: patient
text: No, nothing like that.

speaker: doctor
text: Any hearing problems?

speaker: patient
text: Um, no.

speaker: doctor
text: Any dizziness or spinning sensation?

speaker: patient
text: Nope.

speaker: doctor
text: Good morning, ma'am. You're eighty two years old, is that correct?

speaker: patient
text: Good morning, doctor. Yes, that's correct.

speaker: doctor
text: Good, and just one more piece of background information, which hand do you write with?

speaker: patient
text: I use my right hand for everything.

speaker: doctor
text: Good, so what seems to be the problem today?

speaker: patient
text: Doctor, I've had years of pain in this shoulder.

speaker: doctor
text: What kind of treatments have you had?

speaker: patient
text: Well, um, I've had antiinflammatories, and rested, and none of it has helped so far.

speaker: doctor
text: Can I assume the pain is impacting your daily life?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, it certainly is. The pain is unbearable now.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you ever had surgery?

speaker: patient
text: What, like a joint replacement?

speaker: doctor
text: Well, anything from joint replacements, to appendix removal, or C sections?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I've had an appendectomy and hysterectomy, actually.

speaker: doctor
text: Can you confirm your age for me, ma'am?

speaker: patient
text: Absolutely, I'm sixty six now.

speaker: doctor
text: Good, so it's been about five months since you last evaluation for type two diabetes and high blood pressure.

speaker: patient
text: Yes, and I have a few other problems today, too.

speaker: doctor
text: Sure, we can treat all of them. What seems to be the problem today?

speaker: patient
text: I'm having some right shoulder pain.

speaker: doctor
text: Can you remember an injury to this shoulder?

speaker: patient
text: No, not that I can remember.

speaker: doctor
text: What aggravates your symptoms?

speaker: patient
text: It hurts when I move the shoulder.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any weakness, numbness, or tingling?

speaker: patient
text: No, I don't have any of that.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, back to diabetes, how has that been progressing?

speaker: patient
text: Well, I can only check it in the morning, and it's usually less than one hundred.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you been checking your blood sugar two hours after meals?

speaker: patient
text: No, doctor, I haven't been. When I check them, it's normal though.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any records to prove that?

speaker: patient
text: No, I don't have that with me today.

speaker: doctor
text: That's important, do you have any other issues or concerns today?

speaker: patient
text: No, I can't think of anything.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay. I'm looking at your charts, and I see you had a benign breast biopsy done on June eleventh two thousand four. Did you have a repeat done after six months like they asked?

speaker: patient
text: No, I never had that done, I need to.

speaker: doctor
text: What is your family medical history?

speaker: patient
text: None, that I know of.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you mind giving me a run down of his past medical history? I want to make sure it's all in his chart.

speaker: doctor
text: I see. When did he have these done?

speaker: doctor
text: If it's his prostate, then B P H is correct.

speaker: doctor
text: Is he currently experiencing any symptoms?

speaker: doctor
text: How long have you been living with diabetes, sir?

speaker: patient
text: Oh, it's been about thirty five years now.

speaker: doctor
text: How long have you been taking insulin for this?

speaker: patient
text: Well, um, I've been taking insulin for about twenty years now.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any major medical conditions that I should know about?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, um, prostate cancer.

speaker: doctor
text: How were you treated for this?

speaker: patient
text: I've had radiation. Oh, my P S A is zero point zero one, by the way.

speaker: doctor
text: So, what stomach symptoms are you experiencing?

speaker: patient
text: I feel an intense burning in my throat.

speaker: doctor
text: When do you feel this?

speaker: patient
text: It really hurts after eating food, especially junk food.

speaker: doctor
text: That's pretty consistent with reflux disease.

speaker: patient
text: Ah, yes.

speaker: doctor
text: I got your survey results back as well, let's discuss them.

speaker: patient
text: Absolutely, please, what does it show.

speaker: doctor
text: According to your answers, it looks like you have depression as well.

speaker: doctor
text: Any difficulty in swallowing?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Any nausea, vomiting or blood in your vomit?

speaker: patient
text: No, no vomit at all. No problem there.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, any stomach pain?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: Hello, ma'am. How are you feeling today?

speaker: patient
text: I'm sad and depressed.

speaker: doctor
text: I'm sorry to hear that. Why do you feel that way?

speaker: patient
text: My cancer came back.

speaker: doctor
text: What's going on with you? What brings you here today?

speaker: patient
text: I am having loose watery stools for more than two weeks now. I feel very lethargic. I also have pain in my tummy.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you allergic to anything?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you a smoker?

speaker: patient
text: I used to smoke. I quit in nineteen sixty eight.

speaker: doctor
text: Excellent! Have you weighed your self recently?

speaker: patient
text: I weighed myself this morning. I am at one hundred and eighty three pounds.

speaker: doctor
text: And how tall are you?

speaker: patient
text: I used to be five foot ten but I think I have been shrinking.

speaker: doctor
text: That is definitely a possibility. We do shrink as we go through life. I can have the nurse get your height after we do your exam.

speaker: patient
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you smoke?

speaker: patient
text: No, I have never smoked in my entire life.

speaker: doctor
text: Welcome to the clinic, sir.

speaker: patient
text: Thank you.

speaker: doctor
text: Let us start with your medical history.

speaker: patient
text: I used to have seizures, but they have stopped now.

speaker: doctor
text: Was there a cause of the seizures?

speaker: patient
text: About seven years ago I had a traumatic stroke. They told me I had bleeding in the brain. After the stroke I was left with this weakness on my right side.

speaker: doctor
text: What part of your body is affected by the weakness?

speaker: patient
text: My arm, hand, and my face.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any other health problems?

speaker: patient
text: My liver is falling. It is because of all the alcohol that I have consumed over the years. I am not drinking anymore.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you being treated for your liver disfunctions?

speaker: patient
text: No. I just stopped drinking. I think I have diabetes.

speaker: doctor
text: What makes you feel like you have diabetes?

speaker: patient
text: I have been really thirsty, and I have been having numbness and tingling in my feet.

speaker: doctor
text: Oh okay. We can definitely do some test today to find out if you are diabetic or not.

speaker: doctor
text: Hi miss. How old are you?

speaker: patient
text: I am sixteen.

speaker: doctor
text: What race do you identify as?

speaker: patient
text: White.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you okay? You have a headache?

speaker: patient
text: No I have a really bad migraine.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay can you point to where you are feeling it the most?

speaker: patient
text: Here, since Monday.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay so mostly on the right frontal side and it's been forty eight hours now?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I am feeling a lot of pressure.

speaker: doctor
text: I can understand the discomfort. Is it continuous or throbbing?

speaker: patient
text: It is throbbing.

speaker: doctor
text: On the scale of one to ten, ten being the worst, how would you rate it?

speaker: patient
text: Nine or more.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you ever experienced similar symptoms in the past?

speaker: patient
text: No I haven't.

speaker: doctor
text: Did you hit your head buy any chance?

speaker: patient
text: No no.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay can you tell me if you have any fever or chills, congestion, cough cold like symptoms?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Any nausea, vomiting, diarrhea or trauma anywhere?

speaker: patient
text: No nothing like that.

speaker: doctor
text: Anything from head to toe?

speaker: patient
text: No everything else is fine.

speaker: doctor
text: Has the patient signed a do not resuscitate order?

speaker: doctor
text: Does she have a healthcare proxy or durable power of attorney?

speaker: doctor
text: How are you doing today?

speaker: patient
text: I have a long history of lung disease. COPD to be exact. Recently, I was experiencing a lot of coughing and shortness of breath even on walking from one room to another. All the time I felt sleepy, tired, or confused.

speaker: doctor
text: How is it now?

speaker: patient
text: It is getting better.

speaker: doctor
text: What else?

speaker: patient
text: I was also diagnosed with pneumonia; I was on trip and there they found it. It is also getting a lot better now, but doctor said to continue taking oxygen for some more time.

speaker: doctor
text: Oh wow!

speaker: patient
text: With everything going on, I felt weak and tired and it looks like I have lost all my strength and muscle.

speaker: patient
text: I also felt very instable and had a fall. I did not call for any assistance but now I think I should have called someone. Everyone including my family and nurses all tell me all the time to call for assistance. I was just being stubborn and hurt myself.

speaker: doctor
text: Did you use a wheelchair?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: You know I would agree with everyone else; you should call for assistance if you need help like getting out of bed or need to use the restroom.

speaker: doctor
text: Were there any medical issues in the past?

speaker: patient
text: Oh, I have a list. I have asthma and sinus issues. I also had hives at some point and psoriasis.

speaker: doctor
text: How about allergies?

speaker: patient
text: I don't know of any.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you use tobacco products, alcohol, or recreational drugs, miss?

speaker: patient
text: I have a drink every once and a while.

speaker: doctor
text: How many drinks do you consume in a week?

speaker: patient
text: I don't even drink that often. I probably have one drink per month.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you married?

speaker: patient
text: I was engaged but that is not happening anymore. It is a long story.

speaker: doctor
text: I am sorry the hear that. What do you do for work?

speaker: patient
text: I am a metal grinder.

speaker: doctor
text: Now that you're eighteen, I have a big question to ask you. Do you smoke?

speaker: patient
text: Never have, never will.

speaker: doctor
text: That's what I like to hear. You have a good head on your shoulders, bud.

speaker: patient
text: Thanks. I'd like to think so, too. I have some friends who smoke weed, but stay clear of tobacco.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you ever been diagnosed with any illnesses?

speaker: patient
text: No, I do not have any diseases.

speaker: doctor
text: How about any issues with B P, thyroid, diabetes?

speaker: patient
text: Nope none.

speaker: doctor
text: He was a former smoker and tested positive for cocaine during his last visit in January O eight.

speaker: doctor
text: I just quickly wanted to check few things, let's go over them together?

speaker: patient
text: Sure.

speaker: doctor
text: Any heart condition like heart failure or anything?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Any heart catheterization?

speaker: patient
text: Um, no.

speaker: doctor
text: Any history of chest pain, palpitation, or irregular heartbeat?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have high blood pressure?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Any history of high cholesterol?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Any excessive or abnormal sweating?

speaker: patient
text: Not really, no.

speaker: doctor
text: Any stress test or heart tests done recently?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, thank you for answering these questions.

speaker: patient
text: No problem.

speaker: doctor
text: Hello Miss Sherry, how are you doing today?

speaker: patient
text: I have seen worse days.

speaker: doctor
text: Ha, I will take that as a positive answer then. I have my resident here with me, Doctor Helm, she will be representing your case today.

speaker: patient
text: Hello Doctor Helm.

speaker: doctor
text: Doctor Helm.

speaker: doctor
text: Thank you Doctor Helm. So, Miss Sherry, how are you doing after the treatment?

speaker: patient
text: I feel nauseous.

speaker: doctor
text: How would you define it mild, moderate, or severe?

speaker: patient
text: I would say mild.

speaker: doctor
text: What about vomiting?

speaker: patient
text: No, only nausea is there. If I try to take deep breaths, then I still have pain.

speaker: doctor
text: How is your dysphagia? Are you able to swallow and eat your food and drink now?

speaker: patient
text: It has been better now. I won't say I am all good but as I said I have seen the worst days.

speaker: doctor
text: Is there any heartburn or rash?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you coughing up blood, or just cough?

speaker: patient
text: No, none of them.

speaker: doctor
text: Let me exam for any rib pain, okay?

speaker: patient
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: Any pain if I touch you here or here?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Around what time did the car crash take place?

speaker: patient
text: About forty five minutes ago. I think someone called nine one one shortly after it happened.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you happen to remember how fast you were driving at the time of the crash?

speaker: patient
text: I was driving about forty miles an hour.

speaker: doctor
text: What kind of car were you driving?

speaker: patient
text: A minivan. The car in front of me stopped suddenly and I hit them right from behind. The front of my car is pretty wrecked.

speaker: doctor
text: Were you wearing a seatbelt? And did the airbag deploy?

speaker: patient
text: Yes and yes.

speaker: doctor
text: Any passengers in the car with you?

speaker: patient
text: No, just me.

speaker: doctor
text: Did you hit your head anywhere?

speaker: patient
text: No, but I do have some pain on the left side of my neck.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you think you lost consciousness at any point in time?

speaker: patient
text: Actually, I do. Right after the crash.

speaker: doctor
text: Any pain elsewhere?

speaker: patient
text: Um I'm having some pain in my lower stomach area. I think it could be due to slamming into the airbag or steering wheel.

speaker: doctor
text: How would you rate this pain, ten being the worst pain ever?

speaker: patient
text: Um I'd give it a five out of ten right now.

speaker: doctor
text: Any knee, ankle, or foot pain?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: How about pain in your shoulders, elbows, or wrists?

speaker: patient
text: Uh no, but I guess I do have a little bit of pain in my pelvic area.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you remember walking before or after the ambulance arrived?

speaker: patient
text: I don't think so. Someone told me that I was placed on the stretcher after they got me out of the car.

speaker: doctor
text: Just to confirm, no chest pain or difficulty breathing?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you noticed any cuts on your skin?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Any headache, nausea, or vomiting?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Fever or chills?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Any chance of pregnancy?

speaker: patient
text: No, I've been good at taking my birth control and I also have an I U D.

speaker: doctor
text: When was your last period?

speaker: patient
text: Um end of May I believe.

speaker: doctor
