text: Are you taking anything besides birth control?

speaker: patient
text: Accutane for my pimples.

speaker: doctor
text: Any known allergies?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Any allergy to any drug?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Let's talk about your family history. Did anyone in your family have any medical issues that you were aware of?

speaker: patient
text: I don't think so. My family has been pretty healthy. Both my parents died of old age.

speaker: doctor
text: What about your siblings? Any kind of thyroid issue or diabetes or blood pressure issue there?

speaker: patient
text: I have one older brother. He's into weightlifting and all. I would say he's pretty healthy.

speaker: doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your parents, please? How are they doing?

speaker: patient
text: Thank you for asking, they're both doing very well. They're very healthy.

speaker: doctor
text: That's great to hear. How old are they?

speaker: patient
text: My mom is fifty, and my dad is forty.

speaker: doctor
text: Wonderful, do you have any siblings?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I have two sisters, one is a half sister, and the other we have the same mom and dad.

speaker: doctor
text: How old are they?

speaker: patient
text: My half sister and I have the same mom, and she's thirty four. My other sister is ten.

speaker: doctor
text: Do they have any history of medical conditions that you know about?

speaker: patient
text: My half sister, um, no. My other sister has had some yeast infections.

speaker: doctor
text: Hello sir, what brings you here today? Also, please confirm your age for the records.

speaker: patient
text: I am seventy years old. I am here for nothing particular but I just have discomfort on the right side.

speaker: doctor
text: We did electromyography study. This was to assess the health of muscles and the nerves in your body. When did you first notice this discomfort?

speaker: patient
text: About five years ago. After my stroke. I've been to a neurologist before.

speaker: doctor
text: Yeah, I can see that you have taken different kinds of medications, but nothing seems to help you.

speaker: patient
text: That sounds right. Nothing seems to help me to get rid of this discomfort.

speaker: doctor
text: How often do you check your sugar levels?

speaker: patient
text: I do it at home. Mainly two to three times a day. I increase or decrease the amount of insulin that I take based on my numbers.

speaker: doctor
text: Don't you consult anyone before doing that?

speaker: patient
text: It's been so many years now. I do it all by myself.

speaker: doctor
text: We did reevaluations of your symptoms. It turned out to be all negative. Do you smoke?

speaker: patient
text: I used to chew tobacco a lot and then there were drinks. I used to drink at least half a bottle of single malt in one night. I quit everything five years ago after my stroke.

speaker: doctor
text: It is nice to see you again, miss.  We are following up on a few things today. How is your arm feeling?

speaker: patient
text: My arm is all better. It is not in pain at all anymore.

speaker: doctor
text: How has your mood been? Are you feeling any relief from your symptoms since you have been on the Lexapro?

speaker: patient
text: It's helping a little bit.

speaker: doctor
text: How much Lexapro are you taking now?

speaker: patient
text: I am taking ten M G.

speaker: doctor
text: How long have you been taking the full dosage?

speaker: patient
text: About a week ago. I don't take it every day. I don't feel like I need it some days.

speaker: doctor
text: I want you to take the full dosage every day. This might be why you have not had much relief with your symptoms yet.

speaker: patient
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: Your hands are a little shaky. Is this a normal occurrence for you?

speaker: patient
text: I didn't even notice.

speaker: doctor
text: It is very subtle. We will keep an eye on it for now. Your blood pressure is a little better today. Have you experienced any worsening joint or bone pain?  I want to check on your osteoporosis and osteoarthritis.

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any past medical history?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: How long it has been since these psychotic periods are going off and on?

speaker: patient
text: It has been around twenty years.

speaker: doctor
text: So, you were taking Clozaril and some other medications?

speaker: patient
text: Yes.

speaker: doctor
text: Were you feeling better with them, sir?

speaker: patient
text: Yes. It was better for some years.

speaker: doctor
text: These antipsychotics, they were good on you, right?

speaker: patient
text: They were at times, but eventually there was a new episode.

speaker: doctor
text: Does anyone in your family ever have any neurological disorder?

speaker: patient
text: Not anything specific but, many of my family members had lazy eyes.

speaker: doctor
text: Who is in your family?

speaker: patient
text: My parents and my two little sisters.

speaker: doctor
text: How old are your sisters?

speaker: patient
text: One is nine, another one is five.

speaker: doctor
text: How are they both health wise?

speaker: patient
text: They both are healthy.

speaker: doctor
text: I have their surgical history if you'd like to go over it.

speaker: doctor
text: So they had an exploratory laparotomy in nineteen sixty seven.

speaker: doctor
text: They had a number of surgeries in nineteen seventy five, which include an L five S one lumbar laminectomy, anal fissure surgery, tonsillectomy, and adenoidectomy.

speaker: doctor
text: None were mentioned by the patient or their spouse.

speaker: doctor
text: How is your foot feeling?

speaker: patient
text: It feels good.

speaker: doctor
text: Any pain or discomfort when you walk around on it?

speaker: patient
text: No. I am good doc.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you married?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, for almost twenty two years now.

speaker: doctor
text: That is amazing! And are you working?

speaker: patient
text: Ah yes, I drive a delivery truck in the town.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay. So, tell me do you smoke or drink? Yes, I do both.

speaker: doctor
text: And how much would you say you smoke per day?

speaker: patient
text: I smoke about two packs a day.

speaker: doctor
text: Hm, how much do you drink?

speaker: patient
text: I drink three, oh wait, I drink two beers every day.

speaker: doctor
text: And do you do any drugs like coke or anything?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you married?

speaker: patient
text: No sir, I'm happily single.

speaker: doctor
text: Where do you work?

speaker: patient
text: I am a press worker, I work in a newspaper printing.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you smoke? Have you ever taken any Illicit drug?

speaker: patient
text: No, none of them.

speaker: doctor
text: What about alcohol?

speaker: patient
text: I don't take any now. I was a heavy drinker, but I quit in the seventies.

speaker: doctor
text: Ever reacted poorly to any medications taken in the past?

speaker: patient
text: Hm I don't think so. No reactions so far.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you taking any medications?

speaker: patient
text: Yes I am taking thyroid meds and Lipitor.

speaker: doctor
text: Any past medical history like any diabetes or high blood pressure or any heart disease?

speaker: patient
text: No, I don't remember any such thing.

speaker: doctor
text: How about any surgeries in the past?

speaker: patient
text: No. No surgeries at all.

speaker: doctor
text: Good morning, young lady, how old are you?

speaker: patient
text: Good morning, doctor. I'm thirteen.

speaker: doctor
text: Good, and what seems to be the problem today? Mom, can you explain for me?

speaker: doctor
text: I think, it's rounding about the thoracic spine. Is there a family history of this problem?

speaker: doctor
text: Yes, that's what this is. This is thoracic kyphosis to be specific. Has she seen another doctor for this?

speaker: doctor
text: What did they recommend?

speaker: doctor
text: Good, is there any back pain, numbness or tingling?

speaker: patient
text: No, I don't have any of that.

speaker: doctor
text: Is there any weakness, numbness or tingling in your legs and arms, my dear?

speaker: patient
text: No, I'm very strong, especially for my age.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you going to the bathroom with no problem?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, doctor, everything is regular there.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you allergic to anything?

speaker: patient
text: No, I am not allergic to anything.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay so no drug allergies.

speaker: patient
text: Yeah.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you married, ma'am.

speaker: patient
text: Yes, to my husband, I can't even remember how long my husband and I have been married.

speaker: doctor
text: That's wonderful. Do you drink or smoke?

speaker: patient
text: Absolutely not, I've never have used that stuff.

speaker: doctor
text: Uh let's see here. Are there any diseases that run in your-

speaker: patient
text: Family?

speaker: doctor
text: Yes.

speaker: patient
text: Nope.

speaker: doctor
text: What happened to you? How did you get involved in this accident?

speaker: patient
text: I was just trying to adjust cable that my brother's dog was tied to. All of a sudden, he attacked me out of nowhere. The injury to my leg is V shaped and the V is pointing towards my foot.

speaker: doctor
text: What kind of dog?

speaker: patient
text: German shepherd. But he is up to date on his shots, and he is completely healthy.

speaker: patient
text: He bit me on my foot, and it looks like his teeth went into my skin. I went to my P C P.

speaker: doctor
text: What did you do there?

speaker: patient
text: They cleaned the wound and did some bandage along with it he gave me a tetanus shot.

speaker: doctor
text: And he sent you to us?

speaker: patient
text: Yes.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay let me examine your wound.

speaker: patient
text: Sure!

speaker: doctor
text: It looks like there is a flap injury developed after puncture wound. It seems like a centimeter long and viable. How old are you sir? And what ethnicity do you identify with?

speaker: patient
text: White male. I am fifty years old. Is my right leg going to be okay?

speaker: doctor
text: The skin looks viable. We can save the tissue.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you aware of any family medical history?

speaker: patient
text: Nope. Both of my parents, they died of old age. They were in their eighties. I cannot remember of any other medical issue in any of my relatives.

speaker: doctor
text: What about memory loss or stroke or high blood pressure, diabetes, or any other kind of mental illness?

speaker: patient
text: Nope.

speaker: doctor
text: Anyone sick in your family out of these things?

speaker: patient
text: Nope.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have kids?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I have five children and they all are doing well in their life.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any significant medical conditions in your history that I should know about?

speaker: patient
text: What, like high blood pressure?

speaker: doctor
text: Well, it could be anything from high blood pressure, to depression, to something as serious as cancer.

speaker: patient
text: Oh, no, I don't have anything like that, at least not that I know if.

speaker: doctor
text: Hi! How are you two doing today?

speaker: doctor
text: Our records show that he is up to date on all of his two month old immunizations.

speaker: doctor
text: Does he have any health conditions or difficulties during childbirth?

speaker: doctor
text: Hello! How are you all today?

speaker: doctor
text: What happened?

speaker: doctor
text: Do you know what the ant bait was called?

speaker: doctor
text: Do you know how big the container was?

speaker: doctor
text: How old is she?

speaker: doctor
text: Have you noticed and strange behavior or vomiting?

speaker: doctor
text: Hello. Are you ready for your surgery today?

speaker: patient
text: I'm ready as can be. This isn't my first rodeo.

speaker: doctor
text: I see. Have you had surgeries before?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I have. I think it's in my report that you have with you.

speaker: doctor
text: You're right. It says here you've had some stripping of veins in your legs, a tonsillectomy, and a adenoidectomy.

speaker: doctor
text: Is she married?

speaker: doctor
text: Any history of tobacco, alcohol or drug use?

speaker: doctor
text: And tell me, are you allergic to any medications?

speaker: patient
text: No. Not that I know of.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: I'd like to get her in to see you sometime next week for her enlarged thyroid.

speaker: doctor
text: Yes, she's experiencing increased difficulty swallowing. She's also reporting throat tightness on an off.

speaker: doctor
text: Hi! How are you today?

speaker: patient
text: I am doing well. I start a new job on Monday. I have been unemployed for about a year now. It is going to be nice to get back to work.

speaker: doctor
text: Congratulations. Do you use tobacco products, drink alcohol or recreational drugs?

speaker: patient
text: I used to smoke a little bit, but I quit ten years ago.

speaker: doctor
text: Great!

speaker: patient
text: I don't drink or do drugs.

speaker: doctor
text: So, tell me about your family's medical history.

speaker: patient
text: Hm, my mother passed away due to cancer.

speaker: doctor
text: Oh, what type?

speaker: patient
text: Actually, I don't know that.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

speaker: patient
text: And my dad died due to heart attack.

speaker: doctor
text: Oh.

speaker: patient
text: Yeah.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, I don't see your vaccination record here, do you have it?

speaker: patient
text: No, I don't have it. I moved here from a different country a long time ago with barely anything. I don't have any medical records from my past.

speaker: doctor
text: I see.

speaker: doctor
text: Welcome back to the clinic, Miss A B C.

speaker: patient
text: Thank you.

speaker: doctor
text: It looks like we last saw you June twenty first, this year. Doctor X and Y referred you for the evaluation of your pinched nerve in the C six regain on the left side. I also see that we are following up on the significant rotator cuff tear on the left side.  Did you get scheduled for the surgery with Doctor Yen yet?

speaker: patient
text: Yes. I believe the surgery is scheduled for July twentieth.

speaker: doctor
text: How is your shoulder feeling?

speaker: patient
text: My shoulder is the same. I am still in a significant amount of pain.

speaker: doctor
text: I am sorry to hear that. Your surgery is coming up soon and that should help.

speaker: patient
text: I hope so.

speaker: doctor
text: We are also following up the pinched nerve in your upper left extremity C six. How are you feeling?

speaker: patient
text: I have had some pain starting in that same spot, and it goes down the left arm into my wrist.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you had any weakness associated with your upper extremities on the left side?

speaker: patient
text: It is mild and it is about the same as the last time.

speaker: doctor
text: Is it about the same as the last time you were here? We have it noted in the last note that it was mild as well.

speaker: patient
text: Yes. It has been the same.

speaker: doctor
text: Any weakness or symptoms on the right side?

speaker: patient
text: No, not really.

speaker: doctor
text: Any difficulty with mobility or moving around on either side?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you been experiencing any bowel or, bladder dysfunction.

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: I see in the chart for our last visit, I only had a report of a prior cervical spine M R I.  I don't have any recent images. I going to refer you for a cervical spine M R I. Are you able to get the imaging done today and I will have you return to the clinic at the end of today?

speaker: patient
text: Yes. I can do that. I took the whole day off of work today.

speaker: doctor
text: Great! I will put the order in right now.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you on any medications at this time?

speaker: patient
text: None whatsoever.

speaker: doctor
text: Got it.

speaker: doctor
text: Hey, how is the patient doing?

speaker: doctor
text: Oh, I see.

speaker: doctor
text: Yes, it is probably sinus infection and then cough secondary to that infection.

speaker: doctor
text: Yes, it is.

speaker: doctor
text: You have an infection that has become septic. We are going to have to start you on intravenous antibiotics.

speaker: patient
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: We also need to address the blood clotting. I am going to give you an anticoagulant to prevent any further clotting issues. Do you have any questions?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: So, what do you do for a living, sir?

speaker: patient
text: Right now, I'm a truck driver, sir.

speaker: doctor
text: Wow, that's hard work. Are you working right now?

speaker: patient
text: No, I can't right now, I'm on sick leave.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you married?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, to my wonderful wife. She's helping to take care of me.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you two have any children?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, we have three. We all live together, and for that I'm very thankful.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you smoke, sir?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I smoke about two packs a day.

speaker: doctor
text: How about alcohol? Do you drink?

speaker: patient
text: No, just smoking for me.

speaker: doctor
text: How about more illicit substances, have you used illegal or prescription drugs inappropriately?

speaker: patient
text: Oh, absolutely not.

speaker: doctor
text: That's good. Do you have any other medical conditions that run in your family that I should know about?

speaker: patient
text: No, not that I know of.

speaker: doctor
text: Hello there, how are you?

speaker: patient
text: I am good, thank you for asking.

speaker: doctor
text: So, what brings you in today?

speaker: patient
text: Well, I think I am suffering from memory loss, like short term memory loss.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, and why do you say so?

speaker: patient
text: I have been under tremendous stress for the last five to ten years. I am currently working for T mobile customer service and my work is really hectic. It requires a lot of technical knowledge with project deadlines which is adding to my stress.

speaker: patient
text: Sometimes I have trouble absorbing all the technical knowledge and computer skills or customer issues.

speaker: doctor
text: Hm.

speaker: patient
text: I did my M B A in business for a reason, I wanted to make a good career, but this job is very demanding and stressful. I previously worked at a bank in Conway Springs, Norwich. I have worked many jobs around accounting and management services, but my current job is a high stress one.

speaker: doctor
text: I see, are you married?

speaker: patient
text: I have been widowed for past eleven years. My husband died in a car accident, he was hit by drunk driver. It was not the time for my husband to go! After he left, I had to take care of everything and that's another reason for my stress from the past several years.

speaker: doctor
text: I am so sorry to hear that.

speaker: patient
text: Yeah.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, so tell me any weakness or dizziness or lethargy in the past or now?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Any history of stroke?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Hi there! Welcome to the clinic.

speaker: patient
text: Thank you.

speaker: doctor
text: Doctor Murphy sent your records over. I reviewed the ultrasound, and we did find a kidney stone that has become stuck in the ureter on the left side. The stone is large enough to block the flow of urine from the kidney to the bladder.  How much pain are you having and where is the pain located?

speaker: patient
text: I am in a great deal of pain. It is coming from my left side right here.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay. Let use discuss your treatment options.

speaker: patient
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: Any allergies?

speaker: patient
text: What do you mean?

speaker: doctor
text: Are you allergic to anything?

speaker: patient
text: No no, oh no.

speaker: doctor
text: You have type two Diabetes?

speaker: patient
text: Yes.

speaker: doctor
text: And High Cholesterol?

speaker: patient
text: Yes.

speaker: doctor
text: Your diabetes is poorly controlled.

speaker: patient
text: I will keep an eye on it.

speaker: doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your daughter's injury?

speaker: doctor
text: Did she have surgery on this?

speaker: doctor
text: Remind me, how old are you, dear?

speaker: patient
text: I'm thirteen now.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, thank you. So, um, if you look her at the x rays, it appears that the screw is now going into the hip joint.

speaker: doctor
text: We'll need to do another operation in order to remove this screw and put a shorter one in. We need to do the surgery because this can cause further joint damage.

speaker: doctor
text: Overall, the risk of infection is very low, honestly its less than one percent.

speaker: doctor
text: Yes, we'll use anesthesia the entire time. She won't feel a thing.

speaker: doctor
text: I expect her to heal up very well, but there's always a risk of some changes in sensation and motion, and she may be stiff for some time following everything. Other risks include bleeding, but I would not worry about these things.

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I want to get back to playing sports with my friends.

speaker: doctor
text: What brings you in today?

speaker: patient
text: Um a number of different things. I don't even know where to start to be honest.

speaker: doctor
text: I understand. What's bothering you the most?

speaker: patient
text: Lemme think. I'm uh having really bad pain.

speaker: doctor
text: Where's the pain located?

speaker: patient
text: Hm. It's in a tricky spot.

speaker: doctor
text: Any recent injuries or falls?

speaker: doctor
text: Hello, I want you to meet my assistant. She will be helping me out with your case today.

speaker: doctor
text: Please represent the patient's case.

speaker: doctor
text: You said you are feeling dizziness, so what makes it worse?

speaker: patient
text: It's bad whenever I try to stand straight. I also have these intermittent headaches where it feels like somebody is hammering inside.

speaker: doctor
text: Do these headaches change with changing the positions or standing straight?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Does the patient have any known medical history?

speaker: doctor
text: So, your headaches-- how long has this been going on?

speaker: patient
text: Many weeks now.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you smoke?

speaker: patient
text: I used to smoke a hundred and even more packs per year. Now it's just one to two packs each day.

speaker: doctor
text: Has there been any weight loss?

speaker: patient
text: I lost forty pounds.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you ever had jaundice?

speaker: patient
text: Um, no.

speaker: doctor
text: Any rash or anything?

speaker: patient
text: Nope.

speaker: doctor
text: Good morning, ma'am, before we begin, how old are you?

speaker: patient
text: Good morning, doctor, I'm twenty five.

speaker: doctor
text: Good, thank you. So, how are you feeling today?

speaker: patient
text: I'm okay, but I have this rash and itching over my right arm. It's so itchy and I scratch all the time.

speaker: doctor
text: Is this your dominant hand?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, so this had especially been bothering me.

speaker: doctor
text: When did you first notice these symptoms?

speaker: patient
text: Um, I think it was in October of nineteen ninety two. I think it was the twenty third.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you had any symptoms in any other parts of your body?

speaker: patient
text: Um, yeah, I've had tingling in both my legs, like in the front, and then it goes into my toes too.

speaker: doctor
text: Did this tingling sensation go away?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, it went away the next day without me doing anything.

speaker: doctor
text: Have these symptoms returned at any point?

speaker: patient
text: Well, two days later, so that'd be the twenty fifth, I noticed that my legs felt like they were asleep. I really couldn't feel anything.

speaker: doctor
text: Have these symptoms spread to any other part of the body?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I couldn't really feel anything in the middle of my chest. I also have started having pain in my right shoulder blade.

speaker: doctor
text: Do these symptoms interfere with your ability to move?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I don't really feel comfortable standing on my own, and I can't walk very well.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any cold or flu like symptoms?

speaker: patient
text: No, heat and cold don't bother me

speaker: doctor
text: Do you feel any significant fatigue?

speaker: patient
text: No, not really.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you had any significant weight loss?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: How's it going?

speaker: patient
text: Good, can't complain.

speaker: doctor
text: Glad to hear. So today we're going to do a comprehensive eval. It'll be a bit different than our usual visits together. Would you like your mom to step in the room, too?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, that's not a problem.

speaker: doctor
text: Alright. I'll grab her from the waiting room. I'll be right back.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: Oh yeah, she has chronic AFib and she is on Coumadin. Not sure if she has stopped the medicine due to upcoming surgery.

speaker: doctor
text: Alright.

speaker: doctor
text: Hello. What is the reason for your visit today?

speaker: patient
text: I keep having this dry cough and it gets hard to breathe at times.

speaker: doctor
text: Were you exposed to anything recently?

speaker: patient
text: Here's a note from a contractor that worked on my house recently. I wasn't sure what it meant.

speaker: doctor
text: I see. It looks like you may have been exposed to asbestos.

speaker: patient
text: Oh, no! Am I going to be fine?

speaker: doctor
text: I'll take a look, but I want to ask you a quick question. Did you have any family living with you at the time?

speaker: patient
text: Nope. I live alone, so my family wasn't there to be exposed.

speaker: doctor
text: How are you feeling today, ma'am?

speaker: patient
text: Honestly, overall, I'm feeling a lot better.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you still having the diarrhea and decreased appetite?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, but I'm still feeling better though.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you been peeing a normal amount?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, no problems there. I measured it like you told me to—six hundred M L.

speaker: doctor
text: When was the last time you peed?

speaker: patient
text: Um, it was about seven this morning.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you having any fever symptoms?

speaker: patient
text: No, I feel pretty well.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you smoke, sir?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you drink?

speaker: patient
text: No. I was a boxer before so that's why I was always stayed away from these things.

speaker: doctor
text: How is your living condition? Are you living alone or with family?

speaker: patient
text: Mostly I'm by myself during the daytime. Family comes to help with me on and off. I just love it that way. I wasn't to be in an independent home setting soon.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you smoke cigarettes?

speaker: patient
text: Yes.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you drink alcohol or use recreational drugs?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I have been in and out of treatment. I am not doing so well with staying clean.

speaker: doctor
text: What substances do you use?

speaker: patient
text: I drink, and I did some coke today. I have been in treatment for heroin and alcohol.

speaker: doctor
text: Hello how are you? Doctor Mina is an intern working with me. She will be taking notes and discussing your case today.

speaker: patient
text: That's okay.

speaker: doctor
text: So, tell me Doctor Mina, what brings this young man today here?

speaker: doctor
text: Thank you Doctor.  Tell me how are you doing young man? Are there any difficulties going back to school?

speaker: patient
text: I am doing fine. I do get some headaches and it feels like somebody is ringing bells in my ears. My eyesight has improved a lot.

speaker: doctor
text: Remind me, please, when was your surgery?

speaker: patient
text: Well, it's been about two and a half months now.

speaker: doctor
text: Great, we repaired that slipped capital femoral epiphysis on both sides, we call it S C F E.

speaker: patient
text: Thank you for reminding me, I forgot the names of everything.

speaker: doctor
text: Any medications I should know about?

speaker: patient
text: Nah, no daily meds.

speaker: doctor
text: Is your husband still around, ma'am?

speaker: patient
text: No, he passed away a few years ago.

speaker: doctor
text: I'm so sorry to hear that.

speaker: patient
text: Oh, it's quite all right.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you drink or smoke?

speaker: patient
text: No, I don't do either of those.

speaker: doctor
text: Good, so where are you living now?

speaker: patient
text: I'm living at Kansas Christian Home.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you live independently there?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, thankfully. But, I can't do a lot of things. I have to be sure to take my medicines.

speaker: doctor
text: Did you drive yourself today?

speaker: patient
text: No, I had a driver today. Can we speed this up, I need to get to the noon meal.

speaker: doctor
text: Welcome in, Miss A!

speaker: patient
text: Thank you.

speaker: doctor
text: How have you been doing?

speaker: patient
text: I am good today!

speaker: doctor
text: Have you not been feeling good other days?

speaker: patient
text: I have been feeling nervous and having some anxiety lately.

speaker: doctor
text: Is your feelings of nervousness or anxiousness triggered by anything specific?

speaker: patient
text: It varies. I feel anxious when I think about retuning to work or this upcoming trip that I have planned.

speaker: doctor
text: How often do you feel this way?

speaker: patient
text: It comes and goes.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you ever had any treatment or history of depression, anxiety, or mood disorders?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Who lives with you, miss?

speaker: patient
text: I live with my boyfriend.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you smoke cigarettes?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I do.

speaker: doctor
text: How about drugs?

speaker: patient
text: Sometimes, but I don't want to talk about it.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay. Anything else you want to talk about?

speaker: patient
text: Pardon?

speaker: doctor
text: Good afternoon, sir.

speaker: patient
text: Good afternoon, doctor.

speaker: doctor
text: Refresh my memory, please, how old are you, sir?

speaker: patient
text: I'm forty nine.

speaker: doctor
text: Also, I need you to remind me, when was your lower back surgery?

speaker: patient
text: It was in January of two thousand five. What was the name of the surgery, again?

speaker: doctor
text: It was a lumbar disc replacement. So, how are you feeling today?

speaker: patient
text: Truthfully doctor, the surgery did nothing. I'm still in a lot of pain.

speaker: doctor
text: Besides the surgery, what other interventions have you tried?

speaker: patient
text: I have them written down, let me look. Um, I did acupuncture, T E N S unit at P T, and I've been to the chiropractor too.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you taken any medicines?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I have those written down here. I've taken Elavil, Topamax, Cymbalta, Neurontin, and Lexapro.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you still taking any of these?

speaker: patient
text: No, I had bad side effects to some, and the others just didn't do anything.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you had any injections for this pain?

speaker: patient
text: I've had a few into the, um, piriformis.

speaker: doctor
text: Did that do anything?

speaker: patient
text: Um, it provided some brief relief, I guess. I had a Botox procedure done on March eighth two thousand six.

speaker: doctor
text: How did this work?

speaker: patient
text: Honestly, it did nothing.

speaker: doctor
text: Where is your pain, exactly?

speaker: patient
text: I'd say its seventy five percent in my butt and leg, and twenty five percent in my lower back.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you able to workout, or exercise, anything like that?

speaker: patient
text: I've tried to increase how much I walk, but when I do I get spasms in my lower back.

speaker: doctor
text: I see, with ten being the worst pain of all time, how would you rate your pain today?

speaker: patient
text: I'd say it's a six out of ten today.

speaker: doctor
text: What adjectives would you use to describe the pain?

speaker: patient
text: Um, I'd say its shooting, sharp, and, um, aching.

speaker: doctor
text: Specifically, what activities make the pain worse?

speaker: patient
text: Well, lifting, standing for a long time, or, um, squatting. I can't do that anymore.

speaker: doctor
text: Does anything make the pain better?

speaker: patient
text: Um, sitting back, ice, and I guess there's some improvement with the pain medication.

speaker: doctor
text: Is the pain constant, or does it come and go?

speaker: patient
text: It's constant now, but, um, the intensity of it comes and goes.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you able to sleep at night?

speaker: patient
text: Not really, it is affecting my sleep, which in turn affects my mood.

speaker: doctor
text: So, overall, I can summarize and say you're not happy with your pain relief so far?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, doctor, that's correct.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have a family history of neurological conditions that I should know about?

speaker: patient
text: What exactly do you mean by that, doctor?

speaker: doctor
text: Well, it could be anything from A D H D, to epilepsy, to Alzheimer's.

speaker: patient
text: Oh, no.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you on any medications?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah. I take Abilify to help with my mood.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you find that it's helping?

speaker: patient
text: A little, yeah.

speaker: doctor
text: Your culture results came back positive for Streptococcus pneumoniae. This is a bacterial infection. I would like to take a course of antibiotics.  This should start to improve your symptoms with in three to four days.

speaker: patient
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: Please let me know if your symptoms have not improved or becomes worse.

speaker: patient
text: I will. Thank you.

speaker: patient
text: I had a lung transplant in two thousand and four because of Pulmonary Fibrosis.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, how are you now? It was, was that for both lungs?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, both sides.

speaker: doctor
text: You do have irregular heart rhythm, right?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I do.

speaker: doctor
text: How are you?

speaker: patient
text: Look at this fifth fingernail on my left hand, doctor.

speaker: doctor
text: Oh what is stuck here?

speaker: patient
text: I think it's wood splinter.

speaker: doctor
text: Oh, must be painful!

speaker: patient
text: Yes a lot.

speaker: doctor
text: Can you move your arms? I would like to see how your range of motion is.

speaker: patient
text: Sure, see. Like that?

speaker: doctor
text: Yes, yes, looks good for both arms and legs.

speaker: patient
text: Great.

speaker: doctor
text: I do not see any obvious deformities in head neck or in extremities.

speaker: patient
text: Yes, no problems.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay?

speaker: patient
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you allergic to anything?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I am allergic to eggs and peanuts.

speaker: doctor
text: Oh, okay.

speaker: doctor
text: Anything else? Any medication?

speaker: patient
text: No, nothing else.

speaker: doctor
text: Alright.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you smoke, sir?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you drink?

speaker: patient
text: Sometimes I take a beer or two.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you married?

speaker: patient
text: For last ten years.

speaker: doctor
text: What do you do for living?

speaker: patient
text: I install floor. I am associated with a construction company and my main work is flooring installation.

speaker: doctor
text: Good morning, young lady. Is this your mother?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, this is my mommy.

speaker: doctor
text: Good morning, mom. Can you tell me more about your daughter, please?

speaker: doctor
text: What's been the problem with her feet?

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, how has she been since that procedure?

speaker: doctor
text: Yes, I see. She has pretty significant calcaneal valgus deformity.

speaker: patient
text: What does that mean, doctor?

speaker: doctor
text: Your heel is out of alignment, sweetie. Do you have pain?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I have a lot of pain, doctor.

speaker: doctor
text: Well, given all of her symptoms, I think we should do a calcaneal osteotomy and Achilles lengthening procedure.

speaker: doctor
text: Well, in short, we'll go in there and straighten everything out, and get everything lined back up.

speaker: doctor
text: Actually, it's less than one percent, so it's extremely low.

speaker: doctor
text: We use antibiotics to control for infection the entire time.

speaker: doctor
text: Yes, we'll use anesthesia the entire time. She won't feel a thing.

speaker: doctor
text: Well, I'll need your help. We have to be strict about her being nonweightbearing for six weeks at minimum.

speaker: doctor
text: Yes, at least for six months, but if she does everything I ask of her, it will be only six months.

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I want to get back to playing sports with my friends.

speaker: doctor
text: The other risks include bleeding; changes in sensation in most of extremity; hardware failure; need for later hardware removal; possible nonunion; possible failure to correct all the deformity; and need for other surgical procedures.  I would not worry about these issues, though. It is quite rare. So, looking at her radiographs, the spinal arch is definitely collapsed. I think you guys are making the right decision.

speaker: doctor
text: Good morning, young man. Are these your parents?

speaker: patient
text: Yes.

speaker: doctor
text: Good, can you tell me more about your son, please?

speaker: doctor
text: After he fell, how was he treated?

speaker: doctor
text: Yes, I see that here, he also has shortening bayonet apposition.

speaker: doctor
text: There's actually a few options here. First we can cast it and see how he heals, generally, children heal up very well from fractures.

speaker: doctor
text: However, surgery is also an option here as well.

speaker: doctor
text: The risk of infection is very low, generally less than one percent. We use antibiotics to control for infection.

speaker: doctor
text: Absolutely, he won't feel a thing. Other risks include bleeding, changes in sensation and motion of the extremity, hardware failure, and need for later hardware removal, and cast tightness. I would not worry about these risks. We have great results with these surgeries.

speaker: doctor
text: Hello. Are you a new patient?

speaker: patient
text: I am. I've been traveling a lot, so I don't have a local doctor I usually see.

speaker: doctor
text: That's fine. What is the reason for your visit?

speaker: patient
text: I've had this dark spot on my leg for a long time.

speaker: doctor
text: I see. Do you know if your family has any chronic medical problems?

speaker: patient
text: Not that I know of.

speaker: doctor
text: That's good. I think I'll be able to remove it surgically. Before I go over the procedures, have you had a surgery before?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I have. I had surgery on my back and to remove my appendix.

speaker: doctor
text: Sounds good. Other than that dark spot, you seem to be very healthy.

speaker: doctor
text: It's surgery day! How are you feeling?

speaker: patient
text: Not as excited as you.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you had a surgery before?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah. It was something with my chest.

speaker: doctor
text: I see. Thank you for letting me know.

speaker: doctor
text: What is your living status? Do you live alone or with family?

speaker: patient
text: I live with my boyfriend.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you smoke?

speaker: patient
text: Yes.

speaker: doctor
text: For how long you are smoking?

speaker: patient
text: Around ten years.

speaker: doctor
text: How many cigarettes do you take?

speaker: patient
text: Well, one pack of cigarettes lasts for around three days.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you drink?

speaker: patient
text: I do take beer.

speaker: doctor
text: How many do you drink a day?

speaker: patient
text: I take around six bottles once a week.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you working somewhere?

speaker: patient
text: I was working in a herbicide plant. There were so many layoffs because of this pandemic. I lost my job too.

speaker: doctor
text: I want to talk to you about your reproductive history, okay?

speaker: patient
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you take birth control pills?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I do.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any kind of medical history that I should be aware of?

speaker: patient
text: I had both chickenpox and measles when I was a kid.

speaker: doctor
text: Just want to ask you few questions.

speaker: patient
text: Okay shoot.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any nausea, vomiting?

speaker: patient
text: Yes to both.

speaker: doctor
text: How about fever?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I do.

speaker: doctor
text: Any blood in sputum or chest pain?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I do.

speaker: doctor
text: Well, this is a case of hypothermia.

speaker: doctor
text: Don't worry, we will take care of him.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you take any tobacco related products?

speaker: patient
text: I used to chew tobacco, but I quit when I was thirty seven.

speaker: doctor
text: What about alcohol consumption? Do you drink?

speaker: patient
text: I take one glass of wine every day.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you married?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, sir. I'm married to a wonderful woman for last thirty five years.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you still working?

speaker: patient
text: I used to. Now I'm retired, I was a lab manager before.

speaker: doctor
text: Hello! What brings you back into the clinic today?

speaker: patient
text: I came back because I increased my methothrexate as we discussed the last time I was here. A few days later I started getting multiple canker sores in my mouth. They hurt.

speaker: doctor
text: I am sorry. It is likely that the increased dosage of your methothrexate is the cause of the mouth sores. Have you experienced a decreased appetite, nausea, abdominal discomfort or diarrhea?

speaker: patient
text: No. It is painful to eat with the sores, but I still have an appetite.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you had any new rashes, or hair loss?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: I would like to get some bloodwork done. I would also recommend we decrease your dosage back to your previous amount. I would also like to see you back in two weeks to see how you are doing.

speaker: patient
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you aware of any medical issues in your family?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: How about any known heart disorder or diabetes in the family.

speaker: patient
text: No, I'm not aware of anything like that.

speaker: doctor
text: So, I am looking at his x ray and it does not show any open fracture or any kind of bone abnormality.

speaker: doctor
text: I understand, but like I said, I didn't see any open fracture in his x ray report nor any abnormality.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you drink?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I do take two or four beers in a day.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you smoke?

speaker: patient
text: Oh yeah, I'm a smoker. I take around one to two packs of cigarettes each day.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you live alone?

speaker: patient
text: I wouldn't say I live alone. I have three cats and they always keep me company.

speaker: doctor
text: Aw, what kind of cats?

speaker: patient
text: Two Persian cats and one Chartreux.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you currently working?

speaker: patient
text: I retired a few months ago. I used to work as a psych aide for the State of Pennsylvania.

speaker: doctor
text: Congratulations on your retirement.

speaker: patient
text: Thank you.

speaker: doctor
text: How long did you work as a psych aide?

speaker: patient
text: Thirty two years.

speaker: doctor
text: Incredible. One more question. Do you smoke, drink, or use drugs recreationally?

speaker: patient
text: I drink wine every now and then. I used to smoke back in the day, but I'm five years smoke free. I do not do drugs.

speaker: doctor
text: Always great to hear.

speaker: doctor
text: Hi there! What brings you in today?

speaker: doctor
text: What kind ant bait did he get into?

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have a picture of it?

speaker: doctor
text: Good morning, ma'am. I just need to confirm some information about you before we begin today.

speaker: patient
text: Good morning, doctor. Sure, that's no problem.

speaker: doctor
text: Great, so you're sixty seven years old, and White, correct?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, that's right doctor.

speaker: doctor
text: Thank you. Do you remember how many cycles of carboplatin and Taxol you've had for your cancer, ma'am?

speaker: patient
text: Um, I've had six, I'm here for a follow up today.

speaker: doctor
text: Yes, I see here that your last chemo treatment on January eighteenth two thousand eight.

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I remember that. Can you remind me the full name of my cancer?

speaker: doctor
text: It's a uterine papillary serous carcinoma.

speaker: patient
text: Thank you, doctor.

speaker: doctor
text: Sure, do you have any problems today?

speaker: patient
text: Well, I just have some numbness in my right upper arm today.

speaker: doctor
text: Has this gotten worse recently?

speaker: patient
text: Well, no, not really.

speaker: doctor
text: That's good. Do you feel this in your toes at all?

speaker: patient
text: No, there's no numbness there.

speaker: doctor
text: Good, do you have any tingling or burning to speak of?

speaker: patient
text: No, thankfully no.

speaker: doctor
text: How long has she had difficulty swallowing?

speaker: doctor
text: It does appear that her thyroids are fairly enlarged. I believe that's where most of her symptoms, if not all, are stemming from.

speaker: doctor
text: We'll have to see, but chances are higher since she's experiencing symptoms due to her thyroid.

speaker: doctor
text: I'd like to get some imaging done and see if we can get a consult in first.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any significant medical conditions that run in your family that I should be aware of?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, um, I know some of my relatives have had coronary artery disease, and, um, high blood pressure.

speaker: doctor
text: What about cancer? Does anyone in your family have a history of cancer?

speaker: patient
text: No, that doesn't ring any bells.

speaker: doctor
text: When was your injury, sir?

speaker: patient
text: Um, if I recall, it was on November twentieth two thousand eight.

speaker: doctor
text: What do you do for a living, sir?

speaker: patient
text: I work at the Purdy Correctional Facility, doctor.

speaker: doctor
text: How did you get hurt?

speaker: patient
text: Well, an inmate broke some of the overhead sprinklers, and I slipped on all the water and I landed on the back of my head, and then onto my back.

speaker: doctor
text: Which side took most of the hit?

speaker: patient
text: It was mostly on my left side.

speaker: doctor
text: How were you after the fall?

speaker: patient
text: Well, I was pretty stunned, mostly. I didn't want to come in, but my employers asked me to just to be sure.

speaker: doctor
text: Who has evaluated you to date?

speaker: patient
text: Um, I went to Gig Harbor Urgent Care, and then they sent me to Tacoma General Hospital. At Tacoma they said I have a whiplash and concussion.

speaker: doctor
text: What did they do at the hospital?

speaker: patient
text: Um, they did a C T scan, and they found a dark spot on my brain.

speaker: doctor
text: What did they recommend about the spot?

speaker: patient
text: They said I should have another M R I and they diagnosed an, um, recurrent acoustic neuroma.

speaker: doctor
text: So, you've had this before? How did they know you had it?

speaker: patient
text: I used to see a chiropractor, and they suggested that I get a scan and that's how they found it before.

speaker: doctor
text: When was this?

speaker: patient
text: Um, it was in October of two thousand five.

speaker: doctor
text: Did you have surgery on this?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I'm recovering now.

speaker: doctor
text: Are they still considering radiation?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, it's under consideration but there's no final decision yet.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, what does the chiropractor do for you?

speaker: patient
text: You know, the usual, adjustments and massages, stuff like that.

speaker: doctor
text: Has there been any improvement?

speaker: patient
text: Overall, my spine pain has improved a lot.

speaker: doctor
text: That's good. Okay, so after your fall, what other treatments did you have?

speaker: patient
text: I went to Prompt Care in Bremerton, and saw Doctor X Y Z. She's an osteopathic doctor.

speaker: doctor
text: How did she treat you?

speaker: patient
text: She ordered an M R I of my neck, I have the report right here.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, this shows some mild disc bulge at C four C five. Did she let you go back to work?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, she released me back to full duty. I was doing fine after the neurosurgical treatment.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any other treatment planned?

speaker: patient
text: Some radiation.

speaker: doctor
text: What else has she treated you for?

speaker: patient
text: Oh, you know, just general aches and pains on my back and neck. I have been seeing her since two thousand and two.

speaker: doctor
text: Any past medical problems or surgeries that I should know of?

speaker: patient
text: Nope, none that I can think of.

speaker: doctor
text: So, I see here in your reports you have arthritis in you both knees.

speaker: patient
text: Yes.

speaker: doctor
text: And you got a tear in your eye in the past, right?

speaker: patient
text: Ah yes, I got a tear in my retina.

speaker: doctor
text: Right. Also, it's mentioned here that you have atrial fibrillation.

speaker: patient
text: That's correct.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you taking any medications?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I am on anticoagulants.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you had any procedures in the past?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any medical conditions that run in your family that I should know about, ma'am?

speaker: patient
text: Um, yeah, my dad had prostate cancer.

speaker: doctor
text: What about your mother, or the rest of your family?

speaker: patient
text: Um, my mom's brother had Hodgkin's disease, melanoma, and prostate cancer.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you drink?

speaker: patient
text: Not really, no.

speaker: doctor
text: Any drugs?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you get a chance to exercise during the week?

speaker: patient
text: I like to go on walks with my dog every day. I'm also eating a lot healthier these days.

speaker: doctor
text: That's wonderful. How's work going for you?

speaker: patient
text: I actually got promoted last month so it's been going well. I've had a lot more time to spend with my family as a result.

speaker: doctor
text: That's great to hear. Congratulations!

speaker: patient
text: Thank you so much.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you allergic to anything?

speaker: patient
text: No, I do not have any allergies.

speaker: doctor
text: Great.

speaker: doctor
text: What do you do in the hospital?

speaker: patient
text: I work as a phlebotomist and respiratory therapist.

speaker: doctor
text: Ok, how old are you?

speaker: patient
text: I am fifty four.

speaker: doctor
text: You are very young.

speaker: patient
text: Thank you!

speaker: patient
text: So, as you remember I was trying to measure blood gas as I was working with a patient and I accidently jammed that needle inside my right hand index finger.

speaker: patient
text: I am coming for regular screening.

speaker: doctor
text: Were you wearing gloves?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I had gloves and protective clothing.

speaker: doctor
text: Yes, thank you for that. Did they screen patient?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, he got negative HIV but positive Hep C.

speaker: doctor
text: Ok.

speaker: patient
text: I am scared.

speaker: doctor
text: They took some fluid out of your back remember?

speaker: patient
text: Yes actually.

speaker: doctor
text: We got the results back for that and it looks like it was clear then it turned bloody.

speaker: patient
text: They checked my urine and blood too.

speaker: doctor
text: Yes, they did. I see the orders for urine culture, B M P, C B C, C R P, and blood culture as well.

speaker: patient
text: I got albuterol nebulizer treatment too.

speaker: doctor
text: That is good. but did that help you?

speaker: patient
text: No, it did not.

speaker: doctor
text: Oh I am sorry.

speaker: patient
text: It is okay.

speaker: doctor
text: I see that they gave you some antibiotics in E R?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, Ampicillin and Cefotaxime.

speaker: doctor
text: Tell me about your medical history. Did you have any surgeries? Any medical issues in the past?

speaker: patient
text: I had my tonsils removed when I was a kid, maybe around eight. I was hospitalized for the heart attack in ninety six. They did some surgery to check how my heart is functioning and then they did a bypass I guess.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have some record of those surgeries?

speaker: patient
text: Oh yes, I got it with me. Here it is.

speaker: doctor
text: That is awesome. Let me have a look. So, according to this you had L I M A to L A D coronary bypass graft. You also had had three saphenous vein grafts performed.

speaker: patient
text: Yes I had so many surgeries, it's hard to keep a track of all those complex names. That's why I keep those papers with me all the time if I go to any new doctor.

speaker: doctor
text: I will add all these surgeries into my record. Thank you.

speaker: doctor
text: How's everyone in your family?

speaker: patient
text: My mom, dad and siblings are good.

speaker: doctor
text: They are well, that is good. That's what we want.

speaker: patient
text: Yes.

speaker: doctor
text: So, what do you do for a living, sir?

speaker: patient
text: I work at A B C store, doctor.

speaker: doctor
text: That's great, do you smoke?

speaker: patient
text: No, I don't smoke at all.

speaker: doctor
text: How about alcohol? Do you drink?

speaker: patient
text: I'd say I drink socially, like if I'm at a party, or something.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you take any daily medications or supplements?

speaker: patient
text: Nope.

speaker: doctor
text: Good afternoon, sir, how are you today?

speaker: patient
text: Good afternoon, Doctor, my knees are in a lot of pain today.

speaker: doctor
text: Is the pain equal? Or is one knee worse than the other?

speaker: patient
text: Um, the left knee hurts more than the right, but there's pretty significant pain with both.

speaker: doctor
text: Is it interfering with your ability to walk?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I can walk like, maybe a half a mile a day, then the pain gets too bad.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you able to go up and down stairs?

speaker: patient
text: I have to take them one at a time.

speaker: doctor
text: I see you have degenerative joint disease of both knees, does that ring any bells?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, but what does that mean?

speaker: doctor
text: You have arthritis in both of your knees, sir.

speaker: patient
text: Ah, yes.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you had surgery on these knees?

speaker: patient
text: Um, I had surgery on both of these knees, let me check my notes. It was an, um, arthroscopy.

speaker: doctor
text: When were these surgeries?

speaker: patient
text: They were in the nineteen ninety one nineteen ninety two time frame, somewhere in there.

speaker: doctor
text: How have you managed this since the surgeries?

speaker: patient
text: I've taken antiinflammatories, had injections, and I've even used narcotics.

speaker: doctor
text: I see. If those haven't helped, I think you'd be a good candidate for knee replacements.

speaker: patient
text: Can we do both at the same time?

speaker: doctor
text: No, let's do the left since that one hurts more. Do you have any other conditions I should know about?

speaker: patient
text: I've had a lot of back surgeries, I have spinal stenosis.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you know what surgeries you've had?

speaker: patient
text: Let me check my notes, um, I've had a spinal decompression and epidural steroids injection.

speaker: doctor
text: Who has prescribed you narcotics for this pain?

speaker: patient
text: The pain is so bad, but Doctor X has handled those.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you smoke?

speaker: patient
text: Yes.

speaker: doctor
text: How much?

speaker: patient
text: Two cigarettes per day.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay that is not bad, but try quitting.

speaker: patient
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: Alcohol?

speaker: patient
text: No, I don't drink.

speaker: doctor
text: Hi Ryan, what brings you here today?

speaker: patient
text: Well, you told me to follow up if my cough doesn't get better. Also, I started having several other issues.

speaker: doctor
text: Oh really!

speaker: patient
text: Yeah.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, so tell me about your cough, is it getting worse than before?

speaker: patient
text: It's about the same but not getting better.

speaker: doctor
text: Hm. And what about your diarrhea and stomach pain?

speaker: patient
text: No more diarrhea and no pian.

speaker: doctor
text: Bowel movement?

speaker: patient
text: Normal.

speaker: doctor
text: Any pain while peeing? Are you able to empty your bladder completely?

speaker: patient
text: No pain and no problem emptying my bladder.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay good. Any nausea or vomiting?

speaker: patient
text: Nope, but I have developed this weird sore taste in my mouth.

speaker: doctor
text: Oh okay. How long?

speaker: patient
text: Since last week.

speaker: doctor
text: I see. Any loss of appetite?

speaker: patient
text: No, not really.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay and what other issues were you talking about?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I am also having some trouble with my eyes, I am able see fine, but it feels kind of funny.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

speaker: patient
text: And then my back is hurting so much, and last week my right shoulder and neck started to hurt.

speaker: doctor
text: Did you injure it or had a fall or anything?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: So, sir, what do you do for a living?

speaker: patient
text: Right now, I'm working with Chevron as a petroleum engineer.

speaker: doctor
text: That's fantastic. So, do you drink?

speaker: patient
text: Um, I'd say I drink socially, like if I'm at a party or something.

speaker: doctor
text: Sure, me too. Do you smoke?

speaker: patient
text: No sir, I don't do that.

speaker: doctor
text: Is anyone else at home sick?

speaker: patient
text: No. My husband and daughter seem to be doing okay. They haven't complained of anything yet.

speaker: doctor
text: Hi, how are you doing, ma'am? What brings you here today?

speaker: patient
text: I'm good, thank you. I'm having this weakness on my left side after the brain, I mean, after they removed my tumor from the brain.

speaker: doctor
text: Remind me when did you have your surgery for brain tumor?

speaker: patient
text: It was on October twenty fourth last year.

speaker: doctor
text: How old are you now?

speaker: patient
text: I'm sixty four.

speaker: patient
text: He is my husband, Al.

speaker: doctor
text: Hi, nice to meet you.

speaker: doctor
text: Tell me what happened.

speaker: patient
text: They asked me to go to the physical therapy for all the problems I was having after my brain surgery. I went from November fifth to the fourteenth of last year. I did therapy for around two weeks starting on November fifth. My problems were not solved so I went to the hospital and then they did some tests and they found out something was wrong. They said there is swelling in my brain so they admitted me there and then I had my second surgery.

speaker: doctor
text: When was the second surgery? When did you get admitted?

speaker: patient
text: It was on December fifth. I was there in the rehab the whole time and then I was discharged for home one month after my second surgery.

speaker: doctor
text: Was there any other issue?

speaker: doctor
text: What medication have you tried?

speaker: patient
text: I took Nexium.

speaker: doctor
text: Pain?

speaker: patient
text: Yes.

speaker: doctor
text: Well, I am looking at your test reports and your blood sugars have been running up and down but nothing to be worried about but yeah, we need to keep monitoring. This morning it was perhaps a bit high at one hundred eighty-eight. Last time it was one hundred fifty and in one report it's around one hundred twenty and in lower teens too which is good. So, tell me how are you feeling?

speaker: patient
text: Well, I am doing okay. I am getting treated for hemorrhoids. I am also having some constipation from the past few weeks and I have recently developed this cough which is okay as I kind of get it often.

speaker: doctor
text: Oh boy, that's a lot going on!

speaker: patient
text: Yeah.

speaker: doctor
text: So, tell me are your hemorrhoids painful?

speaker: patient
text: No, it's fine.

speaker: doctor
text: And are you taking anything for constipation?

speaker: patient
text: Well, just prune juice.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, let me write you an order for a laxative that should help. How bout cough? Any pain in the ribs while coughing?

speaker: patient
text: Nah, I am not bothered by it.

speaker: doctor
text: Any headache or nerve pain or body pain?

speaker: patient
text: Um, no I am fine.

speaker: doctor
text: Any fall or imbalance problem?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Any agitation or any other issues?

speaker: patient
text: Well, I am doing okay! Sometimes if I have pain, I take Tylenol and usually it works for me.

speaker: doctor
text: That's good!

speaker: patient
text: Yeah.

speaker: doctor
text: So, you have been seeking psychiatric help from Doctor Hudyncia right?

speaker: patient
text: Yes.

speaker: doctor
text: She mentioned in her report that you are responding well to her treatment and that your depression is under control and the medicine is working for you. That's good news. Oh, what medicine has she prescribed? Um let me see here in the report, oh okay, got it! It's Cymbalta.

speaker: patient
text: Right.

speaker: doctor
text: And no side effects, right?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: And looks like the plan is to treat you for a minimum one year.

speaker: patient
text: Yeah.

speaker: doctor
text: Lastly, any breathing issues?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: The next patient we have is Miss Dey, we have been regularly following up with her for her hydrocephalus since two thousand and two.

speaker: doctor
text: She also had anterior cervical corpectomy, we removed her front part of the vertebra followed by fusion from C three to C five in March two thousand and seven.

speaker: doctor
text: Yeah. We last saw her in March two thousand and eight at that time she was experiencing some head fullness and ringing in the ears, however we decided to leave her shunt setting at one point zero.

speaker: doctor
text: Yes exactly! Let's go see her. Hello Miss Dey, how are you? This is my colleague doctor Jen, and she will be accompanying me today if that is okay with you?

speaker: patient
text: Of course, Hello doctors.

speaker: doctor
text: So, tell me what is going on?

speaker: patient
text: Well, last week I had some urine issue, like had to pee frequently. I had few episodes of urgency.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay and how do you feel this week?

speaker: patient
text: This week it's much better I am not feeling like how I was feeling last week.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay good.

speaker: patient
text: I feel no urgency or inconsistency and I am able to empty my bladder completely.

speaker: doctor
text: That's good.

speaker: patient
text: However, I do leak some pee when I cough. I wear pads daily.

speaker: doctor
text: And did you notice any changes regarding your bladder, do you think it is better than before or worse since the last time I saw you?

speaker: patient
text: I don't think it changed much, it feels almost the same.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay. Let's talk about your memory, any problem there, are you able to remember stuff and think about stuff?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, all good there, no issues.

speaker: doctor
text: Any headache?

speaker: patient
text: Nope!

speaker: doctor
text: Any changes in your walk or balance?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I feel both have worsened. I am able to walk on uneven surface most of the time. But I feel I have become very slow.

speaker: doctor
text: And are you able to climb up and down the stairs?

speaker: patient
text: Yes.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you able to climb in and out of the car normally without any fuss?

speaker: patient
text: Yes.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you using cane at this point of time?

speaker: patient
text: No, no cane.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay good. Anything else you want to tell me?

speaker: patient
text: Ah yes, in the beginning of May, I got a spell of severe cough and because of continuous coughing I think I developed pain in my hip which travels down to my legs.

speaker: doctor
text: Oh okay, do you feel any tingling or numbness.

speaker: patient
text: Yes! I feel constant tingling sensation and a feeling that something is pinching my never. Sometimes it's just so painful.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

speaker: patient
text: Often I feel like my legs have become like elastic. I feel this tingling sensation is the reason my walking has become slower.

speaker: doctor
text: Doctor Jen did you take the notes of what she said?

speaker: doctor
text: Okay great, anything else Miss Dey?

speaker: patient
text: No, I think I told you everything.

speaker: doctor
text: Alright you take care. I will see you next time.

speaker: patient
text: Bye!

speaker: doctor
text: Bye.

speaker: doctor
text: So, you saw Doctor X?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, seven days back. I went to get my blood work done and then I followed up with Doctor Y.

speaker: doctor
text: Yes, I will look at C B C diff and C M P profile.

speaker: patient
text: I will follow up with my oncologist, Doctor Z, for my swellings.

speaker: doctor
text: Yeah, I couldn't get hold of Doctor Z but here is the phone number. You should book the appointment.

speaker: patient
text: Okay I will do that.

speaker: doctor
text: Also, I would like to follow up with your endocrinologist that is Doctor A for adjustments that is needed in your insulin pump.

speaker: patient
text: And you want me to see my gastro doc too?

speaker: doctor
text: Yes, please follow up with Doctor B for issues with your J tube.

speaker: patient
text: Sure thing.

speaker: doctor
text: Lastly, I want you to see Doctor Y if your condition changes regarding colon cancer.

speaker: doctor
text: I see here that you were in for afib last month.

speaker: patient
text: Yep.

speaker: doctor
text: How're you doing?

speaker: patient
text: It's all under control for now.

speaker: doctor
text: That's good to hear. Are you still taking Metoprolol and Premarin?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah.

speaker: doctor
text: Any health problems I should note?

speaker: patient
text: Diabetes.

speaker: doctor
text: Type one or two?

speaker: patient
text: Type two.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you on insulin?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah. I'm also trying to manage it with exercise.

speaker: doctor
text: Let me examine your leg. Well your x ray looks fine. No defect there, I don't see any mass or swelling. Are you able to walk or use that leg at all?

speaker: patient
text: Oh yes, I am using it. I have also started going back on my regular walk.

speaker: doctor
text: Good, so your muscle strength is good, no loss of muscle tone there.

speaker: patient
text: Yeah.

speaker: doctor
text: Hello, how are you?

speaker: patient
text: Hi Doctor, I am good.

speaker: doctor
text: So, what is going on with you?

speaker: patient
text: Well, I am having nausea and I just want to get it checked.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: How long have you had this cough?

speaker: patient
text: Past three weeks, doc.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you bringing anything up when you cough?

speaker: patient
text: Nah.

speaker: doctor
text: Any shortness of breath or chest pain?

speaker: patient
text: Nah.

speaker: doctor
text: How about fevers or chills?

speaker: patient
text: None of that.

speaker: doctor
text: Let's go over your history.

speaker: patient
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: I see that you had an appendectomy.

speaker: patient
text: Back in the nineteen forties. I also had an ankle resection in nineteen seventy five.

speaker: doctor
text: Any complications with either surgery?

speaker: patient
text: Uh nope.

speaker: doctor
text: I also see that you have a recurring history of pneumonia.

speaker: patient
text: Yeah. Started around age twenty and stuck with me ever since.

speaker: doctor
text: How often have you had pneumonia?

speaker: patient
text: Once every five years or so.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you ever been hospitalized due to pneumonia?

speaker: patient
text: Uh I'm usually given antibiotics and then discharged.

speaker: doctor
text: I see.

speaker: patient
text: Unfortunately, I've had more episodes in the past year than ever before.

speaker: doctor
text: Any history of inherited lung disease, bronchiectasis, or other chronic pulmonary cause for repeated pneumonia?

speaker: patient
text: Not to my knowledge.

speaker: doctor
text: And you recently saw the urologist, correct?

speaker: patient
text: Yes. I had a catheter placed for urinary retention. He told me he thinks it's due to an enlarged prostate.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have a history of diabetes or other medical problems?

speaker: patient
text: Uh no. I've lost about eighteen pounds in the last month but other than that everything else seems to be fine.

speaker: doctor
text: Hi again! How are you feeling today?

speaker: patient
text: I am feeling okay.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you still experiencing any nausea or vomiting?

speaker: patient
text: No. I feel better now.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you had any shortness of breath or chest pain?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Any painful or burning urination?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have a history of any seizure disorder?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Tell me about your family medical history.

speaker: patient
text: No one in my family has any health problems.

speaker: doctor
text: Your son had his circumcision performed here at Children's Hospital, correct?

speaker: doctor
text: Do you remember the date of that procedure?

speaker: doctor
text: Good, the procedure went well. He had some phimosis, but the operation was quite smooth otherwise.

speaker: doctor
text: That's tightness of the foreskin. It sometimes makes the procedure more difficult, but everything went smoothly.

speaker: doctor
text: He also had a little bit of bleeding when he woke up in the recovery room, so we had to put in some additional sutures.

speaker: doctor
text: It's my pleasure. Has he been taking his pain medicine?

speaker: doctor
text: Great, does he have any difficulty urinating?

speaker: doctor
text: Bowel movements? How are they?

speaker: doctor
text: Is this something new? Or have you had it before?

speaker: patient
text: No doctor, this is new.

speaker: doctor
text: What exactly are you feeling?

speaker: patient
text: I feel like my tongue is swollen.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay. How old are you?

speaker: patient
text: I am fifty four years old.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay let me see how we can evaluate that.

speaker: doctor
text: So, I think we need to start you on antibiotics for that ulcer on your right foot and possible osteomyelitis. I will send a prescription to your pharmacy.

speaker: patient
text: Sure.

speaker: doctor
text: Your condition is improved, and you look pretty stable.

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I feel much better.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any allergies to medications?

speaker: patient
text: Yes. Penicillin.

speaker: doctor
text: Looks like you have a U T I and I need to give you some antibiotics to treat it.

speaker: patient
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: I will write you a prescription for Macrobid. Are you still using the Walgreens pharmacy at Thrashers Corner?

speaker: patient
text: Yes.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you taking any other medications?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I am taking quite a few. I always carry the list of my medications, let me tell you the names.  Yeah, so I take Dilantin for my seizures, Toprol for my high blood pressure and Pravachol for my cholesterol.

speaker: doctor
text: Pravachol for my cholesterol. Wow, thank you for that, it helps a lot. Let me make a note of it.

speaker: patient
text: Sure.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you had any operations in the-

speaker: patient
text: Nope. No surgeries.

speaker: doctor
text: How about any past injuries or illnesses?

speaker: patient
text: Nope.

speaker: doctor
text: What is going on?

speaker: patient
text: I have pain in my jaw since the morning.

speaker: doctor
text: How bad is it?

speaker: patient
text: Not that bad.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you taken any medications in the past?

speaker: patient
text: Do you mean prescription, or over the counter?

speaker: doctor
text: Either of those.

speaker: patient
text: Oh, I haven't taken anything in the past.

speaker: doctor
text: Any changes to your diet?

speaker: patient
text: I've been following the A D A diet online and maxing out at around eighteen hundred calories per day.

speaker: doctor
text: How're you feeling since starting this diet?

speaker: patient
text: A lot better actually. My blood sugar isn't as high as it used to be.

speaker: doctor
text: Hello! How are you doing?

speaker: patient
text: I am doing okay.

speaker: doctor
text: Tell me about your past medical history.

speaker: patient
text: I was diagnosed with stage three ovarian cancer two years ago. They found a tumor in my upper abdomen. I had surgery and they removed everything. Doctor King is my oncologist.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you still undergoing treatment?

speaker: patient
text: Yes.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any other medical conditions?

speaker: patient
text: Have a heart murmur. It has not been an issue. I also have acid reflux.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you take medication for the G E R D?

speaker: patient
text: Yes. I take omeprazole.

speaker: doctor
text: Hello, miss. Before we begin your physical, could you verify your age and ethnicity for me, please?

speaker: patient
text: I'm forty two years old and identify as white.

speaker: doctor
text: Thank you. I also see that you're here for a follow up for your asthma, correct? How is your asthma?

speaker: patient
text: That's right. Oh, man. My asthma has been getting worse over the last three months. My allergies are also acting up again.

speaker: doctor
text: Oh, no. Has anything changed that may have made your allergies worse?

speaker: patient
text: Well, my husband has been hauling more corn in since it's busy season. I think that might have made it worse.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you taking any medications to alleviate your asthma and allergies?

speaker: patient
text: I'm using my inhaler every day for my asthma. Here are the other medications and treatments I've been using. I know I wouldn't have remembered, so I put them on a paper for you to see.

speaker: doctor
text: Let me take a look. I see you have been taking Allegra for your allergies. Has that been helping?

speaker: patient
text: Eh. It kind of helps when I do take it.

speaker: doctor
text: You don't take it every day then?

speaker: patient
text: Nope. Only when I feel like I need to.

speaker: doctor
text: I see. What about the Flonase? Has that been helping?

speaker: patient
text: I'm not taking that right now, but it helped me in the past.

speaker: doctor
text: I also see you took Advair in the past, correct? Do you still take it?

speaker: patient
text: I did, but I stopped taking it because it started to annoy my private area.

speaker: doctor
text: I understand. Speaking more on this. Let's begin your physical. Do you have anything you'd like to add that you're starting to notice more?

speaker: patient
text: Oh, yeah. I feel like I'm easily annoyed right before my period. It could also be my husband, but he likes to say it's because I'm about to start my period.

speaker: doctor
text: I see. Do you see any other increased symptoms right before your menstrual cycle?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah. I feel like I've seen an increase in all the signs before my period. I'm also getting more impatient around that time, but when I'm not on my period, I feel like my mood is better.

speaker: doctor
text: When do you see your mood change?

speaker: patient
text: My husband says it's bad the week before I start my period, but I think it gets better a day after I start.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you seen any bleeding during your cycle?

speaker: patient
text: Not as much anymore. Just some spots here and there.

speaker: doctor
text: I see. What about hot flashes or night sweats?

speaker: patient
text: Nope. I feel fine most of the time.

speaker: doctor
text: That's good. I'm looking at your chart right now and it says you showed a U T I present, correct? Your test showed blood in your urine.

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, that's correct.

speaker: doctor
text: Has your urine been checked since then?

speaker: patient
text: Nope.

speaker: doctor
text: I see. I'll order another urine test along with additional lab tests so that we can complete your physical.

speaker: patient
