text: I actually just had some lab work done because it was required for a life insurance application. Crazy, right? Here's the form with all the details for the lab work.

speaker: doctor
text: Oh, perfect. I see they looked at your cholesterol and other areas. Could you send that to me when you get the results?

speaker: patient
text: Of course. I'll get that sent to you A S A P.

speaker: doctor
text: How are your parents doing, sir?

speaker: patient
text: Well, doctor, I've lost both of them now.

speaker: doctor
text: I'm so sorry to hear that, sir. How about your brothers?

speaker: patient
text: Thank you, doctor. Both of my brothers are doing very well.

speaker: doctor
text: Remind me, please, how old are they?

speaker: patient
text: One of them is sixty eight, and the other is seventy seven. I'm in the middle.

speaker: doctor
text: That's great. Do you have any medical conditions that run in your family?

speaker: patient
text: Well, I'm not sure if it counts, but I had a brother and sister, they were twins, they died at birth.

speaker: doctor
text: Oh no, thank you for telling me.

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I thought it would be important.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any children, sir?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I have two sons, they're both doing very well.

speaker: doctor
text: How old are your sons?

speaker: patient
text: One of them is fifty four, and the other is fifty seven.

speaker: doctor
text: In addition to the neonatal deaths, do you have any other conditions that I should know about?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, um, a lot of my family has diabetes, and a lot of them have had heart attacks as well.

speaker: doctor
text: Hello, ma'am. What is the reason for your visit today?

speaker: patient
text: I was referred by a doctor to come see you so that you could check up on my nasal problems. Here is my report from my previous doctor who referred me to you.

speaker: doctor
text: Thank you. Let me take a look.  I see here it says you had severe sinusitis two to three months ago, correct?

speaker: patient
text: Is that what they're calling my nasal problems?

speaker: doctor
text: Yeah, it is. Sinusitis is the inflammation of your nasal airways.

speaker: patient
text: I see. Thank you for describing it to me.

speaker: doctor
text: No problem. Would you be able to describe to me what you had been feeling two to three months ago?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I can. My face would feel uncomfortable, my nose was stuffy, my eyes hurt, and I felt something dropping in the back of my throat.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you ever been prescribed any medication?

speaker: patient
text: Here's the list of medicine I was taking.

speaker: doctor
text: I see you were given antibiotics, correct?

speaker: patient
text: I was, but I don't know what those are. Could you explain them to me?

speaker: doctor
text: Antibiotics are usually used to fight infections.

speaker: patient
text: I had an infection? I thought I just had some nasal problems.

speaker: doctor
text: Your report states you had a severe infection. Do you remember if the antibiotics helped?

speaker: patient
text: Not really. I felt like my symptoms were the same.

speaker: doctor
text: I see. Did your doctor order any advanced imaging's?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah. They did a C T scan of my nose. Here is the report from my C T scan.

speaker: doctor
text: Let me take a look. It looks like you had some thickening of the mucosal layer in your right paranasal sinus. You also had some obstruction in your right ostiomeatal complex and excess growing of some of the bones in your nose. Uhm. Oh, one more thing. I see your nasal septum was shifted to the left.

speaker: patient
text: Oh, wow. Thank you for explaining everything to me.

speaker: doctor
text: No problem. Going back to your list of medications, I know you took antibiotics for your infection, but did you take any medication for your sinuses?

speaker: patient
text: No, I haven't. I did try this cream for my nose, but that didn't work either. Nothing worked!

speaker: doctor
text: I see. Looks like the cream you used was a topical nasal corticosteroid. Are there any other symptoms that you have been experiencing?

speaker: patient
text: I've had some trouble with my balance, and I feel like I've lost some of my hearing. I thought this was odd since I'm only fifty years old. I think my ears felt plugged or full of air, so they just needed to pop.

speaker: doctor
text: I see. Let's perform an audiogram test to check your ears.

speaker: patient
text: Sounds good.

speaker: doctor
text: I'm seeing that you have some mild high frequency sensorineural hearing loss. Your tympanometry seems to be normal. Your speech discrimination was also normal.

speaker: patient
text: That's reassuring.

speaker: doctor
text: I want to ask a few more questions about your ears. Do you feel any fullness or pressure?

speaker: patient
text: No, I don't feel anything like that right now.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you hear any humming, buzzing, or roaring sounds?

speaker: patient
text: Nope. I don't hear anything like that.

speaker: doctor
text: We checked your ears and now understand more about the problem, but I wonder why your balance is affected. When did you start noticing your balance was affected?

speaker: patient
text: I think it could have been to this one medicine that starts with an A. I forgot the name, but it didn't really help my nasal problems. It just made my balance worse.

speaker: doctor
text: Was the medicine called Allegra?

speaker: patient
text: Oh, yeah. That's what it was called. I thought I had some sort of allergy, so I thought it would help.

speaker: doctor
text: I see. Did you ever feel any dizziness too?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I did.

speaker: doctor
text: I will have you do some movements to see if your dizziness occurs.

speaker: patient
text: Sounds good.

speaker: doctor
text: Could you look to the left and then look to the right.

speaker: patient
text: Oh, wow. That made me very dizzy.

speaker: doctor
text: Looks like sudden movements and head turning make your dizziness worse.

speaker: doctor
text: Is there anyone that lives with you at home? You are going to need someone to help you care for your wound.

speaker: patient
text: My wife lives at home with me.  She can help me change my bandages.

speaker: doctor
text: Hello. Looks like you're having surgery today.

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I am. I forgot what the surgery was, but it says it in my report.

speaker: doctor
text: I'm looking at it right now. Looks like you had a PermCath inserted three times and received peritoneal dialysis

speaker: doctor
text: So, what is happening with you?

speaker: patient
text: I had knee replacement for both my knees three years ago and now I am having some pain.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay and in one or both knees?

speaker: patient
text: Both.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: Hi!

speaker: patient
text: Hello!

speaker: doctor
text: How are you feeling now?

speaker: patient
text: I am feeling okay.

speaker: doctor
text: Yeah, looks like your condition is improving.

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I think so too.

speaker: doctor
text: And who are we seeing today?

speaker: doctor
text: Well, hello young man how are you feeling today?

speaker: doctor
text: For how long now?

speaker: doctor
text: No, I mean when did he start complaining of stomach pain?

speaker: doctor
text: Oh okay, let me check him. Did he have any nausea or vomiting?

speaker: doctor
text: And then he is complaining of tummy pain?

speaker: doctor
text: Well, the good part is he is not dehydrated.

speaker: doctor
text: Any diarrhea?

speaker: doctor
text: Hm, but no blood or anything in the stools or vomit?

speaker: doctor
text: Okay good.

speaker: doctor
text: Well, let me run some tests but the signs and symptoms sound like he might have a stomach flu, also called as gastroenteritis in medical terms. I will start him on some medicines and hopefully that should help.

speaker: doctor
text: Hello, nice to meet you, miss. I will be taking care of you today. Before we start, can I get to know you a bit? I like to know who I am treating.

speaker: patient
text: Hello, nice to meet you. Of course. Um, what can I say? I am a recent widow. My husband passed when we were married for only eight years. I am also retired and loving every minute of it.

speaker: doctor
text: I am sorry to hear that, but I am glad you are happy after retirement. Do you celebrate your infinite days off with a drink or a cigarette?

speaker: patient
text: No, I do not smoke. I drink occasionally, but it is very rare.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any children that you spend your time with?

speaker: patient
text: I have three wonderful children.

speaker: doctor
text: What do you use to treat your asthma?

speaker: patient
text: I use my Albuterol inhaler.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you eat three meals a day?

speaker: patient
text: Yes.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you think those meals add up to about two thousand calories a day?

speaker: patient
text: I would say yes.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you still taking Micronase every morning?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I take um two point five M G once a day.

speaker: doctor
text: Great. Continue taking Micronase by mouth every day. As for your infection, I want you to start taking Bactrim twice daily. I'll be prescribing you thirty pills. It'll be Bactrim four hundred M G and eighty M G tablets.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you consume any kind of tobacco?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: What about smoking?

speaker: patient
text: No, I've never done it.

speaker: doctor
text: Any kind of alcohol consumption?

speaker: patient
text: Nope.

speaker: doctor
text: What seems to be the problem today?

speaker: patient
text: I've been having headaches for a while now.

speaker: doctor
text: How long have you been having these headaches?

speaker: patient
text: Um, I had my first one about two months ago.

speaker: doctor
text: Did you suddenly start having them, or was it more gradual?

speaker: patient
text: Um, I'd say it was more gradual.

speaker: doctor
text: Where do you feel your headaches?

speaker: patient
text: Right here, between my eyes.

speaker: doctor
text: How would you describe your symptoms?

speaker: patient
text: I'd say it feels like a pressure sensation.

speaker: doctor
text: What's the intensity of these headaches?

speaker: patient
text: Um, they're about moderately severe, I guess.

speaker: doctor
text: Do these headaches interfere with your ability to do your activities?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, they do. My regular activities are significantly more difficult now.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any sinus congestion?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I do. I also have some light sensitivity.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you stressed out at work?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I have a very stressful job, doctor.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you sleeping well?

speaker: patient
text: Well, no not at all. I even try to have a little drink before bed, and it doesn't help.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any oral symptoms, like vomiting or pain in your jaw?

speaker: patient
text: No, nothing like that.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any medical conditions that I should know about?

speaker: patient
text: No, not that I know of.

speaker: doctor
text: So, there's no history of depression, or cancer, or high blood pressure?

speaker: patient
text: No, it's not ringing any bells.

speaker: patient
text: I am having stomach pain.

speaker: doctor
text: Hm, any nausea or vomiting?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, both.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you been experiencing any mental difficulties or confusion?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Any hallucinations? Are you seeing hearing thing that is not real?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Good afternoon, which gender do you identify with?

speaker: patient
text: Good afternoon, doctor, thank you for asking, I identify as a female.

speaker: doctor
text: Great, thank you. Have you ever had surgery on this knee?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I actually had an A C L reconstruction done in March of two thousand eight. Um, it didn't go well, so they did a revision at the end of that year, in December.

speaker: doctor
text: I see, thank you. What about your upper body? Is there any history of surgery there?

speaker: patient
text: Actually, yes, I had surgery on my arm when I was six.

speaker: doctor
text: Welcome in, sir.

speaker: patient
text: Thank you.

speaker: doctor
text: What do you do for work?

speaker: patient
text: I am professor at the college up on the hill.

speaker: doctor
text: What do you teach?

speaker: patient
text: I teach history and the bible.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you drink alcohol or use tobacco products?

speaker: patient
text: No. I do not partake in either of those activities.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any major medical conditions that I should know about?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I have a history of thyroid problems, actually.

speaker: doctor
text: I'm seeing here that you have a history of allergies too, is that correct?

speaker: patient
text: Oh yes, that's right too.

speaker: doctor
text: He's stable. Heart rate sixty five. Normal rhythm. Oxygen ninety seven percent on room air.

speaker: doctor
text: Tell me about your past problems.

speaker: patient
text: Sure. I just came into the hospital I think about three weeks back for recurrent urine infections.

speaker: doctor
text: Yes it says here that you have bladder problems from a long time, mostly related to tone and capacity.

speaker: patient
text: Yes that is why they put catheter in me.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay and you have recently had right side C V A?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, because of my heart problems they had to put pacemaker in.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay. Good.

speaker: patient
text: I have hereditary diabetes.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay and your neural problem is associated to that as well.

speaker: patient
text: That's right.

speaker: doctor
text: You have pain on the right side now?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, because of my stroke.

speaker: doctor
text: And you take thyroid medications too?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, for my hypothyroidism.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

speaker: patient
text: Yeah.

speaker: doctor
text: What surgeries have you had in the past?

speaker: patient
text: I have had many surgeries. They took out my gall bladder, then colon cancer surgery was in nineteen ninety eight.

speaker: doctor
text: And now pacemaker placement, right?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, that is correct.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any major medical conditions running in your family history that you know about?

speaker: patient
text: No, there's nothing of note.

speaker: doctor
text: So, there's no history of arthritis, or cancer that you're aware of?

speaker: patient
text: No, not that I know of.

speaker: doctor
text: So, does high blood pressure run in your family?

speaker: patient
text: Um, no it's just me.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay and this was your first time?

speaker: patient
text: Yes.

speaker: doctor
text: Because I am looking at your previous charts and I don't see it mentioned before.

speaker: patient
text: Oh yeah first time it shot up this high. I never had a high blood pressure problem before.

speaker: doctor
text: Now, let's talk about your family history. Have any of them had cancer?

speaker: patient
text: Actually, yes, I know a few family members have, but I can't remember who had what kind.

speaker: doctor
text: That's okay. What about heart disease? Can you remember anyone having that?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, that rings some bells.

speaker: doctor
text: Thank you, has anyone in your family had a joint replacement?

speaker: patient
text: I know that a lot of my family has had arthritis in the past, but I can't remember whether or not they had joint replacements, honestly.

speaker: doctor
text: Hi, how are you?

speaker: patient
text: I am good, how about you?

speaker: doctor
text: Well, I am good too, thank you for asking. So, what brings you here?

speaker: patient
text: Um, I have developed this painful ulcer on my hip.

speaker: doctor
text: Oh, let me take a look. Which side?

speaker: patient
text: On my right hip.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, I see it. Looks like you have developed pressure ulcer.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, tell me what's going on and what's brought you here.

speaker: doctor
text: How old is the baby? When did you first notice it?

speaker: doctor
text: Did you get the test result?

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, let me have a look. It says she is having a growing M R S A.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, so you know about it, and I don't have to explain it more.

speaker: doctor
text: So how is the blister on the umbilicus now?

speaker: doctor
text: You did good. I will start the treatment. How are her eating and sleeping habits?

speaker: doctor
text: Did she have any fever?

speaker: doctor
text: Has she been lethargic or crying more than normal?

speaker: doctor
text: Any other changes in her daily routine that you might have noticed?

speaker: patient
text: I am in pain. I get these frequent episodes of pain and discomfort in my head.

speaker: doctor
text: Is it in any side of head or is it overall?

speaker: patient
text: Sometimes it is overall and other times just on any one side. Doctor: This sounds like it is a migraine headache.

speaker: doctor
text: Good afternoon, young man. Is this your mother?

speaker: patient
text: Hi, doctor. Yes, this is my mom.

speaker: doctor
text: Good, can you tell me more about your son, ma'am?

speaker: doctor
text: He's been taking Adderall, correct? How long has he been taking this?

speaker: doctor
text: How has he responded to the Adderall?

speaker: doctor
text: That's great!

speaker: doctor
text: Has he had problems with his appetite?

speaker: doctor
text: Have you gotten any reports from his teachers?

speaker: doctor
text: Has he taken every dose?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, mommy, I thought I needed it, but you didn't give it to me.

speaker: doctor
text: Good afternoon, sir. Welcome in. Let's get started, how old are you?

speaker: patient
text: Good afternoon, doctor. I'm fifty two years old.

speaker: doctor
text: My nurse says that you're here for an independent evaluation, is that correct?

speaker: patient
text: Yes sir, that is.

speaker: doctor
text: Good, what do you do for a living?

speaker: patient
text: Right now, I'm a temporary employee for A B C A B C, I've worked for A B C D, too.

speaker: doctor
text: What do you do there?

speaker: patient
text: Mainly, I handle the loading and unloading of furniture and appliances for people's houses.

speaker: doctor
text: That's hard work. When did you get hurt?

speaker: patient
text: It was about two and a half weeks ago now, back in October.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have a history of back problems, like before this injury?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I've had back pain for a long time.

speaker: doctor
text: What happened when you got hurt this time?

speaker: patient
text: I was unloading one of the A B C eighteen wheelers, when I bent down to pick up some boxes, and I felt the pain.

speaker: doctor
text: What kind of pain did you feel?

speaker: patient
text: I felt a sharp pain in my lower back right away when I tried to lift those boxes.

speaker: doctor
text: Does your pain go down your legs?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, it goes into the right side of my butt, and then all the way down the outside of my right leg, like into the knee.

speaker: doctor
text: How have your symptoms progressed since they began?

speaker: patient
text: Doctor, they've only gotten worse.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any pain in your left leg?

speaker: patient
text: A little, not as bad as the right.

speaker: doctor
text: What other symptoms are you having besides the pain down your leg?

speaker: patient
text: The muscles in my butt are spazzing, and it's happening more and more.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you seen another doctor for this?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I saw Doctor Z at first.

speaker: doctor
text: What did they do for you?

speaker: patient
text: He gave me some muscle relaxers, and some, um, Lidocaine patches.

speaker: doctor
text: Did this help at all?

speaker: patient
text: No, not at all.

speaker: doctor
text: Who else have you seen?

speaker: patient
text: I saw doctor X Y Z too, through worker's comp.

speaker: doctor
text: When did you see them?

speaker: patient
text: That was back in April.

speaker: doctor
text: What did they recommend?

speaker: patient
text: Um, he sent me for an M R I, and I have the report for that right here.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, this M R I report is basically negative, which is good. Did he give you any medications?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, he gave me some opioids.

speaker: doctor
text: Wow, that's strong stuff. What is your work status right now?

speaker: patient
text: Doctor X Y Z put me on restricted duty status, doctor.

speaker: doctor
text: I'm reading your notes from doctor X Y Z, he says he released you in June, and that you have reached maximum medical improvement.

speaker: patient
text: He told me that, but I still have pain, so I went back to see him.

speaker: doctor
text: When you went for follow up, did you still have that pain down your legs?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I did.

speaker: doctor
text: What did doctor X Y Z recommend at that time?

speaker: patient
text: He referred me to a Pain Clinic, and he recommended I have, um, epidural injections with doctor A B C.

speaker: doctor
text: Did you have this done?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I did.

speaker: doctor
text: Did this help at all?

speaker: patient
text: No, it did absolutely nothing.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, so after that, what treatment did you have?

speaker: patient
text: I had an M R I, um, E M G, and nerve conduction study with doctor A B C D.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have the results of that as well?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, doctor, they're right here.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, sir, these tests are essentially normal, which is more good news. What aggravates your pain?

speaker: patient
text: Well, anything like sitting for a long time. When I do that, I feel it in my legs.

speaker: doctor
text: When you sit for a long time, is it in both legs?

speaker: patient
text: It's really on my right.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you able to sleep at night?

speaker: patient
text: No, sir, I'm not able to sleep at all.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you been able to return to work?

speaker: patient
text: Well, I went back to work in June, after doctor X said I'd reached the maximum medical improvement we talked about.

speaker: doctor
text: Finally, have you seen a chiropractor for this pain?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I saw doctor X about eight or nine times.

speaker: doctor
text: Did they do anything to help you feel better?

speaker: patient
text: Really, no, it did not. I still have the pain down my legs today.

speaker: doctor
text: Is there any family medical history?

speaker: patient
text: I have a whole list. See, my grand aunt had a stroke. My M G had heart issues same as my mom, who died of a heart attack at sixty three. My father had some sort of cancer. I don't know what exactly. And my sisters have blood pressure issues.

speaker: doctor
text: Wow, that sure is a list. Anyone with diabetes?

speaker: patient
text: No. Well, that is one thing that skipped my family.

speaker: doctor
text: Does he have any known drug allergies?

speaker: doctor
text: Good morning, can you tell me more about your son, ma'am.

speaker: doctor
text: Great, thank you. Is he still having problems with his hypothyroidism and onychomycosis?

speaker: doctor
text: Has he remained complaint with his Lamisil?

speaker: doctor
text: Good, so we'll do an A L T blood test today.

speaker: doctor
text: Well, at his last appointment in April, he had an elevated T S H level. So, we should recheck that today.

speaker: doctor
text: Has he been taking his Levothroid daily as well?

speaker: doctor
text: Good, thanks for taking care of him, Mom.

speaker: doctor
text: Does he take any other medications?

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any questions regarding your surgery?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I do, multiple.

speaker: doctor
text: Go ahead shoot.

speaker: patient
text: I have them all written down on this.

speaker: doctor
text: How about any drugs, alcohol, or tobacco?

speaker: patient
text: No, no, and no.

speaker: doctor
text: Hey, how are you?

speaker: patient
text: I think I am better.

speaker: doctor
text: So you do not have any more nausea or vomiting?

speaker: patient
text: No I don't.

speaker: doctor
text: How about any acidity?

speaker: patient
text: I think it's all better.

speaker: doctor
text: Great.

speaker: doctor
text: How are you?

speaker: patient
text: I am good.

speaker: doctor
text: That's great. You are stable.

speaker: patient
text: Can I go home now?

speaker: doctor
text: Yes, you can.

speaker: patient
text: Thank you!

speaker: doctor
text: Good afternoon, young man, are these your parents?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, doctor.

speaker: doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your son, please?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, my brother has been doing this too.

speaker: doctor
text: How many times has he had diarrhea per day since this began?

speaker: doctor
text: How many times has he thrown up per day?

speaker: doctor
text: Has he been throwing up today?

speaker: patient
text: No, I haven't today.

speaker: doctor
text: Has he gone to the bathroom today?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I peed this morning.

speaker: doctor
text: Has he had any fever symptoms?

speaker: doctor
text: Has he eaten any solid food?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I had half a hamburger and some milk last night.

speaker: doctor
text: Was he able to keep the food down?

speaker: doctor
text: What has he drank?

speaker: doctor
text: Welcome into the clinic! I would like to start with your past medical history.

speaker: patient
text: I have high blood pressure and macular deterioration. Last year I caught pneumonia but that has cleared up.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.  What brings you in today?

speaker: patient
text: I have had this cough and pain on the right side of my abdomen.

speaker: doctor
text: How long has this been going on?

speaker: patient
text: Two days. I have had body aches and have been feeling nauseous too.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you had a fever?

speaker: patient
text: I think so. I was chilled and my forehead was warm. The cough is a dry sounding cough.

speaker: doctor
text: Does the abdominal pain come during one of these coughing episodes?

speaker: patient
text: Yes.

speaker: doctor
text: Good afternoon, dear, how old are you?

speaker: patient
text: I'm fourteen years old.

speaker: doctor
text: Good, and what brings you in for a visit today?

speaker: patient
text: My left knee hurts really bad.

speaker: doctor
text: Oh no, how long has this knee been hurting you?

speaker: patient
text: Well, since the fall of two thousand seven.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you seen another doctor for this?

speaker: patient
text: Mom, can you tell the doctor?

speaker: doctor
text: I see, and what did this doctor recommend?

speaker: doctor
text: Thank you, yes, so this shows left patellar chondromalacia. Has she been to P T?

speaker: doctor
text: I see, has she been wearing her brace?

speaker: doctor
text: That's good, and how is your pain today, dear?

speaker: patient
text: P T only made the pain much worse, it hurts so much.

speaker: doctor
text: Well, we're in a pretty difficult spot here. The majority of my patients get significantly better by just going to P T.

speaker: doctor
text: Usually, we manage this for six months without surgery, and she hasn't reached that milestone yet. But, because her pain is getting so severe, I can do a lateral capsular release on this knee.

speaker: doctor
text: It's a small procedure, minimally invasive, and we can do it outpatient. Her kneecap is partially dislocating, so this surgery will get everything back into alignment.

speaker: doctor
text: The risk of infection is actually less than one percent. We use antibiotics to control for infection.

speaker: patient
text: Will I be asleep for this?

speaker: doctor
text: Yes, you won't feel a thing.

speaker: patient
text: Will I need to go back to P T?

speaker: doctor
text: Yes, you'll need to go some after the surgery to make sure everything heals up okay. The other risks include bleeding, changes in sensation and motion extremity, failure of procedure to relieve pain, need for postoperative rehab, and significant postoperative swelling.

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I think so too, I want to get back to playing soccer.

speaker: doctor
text: What brings you here today?

speaker: patient
text: I have pain in my tummy.

speaker: doctor
text: When did you first notice it?

speaker: patient
text: It started suddenly around noon.

speaker: doctor
text: Welcome to the clinic., ma'am

speaker: patient
text: Thank you.

speaker: doctor
text: What brings you into see me?

speaker: patient
text: I have been struggling with pain and stiffness in my right neck and shoulder.

speaker: doctor
text: How long has this been going on for?

speaker: patient
text: Maybe for about four months.

speaker: doctor
text: In these past four months have your symptoms becomes worse or has it improved at all?

speaker: patient
text: It has been getting worse. The pain is worse at night. It wakes me up at night. I haven't had a good night sleep in four months.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you experienced any pain or numbness in your arm, wrist, or hand?

speaker: patient
text: Yes! About two weeks after the pain started, I was having some numbness and painful cramping in these two fingers here.

speaker: doctor
text: The right hand and the first and second finger?

speaker: patient
text: Yes.

speaker: doctor
text: How old are you?

speaker: patient
text: I am forty six.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you left or right handed?

speaker: patient
text: Right. It was a throbbing pain in my hand.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you had any other pain anywhere else in your body?

speaker: patient
text: I few times I had some numbness in both of my legs. It started with a pinching from my tailbone area.

speaker: doctor
text: Did you experience any trauma neck, head or back?

speaker: patient
text: No. I don't know where this pain came from. Oh, every once and a while I have this electric shock like sensation shooting down my spine when move my neck certain way.

speaker: doctor
text: Any pain or symptoms in your left arm or shoulder?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you had any visual changes or disturbances?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Any difficulties with your bowels or your bladder?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you been taking any thing for the pain?

speaker: patient
text: I have been taking Naprosyn.

speaker: doctor
text: Has the Naprosyn help relieve your pain?

speaker: patient
text: Only a little bit.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: Is this baby number two?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, this is baby number two.

speaker: doctor
text: How many times have you been pregnant, including miscarriages or abortions if any?

speaker: patient
text: I've been pregnant two times in total. No miscarriages or abortions.

speaker: doctor
text: When was your last period?

speaker: patient
text: About a month ago.

speaker: doctor
text: And how would you describe your periods? Light, normal, heavy?

speaker: patient
text: Pretty normal.

speaker: doctor
text: Any abnormal pap smears?

speaker: patient
text: No, fortunately they've all been normal.

speaker: doctor
text: That's wonderful to hear. And my last question for you is if you've ever gotten a mammogram?

speaker: patient
text: I haven't gotten one before. Do I need to get one? I just turned thirty nine. What's the recommended age again?

speaker: doctor
text: It depends. For example, the recommended age would be younger for someone who has a family history of breast cancer. Given that you don't have a positive family history of breast cancer, I'd advise getting one in a few years at the age of forty five.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, I want you to follow up with our hand therapist Doctor X at her A B C D office in one to two weeks.

speaker: patient
text: Okay, I will make an appointment today.

speaker: doctor
text: So we're here to follow up on a few things. I'd like to know how you're keeping up with your blood sugar checks.

speaker: patient
text: I've been checking my blood sugar one to two times a day.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you been keeping a log?

speaker: patient
text: Uh yeah, but I need to be better at it.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have the log with you today?

speaker: patient
text: Yep, in fact it's right here. Let me grab it for you.

speaker: doctor
text: Great.

speaker: patient
text: Here ya go.

speaker: doctor
text: Thank you. And have you been watching your cholesterol intake since getting blood work done? Your labs show your cholesterol levels are a bit elevated. I'd like for you to monitor your cholesterol and go in for another set of labs before our next visit.

speaker: patient
text: Do I need to fast for it again?

speaker: doctor
text: Yes, you'll need to fast. I'd recommend going in early in the morning before eating any breakfast.

speaker: patient
text: That sounds like a good plan.

speaker: doctor
text: And as for your sinusitis, how have you been feeling since finishing your course of antibiotics?

speaker: patient
text: Much better. No more headaches and a stuffy nose.

speaker: doctor
text: What brings you in today?

speaker: patient
text: My back started hurting last night. I have a stomachache. I have had pain with urination for the last two days.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any other symptoms?

speaker: patient
text: I just started coughing and now I have a fever.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any history of kidney stones?

speaker: patient
text: Yes.  I had kidney stones less than a year ago.  I had a urinary tract infection at the same time.  It was awful.

speaker: doctor
text: A little over a year ago. She received antibiotic therapy and ended up having debridement and instrumentation with Doctor XYZ.

speaker: doctor
text: Really quite well.

speaker: doctor
text: Yes.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have sugar or blood pressure problems?

speaker: patient
text: Oh, I have high blood pressure but it's well under control. I make sure to keep it under normal range.

speaker: doctor
text: Good. Any other health issues?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I have history of high triglycerides. But otherwise, I am pretty healthy.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay. Do you smoke?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Hello, miss. The nurse who seated you tells me you are here for a second opinion on surgery.

speaker: patient
text: Hello, doctor. Yes, I have been told that both eyes need cataract extraction. I came for a second opinion because I will only have surgery if necessary. I am nervous.

speaker: doctor
text: What is the reason for the extraction?

speaker: patient
text: I am not exactly sure because the other doctors said a bunch of medical terms. I have had laser in my eyes though. That was for macular degeneration. Doctor X said I had neurovascular age-related macular degeneration.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you know what laser you had on your eyes?

speaker: patient
text: No. I just know laser was done by Doctor X four times to the macula on the right and two times on the left.

speaker: doctor
text: Any allergies?

speaker: patient
text: Um yeah. I'm trying to remember the name. It's a pain killer that starts with an L. Oh Lortab.

speaker: doctor
text: What happens when you take Lortab?

speaker: patient
text: Really bad hives. I've only ever taken it once.

speaker: doctor
text: I'll make note of that in your chart so we have it in your records.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any known drug allergies?

speaker: patient
text: No, none that I know of.

speaker: doctor
text: Welcome in.

speaker: patient
text: Thank you.

speaker: doctor
text: What do you do for work?

speaker: patient
text: I work in Human Resources for the State of Maryland.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you live alone or with others?

speaker: patient
text: I live alone.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you smoke cigarettes?

speaker: patient
text: I used to smoke like a chimney. I quit smoking a while back. I had been smoking for about sixteen years.

speaker: doctor
text: That's great! When did you quit?

speaker: patient
text: I quit in nineteen eighty four. That is also the year I quit drinking.

speaker: doctor
text: What was the reason behind quitting drinking?

speaker: patient
text: I had a drinking problem. I am in A A. I have been in A A since I quit.

speaker: doctor
text: That's great. Keep up the hard work.

speaker: patient
text: Thank you.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any history of recreational or I V drug use?

speaker: patient
text: Yes. I used to take pills, but I never got into needle drugs. Thank God.  I went through treatment, all those years back. I started going to A A and got my life together.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any other risk factors for H I V? Like multiple sex partners?

speaker: patient
text: No. I had my last H I V test over two years ago. I have been with the same guy for over two years.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: Hi, tell me about your family? Did anyone have any medical diseases?

speaker: patient
text: Both of my parents were healthy, but my maternal grandfather had a stroke.

speaker: doctor
text: Did anyone in your family ever have migraines?

speaker: patient
text: No, not that I know.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any chronic medical conditions that I should know about?

speaker: patient
text: What do you mean by that, doctor?

speaker: doctor
text: Well, it could be anything from high blood pressure, to depression, to cancer. Do any of those sound familiar?

speaker: patient
text: Oh, yeah, I have a few things like that. I have anemia, high cholesterol, and, um, hypothyroidism.

speaker: doctor
text: How old are you?

speaker: patient
text: Oh, I am fifty eight now.

speaker: doctor
text: So, you are here today because you are having some vision difficulties? Tell me about what has been going on, ma'am.

speaker: patient
text: Yeah. Okay. It all started a year ago. It started with losing the color in my vision.

speaker: doctor
text: Was the loss sudden or gradual?

speaker: patient
text: Gradual. And now I am starting to have blurry vision.

speaker: doctor
text: When did that start happening?

speaker: patient
text: I noticed it two months ago.

speaker: doctor
text: Is the blurred vision an all blur or is there a blind spot of blurred vision.

speaker: patient
text: It is an all over vision blur and then I have on blind spot in my right eye.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you had any fluctuations in your symptoms in the last year? Have you gained any vision back?

speaker: patient
text: Some days I feel like things are a little better but not much. I have basically been the same.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you experienced any weakness, dizziness, vertigo, nausea or vomiting?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Any double vision or headaches?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Any pain in or behind the eye at all?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Any other health concerns or complains?

speaker: patient
text: No. Just the vision problems.

speaker: doctor
text: Alright! Let me take a look here.

speaker: doctor
text: How are you feeling today?

speaker: patient
text: I have been having some trouble breathing.  I had tightness in my chest after walking up stairs.

speaker: doctor
text: Let me listen to your lungs.

speaker: doctor
text: Good afternoon, ma'am. Before we begin, can you confirm your age for me, please?

speaker: patient
text: Sure, I'm fifty six years old.

speaker: doctor
text: Great, thank you. What seems to be the problem today?

speaker: patient
text: Well, I have a history of systemic lupus erythematosus.

speaker: doctor
text: How have you been treated for this in the past?

speaker: patient
text: Um, I went to a rheumatologist about four months ago, I had discomfort in both of my hands.

speaker: doctor
text: Which hand was worse?

speaker: patient
text: My left was worse than my right at that time.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you seen anyone else for this?

speaker: patient
text: Um, I came in on October thirtieth two thousand seven. I was having the same problem.

speaker: doctor
text: What did they do for you at that time?

speaker: patient
text: They have me a trial of Elavil because they thought it was, um, ulnar or radial neuropathy.

speaker: doctor
text: Did they give you any topical creams?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, they gave me a prescription for Zostrix but I couldn't fill it because of my insurance.

speaker: doctor
text: I see, have your symptoms gotten worse since they began?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, especially here, at the base of my left hand, like around my wrist.

speaker: doctor
text: Which fingers do you feel it in? If any?

speaker: patient
text: Right here, doctor.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, these are your second, third, and fourth fingers. Do you have any other symptoms of note?

speaker: patient
text: Um, actually yeah, I've been having some respiratory problems for the last three days or so.

speaker: doctor
text: What symptoms have you been experiencing?

speaker: patient
text: Um, I've had a dry cough and I feel like I've had a fever but I haven't taken my temperature.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you had any night sweats or chills?

speaker: patient
text: No, not that I can remember.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you had any chest pain or discomfort?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: What about shortness of breath, or G I problems?

speaker: patient
text: Thankfully, no.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you remember the name of the medication you are taking?

speaker: patient
text: I have two, but I do not remember their name or why I am taking it.

speaker: doctor
text: That is fine, we will figure it out.

speaker: doctor
text: I wanted to talk to you about your family medical history.

speaker: patient
text: Okay, how this will be helpful?

speaker: doctor
text: Family history plays an invaluable role in your health. It provides us with important clues and insight to predict and detect diseases before obvious symptoms appear.

speaker: patient
text: My mom dealt a long time with anxiety and stress disorder.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, let's review your family history.

speaker: patient
text: Ready when you are.

speaker: doctor
text: Does anyone in your family have high blood pressure or high cholesterol?

speaker: patient
text: Both my parents have high blood pressure.

speaker: doctor
text: Are they being treated for it?

speaker: patient
text: Um yes. Oh they also have E T.

speaker: doctor
text: Do any of your siblings have it as well?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Does anyone in your family have an autoimmune disorder.

speaker: patient
text: Hm. Give me a second to think. Does lupus count?

speaker: doctor
text: Yes. Who do you know that has lupus?

speaker: patient
text: My cousin.

speaker: doctor
text: On your mom or dad's side?

speaker: patient
text: Uh mom.

speaker: doctor
text: What are you taking as a maintenance treatment?

speaker: patient
text: Oh, I take Flonase.

speaker: doctor
text: And do you have a lot of issues after taking that?

speaker: patient
text: No I do not.

speaker: doctor
text: That is good.

speaker: doctor
text: Hello. Looks like we are here for a six months follow up. How are we doing?

speaker: patient
text: I have stayed relatively the same. My main complaint is that I feel tired throughout the day. The C P A P is doing fine and I wake up refreshed, but I don't like how I crash.

speaker: doctor
text: Alright. How are the thyroid issues?

speaker: patient
text: I seem to be fine. My thyroid gland does not seem enlarged and I can breathe like normal. No fever or anything.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you experienced any of the following: temperature intolerance, palpitations, muscle weakness, tremors, nausea, vomiting, constipation, or diarrhea?

speaker: patient
text: Nothing of the kind.

speaker: doctor
text: How has you weight been?

speaker: patient
text: It has been stable.

speaker: doctor
text: Any muscle weakness closest to the body's center?

speaker: patient
text: No, nothing like that. Not bad for forty five.

speaker: doctor
text: So I understand you had a fainting episode yesterday?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I did.

speaker: doctor
text: Has this happened to you before?

speaker: patient
text: Yes. It happens whenever needles are involved.

speaker: doctor
text: You had a Vasovagal Syncope. How are you feeling today?

speaker: patient
text: I feel normal today.

speaker: doctor
text: Hello, how are you?

speaker: patient
text: I am not so good.

speaker: doctor
text: Oh, what is going on with you?

speaker: patient
text: Well, I have lot of swelling in my legs.

speaker: doctor
text: Hm, okay.

speaker: doctor
text: Hi there, sir! I am Doctor Frankland.

speaker: patient
text: Hi! It's nice to meet you.

speaker: doctor
text: What brings you into see me today?

speaker: patient
text: I have had this pain in my finger and wrist for about a month. I have had some numbness too. The numbness started in the finger and is now in the wrist too.

speaker: doctor
text: Which wrist and finger is it that is hurting?

speaker: patient
text: The left one and the middle finger, here.

speaker: doctor
text: What was to time frame of the procreation of the numbness from the finger to the wrist?

speaker: patient
text: It started when I woke up and then by the end of the day my wrist was numb too.

speaker: doctor
text: When did you start experiencing pain in the wrist area?

speaker: patient
text: A few days after the numbness started.

speaker: doctor
text: Which hand is your dominate hand?

speaker: patient
text: I am left handed.

speaker: doctor
text: What do you do for work?

speaker: patient
text: I am a cook. I also cut the fish for the whole restaurant.  I cut fish for hours in the mornings and it has been a struggle and it is aggravating my finger and wrist.

speaker: doctor
text: How old are you?

speaker: patient
text: I am forty four.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any history of injuring a neck injury?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Any neck pain or weakness?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Any difficulties with bowel movements or urination?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Good morning.  How are you feeling today?

speaker: patient
text: I feel good, considering.  I slept well last night.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you expensing any pain or discomfort?

speaker: patient
text: No. I feel fine.

speaker: doctor
text: How are you doing with everything?

speaker: patient
text: I'm good. It's hard when you are in quarantine. I hope things will get back to normal soon.

speaker: doctor
text: So, you are here for your breast examination.

speaker: patient
text: Yes, it was due for so long.

speaker: doctor
text: I'm going to touch both of your breasts one by one to check for any lump or kind of mass. Okay?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, so both looks good. Are you feeling any pain while I'm touching?

speaker: patient
text: No, I don't feel any pain.

speaker: doctor
text: That's good, no masses, no pain and I do not feel anything in your armpit area.

speaker: doctor
text: How's your wife doing? I think the last time I saw her was two weeks ago. She was telling me about the remodeling you've been doing around the house.

speaker: patient
text: She's doing well, thanks for asking. Oh yeah, the remodeling has been a lot. I didn't think it'd take as long as it has.

speaker: doctor
text: Yeah, it can take some time. We remodeled our kitchen three years ago and it turned our lives upside down. So tell me, how's training going for you? I believe you were telling me that you have a five k coming up.

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, it's two weeks away. I've been jogging and doing cross country track about five times a week. I also lift twice a week on my better days.

speaker: doctor
text: That's great! And no smoking or drinking, correct?

speaker: patient
text: Nope.

speaker: doctor
text: How's work been treating ya?

speaker: patient
text: Pretty darn well actually. I go into the allergy and immunology clinic four days outta the week. I like that my hours are flexible. My patients also haven't run away from me yet, which is always a good sign.

speaker: doctor
text: My nurse tells me you're thirty four years old, is that correct?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I just had my birthday, doctor.

speaker: doctor
text: You identify as African American, correct?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, that's right, sir.

speaker: doctor
text: You're here for a follow up? What brings you back in today?

speaker: patient
text: Well, I don't really have a single acute complaint, but I have a muscle sprain in my upper back.

speaker: doctor
text: Is there an injury associated with this pain, ma'am?

speaker: patient
text: I think it has to do with me lifting weights.

speaker: doctor
text: Yes, that's common. Is this messing with your ability to work?

speaker: patient
text: No, it's not really.

speaker: doctor
text: What do you do for a living?

speaker: patient
text: I'm a housekeeper, it's my profession.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you having trouble sleeping at night?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, it's not severe, but I'm having some trouble.

speaker: doctor
text: With ten being the worst pain imaginable, how would you rate your pain today?

speaker: patient
text: I'd say it's usually a two out of ten.

speaker: doctor
text: When it's the worst, how would you rate it?

speaker: patient
text: When that happens, I'd say it's a three or a four.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you take any medicines for this pain?

speaker: patient
text: Over the counter medications usually help the pain go away.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any other complaints?

speaker: patient
text: No, just this muscle pain.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any loss of balance when you hold something with this arm?

speaker: patient
text: No, my strength and everything is normal there.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any signs of infection? That'd be anything like fever or chills, anything like that?

speaker: patient
text: No, I don't have anything like that.

speaker: doctor
text: How can I help you today.

speaker: patient
text: I have been having irregular periods.

speaker: doctor
text: When was your last menstrual period?

speaker: patient
text: My last period was on June first two thousand and four.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you currently sexually active? Is there a possibility of pregnancy?

speaker: patient
text: No! There is no possibility that I am pregnant.  I have not had sex in two years.

speaker: doctor
text: How old where you when you had your first menstrual period?

speaker: patient
text: I was ten years old when I got my first period.  My cycle has never been regular. It runs in my mom's side of the family.

speaker: doctor
text: What is your family history of reproductive health conditions on your mom's side of the family?

speaker: patient
text: My mom and my aunt have both had total hysterectomies.

speaker: doctor
text: Is there any other personal medical history I should know about?

speaker: patient
text: I see Doctor X Y Z Allen for my abnormal heart valve condition.  I am on S B E prophylaxis.  I have to limit my activity because of my heart condition.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you avoid decongestants?

speaker: patient
text: Yes.

speaker: doctor
text: How have you been feeling? How is your leg feeling?

speaker: patient
text: My right leg is in a lot of pain. The nurse just changed the bandage. I only have a rash where the bandage is.

speaker: doctor
text: It looks like we have you taking Vicodin for the pain. Is the medication not helping?

speaker: patient
text: The pain medication is horrible. I have been throwing up, off and on. I have been constipated since I have been here.

speaker: doctor
text: I'll note that. Vomiting since February nineteen of two thousand seven. I am sorry to hear that. I will make a change to the medication and get you something for the constipation issue.

speaker: patient
text: Thank you.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you had any shortness of breath, chest pain or coughing up blood?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Any joint pain, headaches or rashes?

speaker: patient
text: No. Just a rash where the bandages are like I said earlier. I also want to discuss this acne while I am here. I have had it for about two years. It's nothing big, just mild to moderate in severity.

speaker: doctor
text: Does anyone in your family have a neurological disorder?

speaker: patient
text: No, not to my knowledge.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you smoke, sir?

speaker: patient
text: Well, I used to a long time ago, but I don't anymore.

speaker: doctor
text: Good, what about alcohol, do you drink?

speaker: patient
text: Well, my wife and I have a drink or two a day.

speaker: doctor
text: Did you had any medical issues in the past?

speaker: patient
text: No, nothing major.

speaker: doctor
text: You said nothing major, so, what was there?

speaker: patient
text: I had a little curve in the spine. It was not major. Doctor said that it can be corrected by exercises.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any medical conditions that I should know about?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I have chronic diarrhea, and C O P D.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you a smoker?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I have been for a long time.

speaker: doctor
text: How would you characterize your smoking level?

speaker: patient
text: Um, I'd say it's pretty heavy.

speaker: doctor
text: You have atrial fibrillation from the past?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, rhythm problem is bad.

speaker: doctor
text: And no dizziness?

speaker: patient
text: Yes. I do.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay well...

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any allergies?

speaker: patient
text: No allergies.

speaker: doctor
text: Nothing? Cat dander, pollen?

speaker: patient
text: Nope.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you live with your husband?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, we live on a ranch about twenty miles away.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have children?

speaker: patient
text: We had six children all together, but two of them passed away suddenly.

speaker: doctor
text: I'm so sorry to hear that. How old were they?

speaker: patient
text: One was forty years old and the other was forty five.

speaker: doctor
text: Wow, they were quite young. I offer you my sincerest condolences.

speaker: patient
text: Thank you. It's been really hard on my family, but we're trying our best to get by.

speaker: doctor
text: That's all you can do. It's important to spend time with each other every chance you get.

speaker: patient
text: Exactly.

speaker: doctor
text: I have a few more questions to ask before we end today.

speaker: patient
text: Go ahead.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have family history of any medical problems?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you smoke or drink?

speaker: patient
text: Never.

speaker: doctor
text: So let's see here. Any history of high blood pressure or diabetes?

speaker: patient
text: No, sir.

speaker: doctor
text: How about heart disease?

speaker: patient
text: No, no heart disease.

speaker: doctor
text: And no cancers?

speaker: patient
text: No and for that I'm thankful.

speaker: doctor
text: What is your family medical history?

speaker: patient
text: My dad had Alzheimer's disease. He is in a facility that cares for him now.

speaker: doctor
text: I am sorry that must be hard.

speaker: patient
text: It is. My aunt, his sister helped me get everything set up for him. She had a stroke last month.

speaker: doctor
text: Oh no. How is she doing now?

speaker: patient
text: She is home now but her husband is having to help take care of her. The doctors said it looks good for her to have a full or almost full recovery.

speaker: doctor
text: That is a relief.

speaker: patient
text: Yes, it is!

speaker: doctor
text: Any other family health problems that you know of?

speaker: patient
text: No not that I know of.

speaker: doctor
text: So, how much longer are you in juvie, young man?

speaker: patient
text: I've got about three weeks left, sir. Twenty five days, if you want to be exact.

speaker: doctor
text: Good, time to make the best of getting out, right?

speaker: patient
text: Absolutely, I don't want to go back.

speaker: doctor
text: Good. Do you smoke, young man?

speaker: patient
text: No sir, absolutely not.

speaker: doctor
text: Hello, I am Doctor Rez. I will ask you a few questions about your personal and family history, okay?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, that's okay.

speaker: doctor
text: Did any one in your family get diagnosed with any medical conditions?

speaker: patient
text: My mom has lumps in her breast but it is benign, however my granny on my father side had cancer.

speaker: doctor
text: What kind of cancer, do you know?

speaker: patient
text: Well, it was breast cancer don't know if there are types for it.

speaker: doctor
text: No, that's fine. Did you ever have palpitations?

speaker: patient
text: What do you mean by that?

speaker: doctor
text: Um, Palpitations means the sensation when you feel that your heart is racing or pounding really fast even without doing any strenuous exercise or anything.

speaker: patient
text: Oh, got it. No, I never had that.

speaker: doctor
text: What about any uncontrolled urine leakage? Any accidents?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: What about any recent sudden hair loss or any other concerns?

speaker: patient
text: No, nothing like that.

speaker: doctor
text: Any other treatments in the past?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I recently got treatment for my sinus.

speaker: doctor
text: Any history of smoking?

speaker: patient
text: Uh yeah, but I quit in two thousand seven.

speaker: doctor
text: On average, how many packs per day did you smoke?

speaker: patient
text: Uh if I were to guess, I'd say one pack per day.

speaker: doctor
text: Any other drugs?

speaker: patient
text: I used to do coke, but I quit that in two thousand five.

speaker: doctor
text: And any history of drinking?

speaker: patient
text: Um I used to drink one pint per day, but I quit drinking more than ten years ago.

speaker: doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your family's medical history? Are there any conditions of note?

speaker: patient
text: Well, my dad died from prostate cancer, and my mom died as well, she was an alcoholic.

speaker: doctor
text: I'm so sorry to hear that, ma'am, how old were they?

speaker: patient
text: Well, my father was eighty, and my mother was sixty seven.

speaker: doctor
text: I'm so sorry, do you have any siblings?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I had a brother, he passed away too, from bone and throat cancer.

speaker: doctor
text: I'm sorry, how old was he?

speaker: patient
text: He was seventy, doctor.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any children?

speaker: patient
text: I have four, two of each.

speaker: doctor
text: That's wonderful, how are your sons doing?

speaker: patient
text: They're thirty seven and thirty eight, and they're both doing really well.

speaker: doctor
text: That's great, what about your daughters?

speaker: patient
text: Well, they're sixty and fifty eight, and they both have cancer. They're real fighters.

speaker: doctor
text: I'm sorry, that must be so hard to deal with. Are there any other conditions you're aware of?

speaker: patient
text: Oh yeah, we have it all, nervous condition, high blood pressure, kidney and lung disease, depression, it's all there.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you married?

speaker: patient
text: Yes.

speaker: doctor
text: Where do you work?

speaker: patient
text: I work as a secretary in a law firm.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you smoke or drink? Have you ever tried any illegal drug?

speaker: patient
text: No, none of these.

speaker: doctor
text: It looks like E M S found you in bad shape?

speaker: patient
text: What?

speaker: doctor
text: Did your mother tell you anything about her condition before E M S arrived?

speaker: doctor
text: Ma'am. How are you feeling now?

speaker: patient
text: I have been sick to my stomach.  My belly has been hurting. I threw up.

speaker: doctor
text: How many times did you vomit ma'am?

speaker: patient
text: I don't know.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you recall the color of the vomit? Did you see any blood or notice the color of the vomit?

speaker: patient
text: I don't know.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have kids, ma'am?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I do. I have two sons and we adopted a girl.

speaker: doctor
text: Where did you adopt?

speaker: patient
text: Just here.

speaker: doctor
text: and you are married right? Are you working?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I have been married a long time. I retired from Avon.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you smoke cigarettes or drink?

speaker: patient
text: I do not smoke or drink alcohol.

speaker: doctor
text: How's the little dude?

speaker: doctor
text: I am guessing he has some mild problems with breathing while feeding.

speaker: doctor
text: Is he sleeping well?

speaker: doctor
text: How about wet and dirty diapers?

speaker: doctor
text: How about any diarrhea?

speaker: doctor
text: Any rashes or acne?

speaker: doctor
text: How about vomiting?

speaker: doctor
text: How old is he? And, sorry this is odd, but what ethnicity do you identify as? I need it foe the paperwork.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you notice him getting blue at all? Or does this area sink in when he tried to breathe?

speaker: doctor
text: Is he having any trouble breathing in general?

speaker: doctor
text: Are you taking Benicar?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, twenty daily.

speaker: doctor
text: And what else?

speaker: patient
text: I take some multivitamin, glucosamine, Vitamin B complex, Vitamin E and a low dose Aspirin.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay that's good information.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you smoke?

speaker: patient
text: Nope.

speaker: doctor
text: How about alcohol intake?

speaker: patient
text: Nope.

speaker: doctor
text: What about any kind of drug usage?

speaker: patient
text: Nope.

speaker: doctor
text: Hi, how are you?

speaker: patient
text: I am okay.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any bone pain or issues around that?

speaker: patient
text: No, I do not.

speaker: doctor
text: So, they gave you a dose of Tylenol here in the emergency department to treat your pain.  Is your pain under control?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, with medication I feel it is better, but I want to be removed from the backboard.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, let's get you off. Yeah, your C T scans of the abdomen appeared normal.  And there was no sign of bleeding.  I believe, you just have a contusion and abrasion to abdomen from the seatbelt and likely from the airbag as well.

speaker: patient
text: Oh okay.

speaker: doctor
text: It's good that you can stand and walk through the emergency department without difficulty. I do not see any abrasions or lacerations.

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, nothing like that and I can walk.

speaker: doctor
text: Lets talk about your family history, does cancer run in your family ma'am?

speaker: patient
text: Oh yes! My family has a history of lung, liver and prostate cancer.

speaker: doctor
text: Oh wow!

speaker: patient
text: Yeah.

speaker: doctor
text: And you mentioned that your mother had Alzheimer's?

speaker: patient
text: Well, I am not sure about Alzheimer, but she had some dementing disease. It started when she was in her eighties. It was kind of mild case.

speaker: patient
text: And she actually passed away in her eighties due to old age.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, how about your siblings, do they have any signs of Alzheimer?

speaker: patient
text: No, they are fine.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: I have here hypertension, diabetes, diabetic retinopathy, and elevated lipids. They're in post C V A.

speaker: doctor
text: I can have the nurse or scribe go in and ask again.

speaker: doctor
text: I tried but was unsuccessful. She's very out of it.

speaker: doctor
text: According to her records, she has a long history of alcohol abuse.

speaker: doctor
text: The patient has a history of C A D.

speaker: doctor
text: Not to my knowledge. I can check their electronic medical records. One sec.

speaker: doctor
text: Hi sir, how old are you?

speaker: patient
text: I am thirty.

speaker: doctor
text: We are following up today for your moderate to severe apnea, right?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, that is correct, I still can't sleep.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay and you did the CPAP?

speaker: patient
text: Yes.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, let's review it today.

speaker: patient
text: Sure.

speaker: doctor
text: Any smoking or alcohol?

speaker: patient
text: No, I don't smoke but I drink wine.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you married?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I am.

speaker: patient
text: I have three stepchildren and one of my own and I work for A B C D.

speaker: doctor
text: Congratulations on your new baby! How are you doing today?

speaker: patient
text: I'm doing well, no headaches, and I'm breastfeeding well.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you had any bleeding?

speaker: patient
text: Nope, none.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you using a mini pad?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I use it twice a day.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any cramping or clotting?

speaker: patient
text: No, thankfully I don't.

speaker: doctor
text: What color is your discharge, ma'am?

speaker: patient
text: Well, its turned from red to brown, and now its kind of yellowish.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, have you had sex again yet?

speaker: patient
text: No, we're waiting a little longer.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you going to the bathroom regularly?

speaker: patient
text: Regularly? Yes, but I'm having some pain with it, and then every once in a while I have some bright red bleeding.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you constipated?

speaker: patient
text: No, I'm not.

speaker: doctor
text: That'll also do it.

speaker: patient
text: Okay, well, my seasonal allergies are back too.

speaker: doctor
text: What symptoms do you have with your allergies?

speaker: patient
text: I get itchy watery eyes, a runny nose, I can't stop sneezing, and I have a lot of pressure in my ears.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any major medical conditions that run in your family that I should know about?

speaker: patient
text: What do you mean by that?

speaker: doctor
text: Well, it could be anything from diabetes to high blood pressure to cancer.

speaker: patient
text: Oh, yeah. My brother had prostate cancer.

speaker: doctor
text: Hi, how are you?

speaker: patient
text: Hi! I am okay other then this back pain.

speaker: doctor
text: I am so sorry. Tell me about your back.

speaker: patient
text: Three nights ago, I fell on my steps bringing in the groceries from the car.

speaker: doctor
text: How did you land when you fell?

speaker: patient
text: I fell and landed on my right hip. I hit my low back on the railing.

speaker: doctor
text: I would like to get some imaging done today.

speaker: patient
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you seen your lab results?

speaker: patient
text: No, do you have those in today?

speaker: doctor
text: Yes, I have them right here. They're essentially negative, except it appears that you had C difficile in the past. Do you remember that?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I got it when I worked at a hospital after graduating.

speaker: doctor
text: Yeah, its unfortunately more common there.

speaker: doctor
text: Breath in breath out, let me tap it and see. Well, your lungs sound clear.

speaker: patient
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you still taking the Trizivir?

speaker: patient
text: Yes.

speaker: doctor
text: How much are you taking?

speaker: patient
text: I take one pill two times a day.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you taking any other medications?

speaker: patient
text: I take Ibuprofen for body aches from time to time but that's it.

speaker: doctor
text: I just need to confirm some information before we begin sir, you're forty one, correct?

speaker: patient
text: Yes sir, that's correct.

speaker: doctor
text: Good, so what happened?

speaker: patient
text: Well, I work at A B C, and about two days ago I slipped on some oil that had spilled.

speaker: doctor
text: How did you fall?

speaker: patient
text: I fell with both my arms outstretched, but I fell mostly on my left shoulder.

speaker: doctor
text: Where is your left shoulder pain?

speaker: patient
text: Mostly, it's in the back of my shoulder.

speaker: doctor
text: Going backwards a little, how about the right shoulder?

speaker: patient
text: It hurt really bad yesterday, but that's gone away now.

speaker: doctor
text: Good, do you have any pain in the front of the shoulder?

speaker: patient
text: No sir, I don't have anything there.

speaker: doctor
text: Good, how about weakness? Is there any shoulder weakness?

speaker: patient
text: No, it's not really weak at all.

speaker: doctor
text: How have your symptoms progressed over the last two days? Have they gotten better, or worse?

speaker: patient
text: Um, overall, I'd say it's gotten better. I have a little better range of motion.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you been able to do any activities?

speaker: patient
text: I was able to get in the swimming pool with my kids, and I didn't really have any trouble.

speaker: doctor
text: Good, what medicines have you taken for this?

speaker: patient
text: I've just taken some Advil so far.

speaker: doctor
text: Hi there! It is good to see you both. How has everything been going for the both of you?

speaker: patient
text: Hi Doctor.

speaker: doctor
text: That is great. Keep me updated on her progress.  Her bloodwork came back showing an underactive thyroid. This explains the recent weight gain and fatigue. I would like to start her on a medication called levothyroxine. We will need to check her bloodwork again in one month to see how her thyroid respond to the medication.

speaker: doctor
text: Is there any other concerns you have today?

speaker: doctor
text: Let me look. Can you remove your socks for me?

speaker: patient
text: Yes.

speaker: doctor
text: Is it this nail?

speaker: doctor
text: This is very common. It is called Onychomycosis. It is nail fungus. Since only one nail is affected, I would recommend starting off with a topical treatment. I will send the drops to your pharmacy. You will put on drop on the affected nail, daily.

speaker: doctor
text: Good afternoon, ma'am.

speaker: patient
text: Good afternoon, doctor.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you ever had surgery, ma'am?

speaker: patient
text: Actually, yes I have. I had pinning surgery done on both of my ears.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you remember how old you were when you had surgery?

speaker: patient
text: Um, I was five or six years old. It was when I was a kid, I know that for sure.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any allergies?

speaker: patient
text: Not that I know of.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: What is your family medical history?

speaker: patient
text: My dad has high blood pressure. My mom has had a ton of skin cancer removed.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you know what type of skin cancer she has removed?

speaker: patient
text: I have no idea.

speaker: doctor
text: Hello, miss. Today we're going to do a recheck for your hypertension. Sound good?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, of course.

speaker: doctor
text: I just want to check to see if you have any symptoms that can possibly raise alarm.

speaker: patient
text: I have been coming to you for the last fifteen of my seventy eight years on Earth. I know how a follow up works.

speaker: doctor
text: You are a seasoned veteran. Alright. So how is your chest? Any pains or tightness?

speaker: patient
text: No, luckily I do not have that.

speaker: doctor
text: Is your heart beating alright? Do you feel like it is beating too fast or hard?

speaker: patient
text: No. I can't really feel my heart beat normally, but I guess that is better than feeling it beat constantly.

speaker: doctor
text: You are correct. You shouldn't notice it. How is sleeping?

speaker: patient
text: Sleeping has been fine. I sleep through the night.

speaker: doctor
text: Great. Any shortness of breath that causes you to wake up?

speaker: patient
text: None. I don't have shortness of breath at any other time of the day.

speaker: doctor
text: Are your legs doing well? Any swelling?

speaker: patient
text: No. No swelling.

speaker: doctor
text: Hello, it's nice to meet you.

speaker: patient
text: It's nice to meet you as well.

speaker: doctor
text: My name is Doctor X and I will be taking care of you today.

speaker: patient
text: Thank you.

speaker: doctor
text: I've been told that you'd like a refill on your Xanax prescription and something to help you break your smoking habit.

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I feel like I've tried everything in the book and I still can't break the habit. One of my buddies was telling me about this medicine called Clantix or something like that.

speaker: doctor
text: Yes, I've heard of Chantix. We can look into it and see what's best fit.

speaker: patient
text: Okay, great. Since moving back home, I've ran out of Xanax.

speaker: doctor
text: How long have you been taking it?

speaker: patient
text: Almost a year now. I usually take it on days where my anxiety is really bad.

speaker: doctor
text: I see here that you also have mesothelioma in the lining of your stomach, is that correct?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I need to find a new cancer specialist that's closer to where I live.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you currently experiencing any pain?

speaker: patient
text: Not at the moment, but I do get pain when I eat sometimes. Other times it's when I'm not even doing anything. It's been chronic so nothing new.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you take anything for the pain?

speaker: patient
text: I haven't in a while.

speaker: doctor
text: When were you diagnosed with mesothelioma?

speaker: patient
text: About six or so months ago.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you allergic to anything?

speaker: doctor
text: Like any medications?

speaker: patient
text: No, I am not allergic to anything.

speaker: doctor
text: Perfect!

speaker: patient
text: Hm.

speaker: doctor
text: Welcome to the clinic.

speaker: patient
text: Thank you. It is nice to meet you.

speaker: doctor
text: It is nice to meet you to. I hear an accent. Where are you from?

speaker: patient
text: I am from Denmark. I speak Danish as my first language. Me and my husband have been in the States for many many years. When we first got here, we did not speak a word of English.

speaker: doctor
text: Wow! Your English is excellent now.

speaker: patient
text: Thank you.

speaker: doctor
text: How old are you?

speaker: patient
text: I just turned seventy four last month.

speaker: doctor
text: Happy birthday!

speaker: patient
text: Thank you.

speaker: doctor
text: So, your primary care physician sent you here for possible hydrocephalus.

speaker: patient
text: Is that the water on brain thing?

speaker: doctor
text: Yes.

speaker: patient
text: Then, yes.

speaker: doctor
text: Can you tell me about the symptoms that you have been having.

speaker: patient
text: I think I have been walking funny lately. I have also been losing my balance.

speaker: doctor
text: How do you know that you have been walking funny?

speaker: patient
text: My husband noticed that I have been walking funny. He noticed it about over six months ago or so.

speaker: doctor
text: What do you notice about the way your wife's walk that has changed?

speaker: doctor
text: Okay. Have you noticed her stabilizing herself all of a sudden?

speaker: doctor
text: What else have you noticed about the way she walks?

speaker: doctor
text: That is good that you are taking your time. Do you use any devices to assist you to get around? Like a cane or a walker?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: patient
text: I have had one emergency room visit.

speaker: doctor
text: What happened that you had to go to the emergency room?

speaker: patient
text: I fell. I was walking to the bedroom. I lost my balance so I put my hand out to brace myself against the wall and my hand slipped. I fell on my wrist.

speaker: doctor
text: When did this fall happen?

speaker: patient
text: March two thousand and seven.

speaker: doctor
text: I can see why that would make you nervous. Have you had any headaches?

speaker: patient
text: No. I never get headaches.

speaker: doctor
text: Aren't you lucky.

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I guess so.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you had any problems with your memory or cognitive abilities?

speaker: patient
text: I am still able to pay the bills on time. I don't feel as smart as I used to be.  I do feel like my thinking has slowed down over the last few months.

speaker: doctor
text: What is your perspective on her memory and her cognitive abilities?

speaker: doctor
text: Has she ever had trouble finishing a sentence the in the past?

speaker: doctor
text: Have you had any fainting or vertigo episodes?

speaker: patient
text: I have not fainted. I have had some dizzy spells in the past but not recently.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you had and problems with your bowel movements?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Any bladder issues or frequent urination?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Okey. Let us do some an exam.

speaker: patient
text: Okey.

speaker: doctor
text: I mean, I am so happy to see your report today, your blood pressure looks much better. That's amazing given your past few visits your B P was out of control and even with changing your medications we were having tough time bringing it down.

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I feel much better, I read about my condition and it is called something as um refraction or--

speaker: doctor
text: Refractory hypertension.

speaker: patient
text: Oh yeah that!

speaker: doctor
text: But the good news is that it is getting better.

speaker: patient
text: Yes.

speaker: doctor
text: Last time we talked about seeing the internal medicine doctor there at your senior center, right?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I made an appointment last week, um, no week before that, but I completely forgot about it.

speaker: doctor
text: Hm, okay we need to reschedule that.

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I will do it today.

speaker: doctor
