text: Okay, your reports look fine. G F R is below sixty percent, that's a good sign.  Overall, Miss K, you look better, but we need to reschedule your appointment with the Internist. That's kind of important.

speaker: patient
text: Okay, I will do that. Thank you!

speaker: doctor
text: You are welcome.

speaker: doctor
text: Did you ever visit any hospital for any kind of surgery?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Hi there! How are doing today?

speaker: patient
text: I am doing well.

speaker: doctor
text: How have you been doing with keeping your hemoglobin levels between four and five point six prercent?

speaker: patient
text: I have been doing well. I have been able to keep it within that range.

speaker: doctor
text: So, are you married, ma'am?

speaker: patient
text: Well, no I'm not. My husband and I got a divorce.

speaker: doctor
text: I'm sorry to hear that, do you have any children?

speaker: patient
text: It's okay, it was for the best. Yes, I have two.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you live with either of them?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, um, I live with my son right now.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you smoke or drink?

speaker: patient
text: No I do not.

speaker: doctor
text: Good afternoon, so, who is the patient today?

speaker: doctor
text: What seems to be the problem today, young lady?

speaker: patient
text: Well, I'm having a lot of headaches, I feel it in my face.

speaker: doctor
text: Does it feel like pressure?

speaker: patient
text: That, and I have the sniffles.

speaker: doctor
text: What other symptoms have you had?

speaker: patient
text: Um, well, last night I had a sore throat, and I was coughing up phlegm.

speaker: doctor
text: Interesting, anything else?

speaker: patient
text: Um, I've had a rash on my face, back, and arms for the last three days or so.

speaker: doctor
text: Is it itchy?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, so we've been taking a lot of Benadryl.

speaker: doctor
text: I see, are you going to school?

speaker: patient
text: I have been, there's been a lot of fifth disease this year.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, and have you been wheezing lately?

speaker: patient
text: No, I haven't been.

speaker: doctor
text: I see you have asthma, have you had any medication for this?

speaker: patient
text: No, I haven't had anything.

speaker: doctor
text: Did you have any surgeries in the past?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I had a partial removal of my ovaries and then I also had my appendix removed.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay anything else?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I also got my tummy tucked.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: Good afternoon, young man.

speaker: patient
text: Hello, doctor.

speaker: doctor
text: How old are you, young man?

speaker: patient
text: I'm thirteen, sir.

speaker: doctor
text: Thank you, so, what happened?

speaker: patient
text: I sliced my right ring finger with a piece of glass while I was playing around with my friends.

speaker: doctor
text: You need to be more careful, young man. What kind of symptoms do you feel in that finger?

speaker: patient
text: You're right. I have a lot of, um, numbness and tingling in it.

speaker: doctor
text: Hello. How are you feeling today?

speaker: patient
text: Not so well. I went to a party last night and my chest and body have been hurting a lot.

speaker: doctor
text: I see. Did you smoke at the party?

speaker: patient
text: Nope. I never smoked in my life.

speaker: doctor
text: Great. Where on your body does it hurt?

speaker: patient
text: Like my upper right side of my stomach area.

speaker: doctor
text: I see. Did you drink alcohol last night?

speaker: patient
text: I had to drive some people home, so I was sober. I also don't like the taste of alcohol, so I stay away from it.

speaker: patient
text: And do I have to restrict my movement or activities?

speaker: doctor
text: Um, I have taken the plaster off and your foot looks good. I don't want you to restrict your activities, but you are the best judge of the situation. So, I will advise you to take it slow and do as much as you can tolerate.

speaker: patient
text: Got it. Thank you, Doctor. Do I need a follow-up?

speaker: doctor
text: As long as you are doing fine, having no pain, I think we are okay.

speaker: patient
text: Alright then bye.

speaker: doctor
text: Bye.

speaker: doctor
text: What is your family medical history?

speaker: patient
text: My dad had stomach cancer.

speaker: doctor
text: How old was he when he was diagnosed?

speaker: patient
text: I think he was seventy something. My sister has breast cancer. She is in her fifty's.

speaker: doctor
text: Any family history of uterine, ovarian or colon cancer?

speaker: patient
text: No. Not that I am aware of.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you drink or smoke?

speaker: patient
text: No I don't. I have to care for my daughter. She is a widow.

speaker: doctor
text: So you live with her?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, she lives at home.

speaker: patient
text: I think I need help.

speaker: doctor
text: I am here to help. Tell me what's going on.

speaker: patient
text: I am having mood swings, sometimes I feel super happy and sometimes I am just super sad and angry with myself. I find myself in tears thinking about things or situations which are not even real.

speaker: doctor
text: How old are you ma'am?

speaker: patient
text: I have just completed five decades of my life.

speaker: doctor
text: Did you ever try to hurt yourself?

speaker: patient
text: No, that thought never came to my mind. I just feel sad, like nobody cares if I exist. Sometimes I feel I can conquer the world and do anything I put my heart and mind into. It's just that I am not sure how will I feel after an hour.

speaker: doctor
text: How long have you had these symptoms?

speaker: patient
text: It has been going on for many months. At first, I ignored everything but now It feels like I am not myself any more with all these mood swings.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you work?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I am a hygienist and work in a Bright Dentals.

speaker: doctor
text: How are you doing at work with your mood swings?

speaker: patient
text: Huh, my symptoms have sure started affecting my work. You know what the worst part is, my boss came to me last week and asked if I was on some kinds of drugs. I literally shouted at her saying no and left the clinic in tears. I think I need some drugs; I mean some medications to deal with my issues.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you ever been on any kind of medicine or treatment before?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I was on Wellbutrin before. It was prescribed by Doctor Jonah. I was eating a lot and even gained like twenty pounds in just a few months. My insurance didn't even cover it, I had to pay from my pocket.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you know what you were diagnosed with?

speaker: patient
text: It is all in these papers, I got my file with me, I just want to be normal me again.

speaker: doctor
text: Let me check and enter it in the medical record for future references. According to this, they prescribed Wellbutrin for obsessive compulsive type disorder and yes it was related to your overeating. Did it help you?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I was doing better once I started taking that medicine regularly. I continued it even though I had to pay out of my pocket.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you ever been on antidepressants?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Any hot flashes or night sweat? Did you ever find yourself waking up to wet bed due to sweating?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Just putting together all that you have told me here. You have mood swings; you find yourself in tears without any specific reason, you are not suicidal, never been on any kind of antidepressants. Am I missing something here?

speaker: patient
text: Sometimes I really find it hard to concentrate. As a hygienist I really need to focus on the gums of the patients and cleaning but sometimes it gets hard to focus. Normally, at work I just stop when it gets hard to focus and take a walk around the clinic. It has started affecting my work. I need help!

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, I understand. Anything else that I should be aware of?

speaker: patient
text: Oh yeah, the insomnia, I am hardly sleeping. At times I feel like a zombie.

speaker: doctor
text: Any surgeries in the past?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I had some complications and they had to remove my complete uterus along with tubes and ovaries.

speaker: doctor
text: Oh! When was this?

speaker: patient
text: In the December of two thousand and three.

speaker: doctor
text: Any known past medical history?

speaker: patient
text: I have high blood pressure.

speaker: doctor
text: Anything else?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I remember I also had higher number of fat in my blood.

speaker: doctor
text: Good morning, ma'am, welcome in. I believe this is our first time meeting.

speaker: patient
text: Good morning, doctor. Yes, this is my first time in.

speaker: doctor
text: Great, how old are you?

speaker: patient
text: I'm fifty five, doctor.

speaker: doctor
text: Thank you, what seems to be the problem today?

speaker: patient
text: Well, I'm having a laundry list of symptoms coinciding with my allergies.

speaker: doctor
text: Like what, ma'am?

speaker: patient
text: Well, my sense of taste is diminished, dry mouth, um, acid reflux, and G I issues, and then I have asthma, and reactions to things like aerosols.

speaker: doctor
text: I see, do you have any food allergies?

speaker: patient
text: Um, I think.

speaker: doctor
text: What's your family history?

speaker: patient
text: Both my parents are deceased.

speaker: doctor
text: I'm so sorry to hear that. I offer you my sincerest condolences.

speaker: patient
text: Thank you. My dad passed away at seventy five from leukemia and my mom fell victim to heart problems and alcoholism at thirty eight.

speaker: doctor
text: Does anyone else in your family suffer from leukemia, cardiac problems, or alcohol abuse?

speaker: patient
text: One of my uncles on my dad's side was recently diagnosed with leukemia.

speaker: doctor
text: Oh, wow. I see.

speaker: doctor
text: Any fever or chills?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Any headache or body pains?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Any nausea vomiting?

speaker: patient
text: I had vomiting a few times.

speaker: doctor
text: Did you observe any blood?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, any diarrhea?

speaker: patient
text: No, on the contrary I am having constipation every now and then, it's really bothering me now. I feel bloated all the time and don't feel fresh in the morning or throughout the day.

speaker: doctor
text: Oh, how long have you had this problem?

speaker: patient
text: Couple of months now.

speaker: doctor
text: Hm, I see, does it hurt you to pass stool? Did you notice any blood?

speaker: patient
text: No. I use suppositories.

speaker: doctor
text: Oh, that's great. You are doing the right thing. In addition to that I will prescribe you some strong laxative you can drink that in morning it should help.

speaker: patient
text: Okay!

speaker: doctor
text: Any complains of heart burn or acidity or stomach pain?

speaker: patient
text: No, not really. I do get this twisty pain in my stomach sometimes which I think is mainly due to my constipation.

speaker: doctor
text: Yeah, you can get that kind of pain with constipation. Any cough or cold like symptoms? Any cough with sputum?

speaker: patient
text: No, I feel fine.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, basically I don't think you have any stomach ulcer or anything, but we need to treat your constipation because I know it can be really uncomfortable.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you take Diovan, estradiol, Norvasc, Wellbutrin?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, and the Wellbutrin is an inhaler.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay so inhaler SR?

speaker: patient
text: Yes.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you take oxygen therapy at home?

speaker: patient
text: Yes.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: Good afternoon, ma'am.

speaker: patient
text: Good afternoon, doctor.

speaker: doctor
text: How long have you and your husband been married?

speaker: patient
text: Oh, at this point I don't even know how long its been.

speaker: doctor
text: I assume you live together?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, we do.

speaker: doctor
text: What do you do for a living?

speaker: patient
text: I'm a school nurse for the School Department. I love working with the children.

speaker: doctor
text: That's wonderful. Do you drink or smoke?

speaker: patient
text: No, I don't drink, and I quit smoking cigarettes about twenty five years ago.

speaker: doctor
text: Good for you.

speaker: doctor
text: It looks like she had an appendectomy along with a total abdominal hysterectomy and bilateral salpingo oophorectomy sometime ago.

speaker: doctor
text: Oh and it looks like she had a right hip fracture back in O five after a fall.

speaker: doctor
text: Before we begin today, sir, I just need a few pieces of background information. I see here on my chart that you're thirty years old, is that correct?

speaker: patient
text: Yes doctor, that's correct.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, and which hand is your dominant hand?

speaker: patient
text: I use my right hand for everything.

speaker: doctor
text: Now, take me through the timeline of your symptoms, please. When did everything start?

speaker: patient
text: I was doing well until July of nineteen ninety three.

speaker: doctor
text: What were your initial symptoms?

speaker: patient
text: I began having weakness in my right arm, and there was some neck pain too.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, when these symptoms began, how did you manage them?

speaker: patient
text: At first, I went to a chiropractor, but after a while my arm started atrophying, and my right hand felt tight. I couldn't extend all my fingers out.

speaker: doctor
text: Once you noticed the atrophy and contractures, that's the tightness you were experiencing, how were you treated?

speaker: patient
text: After that, I went to a neurosurgeon close to my house, and he ordered an, um, C T scan of my neck.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, do you have the report of that C T Scan with you today?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, doctor, I have it right here. They were one on the twenty fifth of September in ninety two.

speaker: doctor
text: Thank you, okay, this shows an intramedullary lesion at C two three, and an extramedullary lesion at C six seven.

speaker: patient
text: That means tumor, right?

speaker: doctor
text: Yes sir. Did you have neck surgery?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I have the op notes right here.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, just so you know, you had a C six T one laminectomy, and they decompressed the spinal cord. How did you respond to this surgery?

speaker: patient
text: Well, honestly, I improved for about three months following the operation, but after that I just got worse and worse.

speaker: doctor
text: Once your symptoms worsened, what happened?

speaker: patient
text: Um, I started having this burning sensation on my left side.

speaker: doctor
text: Did you have any weakness, sir?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I had weakness in both my arms.

speaker: doctor
text: Was one side worse than the other?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, my right side was worse than my left.

speaker: doctor
text: In addition to the burning and weakness, did you have any other symptoms?

speaker: patient
text: Um, I had really bad balance, I felt nauseous, like I was going to throw up at all times, which I did do some, and, um, my heart was beating really fast, and my blood pressure went up really high.

speaker: doctor
text: After all these symptoms began, how were you treated?

speaker: patient
text: On, um, August thirty first nineteen ninety three I had an M R I of my neck, and I have that report right here, too.

speaker: doctor
text: Thank you, this shows diffuse enlargement of the cervical and thoracic spine and multiple enhancing nodules in the posterior fossa.

speaker: patient
text: Sorry to interrupt, what does all that mean?

speaker: doctor
text: Well, that's more tumors in the spine. Did you have another surgery for this?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I had brain surgery. I have those notes right here, too.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, so you had a suboccipital craniotomy with tumor excision, decompression, and biopsy. The biopsy showed hemangioblastoma.

speaker: patient
text: That's cancer, right? This was all done on September first of nineteen ninety three.

speaker: doctor
text: Well no, not exactly, it's a benign tumor. After this surgery how were your symptoms?

speaker: patient
text: I felt good, the doctors said I stabilized out. I went through some radiation procedures from September of ninety three to January nineteenth of ninety four.

speaker: doctor
text: How have your symptoms progressed since?

speaker: patient
text: I went to the NeuroOncology clinic on October twenty sixth nineteen ninety five because I was having weakness in both arms and both legs, as well as trouble swallowing food.

speaker: doctor
text: How much weakness was there?

speaker: patient
text: It was so bad I couldn't even put on a shirt, or raise my arms, or even feed myself.

speaker: doctor
text: Can you go up and down stairs?

speaker: patient
text: No, not really, but I can climb them.

speaker: doctor
text: How about going to the bathroom, is everything normal there?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, no problems there.

speaker: doctor
text: Good, and what did the doctor at that clinic recommend?

speaker: patient
text: They were considering doing chemo.

speaker: doctor
text: Any other allergies besides Penicillin?

speaker: patient
text: Um no.

speaker: doctor
text: I see here that you've previously tolerated Cephalosporins without any problems. Do you remember when you were last prescribed a Penicillin like antibiotic?

speaker: doctor
text: Where are you having pain?

speaker: patient
text: My left elbow. I hit it against a railing when I was trying to do a new trick on my skateboard.

speaker: doctor
text: Did the pain come on gradually?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah. I even tried icing it, but I think it's only gotten worse.

speaker: doctor
text: Did you injure any other parts of your body?

speaker: patient
text: Only my elbow.

speaker: doctor
text: How long ago did this happen?

speaker: patient
text: About a week ago.

speaker: doctor
text: I see. Have you taken anything for it, such as Advil or Tylenol?

speaker: patient
text: No. I try to deal with the pain as best as I can before resorting to medicine.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you drink?

speaker: patient
text: No, doc.

speaker: doctor
text: How about smoke?

speaker: patient
text: That I do.

speaker: doctor
text: How long have you been smoking?

speaker: patient
text: I long time.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you tried to quit or reduce how much you smoke?

speaker: patient
text: Truly, I have no interest in doing that with my age.

speaker: doctor
text: I see. I'd recommend you consider nicotine patches because smoking brings with it many health problems.

speaker: patient
text: Tell me something I don't know.

speaker: doctor
text: I understand. How about any other drug use?

speaker: patient
text: I know you're not going to like hearing this, but I'm big on weed. I know, I know, I'm going to regret all of this at some point in time. It's just become a habit that's incredibly hard to break.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay. I'd rather you smoke weed than cigs. How many packs a year do you think you smoke on average?

speaker: patient
text: I go through a pack around every two weeks. Let's go with around twenty seven.

speaker: doctor
text: How about any surgeries?

speaker: patient
text: No, I have not had any surgeries.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you sure?

speaker: patient
text: Yes.

speaker: doctor
text: Welcome to the clinic.

speaker: patient
text: Thank you.

speaker: doctor
text: It looks like you were referred to us by Doctor Jones.

speaker: patient
text: Yes I was.

speaker: doctor
text: Great! The chart notes that Doctor Jones sent over says you are currently twenty weeks pregnant. Is that correct?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I am.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any other children?

speaker: patient
text: Yes. I have a two year old son.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you ever had any pregnancies? Including miscarriages or abortions.

speaker: patient
text: Yes. I had a miscarriage before my son was born.

speaker: doctor
text: I am so sorry to hear that.

speaker: patient
text: Thank you.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you married?

speaker: patient
text: Yes.

speaker: doctor
text: Who do you have in your family?

speaker: patient
text: Me, my spouse and three happy kids. One of them is ready to go to college.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you working?

speaker: patient
text: Yes and no.

speaker: doctor
text: What does that mean?

speaker: patient
text: I was an attorney but retired from my official post two years back. I just couldn't stay back home and do nothing, so I just joined a private company and am working there part time.

speaker: doctor
text: Sounds great. Do you smoke or drink?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: I am guessing no drugs either?

speaker: patient
text: Correct.

speaker: doctor
text: When did you stop smoking?

speaker: patient
text: About thirty years back.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay. How about any alcohol or drugs?

speaker: patient
text: No never.

speaker: doctor
text: Yes, please tell me son.

speaker: patient
text: Okay. Yes, that.

speaker: doctor
text: Thank you for that information. How long ago?

speaker: patient
text: I don't remember maybe more than twenty years.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you ever had surgery, ma'am?

speaker: patient
text: No, not that I can remember, and I have a good memory.

speaker: doctor
text: Not even a C section when you had your son?

speaker: patient
text: No, I had all my children naturally.

speaker: doctor
text: Any sudden weight gain or loss?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Any headaches, nose bleeds, coarse voice, blurry vision or loss or change of vision?

speaker: patient
text: No, not at all.

speaker: doctor
text: No fever or chills, right?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, no fever or anything.

speaker: doctor
text: Any chest pain, shortness of breath or shortness of breath while sleeping?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Any palpitation, swelling or varicose veins or pain in your legs?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Any sore throat or cough or cough with mucous or blood sputum?

speaker: patient
text: I have this prolonged cough, but other than that nothing.

speaker: doctor
text: No wheezing?

speaker: patient
text: No, no wheezing.

speaker: doctor
text: Any heart burn, nausea or vomiting?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Loss of appetite or blood in stool or abdominal pain?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Constipation?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: How is the color of your urine? Is it dark or cloudy?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Any pain while urinating or burning sensation?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Any flank or groin pain?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: So, any joint pain, muscle stiffness or pain? Any backache? Ligament, tendon pain or strain?

speaker: patient
text: Nothing.

speaker: doctor
text: Did you experience any blackouts or seizures lately?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Any hallucinations or memory loss?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Any weakness? Numbness or tingling?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Tremors or loss of sensation like paralysis or-

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Any anxiety, irritability, apathy or depression like feeling?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: How is your sleep?

speaker: patient
text: It is fine.

speaker: doctor
text: And how is your appetite?

speaker: patient
text: It's good.

speaker: doctor
text: How is your mental state? Any suicidal thoughts crossing your mind?

speaker: patient
text: No, nothing like that.

speaker: doctor
text: Sorry, I have to ask these questions.

speaker: patient
text: It's okay.

speaker: doctor
text: Just a few more and we will be done.

speaker: patient
text: Sure.

speaker: doctor
text: Any unusual hair loss or hair or nail breakage?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Did you notice any skin lesion or discoloration?

speaker: patient
text: Nope.

speaker: doctor
text: Alright then.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you or have you used tobacco products,sir?

speaker: patient
text: No. I have never been a smoker.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any history of alcohol or recreational drugs use?

speaker: patient
text: I have never been a drug user, but I used to drink a little, but it was never a problem. I don't drink any more.

speaker: doctor
text: What do you do for a living?

speaker: patient
text: I am retired. I used to be an insurance salesman.

speaker: doctor
text: Any old or new medications I should know about?

speaker: patient
text: Nope.

speaker: doctor
text: Good afternoon, sir. My nurse has it written down here that that you're a thirty three year old black male, is that correct?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, doctor, that's correct.

speaker: doctor
text: Great, what seems to be the problem today, sir?

speaker: patient
text: Well, I think I'm having some sexual dysfunction. I was wondering if Cialis would help.

speaker: doctor
text: What makes you think this, sir?

speaker: patient
text: Well, I did a quiz online on the Cialis website and I didn't score in the normal range, so I figured I would come in.

speaker: doctor
text: Is there anything else of note, sir?

speaker: patient
text: Well, there may be some decreased desire, but honestly, I don't think that's the main problem here. I'd like to have my erections last longer, doctor.

speaker: doctor
text: What was this quiz like?

speaker: patient
text: Well, on the quiz, I said that less than half of the time I'm able to get an erection and keep an erection after penetration.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you having difficulty maintaining an erection until completion?

speaker: patient
text: Well, I'd say there's slight difficulty.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, do you have any significant medical conditions in the past that you have been treated for?

speaker: patient
text: No, not that I know of.

speaker: doctor
text: What about testicular infections?

speaker: patient
text: No, that sounds painful, but no.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you had any traumatic injuries to the groin?

speaker: patient
text: No, not that I can remember.

speaker: doctor
text: What about hernias? You can get them from playing sports or lifting weights. Have you ever had one of these?

speaker: patient
text: No, that doesn't sound familiar either.

speaker: doctor
text: We were not able to find the cause of your pain right now, but in the future, we will do a few more tests and then we can have a diagnosis.

speaker: patient
text: Will you give me some medicine for my stomach pain? And what about that feeling to throw up all of the time?

speaker: doctor
text: Yes, I will write a prescription. It will help you both with your pain and nausea.

speaker: doctor
text: You had a bad acidity problem?

speaker: patient
text: Yes I was vomiting too.

speaker: doctor
text: What came out in the vomit?

speaker: patient
text: It was all brown colored things like coffee.

speaker: doctor
text: But nothing anymore, right?

speaker: patient
text: Yes I am all better.

speaker: doctor
text: Great!

speaker: patient
text: They told me I can go home.

speaker: doctor
text: Yes your blood count looks good, I just want you to continue Nexium forty M G once a day.

speaker: patient
text: I will do that.

speaker: doctor
text: How long have you been feeling weakness and fatigue?

speaker: patient
text: Well, I'd say it's been a lot worse this week. I haven't had much of an appetite either.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you lost weight as a result?

speaker: patient
text: I've lost about eight pounds, which is the most I've ever lost in a week's time.

speaker: doctor
text: Wow, that's concerning. Are you experiencing any nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, or abdominal pain?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: How about chest pain, shortness of breath, cough, or heart racing?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Any neurological symptoms, such as numbness or tingling?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: We'll get to the bottom of this. I'm waiting for your lab report to come back and then we can figure out the next steps.

speaker: doctor
text: I see here that you have no surgical history. Is this correct?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, indeed. At least for now. Who knows what the future will bring.

speaker: doctor
text: So, sir, tell me about your knees, how long have they been bothering you?

speaker: patient
text: Well, I'm sixty nine years old now, so I'm not as young as I used to be. But, these old knees have been bothering me for a couple years now.

speaker: doctor
text: What kind of symptoms do you notice in these knees?

speaker: patient
text: I hear clicking noises, which really bothers me when I'm going up stairs. There's also some stiffness when I try to move them.

speaker: doctor
text: Were you previously a pretty active guy?

speaker: patient
text: I absolutely used to be, and had no problems, but now this pain is affecting my daily life and activities.

speaker: doctor
text: You smoke or drink?

speaker: patient
text: Nope, I never did any such thing.

speaker: doctor
text: Any drugs?

speaker: patient
text: Never.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you still working?

speaker: patient
text: I'm retired. I used to work. I used to work in Morse chain. I also used to deliver newspapers. But now I'm retired, and I enjoy life.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you married?

speaker: patient
text: I was happily married. But then my husband died.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you live alone or with family?

speaker: patient
text: I live alone. I do have family who lives very close by in the neighborhood. I have a niece who lives with her family in my house on Temple Street.

speaker: doctor
text: As far as you know, is there any family history of cancer?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, actually, my mom told me that someone had cervical cancer.

speaker: doctor
text: What about heart disease, does that sound familiar?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I know someone had heart disease, and another person had heart failure.

speaker: doctor
text: Good to know, what about the lungs, any history there?

speaker: patient
text: I know someone had C O P D.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you know of anyone with dementia or Alzheimer's?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, my uncle has dementia right now, actually.

speaker: doctor
text: I'm sorry to hear that, that's a hard disease to see your family go through. What about diabetes, does anyone have that?

speaker: patient
text: Thank you doctor, it's hard. Yes, my dad has the sugar.

speaker: doctor
text: Can you give me a quick run down of her medical history?

speaker: doctor
text: I'm sorry to hear that.

speaker: doctor
text: When was she diagnosed with dementia?

speaker: doctor
text: Any history of heart disease, diabetes, or stroke?

speaker: doctor
text: Hi, there. How are you both doing? What brings you two to the Emergency Department?

speaker: doctor
text: I see. Let me ask your daughter a few questions before we start. Hi, ma'am. I understand you feel sick. Before we begin I just want to confirm some information with you. Where is your primary residency?

speaker: patient
text: My mom can give you the address. I still live with her.

speaker: doctor
text: Thank you. One last question. Do you smoke?

speaker: patient
text: Nope. My Mother has forbidden smoking in her home.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you married, sir?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I'm lucky to have, and live with my lovely wife.

speaker: doctor
text: That's very nice. Did you speak with the nurse before I came in here?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, she was lovely as well, I hope you're paying them well.

speaker: doctor
text: We take good care of them. They'll be happy to hear that. Let me look, she should have left me some notes, um, yep, these look good, I agree with all of this. This looks good.

speaker: patient
text: Thank you, Doctor.

speaker: doctor
text: Hi. How are you doing, sir?

speaker: patient
text: Hi. I am doing fine.

speaker: doctor
text: The nurse told me that you are on disability from work now. What happened?

speaker: patient
text: I got hurt at work and now I am on disability.

speaker: doctor
text: What did you do for work? How long ago was your injury?

speaker: patient
text: I worked on the pipeline. The accident was five years ago.

speaker: doctor
text: Which condition led to the disability?

speaker: patient
text: I don't know really. I sent in all the notes for my doctor for evaluation and they approved the disability.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay. Do you live alone or with family?

speaker: patient
text: I live with my wife.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you a smoke or have you ever been?

speaker: patient
text: I used to smoke. I quit years ago.

speaker: doctor
text: How long ago did you quit?

speaker: patient
text: Oh, about twenty years ago.

speaker: doctor
text: How many years did you smoke? And how much did you smoke?

speaker: patient
text: Probably twenty years. I was up to two packs a day. I feel way better now.

speaker: doctor
text: That's great. Any use of alcohol or illicit drugs?

speaker: patient
text: Nope.

speaker: doctor
text: What do you do for fun? Do you have any hobbies?

speaker: patient
text: I don't really do much these days. Work was my hobby.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: How're you doing today?

speaker: patient
text: Overall, pretty good.

speaker: doctor
text: Any plans for the weekend?

speaker: patient
text: No, not really. Just dog sitting my friend's golden.

speaker: doctor
text: Gotcha. That's still nice. We used to have a golden when I was a kid. They're the sweetest dogs.

speaker: patient
text: They are very sweet.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, so you're in for a follow up for your neck and back pain.

speaker: patient
text: Yessir.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you been going to pain management?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I go once every week or so.

speaker: doctor
text: How's your pain now?

speaker: patient
text: Manageable, I guess.

speaker: doctor
text: Is the pain still keeping you up at night?

speaker: patient
text: Not like it used to.

speaker: doctor
text: Good, great to hear.

speaker: doctor
text: Let's see. Are you taking any medications?

speaker: patient
text: No, none right now.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you smoke cigarettes?

speaker: patient
text: Yes. I smoke.

speaker: doctor
text: How much do you smoke per day?

speaker: patient
text: About a pack or two a day.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you drink alcohol?

speaker: patient
text: No. It is very rare that I will have a drink.

speaker: doctor
text: What is your family medical history?

speaker: patient
text: Well, I don't know very much about my dad's side of the family but my dad did pass away from renal cancer.

speaker: doctor
text: I am so sorry for your loss.

speaker: patient
text: Thank you.

speaker: doctor
text: What about your mother or siblings? Do they have any health conditions?

speaker: patient
text: No. They don't have any health problems. That I know of.

speaker: doctor
text: So, ma'am, what do you do for a living?

speaker: patient
text: Actually, I'm retired, I don't work at all anymore.

speaker: doctor
text: Congratulations on your retirement. Where did you go to college?

speaker: patient
text: Oh, I didn't go to college, I stopped after high school.

speaker: doctor
text: That's understandable. Do you have children?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, my husband and I were blessed with three wonderful children.

speaker: doctor
text: Fantastic, do they live at home?

speaker: patient
text: Nope, we got them all out of there. They're all grown now.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you drink or smoke?

speaker: patient
text: No, I never had either.

speaker: doctor
text: What about harder substances?

speaker: patient
text: No, absolutely not.

speaker: doctor
text: You are five feet four inches.

speaker: patient
text: Yes.

speaker: doctor
text: Weight one ninety seven.

speaker: patient
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: Your blood pressure is one twenty five over seventy five.

speaker: patient
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you smoke or drink?

speaker: patient
text: Never smoked a cigarette a day in my life. As for alcohol, I'll drink socially with friends and family.

speaker: doctor
text: How's he feeling today?

speaker: doctor
text: I'm sorry to hear that he hasn't been feeling well. What symptoms has he been having?

speaker: doctor
text: I see. What was his temperature?

speaker: doctor
text: Let me evaluate and see what we can do for him today.

speaker: doctor
text: I suspect that he has an upper respiratory infection, possible pertussis. Is he still experiencing apnea?

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, let me quickly examine him. Mom do you give the permission? I will quickly check his genitalia. Can you pull his pants down?

speaker: doctor
text: Well, everything looks fine, his penis and testes are normal shape and size for his age. No fluid accumulation or swelling in the scrotum area, no evidence of herniation there.

speaker: doctor
text: We can release you from the hospital today if we have a safe place for you to go. Is there a parent or guardian we can release you to?

speaker: patient
text: I am in foster care. My foster mom is going out of town on the nineteenth to the twenty third.

speaker: doctor
text: In that case, we will have to keep you in the hospital until your foster mom returns from her trip.

speaker: patient
text: Can my mom and grandmother come and visit me here on Thursday? That is the day they usually come to visit me at my foster home.

speaker: doctor
text: Yes. I think we can make some arrangements to make that happen.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you know about any medical issues running in your family?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, almost everyone had diabetes.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any past or present medical conditions?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any family history of lung disease, thromboembolism, pulmonary embolism, stroke, or heart disease.

speaker: patient
text: No.  My parents are healthy with no medical issues.

speaker: doctor
text: How many children do you have?

speaker: patient
text: I have five kids.

speaker: doctor
text: Do your children have any health condition?

speaker: patient
text: My children are all healthy with no medical problems.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you smoke or drink alcohol?

speaker: patient
text: Nope.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you know of any medical problems that run in your family?

speaker: patient
text: I have no idea to be quite honest with you. My parents never shared their medical history with me and neither did their parents with them. I don't think they want any of us to worry.

speaker: doctor
text: Oh wow, I understand. It can be hard for many people to share intimate details about their health to others, even when it comes to disclosing medical info to their own children. For now, I'll put unknown but please let me know if anything changes.

speaker: patient
text: Will do. Thanks for understanding.

speaker: doctor
text: Of course. It's not totally uncommon for people to not know their family history.

speaker: doctor
text: Hello again, how are you doing, miss?

speaker: patient
text: I'm good. Thank you. How about you?

speaker: doctor
text: All good here too. I know you are an established patient of dermatology here and was last seen in our office on July thirteenth, two thousand and four.  I will be asking you a few questions just to check whether the entry in our record is updated or not.

speaker: doctor
text: How old are you now?

speaker: patient
text: Twenty nine.

speaker: doctor
text: Where are you from originally?

speaker: patient
text: I'm from Vietnam.

speaker: doctor
text: I am seeing you today as a referral from A B C for reevaluation.

speaker: patient
text: Yes, for my hand eczema.

speaker: doctor
text: So, let's see what you have been treated with. Your record here says with Aristocort cream, Cetaphil cream, increased moisturizing cream and lotion. Does this sound right to you?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, that's correct.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you washing your hands in Cetaphil cleansing lotion?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I'm doing all that.

speaker: doctor
text: What brings you here today?

speaker: patient
text: I'm having this flaring. My hands are all dry. I have these like cracks in my hands. I have been washing with the soap and the lotions that you prescribed, but still, it is happening. Maybe because of cracks or what, I don't know, but the Cetaphil cleansing lotion, whenever I'm applying that it is causing me a lot of burning pain. I have been wearing gloves though.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you married?

speaker: patient
text: Still, a single. I'm not even looking for a husband yet.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you working somewhere?

speaker: patient
text: Not currently.

speaker: doctor
text: You have been diagnosed with allergic rhinitis, right? For how many years?

speaker: patient
text: Um, I would say around four years now. Oh my God it has been so, so many medications that I had to take for this.

speaker: doctor
text: Yeah, it's hard to control. Are you diabetic?

speaker: patient
text: No, I don't have any such conditions.

speaker: doctor
text: So no hypertension or any kidney diseases?

speaker: patient
text: Nope.

speaker: doctor
text: Every been diagnosed with tuberculosis, asthma, or lung disease?

speaker: patient
text: No I have not.

speaker: doctor
text: Hm how would you describe her diet?

speaker: doctor
text: Does she eat solid food?

speaker: doctor
text: I see.

speaker: doctor
text: Hello there, I am Doctor Nathan.

speaker: patient
text: Hello.

speaker: doctor
text: How old are you?

speaker: patient
text: I am forty eight?

speaker: doctor
text: Do you get regular periods?

speaker: patient
text: No, I didn't get any periods for the last year after my surgery.

speaker: doctor
text: Any hot flashes?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, it's been happening for the last several months. Sometimes I feel hot even in a fully air conditioned room. Other times I just feel like opening the refrigerator and standing in front of it.

speaker: doctor
text: Any other symptoms?

speaker: patient
text: I am also experiencing a lot of mood swings for the last few weeks.

speaker: doctor
text: Based on all the symptoms my assessment would be mood swings along with postsurgical menopause. That would be the cause for your hot flashes.

speaker: doctor
text: Any change in appetite?

speaker: patient
text: Um, no.

speaker: doctor
text: Any stomach pain or change in bowel movement?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Any history of bowel issues?

speaker: patient
text: No, not really.

speaker: doctor
text: Any hernia problem?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Any history of stomach ulcer?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Did you notice any rectal bleeding?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Any liver issues or jaundice?

speaker: patient
text: Um, no.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you drink alcohol?

speaker: patient
text: Nope! I use to occasionally, very long time ago. But not anymore.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay and how bout cigarettes? Do you smoke or vape?

speaker: patient
text: No, none of those.

speaker: doctor
text: And no drugs and stuff, right? No snorting, I V or anything right?

speaker: patient
text: Right, I don't do drugs either, never did. Even though pot is legal here, I never ever felt like trying.

speaker: doctor
text: That's a good thing.

speaker: patient
text: Yeah.

speaker: doctor
text: Let me check your neck, it looks nice and symmetrical. Your thyroid looks normal it is not enlarged.

speaker: doctor
text: Does it hurt you when I press on your neck?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Neck is nontender.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, I don't see any bulging of external jugular vein.

speaker: patient
text: These medical terms I don't understand.

speaker: doctor
text: Oh, I am talking about the vein in your neck, it shows no bulging. No abnormal masses present. Can you turn your head from left to right and right to left, any pain in your neck or difficulty turning?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Can you rotate your head clockwise and anti clockwise.

speaker: patient
text: Sure.

speaker: doctor
text: Any pain?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, let me just make a note here full range of motion with no pain.

speaker: doctor
text: Hello, miss. It looks like you are here for your yearly physical. How is everything going?

speaker: patient
text: Great, I think. I just got a mammogram and nothing showed up. I still am taking my multivitamin and low dose aspirin.

speaker: doctor
text: Great to hear. Has there been any changes in drinking and smoking?

speaker: patient
text: No changes. Check the chart, I answered that last time.

speaker: doctor
text: Great. Looks like drinking and smoking is off the menu. In regard to the mammogram, do you make sure to do self breast examinations? I believe I showed you how to do this last time.

speaker: patient
text: No, I do not. I don't see a point if I come and do the mammogram.

speaker: doctor
text: I highly suggest you start doing so. Sometimes people do not get mammograms for a few years and it is important to make sure nothing is growing.

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I know. I am just lazy. Recently it has been hard to do a lot of my selfcare routines. I do not even exercise anymore.

speaker: doctor
text: Hello. How are you doing today?

speaker: patient
text: I want to get surgery on my leg.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you ever had a surgery.

speaker: patient
text: I did. Here's a list of them.

speaker: doctor
text: Looks like you had eye surgery, cataract surgery, and lumbar decompression, correct?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah. So, what options do I have for surgery?

speaker: doctor
text: I need to see what the problem is first.

speaker: doctor
text: Hi you guys, how are you?

speaker: patient
text: I am good, he is my stepdad.

speaker: doctor
text: I am fine, thank you. So, she gets seizures?

speaker: doctor
text: And when did it start?

speaker: patient
text: Dad I was fourteen, when it started.

speaker: doctor
text: Fourteen, okay. Are you taking anything for it?

speaker: doctor
text: Anybody else in the family have a similar problem?

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, any other siblings or family members with medical conditions?

speaker: doctor
text: Okay. Sorry but I must ask this, any recent death in the family in past one year child or adult?

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any known allergies to medications?

speaker: patient
text: None whatsoever.

speaker: doctor
text: Did you have your vaccines?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah.

speaker: doctor
text: Did you skip any?

speaker: patient
text: No, I had all of them and am up to date with my immunizations.

speaker: doctor
text: Hi, how can I help you, ma'am?

speaker: patient
text: I have no complaints.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay but tell me what is going on and we can figure this out.

speaker: patient
text: Okay so my right hand and left foot was very swollen and very painful, and that's why I came to emergency room.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have urine bag?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I could not go so they put it in.

speaker: doctor
text: Yes, it looks like five hundred M L came out. So possible urinary obstruction. Also, they started you on steroids and colchicine. How are you feeling now?

speaker: patient
text: I am feeling a little better, my pain is improving, and the swelling is getting better.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay that is good. Any fever and chills?

speaker: patient
text: No, no fever.

speaker: doctor
text: Any problem with urination like pain or frequency or blood in urine?

speaker: patient
text: No but I am not able to empty my bladder well, the pee has decreased a lot, I could not urinate.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay I will evaluate that. How about any cough, blood in sputum?

speaker: patient
text: No nothing like that.

speaker: doctor
text: Any chest pain, or difficulty breathing?

speaker: patient
text: No pain, I can breathe well.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay that sounds good.

speaker: doctor
text: Does low blood pressure run in your family?

speaker: patient
text: No. As far as I know, no one else has it.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: Were you ever diagnosed with any kind of cancer in the past?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Did you ever had any rashes? Was there any change in your moles?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Any sudden weight loss history?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: How about your energy level how do you feel?

speaker: patient
text: I feel great, my energy level is quite good.

speaker: doctor
text: What medications are you currently taking?

speaker: patient
text: I am a diabetic, so I take Insulin.

speaker: doctor
text: How much Insulin do you take?

speaker: patient
text: It varies from day to day.

speaker: doctor
text: Anything else that is going on?

speaker: patient
text: Just some pain in the buttock.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

speaker: patient
text: I do not have anything else.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay no fever, nausea, anything of that sort?

speaker: patient
text: Nope.

speaker: doctor
text: You recently turned sixty seven, correct?

speaker: patient
text: Yes. Sixty seven years young.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you right or left handed?

speaker: patient
text: Right.

speaker: doctor
text: When were you first diagnosed with Parkinson's?

speaker: patient
text: September first of nineteen ninety five.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you remember who diagnosed you?

speaker: patient
text: A local doctor I was seeing at the time. A year before my diagnosis, I had a few falls and episodes of lightheadedness. I also noticed that I was staggering a lot more when walking.

speaker: doctor
text: Did you lose consciousness during any of your falls?

speaker: patient
text: Not that I know of. I had noticed that I was losing my normal voice to a degree. On top of losing my normal voice, my handwriting became smaller and smaller. I don't ever remember writing so small. Something seemed really off to me.

speaker: doctor
text: I'm sure that was difficult to experience.

speaker: patient
text: It was very difficult. Two months prior to being diagnosed, I started to move much slower than before.

speaker: doctor
text: By slower, do you mean the movements of your arms and legs were slower and impaired?

speaker: patient
text: Yes. I was prescribed Sinemet back in September of nineteen ninety five.

speaker: doctor
text: Did you notice any improvement while taking it?

speaker: patient
text: None. I was pretty disappointed and discouraged as a result. I have problems with coordination and walking without staggering even today.

speaker: doctor
text: Noting that it's February thirteenth nineteen ninety six.

speaker: patient
text: I felt weak in the morning and worse as the day went on.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you experiencing any other symptoms, such as stroke like events, vision changes, seizures, or problems with moving and coordinating your arms?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Any headache, nausea, vomiting, chills, or fever?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Hi there! How are the both of you doing today?

speaker: doctor
text: What are his symptoms?

speaker: doctor
text: During his coughing episode this morning, did you notice any loss of breath or gasping for air?

speaker: doctor
text: Has he had a runny nose?

speaker: doctor
text: Any fever?

speaker: doctor
text: Is anyone else in the household sick?

speaker: doctor
text: Is anyone in the household a smoker?

speaker: doctor
text: Any medical diseases in the family?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, mainly heart issues. My father died from heart attack.

speaker: doctor
text: What about your mother?

speaker: patient
text: She had the second type of diabetes.

speaker: doctor
text: So just to double check. No past medical history?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, sir. None.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you drink or smoke, ma'am?

speaker: patient
text: No, I don't do any of that.

speaker: doctor
text: Good, what about harder drugs?

speaker: patient
text: No, none of that either.

speaker: doctor
text: Very good. Do you have any history of S T D that you know about?

speaker: patient
text: No, there's no history of any of that there.

speaker: doctor
text: What medications are you taking?

speaker: patient
text: I take Prilosec and Tramadol when I have back pain.

speaker: doctor
text: Any drug allergies?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: How often are you vomiting?

speaker: patient
text: At least three times until my stomach is empty.

speaker: doctor
text: Can you think of something this is related to?

speaker: patient
text: Just when I eat raw carrots and celery.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you get belly pain?

speaker: patient
text: Yes.

speaker: doctor
text: Good morning, ma'am. Can you confirm your age for me?

speaker: patient
text: Well, doctor, I'm sixty six years old now.

speaker: doctor
text: Thank you, so, how is your knee doing today? Hope the osteoarthritis is getting better.

speaker: patient
text: It's so bad, doctor.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you had any improvement with the rest and antiinflammatories we've talked about before?

speaker: patient
text: No, they haven't helped at all.

speaker: doctor
text: I see, you'd be a good candidate for a knee replacement.

speaker: patient
text: What's the risk of infection from the surgery?

speaker: doctor
text: Historically, it's less than one percent, we use prophylactic antibiotics to control for infection the entire time.

speaker: patient
text: Great, and will I be asleep for this?

speaker: doctor
text: Yes, you won't feel a thing.

speaker: doctor
text: How old are you?

speaker: patient
text: I am twenty four.

speaker: doctor
text: What brings you in today?

speaker: patient
text: I have been having this back pain for a long time. I thought I should come and get it checked out because it has not gotten any better.

speaker: doctor
text: Any medical issues running in your family?

speaker: patient
text: I don't know anything about that.

speaker: doctor
text: You know anyone in your family or relatives who ever had diseases like diabetes or any heart issues?

speaker: patient
text: Nope.

speaker: doctor
text: Hello, miss. Could you verify your age, please?

speaker: patient
text: I'm fifty five years old.

speaker: doctor
text: Great. What is the reason for your visit today?

speaker: patient
text: I've been having a lot of problems recently, so I decided to come get it checked out by you.

speaker: doctor
text: I see. What kind of problems are you experiencing?

speaker: patient
text: Oh, it's a long list. Here it is.

speaker: doctor
text: Thank you. Let me take a look. Looks like you have some general allergies and food allergies, loss of taste, problems with your G I tract, asthma, G E R D, and dry mouth or xerostomia.

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, that sounds about right. I think I forgot to add it, but I also have bad allergies during the spring time.

speaker: doctor
text: Oh, I see. I would describe that as environmental inhalant allergies.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you a smoker?

speaker: patient
text: Yes.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you use alcohol or any recreational drugs?

speaker: patient
text: I have been in treatment for heroin and alcohol in the past.

speaker: doctor
text: Any current use of drugs or alcohol?

speaker: patient
text: I did do a little bit of coke today.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you take any-

speaker: patient
text: Meds?

speaker: doctor
text: Yes.

speaker: patient
text: I do. I take Allegra for seasonal allergies. I also take something that starts with a P. I'm blanking on the name. My other doctor prescribed it to me for exercise induced asthma.

speaker: doctor
text: Oh, do you mean Proventil?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, that's it! I keep that on hand in case my asthma gets outta control.

speaker: doctor
text: Is it up to date?

speaker: patient
text: You mean is it expired? No, I don't think so. It hasn't been long since I visited the pharmacy.

speaker: doctor
text: Good. I always like to advise my patients to check expiration dates.

speaker: doctor
text: Welcome into the office.

speaker: patient
text: Thank you.

speaker: doctor
text: Let us start with your family medical history.

speaker: patient
text: That is going to be a hard one. I was adopted and I do not know any family medical history.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay. That is alright.

speaker: doctor
text: So, you are here to review your sleep study results, right?

speaker: patient
text: That's right.

speaker: doctor
text: First let's go back to your medical history a little bit and then we will continue with the result. Patient: Sure.

speaker: doctor
text: So, you first came to our Pulmonary Clinic, and you were suffering with dyspnea even on minimal exertion. At that time, we evaluated you and we realized that there was some evidence of irregular sleep and daytime fatigue. At that time you also complained of nighttime choking episodes which got less intense over the past many months.

speaker: patient
text: That's right. I was then scheduled for the overnight sleep study to be evaluated for interruptions in my sleep and here we are today to discuss results.

speaker: doctor
text: Sure. But first tell me, how is your sleeping routine like?

speaker: patient
text: It is consistent. I go to bed anytime between nine to ten at night and wake up in the morning around five to six.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you able to sleep as soon as you go to bed?

speaker: patient
text: No, it's hard for me to start that sleeping process and then I'm awake in like every one or two hours throughout the night. I keep on tossing and turning throughout the night. I always find my sheets out of order when I wake up.

speaker: doctor
text: How would you compare your sleep here in the lab and at your home?

speaker: patient
text: I would say I slept better in the laboratory than I do at home.

speaker: doctor
text: How do you feel when you wake up in the morning?

speaker: patient
text: Honestly, I feel tired. Sometimes I also have this dull headache.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you snore?

speaker: patient
text: I don't know for myself, but yeah, my daughter was teasing me another day that I was snoring and was talking in my sleep.

speaker: doctor
text: Did you ever feel that you have difficulty breathing while you are asleep?

speaker: patient
text: No. But I used to cough a lot in the middle of the night.

speaker: doctor
text: You said you used to, so it is not anymore?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I haven't been coughing for the last few weeks.

speaker: doctor
text: How's your daily routine? Do you nap in the daytime?

speaker: patient
text: I spent a lot of time reading and watching T V. Sometimes I doze off while doing that. Not regular, but I do take nap sometimes in between two to three in afternoon and also in the evening hours.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you smoke?

speaker: patient
text: Oh yes, I take around one to two packs of cigarettes each day mainly after dinner.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you noticed any change in your weight?

speaker: patient
text: My weight always keeps fluctuating. I remember I was at my maximum weight of two hundred and sixty pounds around one year ago.

speaker: doctor
text: If that was your maximum how is your weight now?

speaker: patient
text: Now it is down by approximately thirty pounds.

speaker: doctor
text: So, for your health care, you are coming here in the outpatient psychiatry and also going to your maintenance clinic, right?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, that's right.

speaker: doctor
text: Your current medications include Methadone, Trazodone, and Seroquel.

speaker: patient
text: That sounds right.

speaker: doctor
text: So, I see you were diagnosed with an acid reflux problem and high blood pressure twenty years back?

speaker: patient
text: Yes.

speaker: doctor
text: And then you also have arthritis and Parkinson's.

speaker: patient
text: Yes, both.

speaker: doctor
text: Also, you had a brain stroke?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, mini stroke!

speaker: doctor
text: Ah, yes. We also call it as T I A.

speaker: patient
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: And currently are you on any medications?

speaker: patient
text: Just Coumadin, for my chronic A Fib. I have been on it three years.

speaker: doctor
text: Yeah, atrial fibrillation.

speaker: patient
text: Yes.

speaker: doctor
text: Good morning, ma'am.

speaker: patient
text: Good morning, doctor.

speaker: doctor
text: How are you feeling today?

speaker: patient
text: Honestly, I'm feeling a little bit better.

speaker: doctor
text: That's good to hear, ma'am.

speaker: doctor
text: According to the patient, his symptoms started getting progressively worse over the past two days.

speaker: doctor
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Welcome to the clinic.

speaker: patient
text: Thank you.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you from the area?

speaker: patient
text: No. I was born and raised in North Carolina. I am the sixth of nine siblings.

speaker: doctor
text: Tell me about you family medical history.

speaker: patient
text: My family has significant amount of diabetes, heart disease, high blood pressure, thyroid problems, autoimmune disease, possible multiple sclerosis, and depression issues.

speaker: doctor
text: That is a lot. What is your medical history involving your parents?

speaker: patient
text: My dad died due to complications of his diabetes.  He passed when he was sixty. My dad was a chef. My mom is doing well. She is ninety three. Both my parents never finished high school. My dad had a third grade education and my mom made it through fourth grade. She was a janitor. She was a smart woman she just never finished her schooling. My parents encouraged me to finish school and to go to college. I got my Bachelor of Science in Nursing at the State University in nineteen seventy nine.

speaker: doctor
text: Did you have any problems in school such as learning disabilities, attentional problems, difficulty learning to read, failed grades, special help in school or behavioral problems?

speaker: patient
text: No. I mostly got A's and B's.  My strongest subject was math, but my worst subject was spelling. My grades were still quite good in spelling, but I had to work hard at it.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you married?

speaker: patient
text: I was married for two years. We had two children together. They are forty three and thirty now. My son is the youngest, lives nearby and calls me or stops by every day. My daughter calls me often but she lives in New York. We are close. Their dad, my exhusband passed away in nineteen eighty. He was an alcoholic. His pancreas had enough and shut down.

speaker: doctor
text: I am so sorry.

speaker: patient
text: He did it to himself.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you working in health care with your nursing degree?

speaker: patient
text: I worked for Hospital Center for four years. Prior to that, I worked for an outpatient mental health center. I was there for about two and a years. I was fired or laid off I guess? I was not sure why they let me go. I was given no explanation. And before that, I worked for Walter P. Carter Center for twenty one years. I also worked as an O B nurse.  Other than the two instances, I had never been fired or let go from a job.

speaker: doctor
text: What do you do in your spare time now?

speaker: patient
text: I enjoy reading, doing puzzles, playing computer games. I joined a women's support group for women my age. I keep myself, busy.

speaker: doctor
text: Good afternoon, young man.

speaker: patient
text: Good afternoon, doctor.

speaker: doctor
text: How old are you, sir?

speaker: patient
text: I'm thirteen.

speaker: doctor
text: So, what brings you in today?

speaker: doctor
text: Yes, I see that from the report.

speaker: doctor
text: Yes, we should do surgery on this knee. There's gross instability of the fragment, and we don't want that get worse.

speaker: doctor
text: It's less than one percent. We use antibiotics to control for infection. Other risks include bleeding, changes in sensation of the limb, changes in motion, failure to relieve pain or restore the articular cartilage, the possible need for another procedure, and possible early arthritis. I would not worry, though. These things are rare.

speaker: doctor
text: Yes, he won't feel a thing.

speaker: doctor
text: Good afternoon, young lady.

speaker: patient
text: Good afternoon, doctor.

speaker: doctor
text: Let's get the personal questions out of the way to begin, shall we?

speaker: patient
text: Sure.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you had any S T D s recently?

speaker: patient
text: No, not that I know of.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you sexually active?

speaker: patient
text: No, I'm not.

speaker: doctor
text: I'm looking here, and your last P P D was negative, but we'll do another one today.

speaker: patient
text: Okay, that's fine, doctor.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you been compliant with all of the medicine you've been prescribed?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I've taken everything exactly as you told me to.

speaker: doctor
text: Good, do you remember when your last dentist appointment was?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, it was in November of two thousand seven.

speaker: doctor
text: What did they do for you at your last visit?

speaker: patient
text: They pulled two teeth for me.

speaker: doctor
text: Good, and when was your last pap smear?

speaker: patient
text: It was about a year ago.

speaker: doctor
text: I assume it was negative?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, thankfully.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you had a mammogram yet?

speaker: patient
text: No, not yet. I'm not old enough.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have a family history of breast cancer?

speaker: patient
text: No, I don't, at least not that I know of.

speaker: doctor
text: Hi, I would like to physically examine your rectal area, ok?

speaker: patient
text: No, I am not comfortable with that. I don't want you to do that.

speaker: doctor
text: Hello, what brings you here today?

speaker: patient
text: I fell four times on third of this month because my leg suddenly gave out.

speaker: doctor
text: How old are you?

speaker: patient
text: You don't ask age of a lady. She will never tell you the truth.

speaker: doctor
text: I know I'm in the wrong profession. I have to do that every time I meet someone. So how old are you?

speaker: patient
text: That's true. I'm just teasing you. I'm fifty one.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you right handed or left handed?

speaker: patient
text: I am right handed.

speaker: doctor
text: So, you said that your legs suddenly gave out. What happened exactly? Was it sudden? Or were you noticing some weakness before as well?

speaker: patient
text: Oh, I noticed weakness in my right leg before as well and sometimes, like, I have to give the support of my arm to actually move it. Sometimes during these episodes I just turn pale and it's like overall weakness. I feel so tired. My husband, he gives me some sugar, three teaspoons, and then it helps a little bit but not completely.

speaker: doctor
text: So, is your weakness like overall in your legs or it is at any single point?

speaker: patient
text: It's overall. I remember in one of these episodes I was, like, in an odd fisted posture.

speaker: doctor
text: Is there any change in your sensations? Like if I touch you, is it like same before or was there any change?

speaker: patient
text: No, nothing like that.

speaker: doctor
text: Is there change in vision? Are you seeing double?

speaker: patient
text: Nope.

speaker: doctor
text: Any difficulty in swallowing or eating? Any loss of consciousness?

speaker: patient
text: Nope.

speaker: doctor
text: Any difficulty in speech? Slurring, or anything like that?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: You said that these episodes have been happening for some time, so did you see anyone for those before?

speaker: patient
text: Nope. It's just that I fall and then fell again last night. I was feeling so weak. Nothing was helping me. That's when, in the morning, my husband brought me to the U I H C hospital for the evaluation on the fifth.

speaker: doctor
text: Any medical traits in the family?

speaker: patient
text: Oh yeah. Diabetes and high blood pressure runs in my family.

speaker: doctor
text: Anything else?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, my mom suffered with a stroke when she was in her seventies.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you married, ma'am?

speaker: patient
text: No, I'm divorced.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you live alone?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, so I have no support at home, it's difficult.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you drink or smoke?

speaker: patient
text: No, I never have.

speaker: doctor
text: What about more illicit substances?

speaker: patient
text: No, absolutely not.

speaker: doctor
text: What is your family medical history, sir?

speaker: patient
text: We have some heart issues in my family. My sister died during heart surgery two years ago.

speaker: doctor
text: I am so sorry.

speaker: patient
text: Thank you. My mom died of a heart attack.

speaker: doctor
text: How old was she when she passed?

speaker: patient
text: She was in her seventies? My dad died from a brain hemorrhage. He was only forty nine.

speaker: doctor
text: Your family had been through a lot of loss.

speaker: patient
text: Yes, we have.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any siblings that are still living?

speaker: patient
text: I have another sister. Oh yeah. She is a diabetic.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have kids?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I have daughter. The only health problem she has is high cholesterol.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you know of anyone else in the family with neurological disorders?

speaker: patient
text: No. I don't think so.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any known allergies?

speaker: patient
text: Not that I know.

speaker: doctor
text: Any allergies to any drug?

speaker: patient
text: Nope.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you married?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I am.

speaker: doctor
text: Is the baby your first kid?

speaker: patient
text: You see, I am a missionary. I have four kids. My eldest is seven years old. Then the other ones are five and three and this one is the youngest. She is just six weeks old.

speaker: doctor
text: Welcome to A B C D General Hospital. Before we get started, ma'am, how old are you?

speaker: patient
text: I'm thirty nine, doctor.

speaker: doctor
text: Great, and what seems to be the problem today?

speaker: patient
text: I've had this bunion for a good few months now.

speaker: doctor
text: Is the pain getting worse?

speaker: patient
text: Absolutely, I can't take it anymore.

speaker: doctor
text: How have you managed this bunion so far?

speaker: patient
text: I got some wider shoes, and it's done absolutely nothing.

speaker: doctor
text: I see.

speaker: patient
text: Is there surgery or something we can do? I can't take the pain.

speaker: doctor
text: How old are you?

speaker: patient
text: I'm twenty eight.

speaker: doctor
text: So, you are here for the dietary consultation. Is this your first pregnancy?

speaker: patient
text: No, this is my second pregnancy. I had gestational diabetes with my first one as well.

speaker: doctor
text: Were you taking any insulin at that time?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I used insulin last time as well. I'm just here to understand if diet can help me with my gestational diabetes.

speaker: doctor
text: Sure.

speaker: patient
text: My Gynecologist was saying something about ketones, I don't know what they are. She asked me to talk about them with you.

speaker: doctor
text: Sure, I will explain everything to you. We also have a pamphlet to explain it. Here have a look. You can take it with you.

speaker: patient
text: Thank you.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you exercising?

speaker: patient
text: I walk everyday with my daughter. I go to drop her to school and then back home.

speaker: doctor
text: How long is the walk to school?

speaker: patient
text: It takes around twenty minutes on one side. So, everyday it is like forty minutes in the morning and same in the evening around four.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you drink milk?

speaker: patient
text: I try to, I know it is a good source of calcium and is very essential especially with my pregnancy, but I am not a big fan of drinking milk.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you know of any family history of kyphosis?

speaker: patient
text: I'm sorry, what's that?

speaker: doctor
text: It has to do with rounding of the spine. Does anyone in your family have a rounded posture?

speaker: patient
text: Actually, yeah, my great grandmother had that, and my mom would talk about my second cousin, he had it too.

speaker: doctor
text: When did you retire from your job?

speaker: patient
text: About eleven years ago. It's definitely been nice. I'm able to spend more time with my grandkids.

speaker: doctor
text: Aw, how many grandkids do you have? And do you live alone?

speaker: patient
text: I have four grandkids between the ages of two and eleven. I live in the county with my wife and dog. My wife and I've been together for thirty some years now.

speaker: doctor
text: That's so wonderful to hear.

speaker: doctor
text: Good afternoon, young lady.

speaker: patient
text: Good afternoon, doctor.

text: How has your weight been since your last visit, with the phentermine?

speaker: patient
text: Well, since the last visit I've gained about a pound.

speaker: doctor
text: Well, it could be worse, but we're at a plateau, I'd like to see you lose some more per month.

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I've been working really hard, but I haven't been able to get the weight down any further so far.

speaker: doctor
text: What has been your lowest weight?

speaker: patient
text: My lowest? That was one hundred thirty six. I'm just as frustrated as you are, doctor.

speaker: doctor
text: Well, if this plateau continues, we should discontinue the phentermine.

speaker: patient
text: Why is that?

speaker: doctor
text: It shouldn't be used to maintain your weight, but only to get the weight down. So, if it's not serving that purpose, we shouldn't use it. There's no real benefit there.

speaker: patient
text: Okay, yes, I agree.

speaker: doctor
text: Anyone in the family had a stroke?

speaker: patient
text: No, no one had a stroke in my family.

speaker: doctor
text: How about someone in the family with heart disease?

speaker: patient
text: No one that I can remember.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

speaker: patient
text: You know doctor, I was born in Munich, Germany.

speaker: doctor
text: Wow, I cannot tell, you speak English so well, no German accent.

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I always knew how to speak English even before I was a teen. So, when I moved to America I did not have any language problem.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay and did you move with your family?

speaker: patient
text: No, my family moved to the eastern side of the Germany which was occupied by Russia at that time, but I decided to move to America in nineteen fifty seven.

speaker: patient
text: I had a high school degree from Germany, and I could speak German and English fluently.

speaker: patient
text: As soon as I landed here in America, I started working. I started as a secretary at a private firm and later did clerical work at I B M. Now I am retired for almost twenty years due to my cancer complications.

speaker: doctor
text: Your Mesothelioma?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, and who all are there in your family?

speaker: patient
text: Well currently I am alone without any companion. I am divorced. I have a son who lives in Santa Cruz he has grand children, but I have not seen them, I am trying to get in touch with them. I want to see my grandkids.

speaker: patient
text: Other than him I have a brother and a sister both are healthy and living their life we don't talk much.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: And do you drink or smoke?

speaker: patient
text: Hm, nothing significant.

speaker: doctor
text: Any funny drugs like heroine or coke?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: What brings you in today? Can you also please state your age?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah. I am forty five. I've had really bad stomach pain on my right side since last week.

speaker: doctor
text: On a scale of one to ten, how bad is the pain at its worst?

speaker: patient
text: I'd have to say a seven.

speaker: doctor
text: How would you rate it now?

speaker: patient
text: Oh um it's at a five at the moment.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you been taking your diabetes medication?

speaker: patient
text: Micronase?

speaker: doctor
text: Yes.

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I've been taking it every day.

speaker: doctor
text: Great. Okay, let's try to get to the bottom of this stomach pain.

speaker: doctor
text: Your cholesterol appears to be elevated today. Is this the first time you've been told that your cholesterol levels are high?

speaker: patient
text: No, unfortunately. I suffer from a few medical problems so maybe that's to blame.

speaker: doctor
text: I see here that you have diabetes and high blood pressure.

speaker: patient
text: Right.

speaker: doctor
text: Does diabetes or high blood pressure run-

speaker: patient
text: In the family? No, but heart disease does.

speaker: doctor
text: How was the sleep study?

speaker: patient
text: Not bad. Although I hafta admit it was difficult staying up in preparation for it.

speaker: doctor
text: I can imagine. That's always tough. It looks like the eval of your daytime fatigue and insomnia was sent over. Let me print out a copy and we can go over it together. How old are you again?

speaker: patient
text: I am forty eight.

speaker: doctor
text: So what brings you in today?

speaker: patient
text: Ugh.
