text: I'm guessing you're not feeling too great.

speaker: patient
text: You got that right. I've had a fever on and off for the past few days.

speaker: doctor
text: When was the last time you took your temperature?

speaker: patient
text: Right before I drove here.

speaker: doctor
text: I see. Did the nurse take your temperature when you came in?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, she did.

text: Have you been experiencing cold like symptoms, such as cough, nasal congestion, headache, or nausea?

speaker: patient
text: Um no not really.

text: Have you tried taking any medicine to help with the fever?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah. I've taken Tylenol and that's helped a bit.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you had recent sick contacts?

speaker: patient
text: I don't think so. I live with three other roommates and they seem fine.

speaker: doctor
text: Anything that has been going on?

speaker: patient
text: No. What do you mean?

speaker: doctor
text: I mean anything wrong from head to toe that you would like to add?

speaker: patient
text: No everything is well. No other problems.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay. Good.

speaker: doctor
text: How was the procedure?

speaker: patient
text: It was okay. I was nervous to go under the knife at first, but it turned out better than I expected. Do you know others who've gotten hysterectomies that are near my age?

speaker: doctor
text: I do, actually. It's a pretty common procedure. I'm glad to hear that you didn't experience any complications.

speaker: patient
text: Me too.

speaker: doctor
text: Hello and welcome to our dermatology office. What is the reason for your visit?

speaker: patient
text: I have these rashes on my arms.

speaker: doctor
text: Let me take a look. Do you have prior reports about your history?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I do. I gave it to the nurse.

speaker: doctor
text: Let me go get it really quick. I'm reading the report and it looks like your family is positive for atopy.

speaker: patient
text: Oh, yeah. We all usually get some type of rash.

speaker: doctor
text: I see. Do you know if you have psoriasis?

speaker: patient
text: Uh. What's that's?

speaker: doctor
text: It's a skin disease that usually has scaly patches.

speaker: patient
text: Uhm. I don't think so.

speaker: doctor
text: Great. Before I prescribe you medicine to treat your eczema, are you allergic to any drugs?

speaker: patient
text: Not that I know of.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you drink?

speaker: patient
text: Well, I will call myself a social drinker. I would admit that I am addicted to caffeine.

speaker: doctor
text: How much coffee do you consume each day?

speaker: patient
text: I would say three to five cups.

speaker: doctor
text: Any history of sexually transmitted disease?

speaker: patient
text: Nope.

speaker: doctor
text: How're your eating habits?

speaker: patient
text: I would say I am a good eater and follow a healthy diet plan.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you exercise?

speaker: patient
text: I walk every day around five miles. Also, I'm very regular in my sprint training.

speaker: doctor
text: Good afternoon Sir. Do you know how you got here?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I passed out and the paramedics brought me to the hospital.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any recollection of the incidences leading up to your loss of consciousness?

speaker: patient
text: I think I had a seizure and then I passed out.

speaker: doctor
text: Prior to the episode did you experience any chest pain or shortness of breath?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Any feelings of abnormal heart rhythm?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any history of any cardiac problems?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: How are you feeling now?

speaker: patient
text: I feel fine.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you know how old you are?

speaker: patient
text: I am sixty nine.

speaker: doctor
text: Hello Miss Lee how are you?

speaker: patient
text: I am okay, my arms are troubling me so much.

speaker: doctor
text: Yeah, I know it's been a longstanding pain in both your arms.

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, and hands too

speaker: doctor
text: Can you pinpoint where exactly is the pain?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, it's right here in the middle part of arm and my palm.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay so mostly in the medial part. Tell me do you feel any weakness?

speaker: patient
text: No, but I do feel this tingling sensation kind of like numbness in my left hand, and it gets worse at night after doing repetitive work.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you left handed?

speaker: patient
text: No, I'm right handed

speaker: doctor
text: Hm, any neck pain?

speaker: patient
text: Not really, nothing substantial.

speaker: doctor
text: Can you please tell me your age again?

speaker: patient
text: I am fifty two.

speaker: doctor
text: Did you ever have these kind of signs and symptoms in the past?

speaker: patient
text: Nope!

speaker: doctor
text: Okay and are you taking anything for pain?

speaker: patient
text: Ah yes, I am taking Lyrica.

speaker: doctor
text: Lyrica okay and is it helping?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, somewhat.

speaker: doctor
text: Any problem in walking or change in how you walk?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: And you are having regular bowel movements any changes?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, no changes.

speaker: doctor
text: How about urine, any burning or difficulty peeing?

speaker: patient
text: No, it's all fine.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay good. So, the neurological exam we did earlier, I have the results for it.

speaker: patient
text: And?

speaker: doctor
text: Well, you were tested positive for Phalen's test on your left hand.

speaker: patient
text: What does that means?

speaker: doctor
text: It means that you have something called Carpal tunnel syndrome, which explains your numbness and tingling sensation in your left hand. It also explains your pain in the middle part of your hand as it's caused due to pinching or compression of a nerve called median nerve.

speaker: patient
text: Oh, how did that happen?

speaker: doctor
text: Well, it's possible that your repetitive hand motion could have caused it or sometimes it's just the anatomy of your wrist.

speaker: patient
text: Oh, that explains my increased pain in the night after work.

speaker: doctor
text: Yeah.

speaker: patient
text: Anything else came in the neuro test?

speaker: doctor
text: No, rest of your neurological exam was normal.

speaker: patient
text: Okay. I am worried now.

speaker: doctor
text: Don't worry we are here.

speaker: patient
text: Thank you!

speaker: doctor
text: Have we gone over your survey results from your last visit?

speaker: patient
text: No, do you have those results with you right now?

speaker: doctor
text: Yes, I do, they show that you have anxiety disorder.

speaker: patient
text: That makes sense, thank you for sharing that with me.

speaker: doctor
text: I see here that you've been having some chest pain. Where along the chest?

speaker: patient
text: It's mostly on the left side.

speaker: doctor
text: When did it start?

speaker: patient
text: Um a few days ago.

speaker: doctor
text: How'd you describe the pain?

speaker: patient
text: Kinda dull.

speaker: doctor
text: Any other symptoms with the pain, such as shortness of breath?

speaker: patient
text: Not really, no.

speaker: doctor
text: How long does the pain usually last?

speaker: patient
text: For a few minutes. It comes and goes.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you taken anything for the pain?

speaker: patient
text: I've taken some Advil, but it doesn't seem to help.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you had similar pain in the past?

speaker: patient
text: No, I don't think so.

speaker: doctor
text: And you had surgery on your abdomen five days ago, correct?

speaker: patient
text: Yes. Do you think the pain is related?

speaker: doctor
text: I'd like to run some tests and get you in for a CAT scan to see what's going on.

speaker: doctor
text: It looks like he has a history of high blood pressure, high cholesterol, and Afib.

speaker: doctor
text: Not according to his chart. I'll see if I can call his emergency contact to confirm.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you smoke or drink alcohol?

speaker: patient
text: No, I do not smoke or drink alcohol.

speaker: doctor
text: How about drugs?

speaker: patient
text: Nope, I have never.

speaker: doctor
text: Who do you live with?

speaker: patient
text: Just my family.

speaker: doctor
text: How old are you now?

speaker: patient
text: I am sixty five. My kids just through me a surprise birthday party last week.

speaker: doctor
text: Oh wow! That is so nice. Happy belated birthday.

speaker: patient
text: It was nice.

speaker: doctor
text: It looks like you are here today for a recheck for the prostatitis.

speaker: patient
text: Yeah.

speaker: doctor
text: I see you have been followed by Doctor Mathis.

speaker: patient
text: Yes.

speaker: doctor
text: How often do you see him?

speaker: patient
text: He has me coming in about every three or four months.

speaker: doctor
text: Excellent. And the last time I saw you was in May two thousand and four.

speaker: patient
text: Has it been that long?

speaker: doctor
text: Yeah, it has. Okay. You are here to discuss some libido problems?

speaker: patient
text: Sadly, yes.

speaker: doctor
text: How long have you been having these difficulties?

speaker: patient
text: I noticed the change when I started taking the Proscar.

speaker: doctor
text: That is a common side effect that some men experience from Proscar. Have you tried any medication to help bring back your libido?

speaker: patient
text: I take Viagra sometimes.

speaker: doctor
text: Does it help at all?

speaker: patient
text: There is some improvement.

speaker: doctor
text: How many times a night do you get up to relive yourself now?

speaker: patient
text: I still get up about three to four times.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, so still often.

speaker: patient
text: Yes, but I have not had any U T Is since I have been on the Proscar.

speaker: doctor
text: That is good news.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you married, sir?

text: Okay, thank you. Did you go to college, sir?

text: I've worked at Purdy Correctional Institute, you know, the one in Gig Harbor? I've worked there for nineteen years.

speaker: doctor
text: So, looks like you have stones in your C B D. I am not hundred percent sure but most likely its stones.

text: C B D?

speaker: doctor
text: Yeah, short for common bile duct. It's a small tube like structure which connects your liver duct and gallbladder.

speaker: patient
text: Oh!

speaker: doctor
text: Yeah, and because of that you have inflammation in your gallbladder.

speaker: patient
text: Oh, I see.

speaker: doctor
text: No, this is his first one.

text: Can you tell me more about your son, please?

speaker: doctor
text: How long has he used his walker?

speaker: doctor
text: How old was he when he started walking?

speaker: doctor
text: Good, what seems to be the problem today?

speaker: doctor
text: Can you sit on the table, young man? Yes, I'm bending his legs, we call this the popliteal angle, and both sides flex to only about twenty.

speaker: doctor
text: He should be able to get to ninety.

speaker: doctor
text: I think we should do surgery on this leg. How does he walk? Can I see?

speaker: doctor
text: Yes, he does not walk with a crouched pattern, but he is toe walking.

speaker: doctor
text: Well, I believe he should have surgery on the hamstring, as well.

speaker: doctor
text: They're low, historically, they're less than one percent. The risks include anesthesia, infection, bleeding, changes in sensation and the motion of walking, and it may also not always cure the toe walking. There is also possible stiffness after wearing the cast and other cast issues.

speaker: doctor
text: Absolutely, he won't feel a thing. It is worth it because the chances of the risks happening are low.

speaker: doctor
text: Did you ever have any reaction to any medication given? Any known allergies?

text: Do you have any chronic conditions I should know about, sir?

speaker: patient

speaker: doctor
text: Hello, sir. Before we begin your visit, could you verify your age and ethnicity for me, please?

text: Thank you. Let me take a look. So, it looks like you underwent grafting and full thickness skin grafting for closure for a large defect in your left posterior thigh. That seems to be healed in the gluteal fold on the left area.

text: No.

speaker: patient

text: I have the ultrasound results that Doctor X ordered the other day.  The ultrasound found a stone in your left ureteral. The stone is about one point three C M in size.

speaker: patient
text: Is there some thing we can do to remove it? I really want this taken care of.

speaker: doctor
text: Yes. Let us go over the treatment options.

speaker: doctor
text: Good afternoon, ma'am. You're forty one years old, correct?

text: Good afternoon, doctor. Yes, that's correct.

text: Thank you, have you followed up with Doctor X since your surgery?

text: Why would I do that?

text: Oh, just because she referred you to me.

text: Oh, no, I haven't yet.

speaker: doctor
text: Well, you had a complicated case, but we did an anterior cervical discectomy, two level corpectomy, with a spinal decompression and fusion with fibular strut and machine allograft in your large cervical plate.

speaker: patient
text: Oh, that's a lot, doctor.

speaker: doctor
text: Yes, how are you doing today?

text: Well, I've felt good for the last two days.

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I can actually move all four.

speaker: patient
text: No, nothing of note there.

text: Okay, today, I think you'd be a good candidate for a halo vest placement.

text: Okay, we can do it here.

text: Let me get A B C to help me with this. Also, we're going to move you to S I C U room one.

text: Well, this is a P M T halo, I like this one better than the Bremer halo vest, and I'll use morphine and Versed.

speaker: doctor
text: Yes, I have local anesthetic, it's xylocaine and epinephrine, um, it's somewhere between fifteen and twenty C C.

speaker: doctor
text: Is everything fine?

speaker: doctor
text: When did this start?

speaker: doctor
text: Okay let's see what we can do, how old is she?

speaker: doctor
text: Okay. Don't worry, we will see what we can do.

text: Of Course.

text: Okay.

text: Well, right now I am living with my sister in Sacaton. I am currently looking for my own place, but I am staying with her for now.

text: Are you looking for a place in Sacaton?

text: I recently separated from my wife. We lived in Coolidge together. Sacaton is too far away from everything, but it is fine for now.

speaker: doctor
text: I am so sorry to hear that.

speaker: patient
text: Thank you. My sister has been a saint. I am not working right now so my sister is letting me stay with her for free. She gave up her home office and made me a nice room to stay in.

speaker: doctor
text: Your sister is very generous. Are you and your sister close?

speaker: patient
text: Not when we were growing up but now that we are older, we have become very close. She has been a great support for me in these hard times.

speaker: doctor
text: That's wonderful. Are you a tobacco user?

speaker: patient
text: I smoke cigarettes. I only smoke a little bit.

text: How much do you smoke per day?

speaker: patient
text: I only smoke about one or two cigarettes a day.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you or have you ever used drugs or alcohol?

speaker: patient
text: I have never used drugs. I used to be a heavy drinker. I quit drinking a year ago.

speaker: doctor
text: That's great. Do you attend A A meetings?

speaker: patient
text: No, but I might start. Things have been very stressful lately with the separation and being on unemployment.

speaker: doctor
text: I think it could be beneficial to you.

speaker: patient
text: Okay.

text: I have a list for different support groups in the area that I can give you.

text: Great. Thank you.

text: How are you feeling after that insulin drip, Miss A B C?

speaker: patient
text: I am feeling much better. My sugar levels are normal.

speaker: doctor
text: Yes, between one hundred fifteen and one thirty four. So, on the second day after your admission they did laparoscopic removal of your gallstones. You were very difficult to intubate. But everything went well with surgery. There was some swelling and adhesions around your gallbladder, but all is well that ends well.

speaker: doctor

speaker: doctor
text: Yes, sliding scale insulin.

speaker: doctor
text: Yes, you are all set to go home, everything is stable.

text: Good morning, ma'am.

text: Good morning, doctor.

speaker: doctor
text: Welcome to A B C D General Hospital. My nurse says that you are forty one years old, and you identify as a White female, is that correct?

text: Yes, that's all correct.

text: Thank you, so, what seems to be the trouble today?

text: Well, I'm having some pain in this foot, it's right over this bone.

text: No, this is new. Can we do that surgery again? I can't take this pain.

text: On April twenty two four we went over your list of medication and allergies.

text: Sure.

text: Yeah, I guess. I've tried to also reduce my salt intake to about two grams.

text: Hello. Before we begin your visit, could I ask a few questions to fill in some missing information?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, that's fine.

text: Does your family have any health related problems?

text: Yeah, we do. We have a strong history of heart disease. I think it could be because we drink a lot.

text: Oh, yeah. We drink a lot every day. Beer, liquor, you name it.

text: Are you working these days?

text: No, sir. I've been retired for a couple years now.

text: You bet.

text: You mentioned having a smoking history. When did you quit and approximately how much did you smoke?

text: Did you smoke only cigarettes?

speaker: patient
text: Cigars, too.

speaker: doctor
text: How about alcohol?

speaker: patient
text: Hardly ever.

text: Great.

speaker: doctor
text: Good morning, sir, welcome to A B C D General Hospital.

text: Thank you, doctor. I hope you can fix me up quickly.

speaker: doctor
text: We'll do our best. Um, before we begin, I just need some background information. So, how old are you?

speaker: patient
text: I'm forty seven years old.

speaker: doctor
text: Good, and what race do you identify with?

speaker: patient
text: I identify as white, sir.

speaker: doctor
text: Thank you, so, what seems to be the problem today?

text: Well, I have this, um, mass of my left foot, it's been getting worse too.

text: I see it. How long has this tissue mass been there on that foot?

speaker: patient
text: It's been about two weeks now, but it's getting worse way faster now.

text: Do you have any history of cancer?

text: No, but I've had an, um, shave biopsy in the past.

text: I see.

text: Is there any surgery we can do for this to cut it off? I really want it gone.

text: What do you do for a living?

speaker: patient
text: Actually, I'm retired now, but I was an engineer, and I did some real estate brokering as well on the side.

speaker: doctor
text: Wow, that's a lot. Congratulations on your retirement!

speaker: patient
text: Thank you, now I get to spend more time with my wife.

speaker: doctor
text: Wonderful, do you have any children?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, five in total, it's a full house.

speaker: doctor
text: Fantastic, do you drink or smoke?

text: I don't smoke, but I drink a little.

text: How many drinks would you say you have a week?

speaker: patient
text: Um, I'd say up to three drinks a week.

text: Okay, and is there any history of drug or illicit substance abuse, sir?

text: No, never anything like that.

text: As per your chart I am going to put some of the following things in your diagnosis.

text: Yes, I have diabetes, hypertension and gallstones.

text: Yes I can see that in your chart over here.

text: What are the new things?

text: We now have added hyperglycemia and obstructive sleep apnea.

text: Do you smoke?

text: Do you have any orthopedic conditions that run in your family that I should know about?

text: Yeah, does anything like that sound familiar?

text: No, not that I know of.

speaker: patient
text: Hi! Thank you.

speaker: patient
text: Okay.

speaker: patient
text: I have Crohn's disease.

speaker: patient
text: Oh, I don't know. A long time twenty five to thirty years.

text: I had one, four years ago. Do I need to get another one this year?

speaker: patient
text: Sounds good. I am also a diabetic. That has been going on for four years now.

text: Yes, I have high blood pressure and high cholesterol. I also have heart disease. I had a stent placed in there.

speaker: patient
text: I have arthritis now. They said it's due to my Crohn's.

speaker: patient
text: I'm being treated for depression now as well.

speaker: patient
text: Oh, I had a kidney stone removed several years ago. Twenty five years ago. That's it. That's all I got for you.

text: I'll be here.

text: Any sugar or B P problem?

speaker: patient
text: No, it is normal.

text: Okay, how about thyroid or any other hormone related problem?

text: No, everything is fine.

text: Refractory anemia.

text: Do you have patient's family history?

text: Hm, okay.

text: Hello, miss. How can I help you today? The nurse said the matter was urgent.

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I have been having dizzy spells. I have also noticed a new rash on my right calf.

text: Can you describe what type of dizzy spells you are having? What do they feel like?

speaker: patient
text: It is general dizziness and vertigo. I am also lightheaded during the spells.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you feeling okay right now or are you experiencing symptoms?

speaker: patient
text: I am having headaches off and on randomly, but nothing right now. The neck pain and muscle aches also are intermittent.

speaker: doctor
text: Let me take a look at the rash on your legs. Are the bruises new?

speaker: patient
text: They are new, I think. I have noticed them more than usual.

speaker: doctor
text: In the past couple days have you had a fever or chills?

speaker: patient
text: No, nothing like that.

speaker: doctor
text: What about chest pains?

speaker: patient
text: I have had some tightness in my chest, but not right now.

speaker: doctor
text: Does the dizziness make you nauseous?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, but I have not had to throw up or anything.

speaker: doctor
text: What about diarrhea?

speaker: patient
text: No, thank goodness.

speaker: doctor
text: Are there any parts of your body that are hurting?

speaker: patient
text: I do have some left shoulder pain. Not so much painful, but it is uncomfortable and tender.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you measured your blood sugar at all? I ask because the notes state there is a history of gestational diabetes and when blood sugars are out of the normal limits this can cause some of the symptoms you are having.

speaker: patient
text: I measured it today. After lunch it was one fifty five.

speaker: doctor
text: Does anyone in your family have or have history of any colon cancer or unusual polyps?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Any other family history?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, my father died of a cancer called mesothelioma and my mother died of Hodgkin's Lymphoma.

speaker: doctor
text: Any known medical history in the family?

speaker: patient
text: Nope.

text: How about anyone with high blood pressure or heart disease or diabetes in the family?

speaker: patient
text: Nope.

speaker: doctor
text: How are you feeling today?

speaker: patient
text: I am feeling very tired.

speaker: doctor
text: According to your chart, you have seen with us for three separate self harm attempts. Have you had any other self harm events that you have not come to see use for?

speaker: patient
text: No. I have been seeing Doctor Lin.

speaker: doctor
text: I also see that this is your third time in the last two months that you have attempted to harm yourself. Is there anything that is currently going on in your life that could be triggering these resent episode?

text: Last month I lost my job. And then this month my boyfriend left me.

speaker: doctor
text: I am so sorry. That is a lot to deal with.

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, it has been hard.

text: Have you been diagnosed with any mental health conditions?

speaker: patient
text: Doctor Lin just said that I was depressed.

text: Have you ever been put on any medication for the for your depression?

speaker: patient
text: I can't remember.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

text: Do you have any drug allergies?

speaker: patient

speaker: doctor
text: So, if you see here Doctor Patrick there are multiple areas with hypergranulation tissue on the left leg posteriorly and I get a sense that it's associated with the trauma to the back of his right leg.

speaker: doctor
text: How're you today?

speaker: patient
text: Not too bad. I'm hanging in there. My asthma has been acting up.

speaker: doctor
text: Oh no. How long has this been going on?

speaker: patient
text: For the past three months. I've been using my inhaler every day. I used to use it every now and again. This is definitely new for me.

text: Are you experiencing any allergies alongside your asthma?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, actually. My husband has been hauling a lot more corn this season and it seems to be making my allergies much worse.

text: Do you take anything for your allergies?

speaker: patient
text: Not really. I'll sometimes take Allegra and that seems to help just a tiny bit. I was previously prescribed Flonase, but I can't remember the last time I took it. Oh and I was on Advair, too.

text: Did the Flonase or Advair help at all?

speaker: patient
text: I had to stop Advair because it started to bother my lady parts.

speaker: doctor
text: How so?

speaker: patient
text: I noticed that it became more itchy as a result.

speaker: doctor
text: I'm sorry to hear that.

speaker: patient
text: Speaking of this, I wanted to also share that I've been experiencing a lot of P M S symptoms lately. I'm super impatient and moody.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you notice these symptoms are still there after you finish your cycle?

speaker: patient
text: Um lemme think. The symptoms start about a week before my period and tend to get less intense once I get over the first day of bleeding.

text: Are your cycles generally regular?

speaker: patient
text: For the most part, yes. I feel like they don't last as long as they used to. I'm not sure why. I do, however, notice some spotting after my cycles end.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you get any night sweats or hot flashes while you're on your period?

speaker: patient
text: No.

text: Have you had any other medical troubles recently?

speaker: patient
text: I did have a U T I and some blood in my urine because of it.

text: Do you remember how many times you noticed blood in your urine?

speaker: patient
text: Hm about three times. I was prescribed antibiotics for it.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you had any other urinary symptoms since? How about bdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, or anything of the like?

speaker: patient
text: Nothing now.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you gotten your urine rechecked recently?

speaker: patient
text: No, not yet. I really should get it checked out again.

speaker: doctor
text: I can write an order for you if you'd like or you can make an appointment with your urologist. Do you have a specific urologist that you see?

text: Yeah, I can call to make the appointment tomorrow. Do I also need to get blood work done?

speaker: doctor
text: Yes, in fact I'd like to order some blood work while you're here.

speaker: patient
text: I had blood work done a few days ago for my life insurance application. I am forty two so thought I should get that going. My Swedish mother always used to nag about how I procrastinate on important things. Anyways, do I still need to get more blood work done?

speaker: doctor
text: Do you know what they checked?

speaker: patient
text: I think the typical blood work with cholesterol added.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you happen to have a copy on hand or could you fax me the resulxts?

speaker: patient
text: I can fax them to you once I get them back.

speaker: doctor
text: That would be great. Thank you. Let me write down our fax number for you.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, so your psych evaluation came out unremarkable. Do you have any other problems?

speaker: patient
text: I have this acne. I hate it. I am not feeling comfortable in my own skin.

speaker: doctor
text: Hello there, how are you?

speaker: doctor
text: I understand, so how old is she?

speaker: doctor
text: And just wanted to confirm the ethnicity is Caucasian, right?

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, so tell me what's going on with her?

speaker: doctor
text: When did you first notice it?

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, and how many times till now?

speaker: doctor
text: Did you notice any interrupted breathing or bluish color around her mouth?

speaker: doctor
text: While the episode occurs do you notice any color changes in the baby?

speaker: doctor
text: Did you happened to notice any arching of the back or eyes rolling back?

speaker: doctor
text: Okay. Otherwise, is she feeding well and is active?

speaker: doctor
text: And how often are you feeding her and for how long?

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, and how many dirty diapers?

speaker: doctor
text: And did you notice the color of her poop?

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: Has anyone in your family had heart diseases?

speaker: patient
text: Yes my father. They did his heart bypass surgery when he was sixty.

speaker: doctor
text: Is he alright now?

speaker: patient
text: Yes I know what you mean.

speaker: patient
text: Yes by God's grace, both my parents are alive.

speaker: doctor
text: What exactly was the heart disease named? Do you know?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah they said it was something called coronary artery disease and he had many strokes due to that.

speaker: doctor
text: How old is he now?

speaker: patient
text: My father is in his eighties. My mother is eighty years old too and she has dementia. My father has dementia too.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay. Do you smoke or drink alcohol? And how much?

speaker: patient
text: No I do not drink or smoke.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you on steroids?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Any history of cancer, chemotherapy or anything related?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: How have you both been doing?

speaker: doctor
text: I see she has been gaining weight since she has been home. Have you been following the meal plan that we discussed?

speaker: doctor
text: Great!

speaker: doctor
text: We don't have any record of P M H for this patient.

speaker: doctor
text: Oh, dear God! What happened?

speaker: doctor
text: Hello, so what happened?

speaker: doctor
text: So, you fell from the tree?

speaker: patient
text: Yes.

speaker: doctor
text: What is up with your teeth man? It's been giving you problems huh?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, yes, many, many problems. Firstly, they pulled out so many teeth and now I have this bad tooth problem.

speaker: doctor
text: Oh, so this is new?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, it's a new pain. Right now it has been going on for three days on left side's upper and lower teeth.

speaker: doctor
text: Then why didn't you go and visit your regular dentist?

speaker: patient
text: I would have but I have missed so many appointments that they now do not allow me to schedule regular appointments. So they put me on a standby appointment now.

speaker: doctor
text: Oh I am sorry.

speaker: patient
text: It is okay.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay any other problems or any other complaints?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: How about any recent illnesses or injuries?

speaker: patient
text: No, no illness whatsoever.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any medicine at home for pain?

speaker: patient
text: Yes I have  OxyContin and Vicodin at home. I use it for my knee pain. But I want more pain medicines. I do not want to use up that medicine for my toothache.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay I understand. How old are you again?

speaker: patient
text: I am twenty nine.

speaker: doctor
text: How's your jaw doing?

speaker: patient
text: The pain seems to have gotten worse.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you mind if I take a look?

speaker: patient
text: Sure. Ow, ow, ow. That's the spot that hurts the most. What's causing it?

speaker: doctor
text: It's hard to say, but I'm thinking it could be T M J. I'd like to get you in to see a T M J specialist.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you taking Citalopram for depression?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I take it once a day.

speaker: patient
text: It is ten M G tablet.

speaker: doctor
text: Is that so?

speaker: patient
text: Yes.

speaker: doctor
text: What do you take for pain?

speaker: patient
text: Just Tramadol as needed.

speaker: doctor
text: What is your family health history?

speaker: patient
text: My mom and dad are both diabetics. My mom has high blood pressure. My brother is having some issues with his liver.

speaker: doctor
text: Can you tell me about your family?

speaker: patient
text: I have or had two sons both born normally without any complications.

speaker: doctor
text: Why did you say had?

speaker: patient
text: One of my sons was a heavy smoker, he uses to smoke a whole packet or more in a day. We tried everything possible, but he just couldn't quit. He died of clots.

speaker: doctor
text: Does anyone in your family like parents or siblings had any medical issues?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, my father had heart related issues, he died in his sixties, my mother died of colon cancer. I also have a sister but I don't think she has any issues.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you smoke cigarettes?

speaker: patient
text: Yes.

speaker: doctor
text: How about alcohol?

speaker: patient
text: No, I don't consume alcohol.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay. And any history of using drugs like marijuana or stuff like that for fun?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you married, sir?

speaker: patient
text: No divorced. I live a lone.

speaker: doctor
text: What work do you do?

speaker: patient
text: I am a retired postal worker.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have kids?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I have three of my own and seven grandkids.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you smoke cigarettes?

speaker: patient
text: Yes I do.

speaker: doctor
text: How much and what kind?

speaker: patient
text: I keep changing the brands but Newport, one pack a day.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay. How about alcohol or drugs like substance abuse?

speaker: patient
text: No drugs but I drink occasionally depending on the company.

speaker: doctor
text: How long have you smoked?

speaker: patient
text: Thirty years now.

speaker: doctor
text: Hello! How are you doing?

speaker: patient
text: Hello Doctor! I am good.

speaker: patient
text: I am here today for my follow-up, as suggested.

speaker: doctor
text: Has it been a month already?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, seeing you after a month.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any allergies?

speaker: patient
text: I am allergic to IV contrast.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you sure?

speaker: patient
text: Yes.

speaker: doctor
text: Just to debrief, we will rule out angina related heart problems while evaluating your jaw pain.

speaker: patient
text: Oh can that be related to each other?

speaker: doctor
text: Yes they might be.

speaker: patient
text: What else?

speaker: doctor
text: Pardon?

speaker: patient
text: I am asking anything else?

speaker: doctor
text: We have discussed this before, but keep track of your high cholesterol and hypothyroid.

speaker: doctor
text: Hello, sir. How are you feeling today?

speaker: patient
text: Very itchy. I just keep scratching myself.

speaker: doctor
text: Oh, wow. I can see the rashes all over your arms. Are there rashes anywhere else?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, it's all over my back and stomach.

speaker: doctor
text: I see it on your torso. When did this all start?

speaker: patient
text: I woke up this morning and started itching my back. After a few minutes, I noticed the rash was on my arms, chest, back, and stomach areas.

speaker: doctor
text: I'm going to take a look at the rashes and the rest of your body.

speaker: patient
text: Sounds good.

speaker: doctor
text: It looks like your face and lips are not swollen. Could you say ah for me?

speaker: patient
text: Ah.

speaker: doctor
text: It looks like your tongue isn't swollen either.

speaker: patient
text: That's good to hear.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you been feeling a shortness of breath, wheezing, or other related symptoms?

speaker: patient
text: Not that I know of.

speaker: doctor
text: Sounds good. I wonder why this happened. Did you do anything the night before?

speaker: patient
text: Uh. A few days ago, I was working and had to remove some insulation. Other than that, I don't know what else could have given me these rashes.

speaker: doctor
text: I see. Do you remember being itchy after that? Did you try any new foods?

speaker: patient
text: Nope I was not itchy. Also, my diet has been the same.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you taking any new medications?

speaker: patient
text: I haven't.

speaker: doctor
text: You don't recall being exposed to any other substances?

speaker: patient
text: Not that I know of.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any family medical history of migraines?

speaker: patient
text: I know that my brother has them too. Mom, do you know if anyone else gets them?

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: What do you do for work?

speaker: patient
text: I am retired now. I was a school teacher.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you a smoker?

speaker: patient
text: Yes.

speaker: doctor
text: How much do you smoke per day?

speaker: patient
text: I would say about a half to a full pack a day.

speaker: doctor
text: How long have you been a smoker.

speaker: patient
text: Probably sixty years.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you allergic to anything?

speaker: patient
text: No, I am not.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you sure? Penicillin or sulfa?

speaker: patient
text: Nope nothing.

speaker: doctor
text: That's good.

speaker: doctor
text: Hi there, sir! How are you doing today?

speaker: patient
text: I feel out of it.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you been using any substances?

speaker: patient
text: I did a little heroin and some coke earlier today. I still feel high.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay. Any shortness of breath, chest pain, abdominal pain or back pain?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you having any headaches, hallucinations or visual disturbances?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any open sores or wounds?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you had any surgical procedures done?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, in fact I had a hysterectomy back in March of ninety nine. I believe it was done on the twentieth of the month.

speaker: doctor
text: Got it.

speaker: patient
text: You know Doctor, I am widowed for eighteen years now. Never remarried, I live by myself in my house.

speaker: doctor
text: Oh okay, are your still working?

speaker: patient
text: No, I use to run a restaurant, but now retired.

speaker: doctor
text: Hm. And you smoke cigarettes?

speaker: patient
text: No, I don't!  Never liked the smell.

speaker: doctor
text: How about alcohol?

speaker: patient
text: No, I don't drink either.

speaker: doctor
text: How old are you, sir?

speaker: patient
text: I'm sixty five years old.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you right handed or left handed?

speaker: patient
text: I'm right handed.

speaker: doctor
text: When was your last stroke?

speaker: patient
text: Well, it was on January seventeenth. I had these episodes where I was like always so confused and looks like I lost everything. All my memory and everything. And then they did a scan. It was verified that I was having a stroke on the same day.

speaker: doctor
text: Did they put you on some medications?

speaker: patient
text: They gave me an anticonvulsant and aspirin.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you taking them regularly?

speaker: patient
text: There have a few times like one or two days that I forgot to take my, uh, dyphenhydramine, but even when I'm taking it regularly, I'm still having all those symptoms or forgetfulness, confusion, and everything.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you feel anything else along with these episodes like a urine urgency, tendency to bite your tongue, headaches, any visual change, or your heart is beating very fast? Any kind of weakness or numbness or shortness of breath?

speaker: patient
text: No nothing else, just the confusion and forgetfulness.

speaker: doctor
text: How frequent are these episodes?

speaker: patient
text: Well, they occur like two or three times in a week. Each one of the episodes lasts for like one or two minutes.

speaker: doctor
text: Any medical disorders in the family?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, my father had a special kind of tumor, which doctors said is very rare.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you know the name of the tumor?

speaker: patient
text: I don't remember the exact name of the disease, but it was a big name and it started with something with V.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any major medical conditions that I should know about?

speaker: patient
text: Actually, I have a whole list of conditions. I have them written down here.

speaker: doctor
text: Thank you, so I see congestive heart failure, chronic renal insufficiency, azotemia, hyperglycemia, coronary artery disease, and a history of paroxysmal atrial fibrillation. Oh, and azotemia.

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I told you I have a lot going on.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you taking any medications?

speaker: patient
text: Well, they wanted me to take Coumadin but I had, um, a subdural hematoma so they would let me.

speaker: doctor
text: I see, what about any neurological or psychological conditions?

speaker: patient
text: Well, I have depression, and I've had panic attacks while taking Doxepin before.

speaker: doctor
text: I see here that you also have perioperative anemia, does that sound familiar?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, another doctor told me about that.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any other symptoms you'd like to report today?

speaker: patient
text: Um, I'm having some difficulty swallowing.

speaker: doctor
text: Doctor Shami, can you please take down the notes as I examine the patient?

speaker: doctor
text: Can you put the heading as cervical lymph nodes.

speaker: doctor
text: I am going to check for any swelling in your neck okay? Can you look down?

speaker: patient
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: Alright, I do not feel anything here. Can you look up?

speaker: patient
text: Sure.

speaker: doctor
text: No palpable nodes here. None of the lymph nodes are enlarged or have any swellings.

speaker: doctor
text: Yeah.

speaker: doctor
text: You have chronic pain?

speaker: patient
text: Yes I do.

speaker: doctor
text: You use tobacco also?

speaker: patient
text: Yes.

speaker: doctor
text: And you have a history of hepatitis C, right?

speaker: patient
text: That sounds right.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

speaker: patient
text: Yeah.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you had any surgeries in the past?

speaker: patient
text: No, none.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you live close to the office, or did you have to drive a long way here?

speaker: patient
text: I live right around here, I'm a local girl.

speaker: doctor
text: Good, are you working right now?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, doctor, I work full time.

speaker: doctor
text: That's good, sometimes it's nice to stay busy. Is there any history of drug or alcohol abuse I should know about?

speaker: patient
text: No, absolutely not, doctor.

speaker: doctor
text: How are you, Mary?

speaker: patient
text: I am okay, I have got this ulcer on my right hip again.

speaker: doctor
text: Oh, is it like the one you got last time?

speaker: patient
text: Pretty much.

speaker: doctor
text: Oh, I remember that one. It took almost three treatment cycles to get resolved.

speaker: patient
text: Yeah. They keep saying I have some hidden split in my spine still.

speaker: doctor
text: Yeah, it looks like you have residual spina bifida.

speaker: patient
text: I am just so frustrated sitting in my wheelchair. I am spending around sixteen hours a day in this wheelchair.

speaker: doctor
text: I think, that is the reason you developed this pressure ulcer. It appears to be on the right trochanter area. In simple terms you have developed a pressure sore on the outer part of your hip.

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I recently celebrated my thirtieth birthday just sitting in my wheelchair the whole day.

speaker: doctor
text: Oh, I am sorry dear. So, how long since you have had this ulcer?

speaker: patient
text: It's been several weeks, so I thought I should get it checked.

speaker: doctor
text: Yeah, good thing you came. We need to treat it. Did you experience any chills or fever?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Any other symptoms?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any history of heart disease that you know of?

speaker: patient
text: Nope, nothing like that.

speaker: doctor
text: How about diabetes?

speaker: patient
text: No, there's no sugar here that I know of.

speaker: doctor
text: Good, and how about your lungs? Do they work well.

speaker: patient
text: Absolutely, they're in great shape. There's nothing like that here.

speaker: doctor
text: How about allergies to medications?

speaker: patient
text: Nope.

speaker: doctor
text: Your chest x ray showed diffuse pulmonary edema. This means that you have fluid in your lungs. That would explain your chest pain and the difficulies with your breathing. I would like to start you off with a course of antibiotics to prevent any possible infection. I will also send in a prescription for Furosemide. It will reduce the fluid accumulation in your lungs. Do you have any questions?

speaker: patient
text: When should I start to feel better?

speaker: doctor
text: You should start to feel better within three to five days.

speaker: doctor
text: Any headaches?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Any history of seizures or epilepsy?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Any sudden loss of consciousness or have you blacked out?

speaker: patient
text: Um, no.

speaker: doctor
text: Any weakness? Feeling any tremors in your body?

speaker: patient
text: No, nothing like that.

speaker: doctor
text: Any history of stroke or any brain related condition?

speaker: patient
text: No, no such history.

speaker: doctor
text: Are there any known disease running in your family?

speaker: patient
text: My dad has high blood pressure, and he takes medication for it. He is now eighty two years old. He had a stroke around two years ago. This was his second stroke. First one he had when he was forty five.

speaker: doctor
text: What about your mom? How old is she?

speaker: patient
text: My mom is eighty years old. She does have sugar issues.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you currently living alone?

speaker: patient
text: Yep. Just me, myself, and I.

speaker: doctor
text: What do you do for a living?

speaker: patient
text: I've been working as a plumber for the last five years.

speaker: doctor
text: Nice. Where do you work?

speaker: patient
text: Mostly in the city.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you drink, smoke, or do injection drugs?

speaker: patient
text: I drink and smoke here and there, but I've never tried hard drugs.

speaker: doctor
text: Any recent travel?

speaker: patient
text: I was in Mexico earlier this year.

speaker: doctor
text: That sounds nice. How was your trip?

speaker: patient
text: Relaxing. Much needed.

speaker: doctor
text: Great to hear. I have a few more questions I need to ask so bear with me. How is your sexual history? Are you sexually active?

speaker: patient
text: I'm sexually active with women, but my sex life isn't as good as it was in Japan. Over there, I would mix and mingle with prostitutes.

speaker: doctor
text: Did you use protection?

speaker: patient
text: I don't really remember.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you been tested for S T D's?

speaker: patient
text: Yep. I'm negative for right now.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you ever been incarcerated?

speaker: patient
text: Nope.

speaker: doctor
text: One last question. Have you ever been in need of a blood transfusion?

speaker: patient
text: No, thank God.

speaker: doctor
text: Good afternoon, champ, how you holding up?

speaker: patient
text: Good afternoon, Doctor, I have a lot of lower back pain.

speaker: doctor
text: Oh no, before we begin, how old are you, sir and which hand do you write with?

speaker: patient
text: I'm seventy five now. Right.

speaker: doctor
text: Great, so tell me, how long have you had this lower back pain?

speaker: patient
text: It's been about ten days now.

speaker: doctor
text: Have your symptoms improved at all since they began?

speaker: patient
text: No, they keep getting worse.

speaker: doctor
text: Does the pain radiate into your legs?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, it started radiating down my right leg three days after the lower back pain began, and then the left leg three days after the right. The next day I could barely walk, the pain was so severe.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you remember the initial date of the beginning of your low back pain?

speaker: patient
text: Um, it was on December third nineteen ninety five.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you seen another doctor for this pain?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I saw my local physician, um, it was on December eleventh, but he wasn't able to pinpoint what was going on.

speaker: doctor
text: What kind of treatments did he recommend?

speaker: patient
text: He gave me some antiinflammatories and sent me on my way.

speaker: doctor
text: Did you drive yourself?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I did.

speaker: doctor
text: How did the antiinflammatories work?

speaker: patient
text: Um, by the time I got home, I could hardly walk due to the back pain, and I had weakness in my legs. I was, however, able to feed my dogs, and I fixed myself some dinner.

speaker: doctor
text: Was there any leg numbness?

speaker: patient
text: Yes. Since December eleventh.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you seen an orthopedist for this pain?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I saw one the day after my primary care physician, but my legs gave out and I fell while walking to my car because of the leg weakness and back pain.

speaker: doctor
text: What kind of imaging studies did that orthopedist do?

speaker: patient
text: He did a C T and x rays of my lower back, but he didn't see anything wrong. He recommended I follow up at U I H C. The imaging was on my L S Spine.

speaker: doctor
text: Alright. So this is going to be a complex case. Your wound is complicated by methicillin-resistant staphylococcus aureus cellulitis.

speaker: patient
text: Is there a treatment for my right leg?

speaker: doctor
text: There is. It will be more aggressive, but we can do it.

speaker: doctor
text: What is going on with him?

speaker: doctor
text: Good morning, young man. You're a patient of Doctor X Y Z, correct?

speaker: patient
text: Yes sir, that's right. I've seen him for years.

speaker: doctor
text: I just need to confirm some demographic information before we get started today. So, you're a twenty nine year old white male, correct?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, doctor. That's all right.

speaker: doctor
text: Great, thank you. So, what seems to be the problem today?

speaker: patient
text: Well, I got stung by a Yellow Jacket Wasp yesterday.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have a lot of swelling?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, it's in my right hand and right arm.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you every been stung by wasps before?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, this wouldn't be the first time.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you had similar reactions before?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I have. I have had one severe reaction. I came because I wanted to make sure it didn't get to that point again. I've never had, um, anaphylaxis, nothing super serious to date.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, that's good. Do you have any shortness of breath or difficulty with your throat?

speaker: patient
text: No, it's never felt like it was going to close up or anything like that.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any rapid heartbeat or anxiety?

speaker: patient
text: No, I don't have anything like that either.

speaker: doctor
text: So, it's just the localized swelling where you got stung?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, that's really all, doctor.

speaker: doctor
text: When was your last menstrual period?

speaker: patient
text: Um, it was around June third of two thousand nine.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay so it says you have had an abortion recently?

speaker: patient
text: Yes I have, but I am not sure if it is finished, because I am still bleeding.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

speaker: patient
text: Do you want me to do a pregnancy test?

speaker: doctor
text: No I would have you see our Gynecology and Obstetrician.

speaker: patient
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: Oh, I am so sorry to hear that.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay I will look at it. But other than that, everything else looks good? Any other problems related to circumcision?

speaker: doctor
text: Welcome to the clinic, Miss A.

speaker: patient
text: Thank you.

speaker: doctor
text: Let's start with your medical history. What medical conditions do you have?

speaker: patient
text: Okay. I have high blood pressure, asthma and sleep apnea. I had blood clots in my left leg about six months ago. I also have cancer.

speaker: doctor
text: What kind of cancer do you have?

speaker: patient
text: I have stomach cancer. They also did a total abdominal hysterectomy.

speaker: doctor
text: Did they put you on an anticoagulant medication for the blood clotting?

speaker: patient
text: Yes. I took it for six months. I stopped taking it and then I had the stroke.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you had any other surgeries?

speaker: patient
text: Yes. I had a colonic resection to remove benign polyps. I had another benign lump removed from my breast.

speaker: doctor
text: How are you feeling today?

speaker: patient
text: I am still having weakness in my left leg. That is why I still have to us my walker, but I have been able to get around easier.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you been experiencing any daytime fatigue?

speaker: patient
text: No. I have been falling asleep at work. I think it is from looking at my computer screen all day. My supervisor caught me snoring one day and forgot where I was at. My supervisor offered to give me a coffee. This has happened more than once.

speaker: doctor
text: This could be due to your sleep apnea. Who is treating you for your sleep apnea?

speaker: patient
text: Doctor X did a consult and had me do one of those sleep test about two years ago. I only get sleepy when I look at my computer screen.

speaker: doctor
text: Did Doctor X recommend a C P A P machine to use at night?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, but I never used to use it. I had another follow up visit with her and she told me that I need to use it every night. I have been using it every other night.

speaker: doctor
text: How much uninterrupted sleep do you think that you get per night?

speaker: patient
text: Maybe two to five hours, on a good night.

speaker: doctor
text: That is not enough sleep. No wonder you are falling asleep at work. I recommend following up again with Doctor X regarding your sleep apnea. You are at a much higher risk for obesity and high cholesterol if you continue to not address the issues you have been having with the lack of sleep and sleep apnea.

speaker: patient
text: Okay. I will make a follow up visit with her.

speaker: doctor
text: They gave you Procrit for your anemia?

speaker: patient
text: Yes I think so. That is how they treated it in the past.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay. Are you married? Who do you live with?

speaker: patient
text: Oh I am by myself.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, and do you smoke or drink alcohol?

speaker: patient
text: No I do not.

speaker: doctor
text: Great.

speaker: patient
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: Hello. How are you doing?

speaker: patient
text: Not doing that good. I'm here so that you can help me.

speaker: doctor
text: Tell me how can I do that? What's bothering you?

speaker: patient
text: I have gestational diabetes and I'm here for consultation related to my diet. No matter what I eat, I'm kind of scared that it will spike up my numbers.

speaker: doctor
text: Hold on, hold on. First, tell me how old are you?

speaker: patient
text: Sorry. I am thirty eight.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, now tell me what are you afraid of?

speaker: patient
text: No matter what I eat, my number goes up and I just, I'm so afraid of eating anything now.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you work?

speaker: patient
text: I do, at Walmart. I try not to eat anything whenever I'm on the third shift.

speaker: doctor
text: Tell me about the eating habits. Do you prepare meals at home, or do you order from outside?

speaker: patient
text: Well, before all this, I mean this gestational diabetes and pregnancy, I used to eat out a lot. Almost like every day. I like to eat rice a lot. It is like the staple food for me.

speaker: doctor
text: You said you don't try to eat, so are you facing any symptoms because of not eating?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, whenever I'm on my late shift, I work from ten in the night to seven in the morning. I try to avoid eating. And then I feel very fatigued and tired all the time. I also have young kids at home, so after finishing my duty here at in the morning I go home and then there are young children who keep me busy.

speaker: doctor
text: What is your sleeping pattern? How much are you sleeping throughout the day?

speaker: patient
text: Around two to four hours at a time.

speaker: doctor
text: When do you test for ketones?

speaker: patient
text: Normally, it is the first thing that I do when I reach back home from my shift in the morning.

speaker: doctor
text: How old are you? What brings you here today?

speaker: patient
text: I am fifty six years old. I am here for this pain in my legs. It hurts mostly in the night.

speaker: doctor
text: Does changing positions helps you?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, it helps. Whenever I stand it just goes away.

speaker: doctor
text: Is it only in your legs or it starts there and goes somewhere else as well?

speaker: patient
text: It normally starts in my hips and then it goes down my leg and sometimes into my ankles as well.

speaker: doctor
text: When did you first notice it?

speaker: patient
text: It all started after taking that medication. What is it called? Something with L? Yeah, Lipitor.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you ever noticed any night sweats?

speaker: patient
text: Sometimes I do sweat at night.

speaker: doctor
text: Any other issue? Anything else going on? Your body temperature is a little on the higher end.

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I do feel feverish and have nausea as well.

speaker: doctor
text: How are your sugar numbers?

speaker: patient
text: They have been low for quite some time. You know, I have started going to Genesis in Wichita and I've been doing water aerobics. And you know what? Surprisingly, I have lost thirty pounds.

speaker: doctor
text: That's good. How much is your fasting sugar?

speaker: patient
text: Anywhere between a hundred to one hundred and twenty. I check them one and a half hours after meals as well. They are, they have been one hundred and eighty five regularly.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

speaker: patient
text: Yeah. I have a request to make. I will be coming for my diabetic checkup in one month. Can we do all the labs before that?

speaker: doctor
text: Yeah, sure, that's a great idea. I should tell my assistant and they will call you for labs before your appointment for diabetes checkup.

speaker: doctor
text: Anything else going on? How is everything else?

speaker: patient
text: I tried to control my cholesterol with diet, but it didn't help. I cannot keep on dieting. It is just not my thing. I have started eating more meat though. I feel full after that.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you married?

speaker: patient
text: Yes.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have kids?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I do have seven. I have a handful.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you work?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I'm a driver for FedEx.

speaker: doctor
text: Did you ever smoke?

speaker: patient
text: Nope.

speaker: doctor
text: What about alcohol or any other kind of drugs?

speaker: patient
text: Nope. None of that.

speaker: doctor
text: Is patient allergic to any medication?

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, so he is allergic to Lamisil, Equagesic. Oh, he is allergic to Bactrim too.

speaker: doctor
text: That's quite a lot, we need to be careful while making his treatment plan.

speaker: doctor
text: Hi there! I am Doctor Smith.

speaker: patient
text: Hello! It is nice to meet you.

speaker: doctor
text: Let's start with your family medical history.

speaker: patient
text: My mother had breast cancer. My father had lung cancer that ended up taking his life. He was seventy nine when he passed. My mother also passed but not from an illness but from an infection she got after having an elective surgery.

speaker: doctor
text: I am so sorry for your loss. How old was your mother when she passed?

speaker: patient
text: Thank you. She was eighty one when she passed. I am an orphan now. My only living sibling died at forty. He had a hard life. He struggled with mental illness.

speaker: doctor
text: How did your brother pass away?

speaker: patient
text: He had pancreatitis. Oh, my dad had glaucoma.

speaker: doctor
text: You have had a lot of loss.

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I have. My good friend passed away a year and a half ago. It has been a lot.

speaker: doctor
text: I have a support group I can refer you to for people to have been through loss. Would you be interested a referral, sir?

speaker: patient
text: Yes. I would like that. Thank you.

speaker: doctor
text: I will ask some simple questions, okay?

speaker: patient
text: Hm

speaker: doctor
text: How old are you and how would you define yourself in terms of ethnicity?

speaker: patient
text: Well, I am forty seven and would proudly call myself as Latin American.

speaker: doctor
text: Great. What brings you to the emergency room?

speaker: patient
text: I had a blood test before and then it came out to be high potassium. I also went to a regular clinic the other day as I was feeling very weak and extremely tired.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

speaker: patient
text: My potassium came out to be seven and it was highlighted in red. That really scared me, so I wanted to know everything what's going on inside me. I told the emergency doctors too that all these weakness and tiredness is going on for more than half a year.

speaker: doctor
text: Did you noticed any other symptoms other than weakness?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, there was the fever and chills. I was sweating a lot in the nights, and I also had weight loss of around twenty pounds. During that time, I sometimes have nausea and was throwing up a lot. I was not eating. I always felt dizzy every time I tried to stand.

speaker: doctor
text: Did you have wet cough?

speaker: patient
text: No, not wet cough but I did notice back pain gets intense on the upper side whenever I coughed, like in my ribs. I normally massage that area and it gets better.

speaker: doctor
text: Any shortness of breath?

speaker: patient
text: Nope.

speaker: doctor
text: How about while sleeping or doing something else?

speaker: patient
text: Not while sleeping, but I did notice that if I'm walking for two to three blocks then I get out of breath easily. Previously it was not like this. I used to jog for two to three miles without even a single breath loss.

speaker: patient
text: I noticed one more thing. I feel like my balls on one side are getting big.

speaker: doctor
text: Which side left or right?

speaker: patient
text: I think its left.

speaker: doctor
text: For how long?

speaker: patient
text: I guess over the past year. I did see someone when all of this started, and he put me on some antibiotics, but nothing changed. For last few months there is yellow fluid coming out of it too.

speaker: doctor
text: Did you ever get any type of injury in the area?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: What about your bowel movements?

speaker: patient
text: Nope everything is as usual.

speaker: doctor
text: Any change in urinary habits?

speaker: patient
text: Nope.

speaker: doctor
text: Any changes in your skin? Any rash? Any kind of eyesight issue?

speaker: patient
text: Nope, no changes.

speaker: doctor
text: What about pain? Like headache or any joint pain?

speaker: patient
text: Nope, no pain anywhere.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you ever had surgery, ma'am?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I've had a few. First, I had, um, tubal ligation, and three milk ducts removed.

speaker: doctor
text: What year was that in?

speaker: patient
text: That was in, um, nineteen seventy nine.

speaker: doctor
text: Great, thank you. What else have you had done?

speaker: patient
text: I had a breast biopsy in nineteen eighty nine, and a colonoscopy in two thousand seven.

speaker: doctor
text: Thank you, do you have any children?

speaker: patient
text: Well, doctor, I've been pregnant four times, but I've had three children.

speaker: doctor
text: I'm so sorry to hear that. Did you have a C section with any of them?

speaker: patient
text: No, doctor. I had a natural birth for all of them.

speaker: doctor
text: Did you had any surgery in the past?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Any allergies?

speaker: patient
text: Yes just molds.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay so molds reaction.

speaker: doctor
text: Hi there, how are you dear?

speaker: patient
text: I am fine, thank you.

speaker: doctor
text: Nice to meet you. So I see you have been referred by Doctor X.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, so you noticed some behavioral problems with your daughter and reported to her, is that right?

speaker: doctor
text: Well, looking at her reports I am afraid it looks like she does have A D H D, but the good news is we can treat her, so don't worry.

speaker: doctor
text: I am going to prescribe her some medicines which will help her deal with this.

speaker: doctor
text: So, I will write her a prescription for Adderall and Clonidine. They have some really good results in treating A D H D. Which pharmacy do you go to?

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, I will send it there.

speaker: patient
text: Thank you doctor, it was nice meeting you.

speaker: doctor
text: Nice meeting you too, take care.

speaker: doctor
text: He had circumcision?

speaker: patient
text: Yes.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you remember the date?

speaker: patient
text: No I do not. But it should be in the chart.

speaker: doctor
text: Good morning, sir. You're sixty one years old, correct?

speaker: patient
text: Good morning, doctor. Yes, that's correct.

speaker: doctor
text: Great, and you identify as Caucasian, right?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, that's correct as well.

speaker: doctor
text: Thank you, do you have any medical conditions that I should know about?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I have diabetes.

speaker: doctor
text: How are you handling your diabetes?

speaker: patient
text: Well, I've had diabetes for a long time but had never been treated for it.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, thank you for telling me. What seems to be the problem today?

speaker: patient
text: I've been working in my garage over the past few days, and I have this redness and swelling in my right foot.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any itchiness or pain?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, and it's getting worse.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you seen any other doctors about this?

speaker: patient
text: Um, yes. I went to the A B C D General Hospital E R and they gave me an evaluation there.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any images from this visit?

speaker: patient
text: Um, yes. I have them right here.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, these show a foreign body in the foot.

speaker: patient
text: But what about all the stuff on the outside of my foot?

speaker: doctor
text: Well, that's consistent with cellulitis.

speaker: patient
text: What's that?

speaker: doctor
text: It's a skin infection we clean it up in surgery.

speaker: patient
text: What kind of procedure can we do?

speaker: doctor
text: We should do an irrigation debridement for the cellulitis, and remove the foreign body. I think that will really help.

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I agree, doctor.

speaker: doctor
text: Hello, sir. How are you doing today?

speaker: patient
text: I'm flustered. I brought my wife so she can speak for me.

speaker: doctor
text: Hello, ma'am. What seems to be the problem with your husband?

speaker: doctor
text: Are you married, ma'am?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, to my wonderful husband.

speaker: doctor
text: Does he help you out around the house?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, he is just wonderful.

speaker: doctor
text: So, do you drink or smoke?

speaker: patient
text: No, I don't do any of that.

speaker: doctor
text: How about more illicit substances, do you use any of that?

speaker: patient
text: No, absolutely not.

speaker: doctor
text: Anything else going on from head to toe?

speaker: patient
text: No doctor, everything else is fine.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you sure?

speaker: patient
text: Yes I am sure.

speaker: doctor
text: He's doing much better. He'll be going home today with a prescription for Zithromax.

speaker: doctor
text: However, I'd like to still see him in the office next week for a reevaluation.

speaker: doctor
text: Yes, the front desk will be able to help you with that.

speaker: doctor
text: How long have you been running a fever?

speaker: patient
text: It's been on and off for a few days now. I'm also having chills.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you taken anything for the fever?

speaker: patient
text: Tylenol and Advil. I've been taking them interchangeably.

speaker: doctor
text: When was the last time you took your temperature?

speaker: patient
text: An hour ago. The thermometer read one O one point four.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you experiencing any other symptoms, such as shortness of breath, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, or others?

speaker: patient
text: I've been having a stronger urge to pee a lot more than usual. Not sure if that's related.

speaker: doctor
text: It could be. We're still waiting on your urine results. Do you have a history of cataracts or glaucoma?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, great. Any signs of pneumonia or valley fever?

speaker: patient
text: Nothing of the sort.

speaker: doctor
text: What about blood in your vomit or feces?

speaker: patient
text: Nope.

speaker: doctor
text: Any neurological symptoms like T I A or C V A? That is slurred speech or stroke symptoms.

speaker: patient
text: Luckily, no. I don't have seizures or anything like that.

speaker: doctor
text: Great to here. With the pandemic I wanted to check on your mental health too. Any depression or anxiety?

speaker: patient
text: I have always been a homebody. This is normal for me. Nothing like that in my head.

speaker: doctor
text: Cool. Do you have any issues with blood disorders?

speaker: patient
text: Nothing like that.

speaker: doctor
text: Hello, miss. It looks like some information is missing for your profile. Is it fine if I ask you a few questions?

speaker: patient
text: Of course. Go ahead.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you currently smoke?

speaker: patient
text: No, I finally stopped smoking cigarettes.

speaker: doctor
text: Did you smoke before?

speaker: patient
text: I did. I smoked a half a pack for about twenty years.

speaker: doctor
text: Well, it's good to hear that you've stopped. I encourage you to continue to not smoke.

speaker: patient
text: I agree. I need to change up my lifestyle.

speaker: doctor
text: Last question. Do you drink alcohol?

speaker: patient
text: No, I don't. I don't like anything that has alcohol. I can't stand the taste of it. If I do it is rare.

speaker: doctor
text: Hello, sir. So, remind me, how long ago was your procedure?

speaker: patient
text: Let me think. Now, it's been about four months. I just turned fifty nine.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, and just to refresh your memory, we did a percutaneous screw fixation of a Schatzker I V tibial plateau fracture, and we've managed those toe fractures nonoperatively.

speaker: patient
text: Which toes did I break?

speaker: doctor
text: You broke your second and fifth toes.

speaker: patient
text: Do you have the x rays? Can I see where the breaks are?

speaker: doctor
text: Absolutely, if you look here, right here is where the breaks are. These are called the metatarsal heads.

speaker: patient
text: Wow, that's right where it hurts.

speaker: doctor
text: Yep, and where are you living now?

speaker: patient
text: Thankfully, I left the nursing home, and I'm back in my own house now.

speaker: doctor
text: That's really good. Are you in any pain today?

speaker: patient
text: No, not today.

speaker: doctor
text: Great, have you been going to P T?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I've been going about two or three times a week.

speaker: doctor
text: Are there any signs of infection, like drainage from the incision?

speaker: patient
text: Nope, the wound healed up nicely. I'll be able to wear shorts again.

speaker: doctor
text: Great, are you having any fever symptoms, like cough, runny nose, sore throat, fatigue, anything like that?

speaker: patient
text: No, but I have had some tingling in both my feet. I don't know if its related to surgery. If I'm remembering the names right, um, I have a history of spinal stenosis and neuropathy in my legs.

speaker: doctor
text: With your history of spinal stenosis, the broken toes, and the surgery, that's a pretty normal side effect.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you currently smoke? Or did you smoke in the past?

speaker: patient
text: Quit in nineteen seventy two.

speaker: doctor
text: Great to hear. Are you working right now?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I work at a nursing home.

speaker: doctor
text: Does your job allow you to take time for yourself?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, my job is very supportive. I've actually been trying to lose weight. So far, I've lost a good amount since starting a new diet several months back.

speaker: doctor
text: Hello. Are you ready for your surgery today?

speaker: patient
text: Can we reschedule? I'm too scared to do it.

speaker: doctor
text: It'll be fine. Don't worry too much about it. Have you ever had a surgery before?

speaker: patient
text: Never. What if something goes wrong?

speaker: doctor
text: You have nothing to worry about. I've done this procedure multiple times, and everyone was fine after.

speaker: patient
text: Thank you, Doctor. Let's get started then.

speaker: doctor
text: What is your family medical history?

speaker: patient
text: I don't really remember anyone having any major health problems.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

speaker: patient
text: Everyone is pretty healthy.

speaker: doctor
text: That is fortunate.

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, it is.

speaker: doctor
text: How's it going? I haven't seen you in a long time.

speaker: patient
text: Hey, Doctor. My headaches have been getting worse.

speaker: doctor
text: Remind me again. Does you family have a history of migraines.

speaker: patient
text: I don't think so.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay. Let's perform some tests.

speaker: doctor
text: Hello, this is your follow up visit, right? Welcome back! Have you been taking your Plaquenil for lupus, ma'am?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I am.

speaker: doctor
text: Your prescription is two hundred M G twice a day, correct?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, that's it.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have your eye report with you today?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, doctor. Here you go.

speaker: doctor
text: Good, thank you, what seems to be the problem today?

speaker: patient
text: Well, I'm having some aches and pains in my hands and elbows.

speaker: doctor
text: When did this pain start?

speaker: patient
text: It's been a few weeks now.

speaker: doctor
text: Is there any associated trauma? Did you fall?

speaker: patient
text: No, no falls or anything. It just started one day, and it's really bothering me.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you having any fever or chills, or cold or flu like symptoms?

speaker: patient
text: No, I'm not.

speaker: doctor
text: How about swelling? Are any of your joints swollen?

speaker: patient
text: No, everything is normal there. Of note, I have been losing a lot of hair recently.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, that's interesting.

speaker: doctor
text: So, I know you're technically not allowed to drink, but I'm required to ask this anyway. Do you drink at all?

speaker: patient
text: No, actually. I try to steer clear of drinking while training for my marathon.

speaker: doctor
text: When is that by the way?

speaker: patient
text: Next summer.

speaker: doctor
text: Wow, good luck. It'll be yet another big accomplishment.

speaker: patient
text: Thank you.

speaker: doctor
text: And how about smoking of any kind?

speaker: patient
text: Nope.

speaker: doctor
text: Welcome in.

speaker: patient
text: Thank you.

speaker: doctor
text: Let us start with your family medical history.

speaker: patient
text: I have a lot of diabetes in the family.

speaker: doctor
text: Who has diabetes?

speaker: patient
text: My father had diabetes. He passed away.

speaker: doctor
text: I am so sorry. How did he pass away?

speaker: patient
text: He had cancer. He actually had breast cancer.

speaker: doctor
text: That is incredibly rare. Is your mother still with us?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, she is. She just had her eighty ninth birthday. Next year we are going to plan a big birthday bash for her.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any siblings?

speaker: patient
text: Yes. I have a sister. She has diabetes too.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you know of any family members with neurological disorders such as M S, epilepsy, or Huntington's?

speaker: patient
text: No. I don't know of anything like that.

speaker: doctor
text: How're your other children doing?

speaker: doctor
text: For the same?

speaker: doctor
text: Your hands are full then.

speaker: doctor
text: It's definitely been a tough winter for you and your family.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you use tobacco or other drugs?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you drink?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Is this your mother with you today?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, this is my mommy.

speaker: doctor
text: Great, welcome, what did you do this this ankle, young lady?

speaker: patient
text: Well, I was running when I twisted my ankle.

speaker: doctor
