text: Which ankle did you twist?

speaker: patient
text: It was my right ankle.

speaker: doctor
text: Where does it hurt the worst?

speaker: patient
text: Right here, on the outside of my ankle.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have a primary care physician?

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any other injuries to speak of?

speaker: patient
text: No, it's just my ankle really.

speaker: doctor
text: Good afternoon, young lady.

speaker: patient
text: Hello, doctor.

speaker: doctor
text: What grade are you in, young lady?

speaker: patient
text: I'm in middle school, um, I'm in the eighth grade.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you play any sports?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I love to play basketball.

speaker: doctor
text: Good, are both of your parents at home?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I live with my mom and dad.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any siblings?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I have a little brother, um, he's nine now.

speaker: doctor
text: Great, have you started your periods?

speaker: patient
text: Um, yes, my first one was in September.

speaker: doctor
text: How many children do you have, ma'am?

speaker: patient
text: I was blessed with four beautiful children.

speaker: doctor
text: That's wonderful. Did you have any complications with the pregnancies?

speaker: patient
text: Actually, I had two c sections for both of my sons.

speaker: patient
text: I'm right handed.

speaker: doctor
text: Tell me what brings you here, sir?

speaker: patient
text: I'm having these cramps in my feet, in my hand and I just wanted to get checked. It has been happening for like six months. I develop muscle contractions in my toes and both feet. It only happens in night.

speaker: doctor
text: How frequent is it?

speaker: patient
text: Around three times a week.

speaker: doctor
text: What do you do when you have these cramps?

speaker: patient
text: I try to stand and it helps me relieve some of the discomfort. I noticed my toes are kind of extended. Whenever I step on the ground, it seems to pop into place. With all these cramps, I've started having pain in my calf. Sometimes because of that I could not sleep, or it wakes me up in the night. Similar to my toes, these cramps have also started coming up in my hands. They are not that strong or frequent. They're completely random and not in the nighttime. Sometimes my thumb gets so flexed that I have to move it to bring it to the right position and to relieve the cramp.

speaker: doctor
text: Did you ever have this symptom before?

speaker: patient
text: No, not like this.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you taking any medications?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I took an antibacterial called Bactrim around nine months ago. I was taking it briefly before, but now I'm taking it consistently. I cannot think of anything that is causing it.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any other medical condition?

speaker: patient
text: I have H I V for the last twenty one years and I was taking antiretroviral medications for it. I stopped those medications around six or seven years ago.

speaker: doctor
text: Why did you stop the medications?

speaker: patient
text: I could not tolerate them. They were making my stomach weak.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you know your C D four count?

speaker: patient
text: It was three hundred and twenty six. I never developed autoimmune deficiency syndrome. I think I should restart my medicines.

speaker: doctor
text: So, this is your follow up? How are you doing so far with Lamictal?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, it's the follow up. Lamictal was okay. There was no side effect with that. But I had twitching in my muscles a lot of times. It was not generalized, but I was very afraid that this will happen.

speaker: doctor
text: What time of day was it? That you had these episodes.

speaker: patient
text: Mostly in the mornings.

speaker: doctor
text: I have your recent E E G report. It did show multiple spikes and some complexes on both the sides, but it is more prominent on left.

speaker: patient
text: I have been taking my medications very regularly and  I was getting a good amount of sleep as well.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you able to drive?

speaker: patient
text: Yes.

speaker: doctor
text: Is there any change in your social history or any other symptoms that arise or, or is it same as before?

speaker: patient
text: Looks same to me.

speaker: doctor
text: What types of surgeries have you had in the past?

speaker: patient
text: I had gall bladder and appendix surgery then they also took out my ovaries.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you had any surgeries in the past?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I have, I actually had it to repair an undescended testicle.

speaker: doctor
text: Oh, wow, do you remember it at all?

speaker: patient
text: No, nothing about it, I had that done when I was a baby.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you smoke cigarettes?

speaker: patient
text: I don't smoke cigarettes but I do have one on a rare occasion.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you drink alcohol or use any recreational drugs?

speaker: patient
text: I don't drink but I do occasionally smoke weed.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you smoke or drink?

speaker: patient
text: No, neither.

speaker: doctor
text: Any history of drug abuse?

speaker: patient
text: No, I have never used any illegal drugs in my life.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: Yes. I suspect they have possible C M V pneumonitis as well.

speaker: doctor
text: Yes. They have polymyositis and they're taking Prednisone and Methotrexate.

speaker: doctor
text: Alright we already spoke about your past medical history, anything else you might want to add?

speaker: doctor
text: Depression? I don't think we spoke about that.

speaker: patient
text: Yeah we didn't, it slipped out of my mind.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, let me make a note of it.

speaker: doctor
text: How are you?

speaker: patient
text: Not good.

speaker: doctor
text: What brings you here today?

speaker: patient
text: This ulcer in my ankle is just not healing.

speaker: doctor
text: Is it on both sides?

speaker: patient
text: No, just on the right side.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you remember the details of your surgery, sir?

speaker: patient
text: No, can you remind me?

speaker: doctor
text: We did a left inguinal hernia repair.

speaker: patient
text: Thank you for reminding me.

speaker: doctor
text: You have a history of prostate cancer as well, correct?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, they said it was Gleason, um, three plus four.

speaker: doctor
text: Yes, that sounds familiar. What medicines are you taking right now?

speaker: patient
text: I'm taking Lupron, currently.

speaker: doctor
text: How many people do you have in your family?

speaker: patient
text: Well, I have four children, all healthy with no medical conditions.

speaker: doctor
text: Wow, that's great!

speaker: patient
text: My father passed away at the age of sixty nine due to C V A. And my mom died exactly ten years later, her heart just suddenly stopped. She was seventy nine.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay. And do you have siblings?

speaker: patient
text: Well, believe it or not I had eleven siblings, including me twelve.

speaker: doctor
text: Wow!

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I lost six of them. Four of them to diabetes, one of my brothers passed away at the age of seventy two and we could never determine the reason my sister died.

speaker: doctor
text: Hm okay.

speaker: doctor
text: You are referred for some abdominal infection right?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, they told me I might have C Diff?

speaker: doctor
text: Yes that's what we will evaluate you for.

speaker: doctor
text: Hi, how are you doing? How old are you?

speaker: patient
text: I am good, how are you? I am seventy two years old.

speaker: doctor
text: Good. How can I help?

speaker: patient
text: Actually, there is a wooden splinter stuck beneath my left fifth fingernail. I am an American farmer by blood, so this has happened before.

speaker: doctor
text: Oh, when did this happen, sir?

speaker: patient
text: Yesterday evening around four P M.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, then what did you do?

speaker: patient
text: Then I tried to remove it with tweezers at home, but it did not come out. So, I want you to remove this.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay let me see.

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, here.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay. Can you tell me when the last time you had a tetanus shot?

speaker: patient
text: Oh it's been so long. I would say it has been over ten years since I have had any tetanus shot.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay and are you allergic to anything?

speaker: patient
text: Oh yes. I am allergic to horse serum. I think it is added in vaccinations?

speaker: doctor
text: Oh, okay.

speaker: patient
text: But I don't want any tetanus vaccine now.

speaker: doctor
text: Oh! But you need it.

speaker: patient
text: I know, but I get a bad reaction to vaccines so I don't want it.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay. let me fine some alternative.

speaker: patient
text: Thanks.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you had a recent vaccination?

speaker: patient
text: I had a flu shot last winter but I have not had and recent vaccines.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any planned in the near future?

speaker: patient
text: I was going to get another flu shot but I don't think I am due for that for another three months.

speaker: doctor
text: Great.

speaker: doctor
text: How old are you?

speaker: patient
text: Seventy one.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you right handed or left handed?

speaker: patient
text: Right handed.

speaker: doctor
text: What exactly happened?

speaker: patient
text: I, I had this bad headache on fifth of November and then I had a big sneeze, like it was too loud. I had-- it was going on for like three to four days. Then, on the seventh, I had this severe pain over my left eye and I kind of lost my vision there.

speaker: doctor
text: When did you see changes in your eyelid?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, on the following day, it seemed like swelling and then my eyelid, it began like pulling down and getting down. Kind of drooping. We went to a local doctor, and he did some x rays.

speaker: doctor
text: Yeah, I have your brain C T report from there. There is no sign of any kind of bleeding, but I do see a torturous blood vessel there.

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, after looking at this report they transferred us here to the U I H C on the twelfth.

speaker: doctor
text: I see here that you're in for a med refill. Is that correct?

speaker: patient
text: Yep. I ran out of Klonopin one or two days ago.

speaker: doctor
text: What are you taking it for? And how long have you been on it?

speaker: patient
text: Panic attacks. I have really bad episodes without it. Um I think I started it about four months ago. I could be wrong though. I've lost track of time.

speaker: doctor
text: Who usually prescribes it to you?

speaker: patient
text: My doctor back in Georgia.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you happen to have their name or contact info on hand?

speaker: patient
text: No, unfortunately.

speaker: doctor
text: How much Klonopin do you take for your panic attacks?

speaker: patient
text: I take a pretty low dose. I think I'm on zero point five milligrams a day. Is there any way you could verify the dosage?

speaker: doctor
text: I can try to look it up online. When were you last prescribed Klonopin?

speaker: patient
text: Over two months ago I think.

speaker: doctor
text: Let me pull up the page and see if we can figure out your dosage and when you're due for a refill based on your doctor's orders.

speaker: patient
text: Okay, thank you.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you experiencing any symptoms currently, such as headache, nausea, vomiting, shortness of breath or chest pain?

speaker: patient
text: Not right now, no. I did have some nausea yesterday. Oh and I guess I had a slight headache when I woke up this morning, but that's about it.

speaker: doctor
text: How are you? I haven't seen you in a long time.

speaker: patient
text: I'm doing fine. I hurt my hand the other day.

speaker: doctor
text: How did that happen?

speaker: patient
text: My husband and I moved into our new home, and we were building a desk. I tried to nail something in, and I hammered my hand.

speaker: doctor
text: Oh, no. So, you and your husband live together now?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah. We do. We just got married.

speaker: patient
text: Man, what a night.

speaker: doctor
text: What kind of car were you driving that night?

speaker: patient
text: I was driving my small sports car through an intersection when another car hit me from the left side. The impact forced my car off the road and into a utility pole.

speaker: doctor
text: I'm so sorry to hear that. I'm glad that you are here in one piece. Were you wearing your seatbelt?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I had my belt on and everything.

speaker: doctor
text: Good.

speaker: patient
text: Unfortunately, the driver was drunk and ran a traffic signal.

speaker: doctor
text: That's such a shame. Do you remember how fast the car was going when it collided into you?

speaker: patient
text: If I had to guess maybe eighty miles per hour. It looks like the driver who hit me was already cited by police.

speaker: doctor
text: Did you lose consciousness at all?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I briefly lost consciousness when help arrived at the scene. I felt an immediate headache when I regained consciousness. I also had lower back and neck pain.

speaker: doctor
text: Did you get out of the car by yourself?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I got out by myself. Once I made it out, the Rescue Squad drove me to Saint Thomas Memorial Hospital. I was seen in the emergency room and later discharged.

speaker: doctor
text: This was on January fifteenth, correct?

speaker: patient
text: Yessir.

speaker: doctor
text: How're you doing?

speaker: patient
text: Good for the most part. I'm still pretty tired most days, but I'm trying to stay more active. I'm wondering if it has to do with my sugar levels?

speaker: doctor
text: Hm let's see. I'd like to check your glucose and lipid panels and get you back in here again.

speaker: patient
text: And oh I've noticed some blood in my stool. I'm not sure if it's related.

speaker: doctor
text: How long has that been going on?

speaker: patient
text: Maybe a week or so?

speaker: doctor
text: Are you having any other symptoms? Black or tarry stool? Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea? Lightheadedness?

speaker: patient
text: No, none of that.

speaker: doctor
text: I'd like to order a hemoccult then. It's going to check to see if you're still having blood in your stool.

speaker: patient
text: Can I do this at the blood work place?

speaker: doctor
text: Yes, they'll be able to help you and answer any additional questions you may have.

speaker: patient
text: Okay. I'll try to go in tomorrow.

speaker: doctor
text: Remember you need to fast for the lipid panel, so I'd recommend going in early tomorrow morning before eating breakfast.

speaker: patient
text: Okay, got it.

speaker: doctor
text: And before I send you on your way, have you been able to schedule your yearly mammogram?

speaker: patient
text: Oh shoot. I still need to do that. I'll call them tomorrow.

speaker: doctor
text: Hello, ma'am. How are you doing?

speaker: patient
text: My knees hurt. They've been slowly getting worse each year. Life's getting hard at seventy two.

speaker: doctor
text: I'm sorry to hear that. Have you always had knee pain?

speaker: patient
text: I have. Both knees are messed up.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you able to do any activities still?

speaker: patient
text: Nope. I just sit all day.

speaker: doctor
text: I see. We can offer to do arthroplasty to fix your knees.

speaker: patient
text: What's that?

speaker: doctor
text: It's like a reconstruction of your joints. It'll help increase your ability to do daily activities.

speaker: patient
text: I'm up for it. I need to get my life going.

speaker: doctor
text: Sounds great. I just want to confirm some information. Would you say your quality of life and daily activities is decreasing?

speaker: patient
text: Oh, yeah. These knees are making my life terrible.

speaker: doctor
text: How's he doing?

speaker: doctor
text: How long has it been since you noticed any behavioral changes?

speaker: doctor
text: Is he complaining of any pain?

speaker: doctor
text: He's been?

speaker: doctor
text: No problem.

speaker: doctor
text: Is he having any other symptoms?

speaker: doctor
text: Any vomiting with the nausea?

speaker: doctor
text: Good morning, sir. Remind me please, when was your surgery?

speaker: patient
text: Hello, doctor. It was about a week ago now.

speaker: doctor
text: Great, and just to remind you, you had a removal of Ex Fix from the right knee with an M U A following O R I F of a right tibial plateau fracture.

speaker: patient
text: Yes, that all sounds familiar. What's M U A?

speaker: doctor
text: It stands for manipulation under anesthesia. We bent the knee in order to forcibly break up some scar tissue.

speaker: patient
text: Oh, wow.

speaker: doctor
text: Yeah, it's great, eliminates some need for P T in fact. How are you doing today?

speaker: patient
text: Overall, my pain is under control.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you having any flu like, or infection symptoms?

speaker: patient
text: No, nothing like that at all.

speaker: doctor
text: So, no fever, or chills, or sweating at night.

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, nothing like that.

speaker: doctor
text: Great. I see you're having some drainage from the pin sites, but that doesn't bother me too much.

speaker: patient
text: Okay, good. I was getting worried.

speaker: doctor
text: No need to worry. Are you doing your range of motion exercises? Those are imperative.

speaker: patient
text: Yes, doctor. I am.

speaker: doctor
text: Good, and do you have any numbness or tingling?

speaker: patient
text: No, doctor. I don't have any of that.

speaker: doctor
text: Hi, how are you doing?

speaker: patient
text: I'm good. Thank you.

speaker: doctor
text: How old are you, young lady?

speaker: patient
text: Eighty four.

speaker: doctor
text: What brings you here?

speaker: patient
text: I had a fall. And I was told to consult you for my heart conditions.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay. Um? Can you tell me a little detail about anything you experienced before or diagnosed before?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I have high blood pressure. And they also diagnosed me with other heart diseases. I cannot pronounce all the names I don't remember.

speaker: doctor
text: That's fine. Let me go through your medical record first.

speaker: doctor
text: Let's see what we have here. Looks like you have your plate full. Your record says you had hypertension I mean, high blood pressure. Also, you have a history of severe tricuspid regurgitation with mild pulmonary hypertension, mild aortic stenosis, and previously moderate mitral regurgitation.

speaker: patient
text: Wow! Those are a lot of fancy words that I can never remember.

speaker: doctor
text: Ha ha. So, it says here they they want me to check you for atrial fibrillation. Yet another fancy word to add to your list.

speaker: patient
text: What does it mean?

speaker: doctor
text: It means I must check if you have faster than normal heartbeat after your fall. In simple words, just to check if there are any irregularities in your heart beating, okay?

speaker: patient
text: Hm, okay.

speaker: doctor
text: So tell me what happened? How did you fall?

speaker: patient
text: I'm not sure about how it happened, but yeah, I fell yesterday on my driveway and kind of hit a rock.

speaker: doctor
text: Which side did you hit the rock?

speaker: patient
text: Um I think it was left side.

speaker: doctor
text: What happened in the emergency room?

speaker: patient
text: They gave me some medicine. And they put something on my finger. They said that my heart rate was very high.

speaker: doctor
text: Yeah, in the record it says that they found rapid atrial tachyarrhythmia. So, according to this, they have given you Cardizem and they stopped it when your heart rate came to fifties.

speaker: doctor
text: Let me review your electrocardiogram from emergency. It says that there was rapid heart rate. Your heart was really beating very fast and then there was one more electrocardiogram which showed that your pacemaker is acting weird.

speaker: patient
text: They also did the same test this morning.

speaker: doctor
text: One they did this morning shows normal rate with frequent early heartbeats. Looks like they also tested your blood. Your potassium level is three point one.

speaker: doctor
text: How was your heart feeling when you fell yesterday?

speaker: patient
text: I felt that I just ran in a race. I could feel all the pain after that fall. It was ugly. My heart was pounding so fast it was ready to come out, I never felt like that before in my life.

speaker: doctor
text: Did you feel the same way afterwards as well?

speaker: patient
text: No, it was just after fall. It did not stay like that for long, I was normal later. I never felt it again after that incident.

speaker: doctor
text: That is good. Do you have any pain or discomfort in your chest?

speaker: patient
text: I don't think so.

speaker: doctor
text: How about before the fall? Did you have any pain or discomfort in your chest before the fall?

speaker: patient
text: Nope.

speaker: doctor
text: how about shortness of breath?

speaker: patient
text: No, not even before the fall. I'm able to walk and I'm sure I can climb stairs. Maybe two floors without any problems.

speaker: doctor
text: So just a few quick questions before we wrap up. Do you smoke or drink?

speaker: patient
text: I drink sometimes. I've never smoked.

speaker: doctor
text: Any drug use?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you sexually active?

speaker: patient
text: Uh I was back in Haiti, but that was back in eighty two. I had several male partners, but no sex since moving here.

speaker: doctor
text: Did you use protection in your previous encounters?

speaker: patient
text: Most of the time, yes.

speaker: doctor
text: Any history of S T Ds?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you currently working?

speaker: patient
text: Yep. I work for a car dealership down the street.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you taking any medications for your pain?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, occasionally.

speaker: doctor
text: Which one?

speaker: patient
text: Just a regular pain medicine.

speaker: doctor
text: Good morning, sir, I hear you're a patient of Doctor A.

speaker: patient
text: Yes, that's correct.

speaker: doctor
text: Did she refer you to me?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I'm fifty five, so I'm not too young anymore, but I have developed iron deficiency anemia with blood in my stool. At least, that's what she's told me so far.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you having diarrhea?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I am.

speaker: doctor
text: How would you describe the frequency?

speaker: patient
text: I'd say it's chronic at this point.

speaker: doctor
text: How long have you known you have anemia?

speaker: patient
text: Um, it's been a few months now.

speaker: doctor
text: What markers were evaluated in order to diagnose this?

speaker: patient
text: I had, um, an unusual pruritus, and I had a C B C.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have the results of that?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, right here.

speaker: doctor
text: Thank you, so this shows a hemoglobin of nine, and M C V of sixty five.

speaker: patient
text: Are those high?

speaker: doctor
text: Well, actually, both of those are low.

speaker: patient
text: Oh, okay.

speaker: doctor
text: How long have you had blood in your stool?

speaker: patient
text: Um, it's been about five months now.

speaker: doctor
text: What has the color been like?

speaker: patient
text: Well, it's been both dark and bright blood, actually?

speaker: doctor
text: When was your last colonoscopy?

speaker: patient
text: It was about three years ago, I had it with Doctor X. I did it in Las Cruces.

speaker: doctor
text: Was there any abnormality found?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I had polyps removed.

speaker: doctor
text: Were those polyps evaluated?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, the doctors said they were, um, hyperplastic. They diagnosed me with, um, lymphocytic colitis.

speaker: doctor
text: I see, when was the last time you were treated for diarrhea?

speaker: patient
text: At this point, it's been more than three years.

speaker: doctor
text: Good afternoon, before we begin, what are your pronouns?

speaker: patient
text: I identify as a female, and I use she her pronouns.

speaker: doctor
text: Thank you, so, have you ever had surgery?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I actually have a list of them written down.

speaker: doctor
text: That's really helpful, may I see it?

speaker: patient
text: Absolutely, here you go.

speaker: doctor
text: Thank you. So I see you've had a multiple bowel surgeries, including, um, a hysterectomy, rectocele repair, and an appendectomy. Do all of those sound familiar.

speaker: patient
text: Yep, I got this list from all of the surgeons.

speaker: doctor
text: Are there any other major conditions I should be aware of?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, actually, I have another list, um, I have polymyalgia rheumatica.

speaker: doctor
text: That's all great information to know, thank you very much.

speaker: doctor
text: Hello Mister Strange, can you please confirm your age and ethnicity for the records.

speaker: patient
text: Hi Doctor, I am fifty five now and would identify myself as a white male.

speaker: doctor
text: Let's first talk about your medical condition. There has been a diagnosis of polycythemia vera with secondary myelofibrosis. Also, you are J A K two positive. Do you remember when you were diagnosed?

speaker: patient
text: It was sometimes between two thousand and five and six.

speaker: doctor
text: They did phlebotomy and then subsequently you got yourself transferred here in our healthcare.

speaker: patient
text: Yes.

speaker: doctor
text: You have been on hydroxyurea and interferon, right?

speaker: patient
text: Oh, it was a terrible time, I could not deal with anyone of them. I had numbness and tingling with burning pain in my hands.

speaker: doctor
text: You do not have any siblings that we can try for transplant match?

speaker: patient
text: That's right!

speaker: doctor
text: You were also considered for the Matched Unrelated Donor Transplant, but you couldn't be on the list due to social support and also health was in reasonably better state than other candidates normally on that transplant list.

speaker: patient
text: We had some medications here as well when I first started my care here, I forgot the name.

speaker: doctor
text: Yes, here we started you on a trial of lenalidomide and prednisone for some time. You were doing great on that for a while, but then you developed intolerance to lenalidomide.

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I had severe diarrhea and I always felt tired like I have no energy left in me. Eventually it all stopped.

speaker: doctor
text: Yeah, here it says that you injured your leg? Tell me what happened.

speaker: patient
text: It all happened last week, I injured this left leg and got swelling. I had some prescribed steroids, so I took them for about three days only. The swelling is eventually gone now.

speaker: doctor
text: Any other related complaints?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you smoke or drink?

speaker: patient
text: I take marijuana. I feel really hungry after smoking it, so I eat a lot. In just the last few weeks I have gained a few pounds.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, your overall performance status in the E C O G scale is one.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any family history of neurological disorders, such as multiple sclerosis, Parkinson's or dementia?

speaker: patient
text: Nope. Fortunately, no one in my family has neurological problems.

speaker: doctor
text: How long have you had this rash?

speaker: patient
text: Not long. Less than a day if I had to guess.

speaker: doctor
text: Is it causing you any pain?

speaker: patient
text: No, it's just really itchy. I tried applying Cortisone to it, but it didn't help much.

speaker: doctor
text: Is the rash localized to the left arm?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah. I've only noticed it on my left arm.

speaker: doctor
text: Hello. How are you both doing today?

speaker: doctor
text: I see. Did he have a fracture before?

speaker: doctor
text: Great. Let me take a look. It looks like he had a distracted left lateral condyle fracture. He then underwent screw compression to fix the fracture, correct?

speaker: doctor
text: Perfect. So, now we just have to remove the hardware that was used to fix the fracture, right?

speaker: doctor
text: The risks include the risk of anesthesia, infection, bleeding, changes in sensation and motion of extremity, failure of removal of hardware, failure to relieve pain or improved range of motion.

speaker: doctor
text: Of course. Before I do, I just need to confirm your son's age.

speaker: patient
text: Hi. I'm five years old. My birthday is in four months.

speaker: doctor
text: Thank you. Happy almost birthday.

speaker: doctor
text: I am looking at her x ray report and she had a sternotomy in the past.

speaker: doctor
text: Oh I see!

speaker: doctor
text: What happened to your right leg?

speaker: patient
text: I had a little accident with a dog, he bit me. I got really scared.

speaker: doctor
text: Don't worry we will take care of this.

speaker: doctor
text: We've been following you for several conditions for a while now. What seems to be the problem today, sir?

speaker: patient
text: Um, I was peeing blood, it's back again.

speaker: doctor
text: Did you do anything that could have provoked it to come back?

speaker: patient
text: No, not that I know of.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you been taking the Flomax for your B P H?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I have been.

speaker: doctor
text: What about the Coumadin?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I've been taking that too. It has been held recently, but I ususally take it.

speaker: doctor
text: Remind me, I don't have my chart with me. What conditions have you been taking the Coumadin for?

speaker: patient
text: I have A F I B and stroke.

speaker: doctor
text: Thank you. Isn't this your second occurrence of gross hematuria this month?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, doctor.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you sure you haven't experienced any falls or anything recently?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, actually I fell about a week ago.

speaker: doctor
text: Where is your pain from that fall?

speaker: patient
text: It's in my butt and leg.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you had your x rays taken yet?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, the x ray tech just brought me back.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, these x rays of the hips, knees, and ankles show severe degeneration in all areas.

speaker: patient
text: What does that mean, doctor?

speaker: doctor
text: I see some pretty significant arthritis in these areas.

speaker: patient
text: Can you tell me some good news, please?

speaker: doctor
text: Well, I don't see any fractures.

speaker: patient
text: I guess that's something.

speaker: doctor
text: When is your pain worst?

speaker: patient
text: It's so severe, and it's worst first thing in the morning.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, I know you are, but be sure to keep taking the Coumadin, that helps with the stroke and A F I B.

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I will. I'm having problems with my sinuses today too. Can I get some nasal spray too?

speaker: doctor
text: Good morning.

speaker: patient
text: Good morning, Doctor.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you married?

speaker: patient
text: No sir, I'm happily single.

speaker: doctor
text: Good for you, what do you do for a living?

speaker: patient
text: I'm actually not working right now, I go to college full time.

speaker: doctor
text: Even better for you, so do you drink or smoke?

speaker: patient
text: No, I don't.

speaker: doctor
text: What about more illicit substances?

speaker: patient
text: Absolutely not, nothing like that.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you like to work out?

speaker: patient
text: I play tennis and swim every week, I love it.

speaker: doctor
text: That's very good, you're keeping very healthy.

speaker: doctor
text: Has anyone in your family suffered from dementia?

speaker: patient
text: Not that I'm aware of.

speaker: doctor
text: Is there any other medical history in your family? Any other medical issues?

speaker: patient
text: My mom died of a stroke.

speaker: doctor
text: How old was your mom when she died?

speaker: patient
text: She was sixty two.

speaker: doctor
text: When was the last time you had a cigarette?

speaker: patient
text: Seventeen years back.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, and how much did you used to smoke?

speaker: patient
text: About one pack per day. I smoked for forty four years.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, how about any I V drugs?

speaker: patient
text: No I have not done that.

speaker: doctor
text: What brings this little guy in today?

speaker: doctor
text: Sorry to hear that. Did he have a fever?

speaker: doctor
text: And did you give him anything for the fever?

speaker: doctor
text: I see. And how has he felt otherwise?

speaker: doctor
text: Has he been coughing at all?

speaker: doctor
text: Any shortness of breath?

speaker: doctor
text: How about any episodes of vomiting, diarrhea, or stomach pain?

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any major medical conditions that I should know about, sir?

speaker: patient
text: Maybe, I might. What exactly do you mean by that, doctor?

speaker: doctor
text: Well, it's broad, but it could be anything from depression to high blood pressure, to cancer.

speaker: patient
text: Okay, that's what I thought. I have high blood pressure.

speaker: doctor
text: What about your mental health, is there anything of note there?

speaker: patient
text: Um, yeah, I have anxiety, too.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you a student?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I am. I go to the University.

speaker: doctor
text: What are you majoring in? Or do you know yet?

speaker: patient
text: Yes! I am studying biology.

speaker: doctor
text: Excellent! Do you live in the dorms?

speaker: patient
text: Yes.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you from the area?

speaker: patient
text: I am from Breckenridge. That is where my parents live.

speaker: doctor
text: That is a beautiful place to be from. Do you use any tobacco, alcohol, or recreational drugs?

speaker: patient
text: I have smoked weed with friends, off and on but not much. I have a few beers at the occasional dorm party.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any history of surgical procedures?

speaker: patient
text: No, none.

speaker: doctor
text: Hello Hello!

speaker: patient
text: Hi there, how are you? I have a bad headache so can you please switch off the lights, it's too bright and uncomfortable.

speaker: doctor
text: Sure thing. Let's see what is going on here. How about that?

speaker: patient
text: Much better.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, let's talk about your family history.

speaker: patient
text: Oh, I have very disturbing family history!

speaker: doctor
text: Why do you say so?

speaker: patient
text: Well, my mother passed away due to heart attack in her late sixties and my father had liver cancer and he passed away from that.

speaker: doctor
text: Oh-

speaker: patient
text: Oh, that is not all. My one son suffers from hypothyroidism and my daughter's two kids have cerebral palsy from being born prematurely.

speaker: doctor
text: Oh, that is so unfortunate.

speaker: patient
text: Yeah.

speaker: patient
text: Hey, man.

speaker: doctor
text: Hey, how's it going? It's been a while.

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, it's been a while that's for sure.

speaker: doctor
text: So anything new I should know of?

speaker: patient
text: Uh I had some stuff on my chest that I saw a dermatologist for.

speaker: doctor
text: What type of stuff?

speaker: patient
text: I think they were cysts.

speaker: doctor
text: Any cause for concern?

speaker: patient
text: Nah, the dermatologist said everything came back alright.

speaker: doctor
text: Glad to hear that.

speaker: patient
text: Me too. I'm actually here to see if you can write me up a P P D slip.

speaker: doctor
text: Is this for a job?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, my last one was negative, but I need to get another one. Last one I did was in nineteen ninety four.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you notied her behaving strangly in any way?

speaker: doctor
text: Has she been gagging, coughing, vomiting or any other symptoms?

speaker: doctor
text: Did you see her ingest any of the fluid?

speaker: doctor
text: Any past medical problems I should know of?

speaker: patient
text: No, ma'am. I am forty three and this is the first time I have had a major issue. It's only been this past month where I've felt weaker than usual. I'm much more tired and short of breath whenever I move around.

speaker: doctor
text: Any recent weight loss?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I actually lost about fifteen pounds in less than two or three months.

speaker: doctor
text: How's your appetite? Any nausea, vomiting, diarrhea?

speaker: patient
text: Appetite is pretty fine. No nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea.

speaker: doctor
text: How about fever, chills, sweats, cough?

speaker: patient
text: No, ma'am.

speaker: doctor
text: And any chest pain with your shortness of breath?

speaker: patient
text: No, ma'am.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any allergies?

speaker: patient
text: No I do not.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you sure?

speaker: patient
text: Yes I am.

speaker: doctor
text: What is your family medical history?

speaker: patient
text: Nothing that I know of.

speaker: doctor
text: Did you have a full term delivery?

speaker: doctor
text: Was he hospitalized?

speaker: doctor
text: Was he on any machine like the ones that help breathing?

speaker: doctor
text: Was he ever hospitalized afterwards?

speaker: doctor
text: Did he have any surgery?

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any allergies?

speaker: patient
text: No I do not.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

speaker: patient
text: Okay.

speaker: patient
text: Are you only asking for medical allergies?

speaker: doctor
text: No, I want to know about all allergies.

speaker: doctor
text: Anyone smokes in the house?

speaker: doctor
text: Both of you?

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you use any tobacco, inhalation or recreational drugs?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: How're you feeling today?

speaker: patient
text: Not great.

speaker: doctor
text: I'm sorry, why is that?

speaker: patient
text: I've had a headache all week along with neck and lower back pain.

speaker: doctor
text: How would you describe the headache?

speaker: patient
text: Throbbing pain.

speaker: doctor
text: Is it constant?

speaker: patient
text: It comes and goes for the most part.

speaker: doctor
text: How would you rate it on a scale of ten with ten being the worst?

speaker: patient
text: A seven or eight.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have a headache currently?

speaker: patient
text: No, not right this second.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you taken-

speaker: patient
text: Anything for the pain?

speaker: doctor
text: Yes.

speaker: patient
text: I took some Ibuprofen, but it doesn't seem to be helping much.

speaker: doctor
text: Any other symptoms associated with the headache, such as fever, chills, nausea, vomiting, blurred vision, or sensitivity to light?

speaker: patient
text: No, not really. I don't feel like I have a cold or anything.

speaker: doctor
text: Any recent injuries to the head?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: And your neck and lower back pain, is this new?

speaker: patient
text: Eh I can't say. It's been bothering me for some time now, but the pain feels a bit different.

speaker: doctor
text: How so?

speaker: patient
text: I don't really know. It's more pronounced.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any other problems?

speaker: patient
text: I do actually, I have back disc degeneration.

speaker: doctor
text: Oh really?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah.

speaker: doctor
text: When were you diagnosed with it?

speaker: patient
text: Maybe twenty ten?

speaker: doctor
text: Any family history of disease?

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any history of surgical procedures?

speaker: patient
text: I remember having surgery as a child, but I don't know what the surgery was for. It was so long ago.

speaker: doctor
text: Who all are there in your family?

speaker: patient
text: Well, it's just me and my brother now. My mom passed away due to stroke at the age of seventy nine.

speaker: patient
text: My father had a good life with no medical conditions. He passed away due to old age, he was ninety one.

speaker: doctor
text: Wow! Any family history of heart disease or diabetes?

speaker: patient
text: My other brother had prostate cancer but that's just it. No diabetes or heart issues.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: And are you allergic to any drugs?

speaker: patient
text: Oh yes, I am allergic to what you call Cipro-

speaker: doctor
text: Ciprofloxacin?

speaker: patient
text: Yes! And also, Asprin but that coated one, what is called?

speaker: doctor
text: Oh, you mean enteric coated Aspirin?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, yes, that one!

speaker: doctor
text: Hi, I am Doctor Chandler.

speaker: patient
text: Hello Doctor.

speaker: doctor
text: So, tell me what's going on?

speaker: patient
text: I am having a headache.

speaker: patient
text: In the past I have been treated for osteomyelitis of my right fifth toe with I V antibiotics therapy.

speaker: doctor
text: Oh, how long back was that?

speaker: patient
text: Ah, about five years back! I was treated for six weeks.

speaker: doctor
text: Oh, Okay. You also have a history of diabetes mellitus?

speaker: patient
text: That is correct.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any major medical conditions that I should know about?

speaker: patient
text: Oh, yeah, I have a whole list of things going on, doctor.

speaker: doctor
text: Like what, ma'am?

speaker: patient
text: Well, I have high blood pressure, hypothyroidism, arthritis, and G E R D.

speaker: doctor
text: I see, what about any mental health, or neurological diseases?

speaker: patient
text: Um, I have an anxiety disorder, and I had migraines about thirty years ago.

speaker: doctor
text: Thank you, I also see on my chart that you've had Morton's neuromas before, is that true?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I have one on both feet.

speaker: doctor
text: I will ask you a few questions about your past medical history. Were you ever diagnosed with anything medically related?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Were you ever diagnosed with diabetes or any heart conditions?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Did you ever take medications for any long-term disease?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Did you ever have any surgery?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: So, who is in your family?

speaker: patient
text: Well, my mom, dad, and I have four brothers aged eighteen, sixteen, fourteen and twelve and I also have a younger sister. She is only three.

speaker: doctor
text: Wow, and you all stay together?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, and we also have two dogs and two cats.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay. And everyone at home is doing fine?

speaker: patient
text: Except for my mom!

speaker: doctor
text: Hm, and did you travel anywhere recently, especially during the holiday season?

speaker: patient
text: No, right mom?

speaker: doctor
text: Okay. Anybody in your house smokes?

speaker: doctor
text: No exposure to smoke, right?

speaker: doctor
text: So, are you on any medication currently?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I am taking Atenolol and Mevacor.

speaker: doctor
text: Hm, and no allergy to any medicine?

speaker: patient
text: Not that I know of.

speaker: doctor
text: I think you are good to go home. I am going to prepare your discharge paper.

speaker: patient
text: That's great!

speaker: doctor
text: So how long have you two been married?

speaker: doctor
text: Oh wow, that's so wonderful to hear. How did you guys meet?

speaker: doctor
text: Aw, high school sweethearts. I have a few more questions to ask.

speaker: doctor
text: Any tobacco, hard drugs, or alcohol?

speaker: doctor
text: Great. And do you know of any medical problems that run on her side of the family?

speaker: doctor
text: I see.

speaker: doctor
text: I would like to get a detailed history of your inperforated anus and the curvature of the penis. It is a genetic condition. And do you know if you had surgery soon after birth?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, my mother said that I had to have surgery after she gave birth to me.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you know all the surgeries that you have had for this?

speaker: patient
text: I don't know if I have all of them written down, but I do have most of them here.

speaker: doctor
text: Oh, good you have a list.

speaker: patient
text: Yeah. I was hospitalized in nineteen seventy for a U T I. That is when the problems started happening. It was a really bad infection.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

speaker: patient
text: In nineteen eighty eight I the tissue removed from the anus. There was a blockage. They also did an operation in the shaft of the penis too.

speaker: doctor
text: I bet things improved after that surgery.

speaker: patient
text: It did. I have here in January of nineteen ninety one I had a cystoscopy to remove a blockage.

speaker: doctor
text: Um hum.

speaker: patient
text: In two thousand and one I had a colonoscopy that was normal. Later that year I had a biopsy of my prostate.

speaker: doctor
text: What did the biopsy show?

speaker: patient
text: They said I had severe inflammation in the prostate. I was never told that cause of the inflammation.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay. Any other surgeries for your condition?

speaker: patient
text: Oh yeah. I had that same procedure done again when I was twenty seven and twenty eight. The same one that I had as a newborn. I had a third surgery when I was seventy with just a correction of the shaft area.

speaker: doctor
text: Um hum. Any other surgeries unrelated to your condition?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah. I have it written down here. In two thousand and one there was a left rotator cuff repair with acromioplasty and distal clavicle resection and in two thousand and three I had a left inguinal hernia repair with M E S H. That is what my notes say.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you ever had any complications during any of your surgeries?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I did. I have a blood clot that apparently went into my lungs. I was very scary.

speaker: doctor
text: That is very scary.

speaker: doctor
text: As per your chart, I see you have C O P D and hypertension.

speaker: patient
text: Yes that is right.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you use any tobacco products?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you drink alcohol or use any recreational drugs?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Any history of needle drugs or prescription drug abuse?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Hi!

speaker: patient
text: Hello, how are you?

speaker: doctor
text: I am good.

speaker: patient
text: I think I am all well now.

speaker: doctor
text: Yes, looking at your results I think your kidney failure is resolved too.

speaker: doctor
text: How old are you, young man?

speaker: patient
text: I am twenty one.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you right handed or left handed?

speaker: patient
text: I am right handed.

speaker: doctor
text: So, tell me what brings you here today?

speaker: patient
text: Everything started on the fifth of November. Then after I saw the gradual increase in my symptoms. So it was all like numbness. I could not feel my legs. They felt numb all the time and there was no coordination between them, and it also affected my walk. All these symptoms were at their limit in just like a half day or more. It is continuing the same way since then. I also feel like somebody is putting pins and needles on my legs approximately  halfway up the calf on both sides.

speaker: doctor
text: You said that you felt decreased coordination or less coordination between your legs, right?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, that's right. It totally feels like I'm walking in space and don't know where to put my next step. I have no up and down spatial awareness.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any issue with the bowel movements?

speaker: patient
text: Nope.

speaker: doctor
text: What about this weakness or the numbness anywhere else except your legs?

speaker: patient
text: No, it's only in the legs.

speaker: doctor
text: Did anything help you with those symptoms?

speaker: patient
text: Well, sometimes, you see, hot showers made me feel better, but it is like only sometimes.

speaker: doctor
text: Any recent flu like symptoms?

speaker: patient
text: Nope.

speaker: doctor
text: Did anyone in your family have anything like that or any other medical issues that was like going on in your family?

speaker: patient
text: Nope.

speaker: doctor
text: Did you have any surgery before?

speaker: patient
text: Nope.

speaker: doctor
text: What about any other major health issues in the past?

speaker: patient
text: No, no medical issues.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you taking any kind of medication for anything?

speaker: patient
text: No medications.

speaker: doctor
text: What brings you in to the clinic today?

speaker: patient
text: Well, I have had a progressive loss of my vision in my right eye. My eye doctor told me that I should come and see a neurologist. So here I am.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay. How long has the vision loss been progressing for?

speaker: patient
text: About two months. It seems like it has been progressing really fast. I have always had bad vision in my left eye. That started about two years ago.

speaker: doctor
text: Can you still see out of you left eye?

speaker: patient
text: No. I am considered blind in this eye now.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you had any other symptoms associated with your vision loss?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Any headaches?

speaker: patient
text: Nope.

speaker: doctor
text: What is you dominate hand?

speaker: patient
text: What do you mean?

speaker: doctor
text: What hand do you write with or use dominantly?

speaker: patient
text: Oh! I am right handed.

speaker: doctor
text: And how old are you?

speaker: patient
text: I am sixty two.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay. I would like to run some test now.

speaker: patient
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any history of rheumatic fever as a child?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Any history of anything other then usual childhood illnesses?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: So, tell me a little bit more about your family history, please.

speaker: patient
text: Sure, I know that my grandmother on my mom's side had pancreatic cancer, and my dad had prostate cancer.

speaker: doctor
text: Besides cancer, are there any other conditions that you know run in your family?

speaker: patient
text: Um, I know that my dad had heart disease, as well as diabetes.

speaker: doctor
text: Thank you, this is good information to know.

speaker: doctor
text: What do you do?

speaker: patient
text: I am a registered nurse.

speaker: doctor
text: That's nice.

speaker: doctor
text: And do you smoke or drink?

speaker: patient
text: No sir.

speaker: doctor
text: Any history of drug abuse or anything?

speaker: patient
text: Absolutely not!

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, good.

speaker: doctor
text: Hello, sir. How are you doing?

speaker: patient
text: I am doing well, thanks. Just trying to come to you more regularly to make sure my lungs and heart are okay.

speaker: doctor
text: That's great. The previous notes said that you quit smoking. Are you still off?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I quit in nineteen ninety six. I come yearly to the doctor's office to make sure that the damage I did to my lungs is monitored.

speaker: doctor
text: You have a great attitude. I appreciate when patient's take their health into their own hands. We can only do so much, but it is up to the patient to bring themselves in.

speaker: patient
text: Yeah. I smoked for a long time and I know it was bad for me. It was just the norm back in the day.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you drink at all?

speaker: patient
text: I do. Only occasionally.

speaker: doctor
text: Right. What brings you here?

speaker: doctor
text: Let me have a look.

speaker: doctor
text: Your condition and all your vital signs look stable to me right now. You must be very careful as your condition can get poor or it might improve as well.

speaker: patient
text: Okay, so what do you recommend?

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any support system? Is there anyone at home to take care of you?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, my son and his family lives with me. They are very caring.

speaker: doctor
text: That is good. Do take care of yourself and let me know if your condition worsens.

speaker: doctor
text: Where do you work?

speaker: patient
text: I'm a truck driver. It's a big construction company. I work for them.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you smoke?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah.

speaker: doctor
text: Cigarette or something else?

speaker: patient
text: I do Cigar.

speaker: doctor
text: Good morning, ma'am. I just need a few pieces of information before we get started today.

speaker: patient
text: Good morning, doctor. Absolutely, that's not a problem at all.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you smoke or drink, ma'am?

speaker: patient
text: I don't smoke, and I drink, um, I'd say on occasionally.

speaker: doctor
text: What about harder drugs, do you use any of those?

speaker: patient
text: No, I don't.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you married?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, to my wonderful husband.

speaker: doctor
text: That's great, what do you two do for a living?

speaker: patient
text: I'm a social worker, and my husband is a high school chemistry teacher.

speaker: doctor
text: What great work both of you are doing. What kinds of people do you work with as a social worker?

speaker: patient
text: I love it, I work with adult abuse and neglect issues.

speaker: doctor
text: Yes, that's great. Do you have any children?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, we have two sons.

speaker: doctor
text: Do they live at home?

speaker: patient
text: No, they're both grown and on their own now.

speaker: doctor
text: Did both your parents have heart complications.

speaker: patient
text: Unfortunately, yes. My mom passed from a heart attack at seventy three and my father at eighty.

speaker: doctor
text: I'm so sorry to hear that.

speaker: patient
text: I lost my brother as well. He passed away from a brain tumor when he was nine years old.

speaker: doctor
text: I can't imagine how hard that must've been.

speaker: patient
text: It was a dark time in our lives, but we survived it as a family.

speaker: doctor
text: I am going write you a prescription for a stimulant. It is called Cylert.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you married?

speaker: patient
text: Yes. I have been married for twenty two years.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you working?

speaker: patient
text: No. I am unemployed. I have not completed my collage degree yet. I have been in school for the last two years.

speaker: doctor
text: Keep at it.

speaker: doctor
text: Nurse, do you have a report on my patient?

speaker: doctor
text: Oh, no. Did she get chemotherapy?

speaker: doctor
text: How are her symptoms now?

speaker: doctor
text: I see. Does she have any imaging done?

speaker: doctor
text: Thank you, Nurse. I'll go see her now.

speaker: doctor
text: Hello, ma'am. What is the reason for your visit today?

speaker: patient
text: I wanted to see if I could get some treatment for my pain.

speaker: doctor
text: What kind of pain are you having?

speaker: patient
text: I feel like it's a burning feeling? I don't know. I can feel it one spot and then it spreads down.

speaker: doctor
text: I see. Where do you feel the pain?

speaker: patient
text: I feel it mostly on my lower right side of my back.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you feel it anywhere else?

speaker: patient
text: The back of my right leg and knee.

speaker: doctor
text: Would you said the pain radiates down from your back to your knee?

speaker: patient
text: That's it. Radiating. I forgot the word.

speaker: doctor
text: No problem. On a scale from zero to ten, with zero being no pain and ten being the worst pain of your life, how would you rate your back and leg?

speaker: patient
text: They're both a ten.

speaker: doctor
text: Oh, wow. Do you feel pain anywhere else?

speaker: patient
text: Yes. Could you check my feet?

speaker: doctor

speaker: patient
text: I'd say when I'm sitting in a car for a long time.

text: So, just sitting for long periods of time?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah. When I stand and walk, too.

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you experienced any episodes of nausea or vomiting?

speaker: patient

speaker: patient

speaker: doctor
text: Even though you have been taking the medications without any issue, for about ten years, the methotrexate may be the cause of the mouth sores and the inflammation in the small intestines. These are both common side effects from the use of methotrexate. I am not as familiar with NSAID's causing mouth sores. Aspirin use can cause gastrointestinal upset. I think the most likely cause of the sores is the methotrexate not the use of Aspirin.

text: Epi one M G, zero point three M L subcutaneously along with fifty M G of Benadryl intramuscularly. In about fifteen to twenty minutes, he reported his itching had improved. The rash itself faded a little bit and he began to feel a lot more comfortable.

text: Hello, how are you?

text: Do you have any change in your medical history since your last visit?

text: My family has a high blood pressure. I have a family member that had colon cancer.  My daughter has a twitch. They don't know what caused it?

speaker: doctor
text: Hello Miss Long, I see that you have been referred today by A B C, D O, for a reevaluation. Are you having issues with your hand eczema again?

text: Okay, since you are an established patient here in our dermatology department, let me just update all your information into the records.

text: Yeah, I think so.

text: I have previously treated you with Aristocort cream and Cetaphil cream. I also ask you to increase your moisturizing cream and lotion and asked you to wash your hands in Cetaphil cleansing lotion.

text: Have you been washing your hands with Cetaphil cleansing lotion?

text: No, I was using soap. The Cetaphil cleansing lotion was not working.  I had a lot of pain and burning sensation whenever I tried to use that.

speaker: patient
text: I have been wearing gloves as much as I can.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

text: Have you been applying Triamcinolone zero point one percent three times a day to your rash?

speaker: patient

speaker: patient
text: Uh yeah. I've been using it much less now.

speaker: doctor

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I mean I'm taking four M G in the morning and six M G at night instead of the six M G and eight M G that was recommended. I feel like I do better with the lower doses.

speaker: doctor
text: So, I am looking at your reports, you don't have anemia or any other blood disorders.

speaker: patient
text: Well, that's a relief!

speaker: doctor
text: Yeah.

text: Let me check your lymph nodes. They are nonpalpable. I don't see any swollen glands or anything.

speaker: patient
text: Great!

speaker: doctor
text: I am well, how's the baby? I see that he is eight pounds and thirteen ounces, and he was born via…?

text: Okay, I would like to ask you some questions about the pregnancy and other history.

text: Great, have you had any infections during pregnancy like G B S or S T D infections?

speaker: doctor
text: Did you smoke during pregnancy?

speaker: doctor

speaker: doctor
text: Great, so looks like you were discharged in forty eight hours and no more hospital stays for you.

text: I remember you had mentioned that one of your family members had bone cancer. Are there any other medical problems that run in your family?

text: I understand. I'm sorry to hear that she hasn't been feeling well. Let me see what we can do for her today.

text: What time did she wake up today?

text: Do you have any family history of chronic illnesses that I should know about?

text: Oh yeah, my mom has arthritis.

text: Little bit, not so much.

text: So just listen to your body and go around as much as you can.

text: Okay.

text: Okay I can do that.

text: Are you allergic to anything?

text: Okay.

speaker: patient
text: Yeah.

text: Yes, and we did O R I F on his fracture dislocation of the left elbow.

text: Which hand does he write with?

speaker: doctor
text: Okay. That fracture appears to have healed very well; kids generally heal pretty well. How does it feel today?

speaker: doctor
text: That's good that he is already in P T. His left elbow fracture is healed, so we should do another surgery in order to remove that hardware. That may help decrease some of the irritation with elbow extension. He looks neurologically intact in terms of movement and reflexed in his wrist and hand.

speaker: doctor
text: Historically, the risk of infection is less than one percent.

speaker: doctor
text: We'll use prophylactic antibiotics, this controls for infection, and helps keep everything clean. Other Risks include bleeding, changes in sensation and motion of the extremities, failure to remove hardware, failure to relieve pain, and continued postoperative stiffness.

speaker: doctor
text: Yes, we'll use anesthesia, he won't feel a thing.

speaker: doctor
text: I can't guarantee it, he may still be in some pain.

text: Since you have a family history of coronary heart disease, let me check you for its risk factors.

text: Yeah, my father had it.

text: Any history of high blood pressure or diabetes?

speaker: patient
text: No.

text: How about smoking, do you smoke?

text: And in the past, did any other Doctor mention that you might have sign or symptom indicating that you may have coronary artery disease?

text: Okay.

text: Who all are there in your family?

text: Is she going to any daycare?

text: Do you drink?

text: Oh, I do but occasionally. Who doesn't like a nice cocktail!

text: Okay. How about cigarettes, do you smoke?

speaker: patient
text: No, I don't smoke.

speaker: doctor
text: I am okay.

text: I have bad nausea.

text: Oh, so sorry.

speaker: patient
text: And I feel very dizzy like I am going to faint.

text: Okay let me see what is going on.

speaker: patient
text: Okay.

text: What brings you into the office today?

text: I had a stroke about a month ago. The right side of my face is still not moving.

text: Is it only the right side of the face that is affected by paralysis?

speaker: patient
text: Yes. It has improved a little bit since I was in the hospital.

text: That is a good sign. It can take up to six months see how much movement you will regain.

text: Do you use tobacco?

text: Oh, no. I don't do anything like that.

text: Oh, yes, that's true. I had that done too.

speaker: doctor
text: So, let's see here. You don't recall anyone in your family having a history of neuromuscular diseases, correct?

text: No, no one I can think of.

text: Do you know of anyone who has had foot deformities or neuropathy in their arms or legs?

speaker: patient
text: No, not one person comes to mind.

text: Great. Does anyone in your immediate family have a high arch?

speaker: patient
text: No, at least no one that I know of.

text: And you said that your aunt or sister has type two diabetes?

speaker: patient
text: My aunt. She's had it for some time now.

speaker: doctor
text: So, what I feel is you might have short term memory loss due to high stress, but I also feel it's probably due to your current situation. The other impression I have is that you have anxiety issues and again it's stress related.

text: Yeah, I do have anxiety issues.

speaker: doctor
text: Who's my patient today?

text: What seems to be the problem today?

text: What kinds of foods did he eliminate?

text: Oh, you know, all of the fun ones. Like cappuccino, quiche, crescents, candy, vending machines, all of that stuff.

text: Yes, I do about three or four times a week instead of eating out so much.

text: Are you exercising right now?

text: Yes, I do about six or seven days a week.

text: What kind do you like to do?

speaker: patient
text: Well, I do just about everything. I swim, I bike, run and then I lift weights.

text: How long do you workout per day?

text: Usually, it's about one and a half to two and a half hours every day.

text: Good, are you training for anything specific?

text: The patient has possible free air in their diaphragm.

speaker: doctor
text: Seventy six.

speaker: doctor
text: Unknown as of now.

text: Out of ten, ten being the worst pain imaginable, how would you rate your pain today?

text: Today it's about a six or seven, and it's usually pretty constant there.

text: Does the pain change with the weather?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, when it's cold out it turns to ten out of ten. It's better when it's warm out.

text: Does the pain change throughout the course of the day?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, it progressively gets worse and worse as the day goes on, but I also have a pretty hard time getting out of bed in the morning, too.

text: Out of ten, how would you rate your pain at night?

speaker: patient
text: Oh, it's ten out of ten.

text: Does the pain wake you up at night?

speaker: patient
text: If I sleep at all. I'm not sleeping well at all, and when I do it's for less than an hour at a time.

text: Are there any activities that really aggravate the pain?

text: Yes, if I sit for more than about twenty minutes, or if I lay flat on my back.

speaker: doctor

speaker: patient
text: Laying on my side helps a little.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay. It's mentioned in her report that she has a history of smoking.

speaker: doctor
text: Well, it's alright. I think it's going to be difficult taking any past medical information from her.

text: Have you been taking anything for high blood pressure?

text: Yeah, I started taking Toprol and uh the one that starts with an A. I forget what it's called.

text: Hm are you talking about Avalide?

speaker: patient
text: Oh right, yeah that's the one.

speaker: doctor
text: Good afternoon, ma'am. Before we begin, may I ask how old you are?

speaker: patient
text: Good afternoon, doctor. I'm fifty six years old, now.

speaker: doctor
text: Great, thank you. What seems to be the problem today, ma'am?

speaker: patient
text: Well, I need some support for dietary recommendations for healthy eating for my husband and me.

text: Why would that be, ma'am?

speaker: patient
text: Um, I have a lot going on, high cholesterol, high blood pressure, acid reflux, and I just want to lose some weight. My husband has high cholesterol too.

text: Tell me more about your eating habits, please.

speaker: patient
text: Well, we live by ourselves now that our children are gone, but I'm used to cooking really large portions.

text: Are you struggling to make food for just two people?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, that's a good way to put it. I'd like to just make less food, that way we're not so tempted to eat so much.

speaker: doctor
text: I understand, are you busy, do you work?

speaker: patient
text: Well, I start a new job this week.

speaker: doctor
text: Hello! What brings you into the office today?

speaker: patient
text: Hi! I have not been able to go pee, and I have had this sharp pain in my left side.

text: Have you recently had any surgical procedures?

speaker: patient
text: No.

text: Do you have a history of an enlarged prostate or kidney stones?

speaker: patient
text: No.

text: I would like to get some imaging done.

speaker: patient
text: Okay.

text: Has he ever had any mental retardation problems in the past?

speaker: doctor
text: Did he go through mainstream education?

speaker: doctor
text: Oh really. That's great.

speaker: doctor
text: What is the job?

speaker: doctor
text: So, he is ambulatory. No issues with performing the work.

speaker: doctor
text: And you are-

speaker: doctor
text: So, do you know about her past medical history?

speaker: doctor
text: Oh, I see.

speaker: doctor
text: Yeah, that will be nice. Let me check her reports quickly. She has a history schizophrenia, chronic anemia and hypothyroidism and she also suffers from asthma.

speaker: doctor
text: Oh, I also see here she tested positive for P P D, was she diagnosed with tuberculosis?

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

text: Your last visit was on April seventh two thousand five, correct.

text: Ah no, it was on April eighth two thousand five, doctor.

text: That's right. So, has anything changed since then?

speaker: patient
text: No, everything is the same really.

text: Any nausea, vomiting or diarrhea?

speaker: patient
text: Nope.

speaker: doctor
text: Well, I think she has hay fever. Otherwise she looks like a healthy two year old.

speaker: doctor
text: Hello, sir. I'll be your doctor today. How are you feeling?

speaker: patient
text: Um uh who? Where am I?

speaker: doctor
text: You're in the emergency room.

text: I'm where?

text: The police found you outside of the local bar. Do you remember what happened prior to your arrival here?

speaker: patient
text: I'm no longer at the bar?

speaker: doctor
text: No, you're here because someone was worried you may need medical attention.

text: I don't know what's going on. Can you call my girlfriend? She was there with me before we got into a fight.

speaker: doctor
text: How's your husband doing?

speaker: patient
text: He's good. He usually comes with me to my appointments, but he had to run some errands this morning.

text: Happy to hear that he's also doing well.

speaker: patient
text: Me too.

text: I just have one more question for you regarding your social history. Do you smoke?

speaker: patient
text: No, never.

text: Okay, so no changes.

text: How are you feeling today?

speaker: patient
text: I am doing good, considering.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you sleeping well?

speaker: patient
text: Yes.  I was able to get some good sleep last night.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you been able to eat without any trouble?

speaker: patient
text: Yes. I ate a little bit of breakfast this morning.

text: Have you been able to have a bowel movement yet?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I did this morning.

speaker: doctor
text: Did you experience any difficulties with your movement?

text: It was still a little difficult and hard.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay. Continue the high fiber diet that we discussed, and it should improve. Please let me or one of the nurses know if it has not improved or becomes worse.

speaker: doctor
text: Our records show that he is up to date with his vaccinations.

text: Are you allergic to any medications?

text: No

speaker: doctor
text: So, do you remember when your last pap smear was?

speaker: patient
text: I have it written down right here in my notes. It was in October of two thousand one.

speaker: doctor
text: Great, do you have any children?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I have a beautiful daughter.

speaker: doctor
text: That's wonderful. Have you only been pregnant once?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I've just pregnant once and it was with my daughter.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you undergone any surgeries?

speaker: patient
text: I had both my tubes tied in O one and I had a polyp removed when I was fourteen.

speaker: doctor
text: And that was a-

speaker: patient
text: Oh, sorry I didn't mean to interrupt.

speaker: doctor
text: It's alright. I just wanted to know if that polyp was found in your colon?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, it was.

speaker: doctor
text: Yes for sure.

speaker: doctor
text: Where's your rash?

speaker: patient
text: All over my torso and arms.

speaker: doctor
text: When did you first notice it?

speaker: patient
text: Well, it started on my back and then it made its way to my torso and arms.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you found yourself itching it?

speaker: patient
text: Yes.

speaker: doctor
text: Any potential triggers for the rash, such as dietary changes, new medications, or unfamiliar exposures?

speaker: patient
text: Nope. I mean I did remove some insulation in my basement a few days ago, but I didn't feel itchy that day.

speaker: doctor
text: Any shortness of breath, wheezing, facial swelling, tongue or lip swelling, or other associated symptoms?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you allergic to anything?

speaker: patient
text: As in drugs?

speaker: doctor
text: Yes, sorry. I was referring to drug allergies.

speaker: patient
text: Oh yeah. I'm allergic to Sulfa drugs.

speaker: doctor
text: What happens when you take Sulfa drugs?

speaker: patient
text: Break out in a terrible rash. I remember I had to go to the E R the first and last time I took it.

speaker: doctor
text: Wow, I'm sorry. Rashes can be very uncomfortable and sometimes require immediate attention.

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, so no more Sulfa drugs for me. That's for sure.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you smoke?

speaker: patient
text: Yes.

speaker: doctor
text: How much do you smoke?

speaker: patient
text: Honestly, I smoke every day.

speaker: doctor
text: Does any of your family member have any major medical problems?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, my mother died of heart attack. She was seventy years old. My father died of cancer; it was prostate cancer. He was around eighty.

speaker: doctor
text: Anything anyone else?

speaker: patient
text: Hm, my brother had both heart disorder and prostate cancer and he died around seventy four.

speaker: doctor
text: Where's your pain?

speaker: patient
text: Right above my belly button. It's been bothering me for three weeks now.

speaker: doctor
text: Does the pain come and go?

speaker: patient
text: Um it's pretty constant, but it does seem to get worse at night.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you find that sitting or laying down in certain positions helps the pain?

speaker: patient
text: Eh not really. I can't seem to really get comfortable since it started.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you taken any medicine for the pain?

speaker: patient
text: I uh-

speaker: doctor
text: Yes?

speaker: patient
text: Um I took Pepto Bismol a few times, but that didn't do much.

speaker: doctor
text: Did they already take you back for your C T scan?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah.

speaker: doctor
text: We should be getting the results of your scan fairly soon then. In the meantime, I'm going to put in some additional orders.

speaker: patient
text: Good morning, doctor.

speaker: doctor
text: So, I've reviewed your past notes, are there any other diagnoses I should know about?

speaker: patient
text: Well, I've had depression for a while now.

speaker: doctor
text: Thank you for sharing that with me.

speaker: doctor
text: Good afternoon, ma'am.

speaker: patient
text: Good afternoon, doctor.

speaker: doctor
text: So, what do you do for a living?

speaker: patient
text: Right now, actually, I'm not working.

speaker: doctor
text: That's okay, I'm not here to judge. Are you married?

speaker: patient
text: No, I'm happily single right now.

speaker: doctor
text: Good for you, do you have any kids?

speaker: patient
text: No, I don't have any, its just me.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you drink or smoke?

speaker: patient
text: No, I don't do any of that.

speaker: doctor
text: Good, and do you use anything harder? Like illicit drugs?

speaker: patient
text: No, I absolutely do not.

speaker: doctor
text: Good, and with ten being the most stressful day every, how would you rate your stress level out of ten?

speaker: patient
text: Today, I'd say its about an eight out of ten.

speaker: doctor
text: Hello. How are you doing today?

speaker: patient
text: My head has been hurting a lot.

speaker: doctor
text: I see. Did the nurse come in and ask you questions about past medical history?

speaker: doctor
text: Perfect. Let's do some tests to see why your head has been hurting.

speaker: patient
text: I'm ready for less pain. Let's go.

speaker: doctor
text: We're going to check around your knee now.

speaker: patient
text: Okay, sounds good.

speaker: doctor
text: Looks like your deep tendon reflexes are the same on both legs. Sensation seems great and intact.

speaker: doctor
text: Can you tell me something about your family? Any illnesses in family?

speaker: patient
text: My dad's mom has diabetes and hypertension and my dad's dad had emphysema and he was a smoker.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

speaker: patient
text: Yeah.

speaker: doctor
text: Is there any history of death of child who was less than a year maybe?

speaker: patient
text: No, there isn't.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay. That's great. No illnesses for small children?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Alright, I am looking at your urine report and it confirms what I was suspecting. You have a urinary tract infection.

speaker: patient
text: I kind of knew it was a U T I. I have had it before, but nothing this painful and severe. I feel like I am going to die!

speaker: doctor
text: Oh yes, it is because you got something called as acute cystitis and its usually very painful and can cause some serious complications.

speaker: patient
text: Well, is it because of my diabetes?

speaker: doctor
text: I am afraid I don't have better news for you, but your diabetes is out of control. It's way too high and you must be really careful. Are you taking your medicines?

speaker: patient
text: Yes!

speaker: doctor
text: How bout diet?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, sometimes I don't care about my diet.

speaker: doctor
text: Well, you must watch your diet, you can't just be careless. I am going to change your diabetes medication. And let's start you on the antibiotic that should give you relief. Also stay hydrated drink plenty of fluids it will help you flush the infection out.

speaker: patient
text: Alright, thank you!

speaker: doctor
text: Take care.

speaker: doctor
text: Good morning, ma'am.

speaker: patient
text: Good morning, doctor.

speaker: doctor
text: Before we begin, I just have a few questions. Do you remember what illnesses you had as a child?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I got a few. I had strep throat, mumps, and, um, chickenpox growing up.

speaker: doctor
text: Hi there! I am Doctor Sherman.

speaker: patient
text: Hello! It is nice to meet you.

speaker: doctor
text: It looks like your P C P sent you to us for a possible prostate problem.

speaker: patient
text: Yes. I am nervous.

speaker: doctor
text: Do not be nervous. We will start with discussing the symptoms you have been experiencing, a physical exam and then we will get a urine sample if you are able.
