speaker: patient
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: What are you taking for allergies?

speaker: patient
text: Claritin.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

speaker: patient
text: For my allergic rhinitis.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any known allergies to medication?

speaker: patient
text: Nope. None that I know of.

speaker: doctor
text: What is your family medical history?

speaker: patient
text: My dad had a heart attack and passed away at sixty one.

speaker: doctor
text: I am so sorry to hear that.

speaker: patient
text: Thank you.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you know of any other major health conditions in your family?

speaker: patient
text: No. None that I know of. Everyone is relatively healthy.

speaker: doctor
text: That's good.

speaker: doctor
text: Hello, sir how are you feeling today?

speaker: patient
text: I feel terrible. Very sick and I can barely move. I feel so weak.

speaker: doctor
text: So, we looked at your previous blood work results, now let me see what these reports say from today's C B C exam.

speaker: patient
text: Sure.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay so your hemoglobin levels look within range, white counts are thirteen point three, then seven point six lymphocytes and twenty six thousand platelets.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay?

speaker: patient
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: Welcome back.

speaker: patient
text: Thank you.

speaker: doctor
text: You are back for a follow up on your right arm pain, right?

speaker: patient
text: Yes. It has been almost a year since the pain first started.

speaker: doctor
text: How has your arm been feeling?

speaker: patient
text: I still have this dull pain in my upper outer area of my arm.

speaker: doctor
text: How long does the pain last?

speaker: patient
text: It was coming and going, but now the pain is more persistent since I last saw you. It is still happening every day.

speaker: doctor
text: Remind me again. You are right handed. Right?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah. It makes is hard to do things with the persistent pain.

speaker: doctor
text: I bet it does. Are you experiencing any numbness or tingling sensation in your arm or hand?

speaker: patient
text: No, but I have had this achy sensation in my hand radiating down to my fingers.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have a history of any other neck or shoulder injuries?

speaker: patient
text: It is not from a specific injury but I have had this neck pain for thirty years.

speaker: doctor
text: Did you see anyone for the neck pain?

speaker: patient
text: Yes. I saw someone for it in two thousand and six, and then I developed this ear pain. They could not figure out what was going on so eventually I was sent to have an M R I of my neck and upper spine, which showed some degenerative changes. Then I was referred to Doctor X who was treating me for neck pain.  He gave me steroid injections.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you still seeing Doctor X for the epidural injections?

speaker: patient
text: Yes. I have been seeing him since two thousand and seven.

speaker: doctor
text: How old are you?

speaker: patient
text: I am fifty eight.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you experiencing any symptoms from receiving the injections?

speaker: patient
text: Those are for neck pain. My arm pain recent. I have been having the injections for a while now, without any trouble.

speaker: doctor
text: What medications have you been taking for the pain?

speaker: patient
text: There are a few of them that I take. I gave the list to the nurse.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

speaker: patient
text: I also have taken several Medrol packs. They make my blood sugars to increase so I try not to take it.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay. Does the pain prevent you from doing your daily activities or decrease your quality of life?

speaker: patient
text: No. I can do everything like normal, but constant nagging pain does get to me at times.

speaker: doctor
text: What type of surgery have you had in past? Anything big or small?

speaker: patient
text: I had a C section for my kiddo and one D and C.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you currently taking any medications?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: So are you allergic-

speaker: patient
text: To any medications? No allergies here.

speaker: doctor
text: Hello again!

speaker: patient
text: Hi!

speaker: doctor
text: The results from you M R I showed nothing concerning.  The growth factors were normal with normal cell function and no signs of decreased blood supply to the brain.

speaker: patient
text: That's great news.

speaker: doctor
text: Yes it is.

speaker: doctor
text: So, I understand that you had a fall.

speaker: patient
text: Yes. I did fall.

speaker: doctor
text: What happened?

speaker: patient
text: I don't really know. I have balancing problems. I have been to my P C P for this issue a few days ago. I saw her about a week and a half ago because I had another fall. Maybe around late December since today is January seventh.  I have been having trouble with my right hand. It is like I am clumsy on my right side. I ended up falling because my right hand missed the railing when I grabbed it to head up the stairs.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you left or right handed?

speaker: patient
text: Right.

speaker: doctor
text: Can you tell me a little bit more about the trouble that you are having with the right hand? Is it localized to the right hand?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, it is only on my right side. It is like the right side of my body is weak and it has been getting worse.

speaker: doctor
text: How long has this issue been progressing for?

speaker: patient
text: About two years.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you experienced any blurred vision or visual disturbances?

speaker: patient
text: Yes. Every once and a while.

speaker: doctor
text: How old are you?

speaker: patient
text: I just turned fifty eight last week.

speaker: doctor
text: Happy belated birthday!

speaker: patient
text: Thank you!

speaker: doctor
text: Did your P C P have any bloodwork or imaging done?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, she did. She did both. She said she would send my records over.

speaker: doctor
text: Oh. I see it here! Did Doctor Madison discuss the results of your H C T and the M R I yet?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay. The results showed clinoid masses. This explains that problems that you have been having with your right side, your balancing problems, and the visual disturbances. With only the M R I I cannot tell if the masses are malignant or not.

speaker: patient
text: So, are the masses cancer?

speaker: doctor
text: I don't know yet. I will have to run some more tests and potently have to do a biopsy.

speaker: patient
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you smoke?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I do.

speaker: doctor
text: How much? I mean can you tell me approximate amount?

speaker: patient
text: Yes sure, I smoke half a pack a day.

speaker: doctor
text: How about alcohol and drugs?

speaker: patient
text: No, I do not drink or use. I have a five month old baby.

speaker: doctor
text: With ten being the worst pain imaginable, how would you rate your pain today out of ten, ma'am?

speaker: patient
text: Well, out of ten, I'd say it's about a seven.

speaker: doctor
text: How would you describe your pain?

speaker: patient
text: Um, I'd say it's deep, and it really aches.

speaker: doctor
text: Where is your pain located?

speaker: patient
text: It's in my right lower back, and then into my butt.

speaker: doctor
text: What activities make your surgery worse?

speaker: patient
text: I can't go up and down stairs without a lot of pain, and it hurts when I sit for a long time, like when I drive.

speaker: doctor
text: Before this pain, how would you describe your activity level?

speaker: patient
text: I was very active before all this started.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you able to do any of your prior activities?

speaker: patient
text: Not really, I'm having a lot of problems with stuff around the house, like all the chores and projects I used to be able to do.

speaker: doctor
text: Welcome in!

speaker: patient
text: Thank you.

speaker: doctor
text: Let us get a little background. What is your medical history?

speaker: patient
text: I have some memory loss problems.

speaker: doctor
text: What kind of memory problems?

speaker: patient
text: Well, I have seizures.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you know what kind of seizures that you have?

speaker: patient
text: I have temporal lobe seizures.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any other health conditions?

speaker: patient
text: I also have high blood pressure.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: Did you have any medical issues?

speaker: patient
text: Nope.

speaker: doctor
text: What about surgery.

speaker: patient
text: No, I never had a surgery.

speaker: doctor
text: How old are you?

speaker: patient
text: I am seventy three.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you right handed or left handed?

speaker: patient
text: Right.

speaker: doctor
text: So, I see the chief complaint is memory loss and cognitive decline. Tell me what exactly happened, and how did you notice the symptoms? Let me document that today is January twelfth of nineteen ninety five.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: I can see why she was frustrated. Anyone can be in such situations.

speaker: doctor
text: Was she slurring?

speaker: doctor
text: Was there any difficulty with vision? Or any weakness?

speaker: doctor
text: How was it after returning from there?

speaker: patient
text: I was not able to take on with my usual task of flower arrangements or dealing with the cash at the cash register.

speaker: doctor
text: How was it after that?

speaker: doctor
text: Yeah, I see the working diagnosis of dementia of the Alzheimer's Type. When did these symptoms increase? Like when did you started noticing them more?

speaker: doctor
text: You are not allergic to anything?

speaker: patient
text: No, I am not.

speaker: doctor
text: Any food or other pollen?

speaker: patient
text: No, I am not allergic to anything.

speaker: doctor
text: Great!

speaker: doctor
text: April twenty two three we checked your list of medications.

speaker: doctor
text: We saw that it lifts up in the morning and evening.

speaker: doctor
text: Yeah.

speaker: patient
text: Yeah.

speaker: doctor
text: How old is the baby?

speaker: doctor
text: What brings you here today?

speaker: doctor
text: How was your pregnancy?

speaker: doctor
text: Is this the only child?

speaker: doctor
text: How much did he weigh at birth?

speaker: doctor
text: Did you remember his milestones?

speaker: doctor
text: What issues are he facing right now?

speaker: doctor
text: How about his speech? How many words do you think he knows?

speaker: doctor
text: Is he able to speak two word phrases?

speaker: doctor
text: Any other unusual behavior that you noticed? Any seizures or just the quivering movement of the jaw?

speaker: doctor
text: What brings you back into the clinic today?

speaker: patient
text: I have been having some severe bruising. I have been taking Coumadin for three months now. Am I taking to much Coumadin?

speaker: doctor
text: You are taking a normal start dose. Some people do not metabolize the medication as well as others. I would like to get you tested for hypersensitivity. After we get the test results back, we will be able to adjust your dosage accordingly.

speaker: patient
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: Let me examine you. Tell me, did you have any fever or chills, any sweating or that sort of thing?

speaker: patient
text: Um no.

speaker: doctor
text: How about abnormal weight loss or weight gain?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you experiencing any chest pain on exertion or shortness of breath normally or when you try to sleep?

speaker: patient
text: No, no chest pain and shortness of breath.

speaker: doctor
text: Let me see your legs. They look good I don't see any pedal edema. Usually that happens due to excess water retention. Any palpitations?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Any feeling of numbness or tingling? Did you faint or lose consciousness anytime?

speaker: patient
text: No and no.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, good!

speaker: doctor
text: Any double and or blurred vision?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Any difficulty hearing or any wired continuous sound you may hear?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, um tell me if you had any um, allergies, or sneezing, or runny nose?

speaker: patient
text: No, no really.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, got it.

speaker: doctor
text: Any indigestion, or heart burn? Did you notice any blood in stool or black stool?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Any diarrhea or vomiting?

speaker: patient
text: Nope.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you feeling thirsty frequently?

speaker: patient
text: No, just normal.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: And I see you got a urine test, so no pus cells or blood present.

speaker: patient
text: Yes.

speaker: doctor
text: Any pain while passing urine though? Any blood?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: And how is the urine frequency? Do you have to wake up at night to urinate?

speaker: patient
text: Well, my frequency is normal. I don't have to wake up at night for urinating.

speaker: doctor
text: How bout the stream while passing urine? You think it's normal or somewhat slow?

speaker: patient
text: No, it's absolutely normal.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, so any cough or cold like symptoms any sputum?

speaker: patient
text: Nope.

speaker: doctor
text: No wheezing, right?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, no wheezing.

speaker: doctor
text: I don't see any lesions, that's good. Any mood swings, feeling depressed or have anxiety?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Any joint pain in the legs, back or anywhere?

speaker: patient
text: Um no.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, so no erythema in the joints. Any heat or cold intolerance?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, any difficulty swallowing? Let me check here, lymph nodes look fine. And do you bleed easily and does the bleeding stop normally?

speaker: patient
text: Oh yes!

speaker: doctor
text: Do you bruise easy?

speaker: patient
text: No, not really.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay. Any abnormal skin lesions?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you allright?

speaker: patient
text: Yes I am fine.

speaker: doctor
text: That's great.

speaker: patient
text: Thanks.

speaker: doctor
text: I think you can go home now.

speaker: doctor
text: I'm reviewing my notes from your last visit. Your last visit was on May tenth two thousand four, correct?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, that's right.

speaker: doctor
text: Has there been any change since your last visit?

speaker: patient
text: Well, I'm having some increased paranoia.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you been treated, and are you taking medicine for this?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, and it's actually gotten a lot better with the medicine another doctor gave me.

speaker: doctor
text: I just met with one of my patients whom I believe has pertussis.

speaker: doctor
text: Hm give me a second to pull up their information.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you ever had psychiatric or psychological treatment?

speaker: patient
text: Uh no, no treatments whatsoever. I mean I do find myself in low moods every now and again when I'm dealing with certain stressors, but the decreased moods rarely ever long lasting.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you remember when your last flu vaccine was?

speaker: patient
text: I don't remember what month, but it was in nineteen ninety nine.

speaker: doctor
text: Good, and do you remember your last pneumonia vaccine?

speaker: patient
text: Let me look at my notes here, um, it was in nineteen ninety six.

speaker: doctor
text: Thank you, now, tell me more about your parents. Do you know their medical histories?

speaker: patient
text: Let me think, my dad is still around, he had a stroke. Oh yeah, and he has high blood pressure.

speaker: doctor
text: How old is your father?

speaker: patient
text: He's seventy nine now.

speaker: doctor
text: Good, what about your mother?

speaker: patient
text: She died when she was seventy four, she had heart failure and emphysema.

speaker: doctor
text: I'm sorry to hear that. Do you have any brothers or sisters?

speaker: patient
text: Thank you doctor, no, its just me and my Dad now.

speaker: doctor
text: How are you doing today, ma'am?

speaker: patient
text: I'm doing just fine.

speaker: doctor
text: Any kind of alcohol consumption?

speaker: patient
text: Nope.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you ever taken any kind of illegal drugs?

speaker: patient
text: Nope.

speaker: doctor
text: What about smoking?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you still working?

speaker: patient
text: No, sir. I had issues with my knees, and they had to put in the new ones. I was kind of disabled and that's why I retired.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any chest pain?

speaker: patient
text: No, I don't.

speaker: doctor
text: Any breathlessness?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I do get breathless only when I have to do some form of exertion like walking a long time or running.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay. How about any bowel issues?

speaker: patient
text: No, I don't have any stomach problems except I have to go frequently to use a bathroom.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay frequency. How about any prolonged bleeding issues or anything like that sort?

speaker: patient
text: No nothing like that.

speaker: doctor
text: Does she lives with anyone?

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: Hi, the weather outside is beautiful, did you get some sunshine?

speaker: patient
text: Yes in fact I came in walking.

speaker: doctor
text: Great way to get some exercise in.

speaker: doctor
text: ok so what's going on?

speaker: patient
text: I am having a bellyache.

speaker: doctor
text: Since when?

speaker: patient
text: Oh, it's been a while now.

speaker: doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your pain like how did it start and what exactly are you feeling?

speaker: patient
text: Ok so the pain started as dullache but it is constant right here in the middle upper part of my stomach. And sometimes it is moving to the back.

speaker: doctor
text: Can you tell me if it is stabbing pain and if it is related to any specific time of the day?

speaker: patient
text: Sure, so i do get episodes of stabbing pain but they are not related to meals. Once the wave comes it lasts for only a minute or so.

speaker: doctor
text: Can you tell me when exactly you noted it?

speaker: patient
text: Approximately six months back. I took over the counter antacids and got some relief so i did not go to doctor. But two months back it got worse, I do get occasional nausea and vomiting.

speaker: doctor
text: I can see that they found H pylori positive infection and treated you with triple drug therapy for two weeks and then gave you antacid omeprazole. But it did not improve your pain.

speaker: patient
text: Yeah that's right.

speaker: patient
text: Do you know I lost twenty pound of weight since all these symptoms began but i have been also admitted for poor appetite.

speaker: doctor
text: Ok tell me how are your bowel movements and if you see any blood in stools?

speaker: patient
text: I get two to three loose bowel movements a day but no blood in stool or anywhere.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you taking any pain medication over the counter? Do you drink alcohol and maybe you are vomiting blood?

speaker: patient
text: No no, nothing like that.

speaker: doctor
text: Can you tell me if any change in position changes the quality of pain? do you have any fever?

speaker: patient
text: No position changing have no effect, no fever or anything.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you been exercising before all this?

speaker: patient
text: Yes I have had very active and healthy lifestyle.

speaker: doctor
text: Any specific family medical history that I should be aware of?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Anyone in your family, even grandparents, if you know them, did they have diabetes or high blood pressure?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Anyone else sick at home?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: What is your family medical history?

speaker: patient
text: My mother has high blood pressure, and she had a stroke last year.

speaker: doctor
text: Is your mother still with us after the stroke?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah. She is doing well.

speaker: doctor
text: Good. What about your father's medical history?

speaker: patient
text: My father died in a car accident, when he was forty.

speaker: doctor
text: I am so sorry to hear that.

speaker: patient
text: Thank you.

speaker: doctor
text: Anyone in your family have a history of drug or alcohol abuse?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Any other medical conditions that might run in your family?

speaker: patient
text: Nope.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you drink?

speaker: patient
text: Like, every day?

speaker: doctor
text: No, just in general.

speaker: patient
text: No, I don't drink at all.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you smoke?

speaker: patient
text: No, I don't do that at all, either.

speaker: doctor
text: Any drug allergies?

speaker: patient
text: Ah yes, I am allergic to... what's the name of the drug? It's called Napro-

speaker: doctor
text: Naprosyn?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, Naprosyn.

speaker: doctor
text: Hi, how old are you madam?

speaker: patient
text: I am ninety three. I am a super duper old Swedish woman.

speaker: doctor
text: Ha! Not so old okay!

speaker: patient
text: I had vomiting episodes and I am feeling very nauseous.

speaker: doctor
text: Oh I am so sorry to hear that.

speaker: patient
text: I have pain in urination too, I think I might have the U T I?

speaker: doctor
text: Let's see here. So you already have a right hip issue, bone disease, hypertension, depression, and heart rhythm disorder for a long time.

speaker: patient
text: Yes that is correct.

speaker: doctor
text: Let me see what we can do here.

speaker: patient
text: Thank you doctor.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you drink?

speaker: patient
text: No, never!

speaker: doctor
text: Did you ever smoke?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: How about drugs? Marijuana or anything?

speaker: patient
text: Well, I always stayed away from drugs.

speaker: doctor
text: Good. And what is your living arrangement? Do you stay with your kids?

speaker: patient
text: I live at my place. My kids visit me but mostly I live alone.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: Good afternoon, how old are you?

speaker: patient
text: Hello Doctor, I'm fifty four years old.

speaker: doctor
text: What gender do you identify with?

speaker: patient
text: I identify as a female.

speaker: doctor
text: Thank you. What symptoms are you experiencing in your right hand?

speaker: patient
text: I have numbness and tingling in my right hand.

speaker: doctor
text: Are there any specific fingers that you feel it in?

speaker: patient
text: I really feel it in my fifth, fourth, and third fingers.

speaker: doctor
text: What kind of treatments have you done for this pain?

speaker: patient
text: I've taken antiinflammatories, stayed away from sports and stuff like that, and rested.

speaker: doctor
text: Has this helped at all?

speaker: patient
text: No, not at all, its still numb and tingling.

speaker: doctor
text: This sounds like carpal tunnel, there's a quick, minimally invasive surgery I can do on this hand, since it hasn't responded to nonoperative treatments. I think that'll really help.

speaker: patient
text: I'd like to do that, what's the name of the procedure?

speaker: doctor
text: Its called a carpal tunnel release.

speaker: doctor
text: Oh, how long?

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: How about fever nausea vomiting diarrhea?

speaker: doctor
text: Okay great.

speaker: doctor
text: What do you do? Are you working or in school?

speaker: patient
text: I am in school.

speaker: doctor
text: Good.

speaker: patient
text: Thanks.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any children, ma'am?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I have a wonderful baby girl at home.

speaker: doctor
text: Wonderful, were there any complications with your pregnancy or delivery?

speaker: patient
text: Nope, everything went very smooth. I'm thankful.

speaker: doctor
text: Good, have you ever been hospitalized for any issue?

speaker: patient
text: No, thankfully.

speaker: doctor
text: Good, so I can assume you've never had surgery?

speaker: patient
text: Correct, I never have.

speaker: doctor
text: Any past surgeries that I should know of?

speaker: patient
text: I had a hip replacement years ago.

speaker: doctor
text: Both hips?

speaker: patient
text: My left.

speaker: doctor
text: Total?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah.

speaker: doctor
text: Got it.

speaker: patient
text: I also had my uterus and appendix removed. I was young when I had my appendix taken out.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you happen to remember who did your most recent surgeries?

speaker: patient
text: Wish I did. I'd have to look back at my records and get back to you. I have everything at home.

speaker: doctor
text: That's no problem. I should be able to look it up from my end, too.

speaker: doctor
text: Where do you live?

speaker: patient
text: I live with my mother around the corner where the Whole Foods is. I have been there for a few years now.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you the mother of the patient?

speaker: doctor
text: How are you dealing with everything?

speaker: doctor
text: Are you taking any medications?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I am taking Accutane for my acne issues.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, any other medicines?

speaker: patient
text: No, just that.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any history of surgeries, sir?

speaker: patient
text: The most recent was seven years ago. I had a craniotomy. I had a brain hemorrhage and there was bleed inside and outside the brain that they had to fix.

speaker: doctor
text: How was the recovery for that?

speaker: patient
text: I took a while but the doctors said I had a normal recovery time.

speaker: doctor
text: That is good. Have you had any other surgeries?

speaker: patient
text: I had surgery on my leg for a fracture. They put some pins in my leg.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

speaker: patient
text: I had some kind of surgery done on my stomach when I was a kid. I am not sure what the surgery was. All I know is that it was a very common procedure with no complications.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay. Is that all?

speaker: patient
text: Yep. That's it.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any past medical problems that I should know about?

speaker: patient
text: Well, what exactly do you mean by that, doctor?

speaker: doctor
text: Well, it could be anything from A D H D to depression to epilepsy.

speaker: patient
text: Oh, no. I don't have anything like that.

speaker: doctor
text: So, lets talk about your family, anybody in your family have any neurological problems?

speaker: patient
text: No, I don't think so, my parents did experience some memory loss but that was when they were in their nineties. And I am assuming it was mostly from the old age rather than any neuro problem.

speaker: doctor
text: Yeah, that is true. And how about your brothers and sisters, do you have any?

speaker: patient
text: Oh yeah, I have five siblings and they are pretty healthy! I mean all of them are doing good, no one has any memory issues as far as I know or any neuro related illness.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any family history of heart disease?

speaker: patient
text: My mother has coronary artery disease.

speaker: doctor
text: Hello, miss X Y Z. Dr. X and I will go over your report with you to make sure everything is correct. Then, I will ask you a few questions.

speaker: patient
text: Sounds good to me.

speaker: patient
text: I'm seventy six years old. I'm also a resident of A S D F if that matters.

speaker: doctor
text: Doctor A B  C requested for you to see us, correct?

speaker: patient
text: That's correct.

speaker: doctor
text: Perfect. Doctor X, could you go over her previous diagnoses?

speaker: patient
text: Sounds about right.

speaker: doctor
text: I see she underwent a procedure. What was it, Doctor X?

speaker: patient
text: He did. He also did surgery on my lower legs.

speaker: doctor
text: I see after the surgery, you had some pain in your right L four distribution, correct?

speaker: patient
text: That's correct.

speaker: doctor
text: Doctor X, did the M R I report of the outside lumbar come in?

speaker: doctor
text: What does the C T myelogram say?

speaker: doctor
text: I see. There are some notes from Doctor Reitman. What does it say?

speaker: doctor
text: I see. Could you review the M R I film as well?

speaker: doctor
text: Thank you for that. So, miss. Where are you feeling pain today?

speaker: patient
text: I feel it in the font of my lower leg and right hip.

speaker: doctor
text: What kind of pain are you feeling?

speaker: patient
text: I told Doctor X about it. He could let you know.

speaker: doctor
text: I see. Is it worse when you do certain activities?

speaker: patient
text: Yes. When I walk and stand.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you able to walk at all?

speaker: patient
text: I can walk around a block before it gets to the point where I get weak.

speaker: doctor
text: When does it feel better?

speaker: patient
text: I feel more comfortable when I'm resting, sitting, sleeping, or getting a massage.

speaker: doctor
text: From a scale of zero to ten, with ten being the worst pain, how would you rate the pain on average?

speaker: patient
text: I'd say like a nine.

speaker: doctor
text: That's the intensity on a daily level, correct?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, that's correct.

speaker: doctor
text: What's the lowest pain you've ever felt?

speaker: patient
text: I think it was a five.

speaker: doctor
text: I see. Doctor X, did you ask her the series of questions about bowel function?

speaker: doctor
text: Great. Have you taken any medication recently?

speaker: patient
text: Uh. I think it starts with a T.

speaker: patient
text: That's correct.

speaker: patient
text: Um, do I have to follow some special or soft diet?

speaker: doctor
text: No, nothing like that. You can have a normal diet. Whatever you like to eat.

speaker: patient
text: At this age, my diet is very limited. I am going to be eighty-two next month.

speaker: doctor
text: Well, I don't think you need to restrict your diet. You can follow your regular diet.

speaker: patient
text: Alright, thank you.

speaker: doctor
text: Do migraine headaches run in the family?

speaker: patient
text: My mother gets migraines and she told me that it runs on her side of the family.

speaker: doctor
text: Any family history of blood clots?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you married?

speaker: patient
text: I was, but my husband died thirty years ago.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you working?

speaker: patient
text: Nope.

speaker: doctor
text: What is your highest degree?

speaker: patient
text: I did high school. I was living alone for fifteen years until December of ninety four.

speaker: doctor
text: How is your living situation now? Who is taking care of you?

speaker: patient
text: My daughters have started taking care of me on a shareable basis.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you smoke? Or drink or have ever used any drugs.

speaker: patient
text: Nope.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you smoke, or have you smoked in the past?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I quit two years ago. But before that I used to smoke two packs per day. I first started smoking as a teenager.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you drink at all?

speaker: patient
text: I used to drink six packs of beer plus two additional drinks a day for many years. Good news is that I've been dry for two years now.

speaker: doctor
text: Any illicit drug use, such as cocaine, marijuana or heroin?

speaker: patient
text: No none of that.

speaker: doctor
text: Hello, miss. How are you doing today? It looks like we are evaluating C O P D and emphysema.

speaker: patient
text: Yes, the last time I was seen in Pulmonary Medicine Clinic was March two thousand and four.

speaker: doctor
text: It has been quite some time. How are you feeling?

speaker: patient
text: I have actually been hospitalized for psychiatric problems and now live in a nursing facility. Things have not been too great. I don't like living there.

speaker: doctor
text: I understand the frustration. When you live in a nursing facility you lose a lot of your freedom.

speaker: patient
text: I want to live back in my apartment, but I know I am too ill to care for myself.

speaker: doctor
text: In spite of all of that how are your respiratory issues?

speaker: patient
text: I feel pretty stable. I still have shortness of breath when I do activities, but with my condition I feel like that is something I will have to live with.

speaker: doctor
text: Unfortunately, that is the nature of the disease. I am happy to see that the pulmonary disease has not changed significantly since your last visit.

speaker: patient
text: The only thing that seems to have changed is that I have a small cough and produce some mucus.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay. Do you have any fever or chills?

speaker: patient
text: No, none of that.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you experience any chest pains? I want to check especially since you have been coughing up some mucus.

speaker: patient
text: No, I luckily do not have any chest pains.

speaker: doctor
text: You can continue working, I just want you to be careful.

speaker: patient
text: Thanks Doctor. I will be.

speaker: doctor
text: Great.

speaker: doctor
text: Can you confirm your age for me, ma'am?

speaker: patient
text: Sure, I'm fifty six years old.

speaker: doctor
text: Great, so what brings you in to see me today?

speaker: patient
text: Um, I'm peeing a lot, and I'm having  a little bit blood in that urine as well.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you ever had a cystoscopy?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, it was unremarkable, that's what they told me.

speaker: doctor
text: When are your episodes for the most part?

speaker: patient
text: Um, usually during the day. I don't usually have them at night.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you having any pain with urination?

speaker: patient
text: No, no pain.

speaker: doctor
text: Aside from the little bit of blood, can you tell if there's any pus in your urine?

speaker: patient
text: No, I don't have any of that, it's just the little bit of blood.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you taken any medications for this?

speaker: patient
text: Um, I had Ditropan, and it didn't do very well.

speaker: doctor
text: Well, this ultrasound of the kidney is also unremarkable, so at this time I think we should try a different medication.

speaker: doctor
text: Any health issues on your mom or dad's side?

speaker: patient
text: No, we're a pretty healthy family.

speaker: doctor
text: Hello sir, how are you?

speaker: patient
text: I don't know, I don't know whether I am good, or my problem is getting worse and that is the reason I got myself to your clinic for a neurological consult.

speaker: doctor
text: Hm, don't worry! We will take care of you, let me start by taking some details.

speaker: patient
text: Sure!

speaker: doctor
text: So were you referred by someone or-

speaker: patient
text: Oh, no I referred myself to your clinic.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay. And what is your age?

speaker: patient
text: I am sixty four years young!

speaker: doctor
text: Ah, that's clever, you certainly look very young. And which is your dominant hand? Are you left handed, or right?

speaker: patient
text: I am right handed.

speaker: doctor
text: So, tell me what is going on with you?

speaker: patient
text: Well, lately I am having difficulty remembering names and phone numbers or even events.

speaker: doctor
text: Well, it's not uncommon.

speaker: patient
text: I know, but I am usually very good at remembering things. I would have not worried that much, but it was brought to my attention by my clerical staff.

speaker: doctor
text: Oh, okay. What do you do?

speaker: patient
text: Well, I was the catholic priest at my parish, like we have our own small administrative district and church.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, and when did you notice first that you are forgetting things?

speaker: patient
text: Around twelve months back.

speaker: doctor
text: And did it cause any problem at work or any mishaps?

speaker: patient
text: No, not at all! No social or professional faux pas whatsoever.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, I have my notes let me put the date, oh what is the date-

speaker: patient
text: It's twenty eighth of February.

speaker: doctor
text: Thank you!

speaker: doctor
text: All right, you can go home now.

speaker: patient
text: Thank you doctor.

speaker: doctor
text: You can stay at your friend's place and make sure to take good care of yourself.

speaker: patient
text: Yes.

speaker: doctor
text: Make sure you follow up with Doctor X on Monday or Tuesday. I know that Doctor Y already discussed his plans. Continue taking your medicines except Prozac. Okay?

speaker: doctor
text: Do you smoke or drink?

speaker: patient
text: Nope, I've never touched a cigarette nor do I plan on ever doing so. Same goes for alcohol.

speaker: doctor
text: Hi there! Welcome to the Neurology clinic, sir.

speaker: patient
text: Hi! Thank you.

speaker: doctor
text: What brings you in to the clinic today?

speaker: patient
text: I was diagnosed with binocular diplopia twenty five years ago but I haven't had much of an issue with it until about a year ago.

speaker: doctor
text: What did you notice as far as symptoms?

speaker: patient
text: Suddenly, I started having double vision.

speaker: doctor
text: Did the double vision happen more than one time?

speaker: patient
text: It has been happening almost every day off and on through out the day.

speaker: doctor
text: How long do the episodes last?

speaker: patient
text: They last for only a few minutes at a time. When I was first diagnosed years ago it happened for a year and then it stopped happening. It was not happening as often as it is now.

speaker: doctor
text: Did you ever receive any treatment for your binocular diplopia?

speaker: patient
text: No. It spontaneously resolved and so I didn't need to seek any treatment. Back when all this was happening it had two episodes of a drooping eyelid. I thought I had myasthenia gravis but I was told that that was probably not the case.

speaker: doctor
text: What eyelid was drooping?

speaker: patient
text: I don't remember?

speaker: doctor
text: What is your dominate hand?

speaker: patient
text: I am right handed.

speaker: doctor
text: And how old are you?

speaker: patient
text: I am sixty seven.

speaker: doctor
text: Involving the double vision, does it become worse when looking at distant objects?

speaker: patient
text: Yes.

speaker: doctor
text: When you look at objects off to either side of midline does it become worse?

speaker: patient
text: Yes. That makes it worse too. When I put my hand over one eye is goes away.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any other symptoms related to the vision issues?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: How old is your son?

speaker: doctor
text: What seems to be the problem?

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, let me see, okay, um, he has rocker bottom feet.

speaker: doctor
text: I believe he would benefit from a subtalar arthrodesis, possible autograft, and lengthening of the Achilles. I'll go over the details of that procedure right now.

speaker: doctor
text: Yes we can. But we'll probably need to do another procedure until his foot matures some more.   This is a stabilizing measure.

speaker: doctor
text: Historically, the risk of infection is very low, usually less than one percent.

speaker: doctor
text: We use prophylactic antibiotics to minimize the infection risk.

speaker: doctor
text: No, he'll need to stay off it for a while, we call this nonweightbearing. It will only be for some time after the procedure, it's not permanent.

speaker: doctor
text: The total risks of surgery include risks of anesthesia, infection, bleeding, changes in sensation and motion of the extremity, hardware failure, need for other surgical procedures, need to be nonweightbearing for some time. I would not worry about these risks, though. The risk is low.

speaker: doctor
text: Welcome back to the clinic.

speaker: patient
text: Thank you.

speaker: doctor
text: I understand that we are doing an impairment rating exam today.

speaker: patient
text: Yes, that's correct.

speaker: doctor
text: And we are evaluating your right shoulder injury. Correct?

speaker: patient
text: Yes.

speaker: doctor
text: Was this a workrelated injury?

speaker: patient
text: Yes. I was working as a C N A at the Veteran's House.

speaker: doctor
text: How did the work injury happen?

speaker: patient
text: I was transferring a patient from a wheal chair to a bed, and I hurt my shoulder.

speaker: doctor
text: What is the date of the incident?

speaker: patient
text: January first, two thousand and two.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you currently working?

speaker: patient
text: No. I have not been able to go back to work yet.

speaker: doctor
text: I am required to ask some specific questions for the L and I paperwork. What is your ago, ethnicity and gender?

speaker: patient
text: I am a thirty one year old, white, female.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you ever had a prior injury to your right shoulder?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Are right or left hand dominant?

speaker: patient
text: Right.

speaker: doctor
text: Other then your shoulder injury, do you have any other chronic health problems?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you experiencing any fever, chills or illnesses?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Let discuss some of the previous treatments and test that you have been done for your shoulder.

speaker: patient
text: Okey. I have done a lot of different treatments.

speaker: doctor
text: What treatments have you done?

speaker: patient
text: I tried physical therapy. They did a subacromion decompression treatment in November, two thousand and two.

speaker: doctor
text: Did either of those treatments help?

speaker: patient
text: Not much. I went and saw Doctor Lin and he said that I might have a nerve fiber injury. I forget what he called it.

speaker: doctor
text: Brachial plexopathy?

speaker: patient
text: Yes. That sounds right.

speaker: doctor
text: Oh, I see his notes in your chart. It says that he felt like you had a right superficial radial neuritis and blocked this with resolution of your symptoms. Then it looks like he sent you to get E M G testing at Valley Medical. Let me look for those results.

speaker: patient
text: Okey. They should be in my chart. I had Doctor Lin send over all my records.

speaker: doctor
text: Here it is. It says that the right suprascapular neuropathy although a C5 radiculopathy could not be ruled out.  MRI testing on the cervical spine was then done which was negative for disk herniation and underwent suprascapular nerve decompression of the scapular notch on December eighteenth, two thousand and three.

speaker: patient
text: Whatever that means? I ended up getting a nerve block because I was still in pain. Doctor Lin did one in the frount of my shoulder and then another in the back.

speaker: doctor
text: This has been a long drawn out course of treatments for you.

speaker: patient
text: Yes, it has been.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you up to date on your vaccines?

speaker: patient
text: I've actually never been vaccinated before. My parents don't believe in vaccines.

speaker: doctor
text: Hi there! Welcome in, sir.

speaker: patient
text: Hi! Thank you.

speaker: doctor
text: What is your past medical history?

speaker: patient
text: No. I don't have any health problems.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have a primary care doctor?

speaker: patient
text: No. I don't have health insurance right now.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you married, ma'am?

speaker: patient
text: Yes.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you smoke, use alcohol or use recreational drugs?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: patient
text: In the past I was very very fat! Actually, I was morbidly obese. I also had high blood pressure, but after my surgery it got resolved.

speaker: doctor
text: So, everything is okay now?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah.

speaker: doctor
text: So, you were referred by Doctor X.

speaker: patient
text: Yeah.

speaker: doctor
text: According to him, I see no changes or correction to your present illness, right?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I think so.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any related family history?

speaker: patient
text: You mean like heart issues in the family?

speaker: doctor
text: Yeah, something like that.

speaker: patient
text: My brother died of heart attack. It was sudden everyone was shocked.

speaker: doctor
text: How old was he?

speaker: patient
text: He was not that old; he was just in his fifties.

speaker: doctor
text: So, tell me what's going on? What brings you to the emergency?

speaker: patient
text: I felt like my heart will explode. I have never felt palpitations like this. I am feeling so weak.

speaker: doctor
text: When did it start?

speaker: patient
text: This afternoon.

speaker: doctor
text: Hm, so your blood pressure is one ninety five by eighty three and your heart rate is one twenty one which is quite high.

speaker: doctor
text: We have started you on I V Metoprolol. This will help to bring your heartrate down.

speaker: doctor
text: And you said you are sixty six?

speaker: patient
text: Yes.

speaker: doctor
text: I can tell from her reports. Her blood pressure is quite high.

speaker: doctor
text: Well, that's not good!

speaker: doctor
text: And does she drink and smoke?

speaker: doctor
text: How much do you drink Ma'am? Is it occasional?

speaker: patient
text: Well, I drink about four to five glasses of wine every day. I drank last night.

speaker: doctor
text: Well, I think you need to cut down on it.

speaker: patient
text: I am trying doctor and honestly these are all withdrawal symptoms. I have never felt like this before.

speaker: doctor
text: Hm, I understand. For now I have put you on five M G of Metoprolol and looks like your blood pressure is under control and your heart rate has come down to seventy.

speaker: doctor
text: Hello, how are you today?

speaker: patient
text: I am here for a breast cancer screening.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you gotten a mammogram before?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I have. I also try to keep up with my self examinations every few weeks.

speaker: doctor
text: That is great. I am happy to see you on top of your preventative healthcare.

speaker: patient
text: I try to be as careful as I can since my sister had breast cancer.

speaker: doctor
text: Good morning, sir.

speaker: patient
text: Good morning, doctor.

speaker: doctor
text: So, what seems to be the problem today, sir?

speaker: patient
text: Well, I've had toe problems in the past.

speaker: doctor
text: I see, what about the rest of the lower body, any problems there?

speaker: patient
text: Actually, yes, I've had left knee issues in the past, too.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have a history of any health conditions that I should be aware of, ma'am?

speaker: patient
text: Um, yeah, I had a mastectomy, and chest tube placement.

speaker: doctor
text: Oh, wow. Do you have any chronic conditions?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I have chronic A F I B.

speaker: doctor
text: How have you been handing erectile dysfunction since your last visit, sir?

speaker: patient
text: Well, I've been taking the Cialis, it's the, um, ten M G version.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you seen any improvement?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I've had some, which is good.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you had any side effects?

speaker: patient
text: No, none yet.

speaker: doctor
text: Good, can you describe your erections for me, sir?

speaker: patient
text: Well, they're firm now, and I can penetrate again for about ten minutes.

speaker: doctor
text: Good, are you having any chest pain?

speaker: patient
text: No sir, I stopped using my nitroglycerin too.

speaker: doctor
text: Good, are you having any fever or chills?

speaker: patient
text: No, nothing like that.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you having any pain with urination, or blood in the urine?

speaker: patient
text: No, nothing like that, sir, everything is normal.

speaker: doctor
text: How often do you urinate during the day?

speaker: patient
text: I go about every three hours or so, I have a good stream and everything.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you wake up at night to go to the bathroom?

speaker: patient
text: No, I sleep through the night very well.

speaker: doctor
text: Good, do you have any other conditions that I should know about?

speaker: patient
text: Well, I have a history of elevated P S A, and I had a biopsy in June when I had a, um, high grade P I N.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you know what that P S A value was?

speaker: patient
text: It was eleven point six.

speaker: doctor
text: Thank you, I see here on Doctor X's notes that there were two specimens that were too small to evaluate.

speaker: doctor
text: I am afraid, I don't have better news for you, your reports confirm cancer.

speaker: patient
text: We were suspecting it all along, but now since it is confirmed it's just hard to accept.

speaker: doctor
text: I am sorry, I totally understand. Do you want some time?

speaker: patient
text: No, I am okay.

speaker: doctor
text: Hm, you also have hypertension and diabetes.

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, that I know.

speaker: doctor
text: Did you have any chest pain or shortness of breath or uneasiness?

speaker: patient
text: No, I don't have any heart condition.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay and no dizziness or loss of consciousness or stroke like symptoms?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay. Well, your B M I looks fine, that means you are not overweight.

speaker: patient
text: Hm.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you married?

speaker: patient
text: Yes. I am happily living together with my husband and my four kids.

speaker: doctor
text: Oh, do you smoke?

speaker: patient
text: Nope.

speaker: doctor
text: What about alcohol or any other kind of drug use?

speaker: patient
text: Nope.

speaker: doctor
text: Anyone in the family had any medical issues?

speaker: patient
text: Oh yes.

speaker: doctor
text: Can you please elaborate?

speaker: patient
text: So, my mother's side family had heart issues. My dad's sister had sugar problem.

speaker: doctor
text: And you are not allergic to anything right?

speaker: patient
text: That's right.

speaker: doctor
text: Any drugs or pollens or anything?

speaker: patient
text: Nope nothing.

speaker: doctor
text: Good.

speaker: doctor
text: Has the redness worsened over the last few days?

speaker: doctor
text: Is she otherwise healthy?

speaker: doctor
text: You had a surgery on your breasts?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, they removed lump from my left breast.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, and what other surgeries have you had?

speaker: patient
text: I do not have a gall bladder, then I had a breast augmentation, I have had heart surgeries three times and they have removed half of my pancreas.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

speaker: patient
text: And knee surgery too, on the left side.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay. What type of heart surgery did you have?

speaker: patient
text: Cardiac ablation.

speaker: doctor
text: What happened?

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, that's good.

speaker: doctor
text: What is your family medical history?

speaker: patient
text: My family has high blood pressure and diabetes.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any family history of nervous system disorder or disease such as multiple sclerosis, Alzheimer's disease, Parkinson's disease, epilepsy, or stroke?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any children, miss?

speaker: patient
text: Yes. I have a son, he was born on October thirty first, two thousand and eight.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you ever had any heart problems in the past?

speaker: patient
text: I remember I did have something heart related but I don't know what that was. I do not understand any medical terms.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay that's fine, I completely understand. We will try to look for your  past medical history.

speaker: patient
text: I do have hypertension and diabetes, you know that right?

speaker: doctor
text: Yes, type two diabetes. Do you know of any other things that you had in the past?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, four years back I had lung embolism. I also get frequent urine infections.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay. And I can see on the file that you have high cholesterol and a gastric ulcer too.

speaker: patient
text: Yes, that's about right.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay. What surgeries have you had in the past?

speaker: patient
text: I have had my appendix taken out, then C Section, cataract surgery and hernia repair done in the past.

speaker: doctor
text: Good afternoon, ma'am.

speaker: patient
text: Good afternoon, doctor.

speaker: doctor
text: So, are you married?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, happily to my husband.

speaker: doctor
text: That's wonderful, um, what do you do for a living?

speaker: patient
text: I work as an office manager right now.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you smoke?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I do. I've smoked a pack a day for the last twenty years.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you drink?

speaker: patient
text: Actually, yes, I drink daily.

speaker: doctor
text: How much do you drink every day?

speaker: patient
text: Well, it varies, but usually about anywhere from three to five drinks a day.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, do you do any illicit drugs?

speaker: patient
text: No, absolutely not.

speaker: doctor
text: What do you do for exercise?

speaker: patient
text: Well, I go for walks, and like low impact cardio. But, I do like playing softball with my friends too.

speaker: doctor
text: Very nice, how often do you exercise?

speaker: patient
text: I work out a few times a month.

speaker: doctor
text: I'm going to run down a list of symptoms and I'd like you to tell me if you've experienced any.

speaker: patient
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: Headache?

speaker: patient
text: No headaches.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you coughing at all? And if yes, then are you bringing up any blood with your cough?

speaker: patient
text: No cough.

speaker: doctor
text: Any chest pain or shortness of breath that wakes you in the middle of the night?

speaker: patient
text: Nope.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you feel short of breath when you move around?

speaker: patient
text: Nope.

speaker: doctor
text: Any visual, hearing, or swallowing problems?

speaker: patient
text: None.

speaker: doctor
text: And finally any changes to your bowel movements or urinary habits?

speaker: patient
text: Nope. All normal.

speaker: doctor
text: Looking at your medical history now. Any changes since your last visit?

speaker: patient
text: No changes.

speaker: doctor
text: Hello, sir. Looks like we are here for a general wellness check?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, sir. In my seventy eight years on this Earth, I have learned to take my health more seriously. I need to start catching things before they come, not after.

speaker: doctor
text: I could not agree more. From your last checkup notes, it looks like you had right knee surgery and back surgery about eighteen months ago. How is that going? Any pain?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I had a right knee replacement. I am doing great so far. Nothing to complain about. I can do almost anything I desire now. It is such a good lifestyle change from before surgery.

speaker: doctor
text: What do you do with your new body?

speaker: patient
text: I travel every chance I get. I just got back from a cruise.

speaker: doctor
text: I hope to be as agile as you when I get to retirement. Now let's check the other systems. Do you feel any type of chest pain? Any heaviness, tightness or pressure?

speaker: patient
text: No, nothing like that.

speaker: doctor
text: How about shortness of breath?

speaker: patient
text: I only get short of breath when I walk up the stairs.

speaker: doctor
text: That is decently normal. I get out of breath when walking from floor to floor in this hospital too.

speaker: patient
text: I thought so. I remember being young and still struggling with stairs.

speaker: doctor
text: Unfortunately, some things are just with us for life. Do you have any coughing fits or irregular heart beating?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Great! You are getting a clean bill of health from me today. On the notes it says you have Crohn's disease. Are you getting regularly checked for that?

speaker: patient
text: Yes. Doctor Ferguson takes care of me for that.

speaker: doctor
text: Excellent. Are you scheduled for a prostate check?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I go to Doctor Roszhart.

speaker: doctor
text: You are wonderfully on top of it. What a breath of fresh air. From all of your travelling, how are your ankles? Have you noticed any swelling?

speaker: patient
text: Surprisingly, from all the walking I do, I do not have any swelling. After quitting smoking ten years ago I had to get addicted to something else and that was walking and travelling.

speaker: doctor
text: And when did you had your last tetanus shot?

speaker: patient
text: Um, I don't remember correctly, but it should be in my reports. I did have one sometime back, just don't remember when exactly.

speaker: doctor
text: Ah, no problem. I see it here in your reports and it's up to date. So that's good.

speaker: patient
text: Cool.

speaker: doctor
text: So where do you stay?

speaker: patient
text: I stay nearby in my apartment.

speaker: doctor
text: Alone?

speaker: patient
text: No, I stay with my boyfriend.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, and do you smoke and drink?

speaker: patient
text: Both.

speaker: doctor
text: And how much would say you smoke per day?

speaker: patient
text: Well, I smoke a lot. Seven to eight packs per day.

speaker: doctor
text: Oh! And for how many years?

speaker: patient
text: I don't remember exactly but for many, many years, I have a long history of chain smoking.

speaker: doctor
text: Hm. And alcohol?

speaker: patient
text: Same, I drink heavily. I have been drinking for many years.

speaker: doctor
text: Hm.

speaker: doctor
text: How are you, sir?

speaker: patient
text: One less than sixty.

speaker: doctor
text: So, what happened?

speaker: patient
text: I was visiting my son in Cheyenne, Wyoming, then I on October tenth when I was taking a shower, I felt a pop in my head. I don't know what happened after that.

speaker: doctor
text: Yeah, his report says he got a hemorrhage, I mean, blood clot in his brain.

speaker: doctor
text: Is this your first surgery or have you had other surgeries in the past?

speaker: patient
text: This will be my second. I had a hernia repair back in O ten.

speaker: doctor
text: Where do you work?

speaker: patient
text: I work at the Hilton as a head chef.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you smoke or consume any form of tobacco?

speaker: patient
text: Nope.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you drink or have ever used any illegal drug?

speaker: patient
text: No, none of that.

speaker: doctor
text: Where do you feel the most pain?

speaker: patient
text: I'd have to say at the heels of my feet. I spend a lot of time on my feet at work.

speaker: doctor
text: I see. What kind of shoes do you normally wear to work?

speaker: patient
text: Regular tennis shoes.

speaker: doctor
text: Are they cushioned?

speaker: patient
text: Eh not really, but they're pretty durable.

speaker: doctor
text: I'd advise getting an orthotic for your shoes to help with the heel pain and resting your feet when you're home. In the meantime, I'd like for you to see a specialist to make sure nothing else is going on.

speaker: patient
text: Alright, I'm good with that plan.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you having any other problems? Joint pain, difficulty walking, nausea, vomiting, or other symptoms?

speaker: patient
text: No, just heel pain for now.

speaker: doctor
text: I'm here to take your social history. So, tell me about yourself.

speaker: patient
text: I was taking drugs. I tried all the methods, mainly I was using inhalation and I V drugs.

speaker: doctor
text: Right now, you are on methadone, right?

speaker: patient
text: Yes. I'm also going to the psychiatry department for my depression and these drug issues.

speaker: doctor
text: What is your living status?

speaker: patient
text: I live with my roommate.

speaker: doctor
text: I will ask you a few questions about your family history, sir.

speaker: patient
text: That's okay.

speaker: doctor
text: Does anyone in your family ever have any medical problems?

speaker: patient
text: Both of my parents had diabetes.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you aware of any medical issues in your family?

speaker: patient
text: I don't know.

speaker: doctor
text: What about your paternal family?

speaker: patient
text: I don't know my father. No idea about his family.

speaker: doctor
text: What about your mom?  Maternal family?

speaker: patient
text: I have no idea. I'm not in contact with her.

speaker: doctor
text: Good morning, sir. Before we begin, how old are you?

speaker: patient
text: Good morning, doctor. I'm forty one.

speaker: doctor
text: Thank you, and how long have you had this left knee pain?

speaker: patient
text: It's been about two years now.

speaker: doctor
text: Is there an injury?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I sprained my MCL while playing hockey back then.

speaker: doctor
text: What kind of symptoms have you had in this knee since then?

speaker: patient
text: Well, the knee locks up on me, I can't extend it all the way, and it just hurts really bad if I try to.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you feel any instability?

speaker: patient
text: No, not at all.

speaker: doctor
text: I see here that you've been feeling more short of breath.

speaker: patient
text: Yes, for three days now.

speaker: doctor
text: Is it worse when you exert yourself?

speaker: patient
text: Um no, not really. I've had a terrible cough along with frequent headaches and chest congestion. I have also had a low fever.

speaker: doctor
text: Did these symptoms start around the same time?

speaker: patient
text: I think so.

speaker: doctor
text: Where does your chest feel most congested? And how would you rate the pain right now? Ten being the worst.

speaker: patient
text: Both sides. I'd say it's at a three currently.

speaker: doctor
text: Does it send pain or numbness or tingling down your arms? How about any jaw pain as a result?

speaker: patient
text: No, but it does get worse whenever I cough.

speaker: doctor
text: Is this your first time experiencing this type of congestion?

speaker: patient
text: Oh no. I had something like it about ten months ago.

speaker: doctor
text: Did that improve on its own?

speaker: patient
text: It would come and go, but over the past few days it's gotten worse. I am a strong German man so I held out coming to the doctor as long as I could.

speaker: doctor
text: You are very strong! You are sixty nine though, so I don't think anyone would see it as weak if you came to the doctor more often.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you aware of any medical problems in your family?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Anyone with any heart disease or diabetes?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Besides pain in your left eye, are you having any other problems?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you happen to have a history of eye problems?

speaker: patient
text: None.

speaker: doctor
text: Hello, sir how can I help you? Looks like we are talking about snoring today.

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I need to get this loud and obnoxious snoring under control. I keep waking up my partner. I have a C P A P right now because I was told I have almost severe sleep apnea.

speaker: doctor
text: Yes, I see on your chart that you were given ten centimeters of H two O nasal pressure and that you predominately suffer from hypopnea. Hypopnea is shallow breathing. How has the device been working?

speaker: patient
text: It definitely has reduced my snoring, but my partner keeps waking me up in the middle of the night because the mask pops off. I wear it around five to seven nights a week, but for some reason it falls off or I take it off randomly in the night. My wife usually must remind me to put it back on.

speaker: doctor
text: So what is your sleep pattern now? When do you usually go to bed and wake up?

speaker: patient
text: Usually I sleep around eleven or eleven thirty and wake up at six or seven on the weekends. I'll sleep in until eight or nine on the weekdays. On Saturday's I might go to sleep around midnight because I usually watch a show with my family. I feel good when I wake up though. Much less tossing and turning. The sheets are always on the bed still.

speaker: doctor
text: That's some good news. I see you have lost a bit of weight too. Around fifteen to eighteen pounds is something to be proud of.

speaker: patient
text: Thanks. It has been a lot of exercising and dieting. I am motivated because I want to stop snoring.

speaker: doctor
text: How has work been? Do you think it has been stressful at all?

speaker: patient
text: I still work at Smith Barney in downtown Baltimore. I work from around eight or eight thirty to five or five thirty. I deal with training on how to sell managed funds and accounts. I do not think I have been stressed because I am able to stay awake through my shift and even when I come home at night. I may get a little tired during hay fever season, but that is rare.

speaker: doctor
text: Yes, I see that you have hay fever. Fatigue is a common symptom from the allergy.

speaker: doctor
text: How are you feeling today?

speaker: patient
text: I have a lot of anxiety.

speaker: doctor
text: Anything else?

speaker: patient
text: I have a lot of pain in my chest as well.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you drink?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I cannot stop myself. I have tried many times but it's hard to control.

speaker: doctor
text: So, do you smoke?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: How about alcohol?

speaker: patient
text: I drink, but just normal. I don't have any alcohol problem.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay. So, no history of any drug or alcohol abuse, right?

speaker: patient
text: No, not at all.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: Hi, how can I help you?

speaker: patient
text: I am here for a follow up on my heart rhythm problem. I think it is atrial fibrillation.

speaker: doctor
text: Oh yes. You are not on Cardizem and your heart rate is up just a little bit today.

speaker: patient
text: That's right. I misplaced it.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay. Let me see. What symptoms are you experiencing right now?

speaker: patient
text: I am feeling very dizzy. I do have some vertigo and lightheadedness.

speaker: doctor
text: You are on blood thinners, right? That is Coumadin therapy? Or am I wrong here?

speaker: patient
text: No, you are right but please stop the Coumadin. I am tired of these regular blood draws.

speaker: doctor
text: See, I understand it is hard to control it. It is difficult to regulate that.

speaker: patient
text: Yes exactly. That is why I don't want it. Give me something simple.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay I will investigate it. Are you experiencing any chest pain or shortness of breath?

speaker: patient
text: Oh no, I am not feeling that.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay great!

speaker: patient
text: Actually, I am moving around a little bit better now and my arm does not hurt.

speaker: doctor
text: How about your back pain?

speaker: patient
text: Um, it is improving as well.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, cool.

speaker: patient
text: Yeah.

speaker: doctor
text: Good morning, young man.

speaker: patient
text: Good morning, doctor.

speaker: doctor
text: Who is this young lady, is this your grandmother, or sister?

speaker: doctor
text: Good, my chart says that you're fourteen years old. Is that correct?

speaker: patient
text: Yes sir.

speaker: doctor
text: Good, so what seems to be the problem today?

speaker: patient
text: I've been having pain in this knee for about a month now.

speaker: doctor
text: Can you remember a specific injury to this knee?

speaker: patient
text: Um, yeah, I was playing basketball when I jumped, and then when I landed I felt this knee pop.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you remember the date of your injury, young man?

speaker: doctor
text: Good, so how have you been treated for this so far?

speaker: patient
text: We went to another clinic first, and they put me in a splint.

speaker: doctor
text: Have they taken x rays yet?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I got back a few minutes ago.

speaker: doctor
text: Let's have a look. Well, you broke your leg.

speaker: patient
text: What, where? Can you show me?

speaker: doctor
text: Right here, this is a tibial tubercule avulsion fracture with patella alta.

speaker: doctor
text: Well, he's broken his leg, and pulled some bone off by doing so. We'll need to do surgery on this.

speaker: doctor
text: It's called an O R I F. We'll go in there with some hardware to put everything back together, and he can get on the road to healing.

speaker: doctor
text: Historically, it's less than one percent. We use antibiotics to control for infection.

speaker: doctor
text: Yes, he won't feel a thing.

speaker: doctor
text: We can remove everything once he has healed up nicely. Other risks include bleeding, changes in the sensation of the leg, hardware failure, need for post op rehab, need for hardware removal, and failure to restore extensor mechanism tension. But I would not worry about these things. I have been doing these surgeries for years and things like this rarely happen.

speaker: doctor
text: Good afternoon, ma'am. Can you confirm your age for me, please?

speaker: patient
text: Sure, good afternoon, doctor. I'm sixty one years old.

speaker: doctor
text: Great, what brings you in for a visit today?

speaker: patient
text: I have some notes here with me, but I have a history of polyarteritis nodosa mononeuritis multiplex.

speaker: doctor
text: Is this in your legs, or arms?

speaker: patient
text: Um, it's in my legs.

speaker: doctor
text: I see here that you have sleep apnea too.

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I was involved in an overnight sleep study on C P A P and oxygen.

speaker: doctor
text: Why did they do this?

speaker: patient
text: It was in order to determine why I had difficulty falling asleep and staying asleep.

speaker: doctor
text: Have You had any other treatments?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I had a review done while I was in the hospital about two weeks ago, I have the results right here.

speaker: doctor
text: Thank you, so, how is your leg pain been managed?

speaker: patient
text: Um, I take pretty substantial doses of opioids in order to control it.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any swelling?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I take Lasix for my leg swelling.

speaker: doctor
text: How do you sleep with the C P A P?

speaker: patient
text: I can fall asleep with it, but I usually rip my mask off because I toss and turn.

speaker: doctor
text: How would you rate your quality of sleep?

speaker: patient
text: I'd, um, say it's pretty terrible.

speaker: doctor
text: Hi there, what's going on?

speaker: doctor
text: Oh, you did the right thing. Ma'am, how are you feeling?

speaker: doctor
text: Oh, okay.How old is she?

speaker: doctor
text: Oh, I see. She has expressive aphasia, correct?

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, let me check her. She does have a droop to her right side of the face. Ma'am, do you feel any weakness on the right side of your body?

speaker: doctor
text: She had her C T scan earlier today and I have the report. It does not show any acute attack or anything.

speaker: doctor
text: But it does show that she has a new onset of a stroke.

speaker: doctor
text: I think we need to admit her for observation. We need to monitor her. We will also get her a proper treatment for her urinary infection which is not getting better due to resistance to the oral medicines.

speaker: doctor
text: Yeah, let me talk to the nurse.

speaker: doctor
text: Hello, are you translating for the patient today? I am sorry, but I do not speak Spanish.

speaker: doctor
text: My chart says this man is fifty two years old, is all of that correct?

speaker: doctor
text: Good, so, what seems to be the problem today?

speaker: doctor
text: Oh no, when was this?

speaker: doctor
text: Which knee did he injure?

speaker: doctor
text: How has he been treated for this so far?

speaker: doctor
text: What did the P C P recommend?

speaker: doctor
text: Do you smoke cigarettes?

speaker: patient
text: I smoke about three packs in a month.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you drink alcohol or use recreational drugs?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: What do you do for work?

speaker: patient
text: I am an editorial assistant at the local newspaper.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you had any adverse reactions to medications you've taken in the past?

speaker: patient
text: No, thankfully.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you okay?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, yeah, I am fine.

speaker: doctor
text: I am asking this as you look a little pale.

speaker: patient
text: No I am okay. I have always been healthy my whole life. Just a little fatigued now.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay that won't be something we can't fix.

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, but I am okay.

speaker: doctor
text: Yes, I do not see any issues with your past history.

speaker: patient
text: As I said, I am healthy.

speaker: doctor
text: Hello today I have my assistant with me, and she will be representing your case. Tell me who do we have today?

speaker: doctor
text: Did you go and see a psychiatrist?

speaker: patient
text: I did. It was okay.

speaker: doctor
text: What brings you here today?

speaker: patient
text: My headaches are back. They are very severe this time. It all happened that, after that scan.

speaker: doctor
text: When did she have her scan?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, and after that I'm having these very bad headaches.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you able to sleep in the night properly?

speaker: patient
text: No, these headaches wake me up in the night. I haven't had a proper sleep in like ages.

speaker: doctor
text: Is there anything that elevates this pain? Or decreases it?

speaker: patient
text: Everything seems like increasing it. It just gets worse with coughing, straining, sneezing, even when I'm trying to stand. I tried all the medications, but nothing is helpful. There was Imitrex and I also tried Motrin eight hundred M G twice a day, but nothing seems to be like effective. Actually, it helps a bit when I lie down.

speaker: doctor
text: Is it like specific to any particular area of your head?

speaker: patient
text: It is like all over but, uh, very much intense in the forehead.

speaker: doctor
text: Is there any nausea associated with the headaches?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Anything else that happens along with these headaches?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I get that ringing sound in my ears, and I just don't feel well.

speaker: doctor
text: Any changes in your vision?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, it gets blurry, and I feel like lights are dimming. I will be meeting Doctor Y tomorrow.

speaker: doctor
text: Any other thing you want to add?

speaker: patient
text: No, that's it.

speaker: doctor
text: Tell me about the medical issues you had in the past or still do.

speaker: patient
text: Well, I have asthma, sinus. I also have hives and there is a history of psoriasis.

speaker: doctor
text: Wow, okay. Any known allergies?

speaker: patient
text: Nothing that I have known.

speaker: doctor
text: Any known allergies?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Hello there, how are you doing?

speaker: patient
text: Sorry, I'm just not feeling well. Something is wrong.

speaker: doctor
text: Don't worry, I will check you up. We will figure it out. Do you remember when you had your last physical?

speaker: patient
text: It was sometime in early May in two thousand and eight.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, I'm going through your chart. It looks like you have not been feeling well for about two weeks now.

speaker: patient
text: That's right.

speaker: doctor
text: Tell me what is happening exactly.

speaker: patient
text: In the beginning I was thinking that it was just the stress and anxiety, but then I become worried that it might be something really different or something bad.

speaker: doctor
text: What are you experiencing exactly? What are your symptoms?

speaker: patient
text: It started with a lot of palpitations at first. My heart was beating so fast it looks like it was ready to go out. I was having this fluttering feeling in my chest.

speaker: doctor
text: Were you feeling tired or fatigued?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, very much for the last two weeks. I am worried it's my job. It is really getting to me.

speaker: doctor
text: What else are you feeling?

speaker: patient
text: Feeling very nervous an anxious actually.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you noticed anything that you are doing or anything else that kind of increasing these symptoms?

speaker: patient
text: Oh yeah, whenever I'm stressed. I feel like I have more palpitations and to the level that it causes a lot of chest pain.

speaker: doctor
text: Is it the same when you are doing a lot of physical stuff like physical activities or something like that?

speaker: patient
text: Nope. Haven't noticed it with the exertion part.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any history of any heart issues in the past?

speaker: patient
text: I had the same kind of symptoms like nine or ten years ago.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay. What did you do that time? How did you recover?

speaker: patient
text: Well, at that time a full work up was done but everything came out to be negative, so they just gave me something for my nerves. It kind of helped.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you remember what they gave you? Like name or anything of the medicine.

speaker: patient
text: No. It was many years ago, I don't remember.

speaker: doctor
text: Anything else going on?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, for the last three days and I am having these tummy issues. I'm having on and off nausea and also, my stools are coming loose.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you seen any color change in your bowel movements?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, it's been some really funny green color. I don't know what's going on inside.

speaker: doctor
