text: Have you ever noticed blood in the stools?

speaker: patient
text: Nope.

speaker: doctor
text: Is there any pain in your tummy?

speaker: patient
text: Nope, it's just some nausea.

speaker: doctor
text: How's your appetite?

speaker: patient
text: Not as good as before.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you smoke?

speaker: patient
text: I never did.

speaker: doctor
text: So just to double check, you're not on any medications?

speaker: patient
text: You got it. Nothing since last year.

speaker: doctor
text: What brings you in today?

speaker: patient
text: I have this nasty cough and my nose has been super stuffy.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you bringing anything up when you cough?

speaker: patient
text: Not really, no.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you having any other symptoms, such as chest pain, headaches, nausea, or vomiting?

speaker: patient
text: No. I did have a slight headache last night but I took Advil and it's since gotten better.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you taking anything for the cough or stuffy nose?

speaker: patient
text: Just drinking tea and taking cough drops here and there.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay. Let's take a look at you. Hm it appears that you have a U R I.

speaker: doctor
text: How are you feeling today, sir?

speaker: patient
text: I feel pretty weak right now, but I am doing okay at the moment.

speaker: doctor
text: I reviewed the chart notes that was sent to me by the nursing home. They also sent me your medical history. You have been going through a lot recently.

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I have. They moved me into the nursing home after I was released from the hospital. I hope that it is just temporary.

speaker: doctor
text: I understand that you had a seizer and that is why you were taken to the hospital.

speaker: patient
text: I had multiple seizures. After I was stabilized from the last seizure this side of my body in not working right.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay so you are having some partial weakness on this side?

speaker: patient
text: Yes. That is why they moved me to the nursing home. I can't stand up. I am too weak. I can't take care of myself. The nurses have to help me do everything.

speaker: doctor
text: I am going to try to help you get back to doing things on your own.

speaker: patient
text: After being in the hospital I got an infection in my intestines. They put me on some antibiotic that I have never heard of and a probiotic.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay. I see here in the chart that you had two surgeries on July sixth.

speaker: patient
text: Yes, and then I had a radiation treatment too.

speaker: doctor
text: Oh yes. On August seventh.

speaker: patient
text: That sounds right.

speaker: doctor
text: Your surgeries may have been the reason for the C diff.

speaker: patient
text: What is C diff?

speaker: doctor
text: It is an infection in the large intestine. It is often caused by overuse of antibiotics, and you have been on them for a while due to the surgeries that you have had. Or it could be from the surgery itself.

speaker: patient
text: That make since.

speaker: doctor
text: How is your sleep? Are you sleeping well?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, without any disturbance. I sleep like a log!

speaker: doctor
text: Good. Any mood swings or did you feel your emotions are out of control?

speaker: patient
text: Nah, just the normal mood swings around my periods otherwise no problem at all.

speaker: doctor
text: Any depression like feeling, sudden mood changes or feeling sad or hopeless?

speaker: patient
text: Nope!

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: How's he doing today?

speaker: doctor
text: Oh, wow. Let's see what we can do.

speaker: patient
text: Help! I need help! I need to see the doctor!

speaker: doctor
text: Yes, what's wrong? Where's your pain?

speaker: patient
text: My stomach! It hurts so much! I've never had this type of pain before!

speaker: doctor
text: When did it start?

speaker: patient
text: At ten! I don't know. It started hurting out of nowhere. One second I'm driving home and the next thing I know I had to call-

speaker: doctor
text: Yes?

speaker: patient
text: The pain is so bad! It's hard for me to even think straight.

speaker: doctor
text: Just want to ask you few routine questions, let me know if any of this is positive.

speaker: patient
text: Sure, go ahead.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any problems like headache, fever, rash, oral ulcer?

speaker: patient
text: None.

speaker: doctor
text: Any problem with vision? Like unable to see or double vision?

speaker: patient
text: Um no, I can see everything.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay. Do you get palpitations, like are you aware of your own heart?

speaker: patient
text: No, nothing like that.

speaker: doctor
text: How about breathlessness while lying down or do you have to get up in the middle of the night to catch a breath?

speaker: patient
text: No I don't feel anything like that.

speaker: doctor
text: That's great. Any diarrhea, constipation, or red blood come out in stool? Or pale stool? Like any change in the color of stool?

speaker: patient
text: No, it is fine.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay. Any jaundice recently?

speaker: patient
text: No. No jaundice.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have problems with appetite?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I mean you can say my appetite is decreased.

speaker: doctor
text: Because of that have you noticed any weight loss?

speaker: patient
text: Oh no.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay sounds good.

speaker: patient
text: Sure.

speaker: doctor
text: Good morning, ma'am. What seems to be the problem with your knee?

speaker: patient
text: I've had pain in this knee since I tripped on some ice on March tenth two thousand three.

speaker: doctor
text: How old are you now?

speaker: patient
text: I'm forty seven.

speaker: doctor
text: What kind of symptoms have you had since the fall?

speaker: patient
text: It's hard for me to stand up without significant pain, and it feels like my knee is going to give way.

speaker: doctor
text: Has this knee given out before?

speaker: patient
text: It has.

speaker: doctor
text: Is there any swelling in this knee?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I also feel a popping, like when I go up the stairs.

speaker: doctor
text: What kind of treatments have you had for this knee?

speaker: patient
text: I've had antiinflammatories and P T, but I didn't respond well at all.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you had surgery on this knee in the past?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, but I can't remember the name of the operation.

speaker: doctor
text: How're you doing today, sir?

speaker: patient
text: Uh I'm hanging in there.

speaker: doctor
text: I see that you've recently celebrated your seventy second birthday.

speaker: patient
text: Yep. My kids and grandkids threw me a surprise party. It was really nice.

speaker: doctor
text: Aw surprises are always fun. However, I'm sorry to hear that you're not doing that well today.

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, me too. The other day, I had a lot of difficulty getting up from my chair because of weakness all over and a lightheadedness I can't seem to explain.

speaker: doctor
text: Is this new for you?

speaker: patient
text: Um I mean I've had falling spells several times a month for the past year, but I've always been able to get myself up one way or another.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you remember losing consciousness during any of those episodes?

speaker: patient
text: Not that I recall. I've noticed I'm a lot weaker than before so maybe that's why I keep falling more frequently.

speaker: doctor
text: I see. Do you experience room spinning dizziness at all?

speaker: patient
text: No. I also forgot to mention that four hours after not being able to get up from my chair, my left hand became numb for about two hours.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you right or left handed?

speaker: patient
text: Right handed.

speaker: doctor
text: And besides what you've mentioned to me so far, no other symptoms of concern?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: And where do you live?

speaker: patient
text: Well, I live in this small town called Fayetteville in Tennessee.

speaker: doctor
text: Ah, I see. And do you have lot of friends there?

speaker: patient
text: I have few.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, and do you drink?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: How about smoking?

speaker: patient
text: Never did!

speaker: doctor
text: How are you feeling?

speaker: patient
text: I am feeling better now.

speaker: doctor
text: What happened last night?

speaker: doctor
text: What did you take?

speaker: patient
text: I took Ecstasy. I only had two drinks.

speaker: doctor
text: How much Ecstasy did you take?

speaker: patient
text: I didn't take them all at once. I think I took six tabs.

speaker: doctor
text: What time did you start taking the tablets?

speaker: patient
text: We started taking it kind of late. I think it was midnight.

speaker: doctor
text: Mom, did you notice any blood, or any yellow or green color in the vomit?

speaker: doctor
text: Are you still feeling nauseous?

speaker: patient
text: No. I feel fine. Well, I feel weird but not nauseous.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you experiencing any pain at all?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Did you or do you feel depressed?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you or have you ever had suicidal thoughts?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you seeing or hearing things that are not real?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you or have you ever had thoughts of harming yourself?

speaker: patient
text: No. I was not trying to harm myself or anyone else. I just wanted to have a little fun.

speaker: doctor
text: Just one more question. Prior to last night have you had any recent illnesses or injuries?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any support system?

speaker: patient
text: No, I am single.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay so live alone at home?

speaker: patient
text: Yes.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you smoke or drink?

speaker: patient
text: Nope I do not.

speaker: doctor
text: So, are you married?

speaker: patient
text: No, my wife and I got divorced a while ago. We have three children together, though.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, and do you have someone who is managing your case?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I have an lawyer handling everything.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you smoke or drink?

speaker: patient
text: No, I never really smoke or drink.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you ever had surgery?

speaker: patient
text: No, not that I can remember.

speaker: doctor
text: No gallbladder or appendix removal, c sections, or joint replacements?

speaker: patient
text: Nope, never had anything done.

speaker: doctor
text: I just need to confirm a few pieces of information from my nurse before we begin today, sir.

speaker: patient
text: Sure, no problem, doctor.

speaker: doctor
text: Great, so it says here that you are forty five years old, and you identify as Caucasian. Is that correct?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, that's correct.

speaker: doctor
text: Thank you, so, what seems to be the problem today?

speaker: patient
text: Well, I have this pain in my right knee, sir.

speaker: doctor
text: Where is your pain?

speaker: patient
text: It's right here, on the inside of my right knee.

speaker: doctor
text: Is there an injury associated with this pain?

speaker: patient
text: Actually, yeah. I twisted it while I was at work.

speaker: doctor
text: Good morning, sir. Can you confirm your age for me, please?

speaker: patient
text: Good morning, doctor. I'm fifty nine years old.

speaker: doctor
text: Great, and which hand is your dominant hand?

speaker: patient
text: Um, I use my right hand for everything.

speaker: doctor
text: Great, thank you. So, what seems to be the problem today?

speaker: patient
text: I have had this weird feeling in both of my legs for about three weeks now.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you been treated for this so far?

speaker: patient
text: Um, I went to the E R about a week ago.

speaker: doctor
text: What did they tell you there?

speaker: patient
text: They said I had progressive sensory and motor deficits in both legs.

speaker: doctor
text: Can you describe your symptoms for me, please?

speaker: patient
text: Um, I have numbness, like here starting at my trunk, and then over the last month or so, it moved into my legs.

speaker: doctor
text: I'm going to apply some pressure right here at the nipple line, can you feel that?

speaker: patient
text: No, I'm numb from there down.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you had any weakness in your legs?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I have for the last week or so.

speaker: doctor
text: Is it getting worse?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, it is.

speaker: doctor
text: When did you start using the cane?

speaker: patient
text: Um, about five days ago, now.

speaker: doctor
text: Why did you begin using it?

speaker: patient
text: I'm having trouble walking and going up and down stairs.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you able to stand without it?

speaker: patient
text: No, I'm not.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you had any loss of bowel or bladder control?

speaker: patient
text: No, thankfully not, but at the same time I haven't had a bowel movement in about three days.

speaker: doctor
text: When was the last time you urinated?

speaker: patient
text: It was about twenty four hours ago.

speaker: doctor
text: In addition to the numbness, how else would you describe your leg symptoms?

speaker: patient
text: Um, I'd say it feels cold, at least I've felt that for the last day or so.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any back or neck pain?

speaker: patient
text: No, nothing there.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any shortness of breath?

speaker: patient
text: Well, I've had it chronically for a while now, but I think it's getting worse.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you had any lightheadedness or feelings of faint?

speaker: patient
text: Um, yeah, when I try to stand up.

speaker: doctor
text: How long have you had that feeling?

speaker: patient
text: I've had it for about two days now.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any known allergies to medications?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Good evening, and welcome to A B C D General Hospital E D.

speaker: patient
text: Thank you, Doctor, I've really messed up this ankle.

speaker: doctor
text: Before we begin, how old are you? And which gender do you identify?

speaker: patient
text: Thank you for asking, Doctor, I'm a fifty year old man.

speaker: doctor
text: Thank you, what happened?

speaker: patient
text: I fell off my liner, and I landed right onto my left foot.

speaker: doctor
text: How far did you fall?

speaker: patient
text: Um, it was really about ten feet.

speaker: doctor
text: Oh, yes, I see. I have some good news for you, there's no gross deformity in this ankle.

speaker: patient
text: What does that mean, exactly?

speaker: doctor
text: I don't see any ankle dislocation, which is good.

speaker: patient
text: Oh, that's good news.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you had your x rays taken yet?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, the tech just brought me back.

speaker: doctor
text: Great, let me pull them up here. Okay, um, if you look here, you'll see a fracture of your talus.

speaker: patient
text: Which bone is that?

speaker: doctor
text: That's your heel, to be specific, it's a grade I V Hawkins fracture of the left talus. You are still neurovascularly intact in the distal region.

speaker: patient
text: What are we going to do about this?

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any other pain from the fall, aside from the ankle?

speaker: patient
text: No, the ankle really took all of the weight of the fall.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, I think we should do surgery in order to repair this ankle.

speaker: patient
text: Why is that?

speaker: doctor
text: There is very weak blood flow to the body of this bone, there's a risk for avascular necrosis, which is bone death.

speaker: patient
text: Okay, you're right. What are the risks of this infection with this surgery?

speaker: doctor
text: Overall, the risks of infection are less than one percent. We'll use antibiotics to keep everything clean.

speaker: patient
text: Will I be asleep for this?

speaker: doctor
text: Yes, you'll be under anesthesia.

speaker: patient
text: Okay, yes, um, I'd like to go forward with the surgery.

speaker: doctor
text: What medications are you currently taking?

speaker: patient
text: Augmentin, Detroal LA and lisinopril.

speaker: doctor
text: Did you ever have any surgery?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Hello, miss. How are you doing today?

speaker: patient
text: I have this massive headache.

speaker: doctor
text: I see. Do migraines usually run in your family?

speaker: patient
text: They do. Everyone has it. We've been having it for many years.

speaker: doctor
text: Oh, wow. I'm looking at your blood reports, and it shows you have high blood sugar. Does diabetes run in your family too?

speaker: patient
text: Yup. We all eat too much rice for dinner.

speaker: doctor
text: What's bringing you in today?

speaker: patient
text: I've had a terrible toothache. I can't stand the pain anymore. I have never experienced this pain in fifty eight years.

speaker: doctor
text: Where are you experiencing the most pain? And when did this pain start?

speaker: patient
text: It started about three weeks ago. It's mostly on the left side of my mouth. Kind of on the lower end. It goes from my jaw all the way up to my left ear.

speaker: doctor
text: That doesn't sound the least bit comfortable. Let's get you feeling better. Do you think it's related to your tooth?

speaker: patient
text: No, I don't think so. I'm pretty good at making my dentist appointments, although I haven't been in since this new pain started.

speaker: doctor
text: I see. When was the last time you visited the dentist?

speaker: patient
text: About two months ago for a routine clean.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you noticed any facial swelling since all of this started?

speaker: patient
text: No, no swelling.

speaker: doctor
text: Any headaches, throat swelling, sore throat, difficulty swallowing or chewing?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: How about any neck pain, swollen lymph nodes, chills, fever, or other symptoms?

speaker: patient
text: No, thank goodness.

speaker: doctor
text: How long has your finger been in pain, sir?

speaker: patient
text: Well, at this point, it's been more than a few months.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you seen another doctor for this pain?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I saw another guy a little while ago.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have the records from the visit?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, actually, they're right here.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, so I see you have a trigger finger, and a mucous cyst, and this other doctor gave you injections. Is that correct?

speaker: patient
text: Yes sir.

speaker: doctor
text: Did the injections help at all?

speaker: patient
text: No sir, honestly, they did nothing.

speaker: doctor
text: So, your finger is still locking today?

speaker: patient
text: Yes sir, the other doctor referred me over here to see if there was anything more we could do. I'd like to try surgery.

speaker: doctor
text: Hello, I am Doctor James.

speaker: doctor
text: Nice to meet you ladies. So, Miya how old are you?

speaker: patient
text: I am fifteen.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, so tell me what is going on with you?

speaker: patient
text: Well, I am having a severe headache.

speaker: doctor
text: Oh wow. Can you tell me where exactly the pain is?

speaker: patient
text: Um, it started from my neck and then moved up to the back of my head.

speaker: doctor
text: I see. Did you get hurt or bump your head?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Does she have any history of headaches?

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, any nausea or vomiting?

speaker: patient
text: I am having nausea, but it's coming and going but no vomiting. Also, I am not able to tolerate light at all.

speaker: doctor
text: Hm, are you able to see properly though, any change in your vision?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Any fever?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: And you said you're right handed, correct?

speaker: patient
text: Yep. Right handed.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, great. I've made note of it in your chart. I have one more question to ask regarding tobacco and alcohol. Do you smoke or drink?

speaker: patient
text: I don't do either. I can't even think of the last time I took a sip of alcohol.

speaker: doctor
text: He's here for sepsis and I suspect he may have spontaneous bacterial peritonitis.

speaker: doctor
text: Let's check your throat. Okay, I don't see any swelling or any mass. Is there any pain when I touch you?

speaker: patient
text: No pain.

speaker: doctor
text: I don't feel any kind of lump in your throat. That is a good sign. It looks very flexible and symmetric.

speaker: patient
text: Good afternoon, doctor.

speaker: doctor
text: Remind me, please, how old are you?

speaker: patient
text: I'm sixty nine years old, doctor.

speaker: doctor
text: Thank you, what seems to be the problem today?

speaker: patient
text: Oh, I've had pain in these knees for years, but it's been getting a lot worse over the last few months.

speaker: doctor
text: Is the pain messing with your ability to do activities?

speaker: patient
text: Absolutely, sir, yes it is.

speaker: doctor
text: What kind of treatments have you had so far?

speaker: patient
text: Another doctor called it conservative treatment, um, I've taken antiinflammatories and had some injections.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you remember what kind of injections you've had?

speaker: patient
text: It was, um, cortisone, and Synvisc.

speaker: doctor
text: Did these relieve the pain at all?

speaker: patient
text: Well, it was only a temporary relief. Is there anything else we can do?

speaker: doctor
text: Well, there is surgery for this.

speaker: patient
text: What are the risks of infection from the surgery?

speaker: doctor
text: Historically, it's less than one percent.

speaker: patient
text: How is this possible?

speaker: doctor
text: We use prophylactic antibiotics in order to eliminate the risk.

speaker: patient
text: That's great, I've heard of D V T from the commercials, is there a risk for that?

speaker: doctor
text: There's a risk, but it's low. Other risks are pulmonary embolism, need for further surgery, and further pain.

speaker: patient
text: Okay, yes, I'd like to do the surgery.

speaker: doctor
text: How's this little guy doing today?

speaker: doctor
text: Oh, I'm sorry to hear that. Let's have a look see.

speaker: doctor
text: Did that seem to help?

speaker: doctor
text: Has he been running any fevers?

speaker: doctor
text: He sounds a bit congested.

speaker: doctor
text: Is his cough productive?

text: Does it seem to be keeping him up at night? How does the mucous look?

text: And no shortness of breath or wheezing that you've noticed?

speaker: doctor
text: First time for everything I guess! When did you first notice the sensation?

speaker: patient
text: Um when I was at work this morning. It felt like something was in my eye. I went to the bathroom mirror to check it out, but didn't see anything. I flushed my eyes with water in hopes of it helping with the weird feeling.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay. Hm, are you experiencing any eye pain, blurred vision, or sensitivity to light?

speaker: patient
text: The pain has definitely gotten worse since this morning. My vision is fine and bright lights don't seem to be a problem.

speaker: doctor
text: What brings you in today?

speaker: patient
text: I've had a lot of discomfort in my private area.

speaker: doctor
text: When did it start?

speaker: patient

speaker: doctor
text: Have you noticed any abnormal discharge?

speaker: patient
text: Not really, no. But it's been super itchy down there.

text: Any abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting?

text: Uh no, but I'm having some pain here.

speaker: patient
text: Yeah.

speaker: patient
text: No.

text: Have you been sexually active prior to or after noticing these concerns?

speaker: patient
text: Uh once this past week, but it was pretty painful.

speaker: doctor
text: I see. You may have an infection, which is why I'd also like to send out samples to the lab. Did you use protection?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I take birth control. But I've been struggling a bit with my mood and I'm wondering if it's because of the new birth control pills.

speaker: doctor
text: We can look into that as well. Hang tight while I grab the nurse for the pelvic exam.

text: Do you have any allergies?

text: Welcome to the clinic. I am Doctor Frank.

text: This morning, I felt like something in my throat. It was a strange feeling. Then I felt really dizzy. My left hand and jaw felt numb.

text: Did you lose consciousness?

speaker: patient
text: I don't know. It is a bit confusing. I woke up this morning and I was so disoriented that I thought it was the middle of the night. My hand was numb. I also felt the numbness on the left side of my neck and my face.

speaker: doctor
text: Did the dizzy episode happen after you woke up this morning?

speaker: patient
text: Yes. I got dizzy when I tried to get out of bed.

text: Has anything like this happen to you in the past?

speaker: patient
text: About three weeks ago, I had a dizzy episodes and I ended up falling down.

text: Did you have any other symptoms like you did this morning?

speaker: patient
text: No.

text: I saw Doctor X Y Z. Doctor X Y Z put me on Antivert.

text: Okay. How old are you?

text: I am seventy five years young.

speaker: doctor
text: Fantastic.

speaker: doctor
text: What is your family medical history?

text: My mom was healthy all her life. She died of old age. She was eighty nine years old. My dad died of a stroke. He was eighty nine as well.

text: Yes I had a brother and a sister. My sister died way too young. She was only thirty when she passed away from cancer. My brother lasted until he was seventy four. He had coronary artery disease.

speaker: patient
text: Yes, on my right thigh.

text: Okay.

text: Okay, let me see what your scan says. I am reading the C T Scan report provided by the patient. It states that patient has dilated bladder with thick wall suggesting an outlet obstruction as well as bilateral hydronephrosis and hydroureter.

text: Historically, it's less than one percent. We use antibiotics to control for infection.

text: Yes, that's correct.

text: Do you remember when your last appointment here was?

text: Um, yes, it was on April twelfth two thousand five.

text: With ten being the worst pain imaginable, what was your pain out of ten at your last visit?

text: Okay, this is between your L four and sacrum. How would you describe your right leg pain?

text: Okay, this shows multi level degenerative changes, with facet involvement at L two L three, L three L four, and L five S1, with no neural impingement, which is good.

text: Did you have an allergic reactions to any medication?

text: Thank you, Nurse. I'll go see her now.

text: Hello Doctor. I've been waiting a long time. I'm getting impatient as I get older.

speaker: doctor
text: What? You don't look old at all, ma'am.

speaker: patient
text: Oh, wow. That's a nice compliment for a sixty year old lady.

speaker: doctor
text: How can I help you today?

speaker: patient
text: I have these super bad headaches. Help me, please.

speaker: doctor
text: When did they start?

speaker: patient
text: I had them since I was twenty five years old.

speaker: doctor
text: Oh, wow. That long? Did you get them every day since then?

speaker: patient
text: Not every day. That's crazy. I did get them more when my husband died in nineteen ninety six. I was heartbroken.

speaker: doctor
text: I'm sorry to hear that. How did the headaches feel?

speaker: patient
text: It felt like a drum in my head.

speaker: doctor
text: I haven't heard that description before. Would you say it was pulsating?

speaker: patient
text: Something like that. Yes.

speaker: doctor
text: Did you take any medication?

speaker: patient
text: Lots of it. My son wrote it on a paper so that I could give you the names. Here you go.

speaker: doctor
text: I see you were given papaverine. Did that help?

speaker: patient
text: They did. My headaches would vanish.

speaker: doctor
text: How long did you take it for?

speaker: patient
text: I think six months. My headaches stopped for a while, but they came back in two thousand and four.

speaker: doctor
text: How often would you say you get headaches now?

speaker: patient
text: I think more than before. Like one to two per week. I also get some dizziness too. It says for two hours.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you take the papaverine when you feel it?

speaker: patient
text: I do. My headaches vanish after thirty minutes of taking it.

speaker: doctor
text: I see. Did you ever experience any problems with your vision too?

speaker: patient
text: Yes. A lot. There were zig zag lines coming out of nowhere. I thought I was going to die.

speaker: doctor
text: Oh, wow. I will do a test right now to check your vision.

speaker: patient
text: Will you use a bright pen?

speaker: doctor
text: I will. Does it give you any discomfort?

speaker: patient
text: The bright light hurts my eyes.

speaker: doctor
text: I see. I'll only do it to the side then. Just look forward for me, please.

speaker: patient
text: Thank you.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you able to see the light?

speaker: patient
text: What light?

speaker: doctor
text: It looks like you have trouble seeing things in your peripheral vision. The discomfort you experience with bright lights is also called photophobia.

speaker: patient
text: That sounds scary. Will I be fine?

speaker: doctor
text: Yeah. You don't have to worry. Are you experiencing any dizziness or lightheadedness right now?

speaker: patient
text: Now that you mentioned it, I am.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you ever fainted before?

speaker: patient
text: I think one time. My son was there to help.

speaker: doctor
text: That's good to hear. I'll write down that you experienced a syncope. Did you take any medication for this?

speaker: patient
text: I took some Russian medicine.

speaker: doctor
text: Oh, wow. Are you from Russia?

speaker: patient
text: No. I'm from Ukraine.

speaker: doctor
text: That's wonderful. How did the medicine help?

speaker: patient
text: It helped me a lot.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you drink?

speaker: patient
text: I used to drink before, but now I have stopped it completely.

speaker: doctor
text: How would you rate your pain?

speaker: patient
text: It is tolerable, like five out of ten but I do need some pain medications.

speaker: doctor
text: Then why do you need more pain medications?

speaker: patient
text: Sometimes it gets hard, I really need some more pain medications.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have morphine? Do you need more?

speaker: patient
text: I don't like morphine. Can you change it to Dilaudid? I like that medicine. That one works for me great.

speaker: doctor
text: Yeah, I am looking at her reports. She had surgery for spina bifida when she was a baby and they had to put a shunt.

speaker: doctor
text: Hm.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you married or divorced?

speaker: patient
text: I am married.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

speaker: patient
text: Hm.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you smoke cigarettes or drink alcohol?

speaker: patient
text: No, I have never.

speaker: doctor
text: What is your family medical history?

speaker: patient
text: I am not sure. Everyone is healthy as far as I know.

speaker: doctor
text: Good morning, ma'am. My chart says that you're forty nine years old, and White, is that correct?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, that's all correct.

speaker: doctor
text: What do you do for a living?

speaker: patient
text: I'm a secretary.

speaker: doctor
text: Great, welcome back to the Dermatology office, do you remember when your last appointment was?

speaker: patient
text: Um, I think it was on August tenth two thousand four.

speaker: doctor
text: Good, that's what I have here as well, so has your acne improved since your last visit?

speaker: patient
text: Well, not really, and I think I have a rash too.

speaker: doctor
text: How long have you been dealing with this?

speaker: patient
text: Um, at this point it's been about two months.

speaker: doctor
text: Where do you see this rash?

speaker: patient
text: Um, it's right here, on my chest, stomach, neck, and back, it's all over my upper body.

speaker: doctor
text: I see, it appears that your acne is flaring, and there are small lesions on the follicles as well. Have you been taking your Amoxicillin and using your Tazorac?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I taken five hundred M G of amoxicillin twice a day, and I use the cream as well.

speaker: doctor
text: Good, the acne on your face appears to be clearing.

speaker: patient
text: Thank you, I've been out of medicine for about three days now though.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, we might refill that. Have you had any other treatments aside from what I've done? I

speaker: patient
text: Um, my husband drove me to Healing Waters and they did, um, photofacials. Is there anything that can be done in the office today, like, um, cosmetic procedures, or do you have any skin care products? I want to keep up my appearances since I work the front office as a secretary.

speaker: doctor
text: It looks like your Xrays show bronchitis.

speaker: patient
text: Is there anything I can take for it?

speaker: doctor
text: Yes, I'm going to prescribe you something that will help clear your lungs.

speaker: doctor
text: How's it going X Y Z? I see you're in a walking boot. What happened?

speaker: patient
text: I hurt my foot pretty bad yesterday.

speaker: doctor
text: How'd it happen?

speaker: patient
text: Basketball. I play for the University of Houston. I went up for a three and came down and landed on this guy's foot. I was so pissed.

speaker: doctor
text: Dang, that sucks. Were you guys playing a home game?

speaker: patient
text: We were traveling to Duke. We could've won the game if I didn't get hurt.

speaker: doctor
text: You'll get them next time. Did you keep playing?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I did. I got taped up by the trainer, and I went back into the game.

speaker: doctor
text: I see. Who was the trainer that helped you?

speaker: patient
text: His name is John Houston. Do you know him?

speaker: doctor
text: Oh, John! He's a good friend of mine.

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, he told me to come see you. He checked my foot. Here's the notes he wrote.

speaker: doctor
text: It looks like you have some tenderness around your navicular, which is a bone in your ankle.

speaker: patient
text: Dang, that's whack.

speaker: doctor
text: Which way did you twist your ankle?

speaker: patient
text: My foot twisted inwards. Kind of like this.

speaker: doctor
text: I see. Your foot inverted. Did it swell up right away?

speaker: patient
text: Aw, man. My foot was huge right after it happened. It hurt so much too.

speaker: doctor
text: Continue to keep that tape on. Are you limping or anything?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I am. I can't really put weight on my foot because it'll hurt a lot.

speaker: doctor
text: I see. Well, I examined your foot, and it looks like the pain is around the top, back and middle of your foot.

speaker: doctor
text: Yeah so, we call it foreign body impaction. It is mostly affecting his right nostril and as you said there is constipation.

speaker: patient
text: I was working when it happened so we are going through workers comp.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay. Don't worry. Let's see. Oh wow!

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, this arm, it was a hot oil.

speaker: doctor
text: Yeah, too bad, looks like from elbow to wrist. The whole medial side is burnt.

speaker: patient
text: I am using cool packs since it happened. My friend is helping me so much, he drove me to Emergency Department.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, how old are you?

speaker: patient
text: I am forty one.

speaker: doctor
text: What is your job? I mean what do you do?

speaker: patient
text: I am a cook at coffee shop.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any medical conditions that I should know about?

speaker: patient
text: Um, I have high blood pressure, and asthma.

speaker: doctor
text: I also see here that you have cervical cancer, can you tell me more about that?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I got diagnosed at fifteen years old.

speaker: doctor
text: How would you describe the progression of your cancer?

speaker: patient
text: Now, um, I'd say it's dormant.

speaker: doctor
text: You can take Ibuprofen as needed for pain.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you take anything for acid reflux?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I take Aciphex.

speaker: doctor
text: Is that twenty M G once a day?

speaker: patient
text: It is. I also take one baby Aspirin in the mornings.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you smoke?

speaker: patient
text: Yes.

speaker: doctor
text: How much do you smoke?

speaker: patient
text: I smoke about two packs of cigarettes a day.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: Any numbness or tingling?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Are your experiencing any muscle weakness?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Any problem walking, or did you lose balance or fall?

speaker: patient
text: Nope.

speaker: doctor
text: So, your gait is fine. Any stroke in the past?

speaker: patient
text: No, nothing like that.

speaker: doctor
text: Past surgeries I should know of?

speaker: patient
text: I had my gallbladder, appendix, and uterus removed.

speaker: doctor
text: Oh wow, I see. When did you get these surgeries?

speaker: patient
text: I had my gallbladder removed in O eight, appendix removed in twenty twelve, and uterus removed this past year.

speaker: doctor
text: Any other medical history?

speaker: patient
text: My bladder was sagging the last time I saw the urologist.

speaker: doctor
text: Does the diagnosis bladder prolapse sound familiar?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I believe so. They said it was grad four last time.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you followed up with your urologist recently?

speaker: patient
text: Chip Winkel? No, not as of late.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have allergies? How old are you, young man?

speaker: patient
text: Yes ragweed. I am twelve.

speaker: doctor
text: So basically, you are just congested?

speaker: patient
text: Yes that's right. The last ten days.

speaker: doctor
text: Any headache? What comes out of your nose?

speaker: patient
text: Yes I had a little yesterday. Clear boogers.

speaker: doctor
text: You feel hot?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Anyone sick at home?

speaker: doctor
text: Are you married?

speaker: patient
text: I'm divorced.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any kids?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I have two boys and they live with me.

speaker: doctor
text: Any abnormal pregnancy. Any abortions?

speaker: patient
text: No, none of them.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you smoke or consume alcohol or have ever used any illicit drug?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: I want to go over your medical history. I see here you saw the dermatologist a month ago.

speaker: patient
text: Yeah. She said that I um have an overactive sweat gland.

speaker: doctor
text: Does hidradenitis suppurativa sound familiar?

speaker: patient
text: It does.

speaker: doctor
text: I ask because it's also included in your last visit with your dermatologist.

speaker: patient
text: Those are the red bumps, right?

speaker: doctor
text: Yes. There's a note here that you could've potentially had Staph with it as well.

speaker: patient
text: Oh yeah. I've also had a lot of abscesses in the past.

speaker: doctor
text: It looks like you've had them in your upper mid thigh, vulva area, and the area between your vulva and anus.

speaker: patient
text: For about two years now.

speaker: doctor
text: Right. And a history of asthma?

speaker: patient
text: Correct.

speaker: patient
text: Hello, how are you?

speaker: doctor
text: I am good, tell me what brings you here?

speaker: patient
text: I am having this chest pain. I was hospitalized last year in October and at that time they put this catheter in my heart. I also underwent a heart scan. It's here in this report.

speaker: doctor
text: Yeah, I see that you got nuclear and myocardial perfusion scan, which was normal. They were looking for some heart artery lesion but then it was thought to be due to spasm.

speaker: patient
text: Right.

speaker: doctor
text: It is also mentioned here that you have hyperlipidemia.

speaker: patient
text: Yes.

speaker: doctor
text: And are you still smoking?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, in fact I have been smoking actively from pass three to four days because I am really stressed.

speaker: doctor
text: Hm. And would you say, you might have had some exertion recently or did some steep hiking or some cardio exercises which might have caused some additional stress on your heart causing chest pain?

speaker: patient
text: No, I did not do any exertion. Just actively smoking that's all.

speaker: doctor
text: I am sorry about that.

speaker: patient
text: Yes, for assault, that's why I was in detention.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: When was this?

speaker: patient
text: Around December of two thousand nine.

speaker: patient
text: Not sure if I am under legal contraints right now.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay so we don't know.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you smoke cigarettes?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I do.

speaker: doctor
text: How many packs a day.

speaker: patient
text: Maybe one a day.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, you should think about quitting.

speaker: doctor
text: What happens when you take Sulfa drugs?

speaker: patient
text: Oh man, I get a really ugly looking rash.

speaker: doctor
text: I'll make note of that so we have it in your chart.

speaker: doctor
text: Any known drug allergies?

speaker: patient
text: Nope, none whatsoever.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you smoke cigarettes or drink alcohol?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Any use of recreational substances or IV drug abuse?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Tell me what brings you here today?

speaker: patient
text: I'm having some issues with my right hand.

speaker: doctor
text: What kind of issues?

speaker: patient
text: I'm having these pins and needles kind of feeling in my hand and it has been going on for several weeks. Sometimes I feel it gets numb. I think it might be carpal tunnel, but I'm not sure. I'm just worried.

speaker: doctor
text: Did you do anything for it?

speaker: patient
text: At work I recently moved my keyboard down. I just hope it will help. You know, I do a lot of the same kind of activities all the time. All of it I typing based.

speaker: doctor
text: What is more difficult, day or night?

speaker: patient
text: It gets worse at night. If I sleep on it, like in a certain way, it will just wake me up and it starts hurting. These tingling sensations are the worst. It helps if I shake it then the sensation goes away. It irritates me all the time.

speaker: doctor
text: Is it complete hand or is there any part of hand that is worse than others?

speaker: patient
text: It is mostly my middle finger, but maybe my first or second finger of the hand also, but mostly my middle finger.

speaker: doctor
text: Is there pain anywhere else?

speaker: patient
text: In my thumb as well. I'm just afraid it can be arthritis. I don't want that, too, on my plate.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you been in any accident?

speaker: patient
text: I have been a truck driver for some time but luckily have not been in any major auto accident. I had hit a moose once, where I bumped my head but do not remember getting hurt anywhere else. I had broken my ankle in the past.

speaker: doctor
text: Hm, I see here you mentioned to the nurse, that a car fell on your chest six years back?

speaker: patient
text: Oh yes, I was repairing my car and it fell off the car jack stand and fell on my chest but fortunately I was not hurt.

speaker: doctor
text: Did you ever had pneumonia?

speaker: patient
text: No, never.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any history of lung disease?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Any history of tuberculosis?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you feeling any shortness of breath or difficulty breathing?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay. Do you have any wheezing?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Tell me about your past medical history. Is there anything that I should be aware of?

speaker: patient
text: No, I don't think so.

speaker: doctor
text: Any known allergies?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you ever been diagnosed with diabetes or high blood pressure?

speaker: patient
text: Oh, last year I did have some incidents of high blood pressure, but I didn't take any medications for it.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you seen any variation in your weight?

speaker: patient
text: How do you know? It's been up. About fourteen pounds since last year.

speaker: doctor
text: How did your treatment for the thrombosis go? I believe we did it on February nineteen of two thousand and seven. We finished the note the next day in order to send to your other following doctor.

speaker: patient
text: The treatment went well. Thanks!

speaker: doctor
text: Where are you having numbness?

speaker: patient
text: In my left hand.

speaker: doctor
text: And no other symptoms? Any coughing or chest pain?

speaker: patient
text: No. Just that weird feeling in my left hand.

speaker: doctor
text: Any visual changes or motor changes.

speaker: patient
text: Nothing.

speaker: doctor
text: Great. What about any phlegm or shortness of breath?

speaker: patient
text: Nope.

speaker: doctor
text: How are you feeling?

speaker: patient
text: I've been having a lot more joint pain lately.

speaker: doctor
text: You're seventy seven, correct?

speaker: patient
text: Don't remind me.

speaker: doctor
text: When did you first start experiencing joint pain?

speaker: patient
text: Couple years ago.

speaker: doctor
text: In what ways has it worsened?

speaker: patient
text: It's caused me to become less active in general. My hands and wrists aren't as mobile.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you noticed any increased swelling?

speaker: patient
text: No, but it's all gotten to be a little too uncomfortable.

speaker: doctor
text: I see here that you take the generic of Daypro. Is that helping?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: And no redness to the area, right?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Fever or chills?

speaker: patient
text: I had diarrhea for a few days, but it's gotten much better. I was also having trouble holding my bladder.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you going to the bathroom more often, experiencing excessive thirst, or other problems?

speaker: patient
text: No. My incontinence is a bit better and so is my ankle and foot swelling.

speaker: doctor
text: How has your blood sugar been?

speaker: patient
text: A little better.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you checked your blood pressure recently?

speaker: patient
text: Not recently.

speaker: doctor
text: Any new medications?

speaker: patient
text: I'm back on Zoloft again because I think I might be depressed. Ever since losing most of my mobility, I haven't been feeling like my usual myself. I'm also sleeping all the time.

speaker: doctor
text: Anyone in your family been sick lately?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, my sister has sinus problems. She was seen today.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay that means she will be treated.

speaker: patient
text: Yes.

speaker: doctor
text: How about other family members?

speaker: patient
text: No, my mom and dad are healthy.

speaker: doctor
text: Good. Good.

speaker: patient
text: Hm!

speaker: doctor
text: So, tell me what's going on with you?

speaker: patient
text: Well, yesterday evening between seven or eight I developed nausea and suddenly it started hurting on the right side of my chest?

speaker: doctor
text: Where exactly did it hurt?

speaker: patient
text: Ah, my upper chest part and it went all around my right side till my back.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, how do you feel now?

speaker: patient
text: I feel very weak and tired, don't feel like doing anything but resting.

speaker: doctor
text: Any fever?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, nurse just took my temperature it was one hundred point three.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay. Did you have these symptoms before?

speaker: patient
text: No, first time. I never felt like this before.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay. Any chills or shivering?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: When was your last bowel movement?

speaker: patient
text: It was yesterday.

speaker: doctor
text: Did you notice any blood in your stool or any rectum bleeding?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: How old are you?

speaker: patient
text: I am twenty eight.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, and you had a gastric bypass surgery, one year ago.

speaker: patient
text: Yes, almost one year ago. I lost about two hundred pounds after that.

speaker: doctor
text: And you felt well after the surgery?

speaker: patient
text: Absolutely! Until yesterday when my nausea and pain started.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, so it looks like your blood work shows that your sodium levels are very low. This could explain some of the symptoms you've been having lately.

speaker: patient
text: What does that mean? Why are my sodium levels so low?

speaker: doctor
text: It could be due to a number of-

speaker: patient
text: Should I start eating more salt?

speaker: doctor
text: Not necessarily. But I believe it's partly due to the diuretic that you've been taking these past few weeks. Your blood work also shows anemia. I'd like to start you on some iron supplements for now and get you back in for another eval. The front desk has access to your orders and they can print you out a lab slip.

speaker: patient
text: Do you think the iron will help with my tiredness? I've been so exhausted and caffeine hasn't been helping one bit.

speaker: doctor
text: So, you are a cigarette smoker?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah.

speaker: doctor
text: How much do you some?

speaker: patient
text: Not as much as some people.

speaker: doctor
text: How much is that exactly?

speaker: patient
text: Well, I probably buy a new pack once a week.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay. So that is about four packs a month and fifty packs a year.

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I guess so.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you married, sir?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, to my wonderful wife.

speaker: doctor
text: Great, can I assume you support each other at home?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, doctor, that's correct.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you smoke or drink, sir?

speaker: patient
text: Well, I don't smoke, and I don't do anything harder, either. But I drink just about every day.

speaker: doctor
text: How much do you drink a day?

speaker: patient
text: I drink maybe two or three drinks a day, so maybe four or nine a week.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you know if anyone in your family has history of heart disease, stroke anything of that sort?

speaker: patient
text: Let me think. You mean only blood relatives?

speaker: doctor
text: Yes.

speaker: patient
text: Yes. We have some of those diseases in our family.

speaker: doctor
text: What kinds of surgeries have you had in the past?

speaker: patient
text: I have had a heart bypass surgery.

speaker: doctor
text: Is that C A B G?

speaker: patient
text: Maybe. And I have had my tonsils and appendix taken out.

speaker: doctor
text: Sure. Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: Good morning, ma'am. Can you tell me more about this low back pain?

speaker: patient
text: Well, I'm not as young as I used to be, I'm fifty nine.

speaker: doctor
text: What set this pain off? Is there any injury?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I had a fall in the beginning of two thousand six. I slipped on a freshly waxed floor.

speaker: doctor
text: What part of your lower back did you fall onto?

speaker: patient
text: I fell onto my tailbone and just general lower back.

speaker: doctor
text: Is this the only fall you've had?

speaker: patient
text: No, I had another one in March of two thousand six.

speaker: doctor
text: What happened when you fell that time?

speaker: patient
text: I was trying to qualify on the gun range with a handgun, when I lost my footing.

speaker: doctor
text: What made you lose your footing?

speaker: patient
text: I think it was more weakness than a loss of balance.

speaker: doctor
text: What treatments have you had for this?

speaker: patient
text: Well, I've been to P T, and I had, um, cauterization of some of the nerves in my lower back.

speaker: doctor
text: How many times have you had this cauterization done?

speaker: patient
text: I've had it twice, once in October and the other in November.

speaker: doctor
text: This was in two thousand eight, right?

speaker: patient
text: Correct. The P T said I have low back pain and degenerative disc disease.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you ever had surgery, ma'am?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, doctor, I've had a whole lifetime worth of back surgeries.

speaker: doctor
text: How many surgeries have you had?

speaker: patient
text: I've had four.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you know the surgeries you've had?

speaker: patient
text: Actually, I have the op notes here.

speaker: doctor
text: I see, you've had an anterior cervical discectomy, and fusion of C three through C seven.

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I had all of those with Doctor L.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any children?

speaker: patient
text: Yes doctor, I have seven, but I had three miscarriages.

speaker: doctor
text: Were any of your children born through C sections?

speaker: patient
text: No, none of them were.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you ever had any major surgeries?

speaker: patient
text: I had a skin tag removed but no. No major surgeries.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: With ten being the worst pain imaginable, out of ten, how would you describe your pain today?

speaker: patient
text: I'd say its about a six out of ten today.

speaker: doctor
text: What makes the pain worse?

speaker: patient
text: It's worse when I try to walk around on it.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any pain at night?

speaker: patient
text: No, thankfully I don't.

speaker: doctor
text: How long have you been wearing that exterior knee brace?

speaker: patient
text: Oh, for a little while now.

speaker: doctor
text: I need to ask you a few questions.

speaker: patient
text: Sure.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you feel any weakness or tiredness?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Any uneasiness or illness?

speaker: patient
text: No, nothing of that sort.

speaker: doctor
text: Any chills or high temperature?

speaker: patient
text: Nope.

speaker: doctor
text: Any excessive sweating or night sweating?

speaker: patient
text: Um, no.

speaker: doctor
text: How about allergies, are you allergic to anything?

speaker: patient
text: No, no allergies.

speaker: doctor
text: Alright.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you smoke or drink?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Any drug use?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you smoke?

speaker: patient
text: Yes!

speaker: doctor
text: How about alcohol, do you drink?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I do.

speaker: doctor
text: And how much do you drink and is it occasional or on daily basis?

speaker: patient
text: Well, I love my wine, I drink about four to five glasses per day.

speaker: doctor
text: Wow! That's a lot.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you smoke cigarettes?

speaker: patient
text: Yes.

speaker: doctor
text: Any important family history, any medical issues in the family?

speaker: patient
text: Well, my father died of a heart attack. I don't remember how old he was, but I do remember that he had some long run heart issues.

speaker: doctor
text: What about your mom?

speaker: patient
text: My mom's death was a mystery for all of us. She died of some complications because of the dental procedures. So never got to know what killed her.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have kids? Are they all doing good health wise?

speaker: patient
text: I have a daughter, she's healthy.

speaker: doctor
text: Hi there! How are you today?

speaker: patient
text: Hi. I am not doing so well. I have had this cough and a pain in my stomach. Right here by my belly button.

speaker: doctor
text: How long has this been going on?

speaker: patient
text: Two days.  It has been very painful.

speaker: doctor
text: I would like to examine your abdomen. Is that okay?

speaker: patient
text: Yes.

speaker: doctor
text: Can you please confirm the medications that you have already taken?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I just finished the course for Minocin. I also took Duraphen II D M.

speaker: doctor
text: Has anyone in your family had a history of heart disease or issues?

speaker: patient
text: Well, yeah. Actually, my dad passed away due heart disease.

speaker: doctor
text: Oh, I am sorry to hear that. Do you know what kind of heart problem he had?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, it is called co-

speaker: doctor
text: Oh, coronary heart disease?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, exactly!

speaker: doctor
text: I see.

speaker: doctor
text: Good morning, ma'am. Just to confirm, you're thirty two years old, correct?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, doctor, that's correct.

speaker: doctor
text: Good, so, have you been able to get a P C P yet?

speaker: patient
text: No, I haven't gotten one just yet.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you in the process of getting one?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, Project Access is trying to find me one.

speaker: doctor
text: Good, um, what seems to be the problem today, then?

speaker: patient
text: Well, I was at Doctor X Y Z's office today, I had an appointment, but they cancelled me because I don't have the Project Access insurance yet.

speaker: doctor
text: I see, what were you going to see Doctor X Y Z for?

speaker: patient
text: I'm having a lot of pain in my foot.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, have you seen Doctor X Y Z before?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I saw him on May fourteenth two thousand four.

speaker: doctor
text: But you still don't have a P C P, correct?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, that's correct.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, we've seen you quite a few times in here. You were in here last week and saw Doctor X Y Z for some back pain, how did they treat you?

speaker: patient
text: Um, I got some pain medicines and muscle relaxers.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, so, can you tell me more about your foot, please?

speaker: patient
text: Well, I have this pain in my foot, and I had surgery before so there's plates and screws in it.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you ever talked to anyone about removing this hardware?

speaker: patient
text: Well, I was supposed to see Doctor X Y Z about it, but since that appointment was cancelled, I came here.

speaker: doctor
text: I see, how long have you had this foot pain?

speaker: patient
text: Um, it started hurting a lot yesterday.

speaker: doctor
text: Is there any injury here?

speaker: patient
text: No, it's just chronically painful, honestly.

speaker: doctor
text: Do any activities bother it?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I can't exercise without a lot of pain.

speaker: doctor
text: I see, well, we've x rayed this before, and I see the hardware in there, but there's no apparent abnormality or evidence of loosening, at least from what I can see.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you smoke or drink?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Any drugs?

speaker: patient
text: You mean like meth?

speaker: doctor
text: Yeah.

speaker: patient
text: No, never did it.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: Hello, miss. How are you? What brings you to my office today?

speaker: patient
text: I am doing well. Just here for a refill on my medication.

speaker: doctor
text: Great. That should be easy. How has the stress management been going to control the acne?

speaker: patient
text: It is going well. My husband has been on board with my meditations and yoga. He is very supportive.

speaker: doctor
text: Wonderful. Are will still clean from drinking and smoking? That can interact with your medications.

speaker: patient
text: Yeah I know. I don't drink or smoke.

speaker: doctor
text: So I have here that you're taking three different medications.

speaker: patient
text: Yeah. I've been taking them every day just like they told me to.

speaker: doctor
text: I see. That's good. Did you refill your prescriptions with the newly revised doses? It looks like they changed the dosing of your medications at the hospital.

speaker: patient
text: Um I've just been taking what I have at home.

speaker: doctor
text: I advise that you take the doses that they prescribed. If you'd like me to put in a new order, please let me know.

speaker: patient
text: Okay, yeah that's fine. I can pick it up on my way home. I didn't think the dosing mattered much as long as I took the meds every day.

speaker: doctor
text: Any major surgeries in the past?

speaker: patient
text: Not too many, but a catheter was put in my heart.

speaker: doctor
text: Oh, so cardiac catherization, correct?

speaker: patient
text: Yep.

speaker: doctor
text: Hello, sir. I see you're being seen for an evaluation for your allergy. Can you please confirm your age?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, that's right. Thirty four.

speaker: doctor
text: Let me take a look at your medical records. I see you were treated at the A B C Medical Center for an allergic reaction, correct?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah. I was rushed to the hospital that day. After, they told me to get checked for a follow up.

speaker: doctor
text: Who told you to have a follow up?

speaker: patient
text: One of the E R doctors and the kidney doctor.

speaker: doctor
text: I see. Your records indicate you had some swelling around the eye on May third of two thousand and eight. The cause was unknown. I see you were transferred from A B C Medical Center to X Y Z Medical center that day.

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, that sounds about right. Were there more details about that?

speaker: doctor
text: Yeah, there is. It says here you have a history of renal failure, so you needed dialysis. They believe the allergic reaction was due to this medicine called, Keflex, which was used during your dialysis treatment. Does that name ring a bell?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, it does. I forgot why they gave it to me.

speaker: doctor
text: Usually, Keflex is used to treat a skin cellulitis dialysis shunt infection.

speaker: patient
text: Oh, I see.

speaker: doctor
text: I would like to ask you more about your allergies. What would you say you're allergic to?

speaker: patient
text: I've had a lot of problems with grass and sometimes pollen.

speaker: doctor
text: I see. I'll put that down as grass allergies, and environmental and inhalant allergies. Do you have any life-threatening allergic reactions?

speaker: patient
text: Nope. Never had that.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you ever had any swelling under the skin due to something you ate or touched?

speaker: patient
text: Nope. Never had that either.

speaker: doctor
text: That's great. I'm taking a look at your medications. I see you aren't taking anything for your allergies, but you are taking Atenolol. Do you have high blood pressure?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I do.

speaker: doctor
text: I see. All that's left from your report are the treatments they gave you before you were discharged from the hospital.

speaker: patient
text: What were the treatments they gave me?

speaker: doctor
text: Looks like they monitored you the whole time and gave you some corticosteroid therapy and antihistamine therapy. You didn't have any additional problems as well.

speaker: patient
text: That is not true!

speaker: doctor
text: Miss Tara, you need to take your medications on time. You are hypertensive and your readings don't look good.

speaker: patient
text: I don't want to take anymore medications. I want to try some natural remedies to treat my high blood pressure. I am not going to take any prescription meds that's it.

speaker: doctor
text: If that's the case then I will make note in your file that you are not complying.

speaker: patient
text: I think I got some allergy, my lips are swollen and its causing me difficulty in swallowing.

speaker: doctor
text: Oh, let me take a look.

speaker: doctor
text: Any medical history?

speaker: patient
text: Um I suffer from depression and high blood pressure.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you taking anything for either?

speaker: patient
text: Only for high blood pressure.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you had surgeries in the past?

speaker: patient
text: I had surgery to get a few hemorrhoids removed back in two thousand and ten.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have a family history of any medical conditions, such as diabetes or heart disease?

speaker: patient
text: No, nothing.

speaker: doctor
text: How's your family?

speaker: patient
text: They're doing well, thank you. My three boys are all grown up. Hard to believe they're living their own as young professionals. One of them is actually a G I doctor in San Diego, California.

speaker: doctor
text: You must be so proud of your boys.

speaker: patient
text: My wife and I always say how lucky we are.

speaker: doctor
text: I'm sure. And I have a few more questions before we wrap up.

speaker: patient
text: Go for it.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you drink or smoke?

speaker: patient
text: I smoke about a third of a pack a day and I drink every now and again, but nothing crazy.

speaker: doctor
text: How's it going, buddy? I haven't seen you in a long time

speaker: patient
text: Hey, Doctor. It's been a while. I've been doing well. Just here for my check up.

speaker: doctor
text: Nice. How's the family doing? Are they all well?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, they're doing great. Nobody has been sick for a while.

speaker: doctor
text: That's great to hear. Nobody has new medical conditions either, right?

speaker: patient
text: Not that I know of. They're all doing good.

speaker: doctor
text: So, you and your husband live together, correct?

speaker: patient
text: Yes. It's a miracle we've lasted this long.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you able to walk any distance without assistance?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, he's right.

speaker: doctor
text: And how often do you walk with your walker?

speaker: patient
text: If I were to guess, I'd say half the time.

speaker: doctor
text: Great.

speaker: doctor
text: It's good that you're both looking out for each other. Now moving onto the last few questions. Do you smoke or drink?

speaker: patient
text: No and no.

speaker: doctor
text: Did you smoke or drink in the past?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: You do not look so well today. What seems to be the problem?

speaker: patient
text: Well‚ I am having a hard time. My whole body aches and I am in pain.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have a history of drug use?

speaker: patient
text: Well yes. I am detoxing.

speaker: doctor
text: What kind of drugs have you been using?

speaker: patient
text: Heroin.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay. How long have you been using?

speaker: patient
text: I don't feel well. Maybe a year. I can't sleep or eat.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you had a fever, chills, vomiting or diarrhea?

speaker: patient
text: I think I have a fever. I feel chilled. I have had some diarrhea.

speaker: doctor
text: How would you rate your general health?

speaker: patient
text: I've been in reasonably good health at least physically. I try to go on frequent walks and eat a clean diet. However, there was one instance where I was not well mentally. After my husband died in nineteen seventy five, I had what I believe was a nervous breakdown. As a result of this, I was hospitalized for several weeks and treated with E C T.

speaker: doctor
text: I'm so sorry to hear about the loss of your husband. I can't imagine how difficult that must've been. I'm glad that you sought the care that you needed to feel better at that time. Did this happen when you were living in the United States or Korea?

speaker: patient
text: This all happened when I was living in Korea. I'm grateful that I had my family and friends to support me.

speaker: doctor
text: Social support is very important, especially when you are processing the loss of a loved one.

speaker: patient
text: Absolutely.

speaker: doctor
text: I have a few more questions before we move on. Any past medical problems?

speaker: patient
text: I used to have high blood pressure.

speaker: doctor
text: When you say used to, do you mean it's been resolved now?

speaker: patient
text: Yes.

speaker: doctor
text: Great news. How about surgeries? Have you had any in the past?

speaker: patient
text: None whatsoever.

speaker: doctor
text: Any alcohol or tobacco?

speaker: patient
text: No, I stay away from things like that.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you experiencing any headaches, or do you have any history of migraine?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Any temporary loss of consciousness?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Any feeling of being off balance or fainting?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Any continuous sound you may hear?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay so no tinnitus. Any mouth sores or ulcers?

speaker: patient
text: Um, no.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you notice any change in your voice, any hoarseness?

speaker: patient
text: No, nothing like that.

speaker: doctor
text: Did you notice any swelling in and around your mouth?

speaker: patient
text: No, I did not.

speaker: doctor
text: Any history of goiter or swelling of your thyroid gland?

speaker: patient
text: Nope.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: Hello, miss. How can I help?

speaker: patient
text: Well, I just turned fifty seven this year and I would like to get rid of these wrinkles on my face. I don't like them one bit.

speaker: doctor
text: You look beautiful and actually have a lot of fullness in the face.  It is great that you do not smoke and do not have history of skin disease. We can definitely help you with these minor issues.

speaker: doctor
text: Good afternoon, ma'am.

speaker: patient
text: Good afternoon, doctor.

speaker: doctor
text: Remind me, how young are you?

speaker: patient
text: Oh doctor, you flatter me. I'm sixty two years old.

speaker: doctor
text: Great, and you've had a rotator cuff repair before, correct?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, that's correct.

speaker: doctor
text: Good, well, what seems to be the problem today?

speaker: patient
text: I'm still having a lot of pain in this shoulder.

speaker: doctor
text: Oh no, have you had any recent imaging done on this shoulder?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I had an M R I not too long ago, can you take a look? I have it right here.

speaker: doctor
text: Thank you, yes, um, this M R I shows that you've torn that rotator cuff again.

speaker: patient
text: Oh no, can we do another surgery to repair it again?

speaker: doctor
text: Yes, we'll have to.

speaker: patient
text: What's the risk of infection of the surgery?

speaker: doctor
text: Its less than one percent. We'll use antibiotics to control for infection the entire time.

speaker: patient
text: Will I be asleep again?

speaker: doctor
text: Yes, you won't feel a thing.

speaker: patient
text: Great, yes, I'd like to go forward with the surgery. I need to get back to playing tennis.

speaker: doctor
text: What brings you in today?

speaker: patient
text: I dropped a glass and one of the broken pieces cut my foot pretty badly. There was a lot of blood.

speaker: doctor
text: Is the area still bleeding?

speaker: patient
text: I got it to stop bleeding while I was waiting for my ride.

speaker: doctor
text: Is there any pain in the area?

speaker: patient
text: No, it doesn't hurt.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you able to walk normally without pain or discomfort?

speaker: patient
text: Yes.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you experiencing any numbness or loss of strength in the area?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any other injuries on any other part of your body?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you had any recent illnesses?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any other concerns while you are here today?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: What do you do for a living, sir?

speaker: patient
text: I'm actually retired, but I used to work as a dock hand.

speaker: doctor
text: That's great, congratulations on your retirement!

speaker: patient
text: Thank you so much, doctor.

speaker: doctor
text: I just need some background information on you, sir. Do you smoke?

speaker: patient
text: Sure, I smoke about a half a pack of cigarettes a day.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you drink, sir?

speaker: patient
text: Well, not anymore, but I used to be an alcoholic.

speaker: doctor
text: Any surgical history?

speaker: patient
text: I had my thyroids taken out.

speaker: doctor
text: When did you have them taken out?

speaker: patient
text: Hm three years ago. Man, time flies.

speaker: doctor
text: Did you experience any complications post surgery?

speaker: patient
text: Nothing out of the ordinary.

speaker: doctor
text: Who was the surgeon who did your thyroidectomy?

speaker: patient
text: Doctor X.

speaker: doctor
text: What was the final diagnosis?

speaker: patient
text: I had a growth on my thyroids.

speaker: doctor
text: Was the growth cancerous?

speaker: patient
text: It was. I was initially reluctant to get them out, but I realized it was necessary. I didn't have much of a choice if I wanted to live ya know.

speaker: doctor
text: That's understandable. I'm sorry you had to go through that. Surgery is daunting, let alone surgery to remove cancer.

speaker: doctor
text: Welcome in. I am Doctor Welch.

speaker: doctor
text: How old is your daughter?

speaker: doctor
text: Hi there!

speaker: patient
text: Hi!

speaker: doctor
text: Mom I would like to start off with some questions regarding pregnancy, childbirth, and prior children.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any other children?

speaker: doctor
text: Have you ever had any miscarriages or abortions prior to having your daughter?

speaker: doctor
text: I am so sorry to hear that.

speaker: doctor
text: Did you have any difficulties or problems during your pregnancy with her.

speaker: doctor
text: How far along were you when you gave birth?

speaker: doctor
text: Did you have a vaginal birth or a C section?

speaker: doctor
text: Were any tools used during the birth to help with the birthing process?

speaker: doctor
text: How long were you in labor for?

speaker: doctor
text: Were you given any anesthesia during the birth?

speaker: doctor
text: What was her birth weight?

speaker: doctor
text: Do you recall her Apgars score?

speaker: doctor
text: How long did you stay in the hospital after the birth?

speaker: doctor
text: Let us move to questions regarding your daughter. Has she had any development problems?

speaker: doctor
text: Okay. How old was she when she spoke her first words?

speaker: doctor
text: When did she start to feed herself, using her hands?

speaker: doctor
text: Has she been toilet trained yet?

speaker: doctor
text: Okay and are you working?

speaker: patient
text: Oh yes, I am a farmer. I have a farmland and my wife, and I do farming.

speaker: doctor
text: Good, so you are one happy married couple working together.

speaker: patient
text: Ah, yes.

speaker: doctor
text: And how about tobacco, do you smoke or eat?

speaker: patient
text: Absolutely not.

speaker: doctor
text: Any use of drugs or alcohol?

speaker: patient
text: Drugs?

speaker: doctor
text: Yeah, like cocaine or anything like that.

speaker: patient
text: Oh that, no. No drugs.

speaker: patient
text: And I don't drink either.

speaker: doctor
text: Alright.

speaker: doctor
text: Well, looking at your hand x ray, the bone looks in alignment, and I don't see any effusion.

speaker: doctor
text: Any tenderness or pain?

speaker: patient
text: Ah, not really!

speaker: doctor
text: There is no asymmetry. Can you move your hand up and down? Now rotate it. Can you move your fingers?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I can do all of that, no problem at all.

speaker: doctor
text: Can you bend your hand?

speaker: patient
text: Yes.

speaker: doctor
text: Perfect.

speaker: doctor
text: How about any surgeries in the past?

speaker: patient
text: Well, I had colon surgery in nineteen eighty nine or was it ninety, oh yeah in nineteen ninety.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay and anything else?

speaker: patient
text: Ah yes, I had three surgeries for my sinus one was the same year as my colon surgery, one was before that. So, the first one was in nineteen eighty seven I believe then nineteen ninety and the last one was in two thousand five.

speaker: doctor
text: Wow, you remember the years also.

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, surprisingly.

speaker: doctor
text: So, do you drink or smoke, sir?

speaker: patient
text: I'd say I have the occasional drink, but I don't smoke.

speaker: doctor
text: What do you do for a living?

speaker: patient
text: I'm a nursing aid in a nursing home right now.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you work the normal day shift?

speaker: patient
text: No, I work the second shift, so I work some late nights and early mornings.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you back at Wichita State this semester?

speaker: patient
text: No, I decided to take some time off.

speaker: doctor
text: Is everything okay?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I'm just really tired, so I decided to step away for a little.

speaker: doctor
text: That's understandable. Are you dating right now?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I've been dating my boyfriend for a while now.

speaker: doctor
text: Is there any significant stress in your relationship?

speaker: patient
text: No, everything is going really well.

speaker: doctor
text: What brings you in today, miss?

speaker: patient
text: I haven't been feeling well since I went to the dentist.

speaker: doctor
text: When did you go to the dentist?

speaker: patient
text: It was in May last year.

speaker: doctor
text: What happened at the dentist? Also, sorry, but how old are you.

speaker: patient
text: It was after I left the dentist. I was driving home, and I got lightheaded. I was so lightheaded that I had to pull over.

speaker: doctor
text: How long did the episode last?

speaker: patient
text: About two to three minutes.

speaker: doctor
text: Is this the only time that this has happened?

speaker: patient
