text: No. In November last year, I was in the middle of eating breakfast when I got dizzy. I was so dizzy that I was nauseous, and I threw up several times. I was so exhausted from the dizziness and throwing up that I went to my room and took a two hour nap. I felt better and back to normal after I woke up from my nap.

speaker: doctor
text: How long did the vertigo last?

speaker: patient
text: It lasted about two to three minutes. So, about the same amount of time.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you had any other dizzy episodes?

speaker: patient
text: No I didn't but in January on the thirteenth my right arm went numb. It lasted for about four to five hours.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you left handed, or right?

speaker: patient
text: I am right handed.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you experienced any slurred speech or trouble swallowing?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you had any continuing weakness other than the time in January?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you experienced any headaches or visual changes?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Any continuing vertigo or lightheadedness?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Oh wow, you got stung quite a few times.

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, you're right about that.  In my seventy six years this i have never gotten stung. This is new.

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, they got both my hands and right knee. Those little monsters.

speaker: doctor
text: Did you notice redness and swelling right away?

speaker: patient
text: Um not right away.

speaker: doctor
text: How long did it take for your body to react?

speaker: patient
text: Bout thirty minutes or so.

speaker: doctor
text: Did you experience any shortness of breath, itching, or hives?

speaker: patient
text: No, surprisingly.

speaker: doctor
text: And no tongue swelling or trouble swallowing?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you gotten stung in the past? Or is this your first time?

speaker: patient
text: I got stung about a month ago. No redness or swelling like I do now. I guess it could've been due to the Benadryl I took as soon as it happened.

speaker: doctor
text: Did you take Benadryl again today?

speaker: patient
text: No, I figured I'd be okay.

speaker: patient
text: And a baby Aspirin in the mornings.

speaker: doctor
text: Did you take your daily medications today?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah."

speaker: doctor
text: What is your family medical history?

speaker: patient
text: I was adopted.  I don't know my family medical history.

speaker: doctor
text: Were you ever diagnosed with any blood or heart disease?

speaker: patient
text: Uh no.

speaker: doctor
text: Any other past medical issues?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Any major or minor surgeries done in the past?

speaker: doctor
text: I can see your medication list here.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you take Accutane and Ovcon?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I do.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

speaker: patient
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: What are you taking?

speaker: patient
text: I take Tylenol.

speaker: doctor
text: Is that only for pain?

speaker: patient
text: Yes it is.

speaker: doctor
text: Thanks, nurse. How are you feeling today, miss? Welcome back to the Pulmonary Medicine Clinic. What happened yesterday?

speaker: patient
text: Well, I was doing fine since last time. My respiratory issues have been great and I have had no major difficulties breathing.

speaker: doctor
text: That's good to hear. What happened yesterday that caused you to want to come in so urgently?

speaker: patient
text: Yesterday I noticed that I have some back and joint pain.  When I breathe deep my back hurts.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you experiencing any coughing?

speaker: patient
text: No, coughing at this moment.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you been producing any mucus the times that you do cough?

speaker: patient
text: No, I already said I didn't cough.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay. Any fevers or chills?

speaker: patient
text: Nothing so far.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any other symptoms currently?

speaker: patient
text: I do notice that I am more tired than usual.

speaker: doctor
text: During physical activity do you seem out of breath or more tired than usual? I want to see if your pulmonary system is inhibited.

speaker: patient
text: No. I don't have issues with breathing when I do daily activities.

speaker: doctor
text: Hello sir, it's been a while since your last visit. How have you been?

speaker: patient
text: Hello doctor, yes, I have come a long way. I guess last time I was here was in two thousand and two if I am not wrong. Was does your system say?

speaker: doctor
text: You are right! It was August second of two thousand and two to be very precise.

speaker: doctor
text: Please confirm for the records, you are a white married man and must be forty nine years old now. Am I right?

speaker: patient
text: You got it all right doctor!

speaker: doctor
text: Are you still working in that airplane company?

speaker: patient
text: Yes sir, still with Alaska Airlines but I have been promoted and work as a plane mechanic.

speaker: doctor
text: That is so nice! Good for you man! So, tell me how can I help you today? What brought you to our dermatology department today?

speaker: patient
text: I'm having pain in my stomach on the right side and down here.

speaker: doctor
text: Is it only on the right side or anywhere else?

speaker: patient
text: It is on both sides and now I can feel it on the middle part of my left thigh as well.

speaker: doctor
text: Tell me more about it. How did it start? When did you first notice it?

speaker: patient
text: It's been going on and off. It was not there for a while, but now it is like back again mainly on my tummy, down here. It is painful when I touch it. At first, I thought maybe I'm having shingles.

speaker: doctor
text: When did you notice it?

speaker: patient
text: It all started before the holidays, I think one and a half months before the holidays. It is still going on for the past eight days in my tummy and the hips mainly on the right side.

speaker: doctor
text: Did you get any treatment for this? Any over the counter medicines?

speaker: patient
text: No, as I told you I thought it was shingles, but then there was no change in the skin, no rashes, nothing. I was not sure what to take.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, do you bathe every day?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I do but I try to use as little soap as possible.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, here is what I think, all your symptoms are pointing towards hyperesthesia. I would like to run some tests to find the underlying cause and then we will start the treatment. A nurse will come and take you to the lab. Does this sound good to you?

speaker: patient
text: Yes.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you finished with your cancer treatments?

speaker: patient
text: Yes.  I am in remission now.

speaker: doctor
text: That is great! When was your last radiation treatment?

speaker: patient
text: It has been over two years since my last treatment.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you smoke?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah. I smoke about a pack a day.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any plans of quitting?

speaker: patient
text: Eh not really.

speaker: doctor
text: As your doctor, I'd advise that you consider nicotine patches and find ways to break your smoking habit.

speaker: patient
text: Okay. I'll see what I can do.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you drink?

speaker: patient
text: Socially.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you married?

speaker: patient
text: No, but I have two littles ones.

speaker: doctor
text: Aw, how old are they?

speaker: patient
text: I have a four year old and a six year old.

speaker: doctor
text: That's great. I'm sure they keep you busy. Any hobbies?

speaker: patient
text: They really do, especially the four year old. As for hobbies, I like fixing up computers. I also like fishing, hiking, and camping with the family.

speaker: doctor
text: Good morning, ma'am. Before we begin today, can you confirm your age for me?

speaker: patient
text: Good morning, doctor. Sure, I'm seventy nine years old.

speaker: doctor
text: Great, thank you. What seems to be the problem today, ma'am?

speaker: patient
text: Well, I have this arthritis, as you know.

speaker: doctor
text: Yes, how would you describe your arthritis?

speaker: patient
text: Well, at this point I'd say it's debilitating.

speaker: doctor
text: I see, so the antiinflammatories and rest haven't helped at all?

speaker: patient
text: No, I haven't had any improvement, doctor. It's still so bad.

speaker: doctor
text: I see, I believe you'd be a good candidate for a knee replacement.

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I thought so. What are the risks of infection for the surgery?

speaker: doctor
text: Um, it's less than one percent, we use prophylactic antibiotics to control for infection the entire time.

speaker: patient
text: That's great, what about anesthesia, will I be asleep for this?

speaker: doctor
text: Yes, you won't feel a thing.

speaker: patient
text: Great, yes, I'd like to do the surgery, doctor.

speaker: doctor
text: Welcome to the clinic.

speaker: patient
text: Thank you.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you from the area?

speaker: patient
text: I was born and raised in Iowa. My husband and I moved here twenty years ago, and we have been here ever since.

speaker: doctor
text: It is a wonderful city. Do you have kids?

speaker: patient
text: Yes! We have two kids.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any history or present use of tobacco, alcohol and recreational drugs or substances?

speaker: patient
text: I have a glass of wine every once and a while but no to the rest.

speaker: doctor
text: Any of your family members have issues like seizures?

speaker: patient
text: None on my father's side, but, yeah, on my mom's side some of the family members had seizures. Like, my mom had them during her childhood. I know that my great grandmother had it and so does my great aunt.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have a sore throat, cough or earache?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Can you tell me what are the diseases you have been diagnosed with in the past?

speaker: patient
text: Sure, I have had hypertension, diabetes, asthma and cholesterol problem.

speaker: doctor
text: Ok, is there anything else?

speaker: patient
text: Nope.

speaker: doctor
text: And it is type two diabetes, right?

speaker: patient
text: Yes.

speaker: doctor
text: Thank you!

speaker: doctor
text: Good afternoon, sir. Do you remember the details of your surgery?

speaker: patient
text: No, can you remind me?

speaker: doctor
text: Well, um, we did a right orchiectomy due to your testicular cancer, when did you have that?

speaker: patient
text: Um, it was about eighteen years ago now, so that was about nineteen eighty nine.

speaker: doctor
text: Good, while you're here, do you have any other conditions that I should be aware of?

speaker: patient
text: Sure, I have G E R D, and um, I B S.

speaker: doctor
text: Thank you, what about allergies, do those bother you?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, unfortunately I have those.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have them in the spring, or in the fall?

speaker: patient
text: Actually, I have them in both. It's really annoying.

speaker: doctor
text: What allergy symptoms do you have usually?

speaker: patient
text: Um, another doctor called it a postnasal drip.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, yes, I'm familiar with that. Have you ever had any other surgeries?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, um, I had a hernia removed and repaired some time ago.

speaker: doctor
text: I see, what about any other major medical conditions?

speaker: patient
text: I've had carpal tunnel before.

speaker: doctor
text: Which hands did you have it in?

speaker: patient
text: I've had it in both.

speaker: doctor
text: Good morning, Miss X Y Z, correct?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, that's me, good morning doctor.

speaker: doctor
text: Before we begin, I just need a few pieces of information. How old are you?

speaker: patient
text: I'm forty four years young, doctor.

speaker: doctor
text: Good, thank you. Next, which hand do you write with?

speaker: patient
text: I write with my right hand.

speaker: doctor
text: Finally, what do you do for a living?

speaker: patient
text: I'm an aircraft mechanic.

speaker: doctor
text: Very nice, so, how did you get hurt?

speaker: patient
text: Um, I was working on repairing an airplane at work when I fell between the plane and one of the stands.

speaker: doctor
text: How big was the gap that you stepped in?

speaker: patient
text: Um, it was about a foot and a half.

speaker: doctor
text: Which knee did you hurt?

speaker: patient
text: It was my left knee.

speaker: doctor
text: Did you have surgery after the accident?

speaker: patient
text: Yes I did, I had two arthroscopies, and an, um, patellar replacement after those.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, yes, I see.

speaker: patient
text: Then, I had a left knee replacement on Month D D, Y Y Y Y.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any imaging of this knee?

speaker: patient
text: I didn't have any x rays done, but I have an MRI report and notes from Doctor A B C D.

speaker: doctor
text: Can I see that report?

speaker: patient
text: Yes absolutely, here.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, so this M R I from September two thousand six shows some nonspecific edema anterior to the patellar tendon, but thankfully there's no evidence of fracture of ligamentous avulsion or abnormality.

speaker: patient
text: What does that mean?

speaker: doctor
text: There's some bleeding in the bone there, but nothing is broken or out of alignment.

speaker: patient
text: Oh, thank you, that's good.

speaker: doctor
text: Oh certainly, yes, it is. What treatments have you had for this knee, aside from surgery?

speaker: patient
text: I've done a full course of PT for this.

speaker: doctor
text: Where is your knee pain?

speaker: patient
text: Mostly, it's here in the front of the knee, and then on both sides, like the inside and outside.

speaker: doctor
text: Does the pain go down your leg at all?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, it goes down my, is this the femur?

speaker: doctor
text: Yes, that's the femur.

speaker: patient
text: Then this must be my tibia, it goes down the front of that too.

speaker: doctor
text: Does it go into your thigh at all?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, it goes into the back of my thigh. I feel numbness and tingling back there.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you feel anything in the feet?

speaker: patient
text: Nope, my feet are completely normal, thankfully.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you having any back pain?

speaker: patient
text: A little, I feel something in my lower back, I'm not sure if it's related.

speaker: doctor
text: Does anything make your knee pain worse?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I can hardly walk anymore, it hurts so bad.

speaker: doctor
text: What kind of symptoms do you see when you walk on this?

speaker: patient
text: I feel popping and grinding, and my knee swells up.

speaker: doctor
text: That numbness and tingling you feel in the thigh, do you feel that in the knee at all?

speaker: patient
text: Actually yes, it feels like pins and needles there.

speaker: doctor
text: What about this, when I touch the knee do you feel any abnormal discomfort or pain over the rest of the knee?

speaker: patient
text: No, nothing out of the ordinary there.

speaker: doctor
text: What about this, this is the fibular head, which is where you feel the pins and needles. I'm applying pretty heavy pressure here, how would you describe what you're feeling?

speaker: patient
text: Um, numbness, tingling, and then that same pins and needles feeling.

speaker: doctor
text: Is there any instability?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, and there's pain with it too.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you working right now?

speaker: patient
text: No, I'm not right now.

speaker: doctor
text: Any allergies I should know about?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, actually, I'm allergic to a lot of pain medications.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, have there been any changes in how you're walking?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I had to change my walking pattern to take weight off my knee, and I think that has to do with my back pain.

speaker: doctor
text: That's certainly a possibility. How would you describe your pain?

speaker: patient
text: I'd say its constant, shooting, cramping, aching, throbbing, feels like it's being pulled, sharp, and , um, stabbing. All of those words seem fitting.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, does the pain wake you up at night?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, it does occasionally.

speaker: doctor
text: Does anything make this feel better?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, it gets a little better if I lay down or if I keep my leg elevated.

speaker: doctor
text: Out of ten, with ten being the worst pain ever, how would you describe your pain on average?

speaker: patient
text: Um, I'd say six out of ten. That's how it is right now, too.

speaker: doctor
text: What about at its worst?

speaker: patient
text: Easily, its ten out of ten.

speaker: doctor
text: Finally, what about when the pain is at its least?

speaker: patient
text: Um, when it's not too bad, I'd say it's a three out of ten. I also have this other M R I report from September of O six, here.

speaker: doctor
text: Thanks. I see. They said that there is nonspecific edema anterior to the patellar tendon, but there is no acute fracture or any ligament abnormalities. That's good.

speaker: doctor
text: How old are you?

speaker: patient
text: I'm eighty six years old.

speaker: doctor
text: What gender do you identify with?

speaker: patient
text: I identify as a female.

speaker: doctor
text: How long have you had this back and buttock pain?

speaker: patient
text: Its been a while, now. I know I have a fracture in my lower back.

speaker: doctor
text: How have you been managing this?

speaker: patient
text: Another doctor called this conservative treatment. I've been resting a lot, and using antiinflammatories.

speaker: doctor
text: Has there been any improvement?

speaker: patient
text: Its been several months at this point, and honestly no, there's been no improvement. I'm still in a lot of pain.

speaker: doctor
text: This C T Scan you had recently shows sclerosis, with some healing of a L five compression fracture, but if you look here, the healing is not complete.

speaker: patient
text: What can we do about this? I'm in so much pain.

speaker: doctor
text: I believe you'd be a candidate for a bilateral L five kyphoplasty.

speaker: patient
text: What's that?

speaker: doctor
text: It's a small procedure on that L five vertebra. Its minimally invasive, and we can actually do it as an outpatient procedure.

speaker: patient
text: Oh, wow, that's good to hear. What are the risks of infection?

speaker: doctor
text: Very low, historically, they're less than one percent.

speaker: patient
text: How is this possible?

speaker: doctor
text: We'll use antibiotics in order to control for infection.

speaker: patient
text: That's great, will I be under anesthesia?

speaker: doctor
text: Yes, you'll be asleep for the whole thing.

speaker: patient
text: Great, yes, I'd like to have this done, I can't keep living in this pain.

speaker: doctor
text: Awesome, I agree. Do you have control over your bladder and bowel movements?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, thankfully, I have complete control over everything like that still.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you wear a brace or corset normally?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I usually wear both.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, last question, can you notice any weakness in your body?

speaker: patient
text: No, I'm still very strong, even at my age.

speaker: doctor
text: Good afternoon, sir, and who's the patient today? You, or your daughter?

speaker: doctor
text: And how old are you, dear?

speaker: patient
text: I'm eighteen.

speaker: doctor
text: What seems to be the problem today?

speaker: patient
text: I hurt my right knee while playing tennis, um, it was about three days ago now. It really hurts.

speaker: doctor
text: I see, tennis, huh? Was there any contact involved?

speaker: patient
text: No, I took a step wrong when I went for an awkward shot.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you able to stand on this knee?

speaker: patient
text: Not well, it feels unstable, like I'm going to fall over.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you ever hurt this knee before?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, tore my ACL in two thousand eight.

speaker: doctor
text: I assume you had surgery for that?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah I did, um, with Doctor X. He called it an, um, A C L reconstruction.

speaker: doctor
text: How did you recover from this?

speaker: doctor
text: What did they do about that?

speaker: doctor
text: When was that done?

speaker: doctor
text: Following the revision, how did you cover?

speaker: patient
text: I did everything they said, I did it exactly as they wanted, and I did fine until this last injury.

speaker: doctor
text: Good, was there any instability following the revision?

speaker: patient
text: Nope, I was really stable.

speaker: doctor
text: How're you feeling today?

speaker: patient
text: Much better. The antibiotics seemed to really help.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you still experiencing any symptoms?

speaker: patient
text: Um no, thankfully. I had some wheezing when I first started the antibiotics, but it's improved a ton. I don't think the wheeze is even there anymore.

speaker: doctor
text: Good, good.

speaker: doctor
text: Any medical problems that run in the family?

speaker: patient
text: No, nothing that comes to mind.

speaker: doctor
text: Hi Mister B, nurse tells me you had a fall?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, a pretty bad one.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, tell me what happened?

speaker: patient
text: Well, I was running to catch a taxi and stumbled upon a piece of rock, lost my balance and fell.

speaker: patient
text: I fell face down and my head hit the sidewalk. The next thing I remember is I am all dazed and people trying to help me.

speaker: doctor
text: I see, did you lose consciousness after the fall?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: So, is your head hurting?

speaker: patient
text: Only the right forehead where I have the scrape and my chin.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, any neck or back pain?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Any stomach pain?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Pain anywhere else, in extremities, hand or leg?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, and how old are you?

speaker: patient
text: I am forty two.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: Let's talk about your family history.

speaker: patient
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: Can you tell me about any kind of medical traits that run in your family?

speaker: patient
text: I think my family has been blessed or I don't know if any.

speaker: doctor
text: What about any heart disease?

speaker: patient
text: Nope. No heart disease or diabetes or any other kind of issues that I'm aware of.

speaker: doctor
text: Hello, Nurse. Could you give me a run down on the eleven month old patient?

speaker: doctor
text: Great. Did he have a follow up after?

speaker: doctor
text: Did he receive any chemotherapy?

speaker: doctor
text: What did they do after chemotherapy?

speaker: doctor
text: Thank you, Nurse. I'll go talk to the mother.

speaker: doctor
text: Hello, ma'am. It's nice to see you again. How is your little boy doing?

speaker: doctor
text: Is it getting worse?

speaker: doctor
text: That's good to hear. Has he been sick or had any fevers?

speaker: doctor
text: Has he been able to eat anything?

speaker: doctor
text: Does he still have a reduced appetite?

speaker: doctor
text: Did he have any nausea or vomiting after he ate?

speaker: doctor
text: That's great. Is he able to pee and poop fine? No diarrhea, right?

speaker: doctor
text: Great. Would you be able to open his mouth for me? I just want to check if everything's fine inside.

speaker: patient
text: Ah.

speaker: doctor
text: Thank you. Oh, wow. It looks like he's showing some symptoms of thrush again.

speaker: doctor
text: It's just a fungal infection inside the mouth. I'll prescribe him fluconazole. It should get rid of it.

speaker: doctor
text: So, how are long have you had pain in this hip?

speaker: patient
text: It's been about eight or ten years now. It began while I was working in construction.

speaker: doctor
text: How old are you now?

speaker: patient
text: I'm thirty two now, so I've been in pain since I was in my twenties.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you seen another doctor for this, or am I the first?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, um, I've actually seen several doctors before, the last I saw was Doctor A B C a few weeks ago.

speaker: doctor
text: What did those doctors tell you?

speaker: patient
text: They thought it was low back pain, and something called, um, radiculopathy.

speaker: doctor
text: Does your pain radiate into your legs?

speaker: patient
text: Yes.

speaker: doctor
text: Has your pain been present for the eight years, or did it come and go?

speaker: patient
text: It's been persistent, and I've had difficulties on and off since then.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay. The x rays from Doctor A B C show severe degenerative changes as well as avascular necrosis of the femoral head. What else did the Doctor do for you?

speaker: patient
text: He gave me some pain medicine, and we talked about going to another specialist for surgery.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you remember the names of the procedures suggested?

speaker: patient
text: Something about resurfacing the hip, or a hip replacement. I'm here for another opinion on that.

speaker: doctor
text: I saw you come in with a cane, do you have groin pain as well?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, and I can't do any of the activities I used to.

speaker: doctor
text: Besides the pain medication, have you had anything else?

speaker: patient
text: I've taken antibiotic steroids before.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay. Do you drink?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, a lot.

speaker: doctor
text: Let me examine your skin.

speaker: patient
text: Sure.

speaker: doctor
text: It looks normal and well hydrated. Any excessive sweating?

speaker: patient
text: No, not really.

speaker: doctor
text: I don't see any injury or wounds.

speaker: patient
text: Yeah.

speaker: doctor
text: Its just a normal protocol to ask these questions for every new patient.

speaker: patient
text: I understand.

speaker: doctor
text: Thank you for your cooperation.

speaker: doctor
text: Hi there! I am Doctor Kirkland.

speaker: patient
text: Hi.

speaker: doctor
text: How are you feeling?

speaker: patient
text: I feel weird. Like I feel confused. I don't know how I got here.

speaker: doctor
text: That's okay. Do you remember what happened to you before you came here?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Can you tell me about your past medical history?

speaker: patient
text: Um.

speaker: doctor
text: Take your time.

speaker: patient
text: I can't think of what it is called. It's something to do with my brain.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

speaker: patient
text: My doctor knows what it is.

speaker: doctor
text: What is the name of your doctor?

speaker: patient
text: Doctor Frank.

speaker: doctor
text: Doctor X? Across the street?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, that is his name. I don't know if that is across the street or not.

speaker: doctor
text: I will have your nurse give him a call and get some background information from him.

speaker: patient
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: Can you please give Doctor X a call and get mister Jones' medical history?

speaker: doctor
text: Thank you.

speaker: doctor
text: Any issues from head to toe?

speaker: patient
text: No, everything is fine.

speaker: doctor
text: Hello, it's been two months already?

speaker: patient
text: I know right?

speaker: doctor
text: Just feels like yesterday.

speaker: doctor
text: Tell me about your family medical history.

speaker: patient
text: No one in my family has any health problems.

speaker: doctor
text: And are you working? What do you do?

speaker: patient
text: Oh, I am a catholic priest!

speaker: doctor
text: Oh wow!

speaker: patient
text: Yes.

speaker: doctor
text: And if you don't mind me asking, do you drink alcohol?

speaker: patient
text: Maybe that is something for my confession box but jokes apart I don't drink.

speaker: doctor
text: Sorry I need to ask these questions it's a protocol.

speaker: patient
text: I understand.

speaker: doctor
text: And can I put down here that you don't smoke or use any kinds of drugs?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I don't do those either.

speaker: doctor
text: Cool.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, so where do you live?

speaker: patient
text: I live at an old age nursing home.

speaker: doctor
text: So, he is Arjun, and he is thirty seven years old and was complaining of chest pain.

speaker: patient
text: Hi Doctors, how are you?

speaker: doctor
text: We are good thanks for asking.

speaker: patient
text: Yep.

speaker: doctor
text: Yeah. I am suspecting coronary spasm but that's questionable.

speaker: doctor
text: I did run a cardiac enzyme profile and it was negative.

speaker: doctor
text: Yes, he does.

speaker: doctor
text: I did, it is normal too.

speaker: patient
text: Thank you.

speaker: doctor
text: So, do you live in the area?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, my husband and I have lived here for a long time. He died a few years back.

speaker: doctor
text: I'm sorry to hear that.

speaker: patient
text: It's alright.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you smoke or drink?

speaker: patient
text: No, I don't.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you use any illicit drugs or substances?

speaker: patient
text: No, I don't do anything like that.

speaker: patient
text: Um, I take the generic for Ultracet. Sometimes I take as many as four times a day.

speaker: doctor
text: Does this help the pain?

speaker: patient
text: No, I'm still in pretty significant pain, doctor.

speaker: doctor
text: Good morning, sir. My nurse's chart says that you're thirty four years old. Is that correct?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, doctor, that's correct.

speaker: doctor
text: How long have you had this back pain?

speaker: patient
text: Well, it's been a while now.

speaker: doctor
text: Does the pain go into your legs?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, into the left leg, more towards the outside of my leg.

speaker: doctor
text: Is there any injury that started this pain?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I was lifting at work on August twenty seventh two thousand three when I lifted something and felt a pretty sharp pain from my back down into my left leg.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you had back pain or surgeries before this injury?

speaker: patient
text: No, I haven't.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you having weakness in the legs?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I am.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, I believe you are a good candidate for surgery, sir. It seems like you have a lot of weakness and pain in the S one nerve root distribution.

speaker: patient
text: Okay. What are the risks of infection for this surgery?

speaker: doctor
text: Overall, the risk of infection is very low, less than one percent. We use antibiotics to control for infection the entire time.

speaker: patient
text: Will I be asleep for the surgery?

speaker: doctor
text: Yes, you'll be under anesthesia. You won't feel a thing.

speaker: patient
text: Okay, yes. I'd like to do the surgery.

speaker: doctor
text: Hello, miss. Doctor X and I will be going over your medical history with you. Before we begin, could you confirm your age for me?

speaker: patient
text: I'm twenty five years old.

speaker: doctor
text: Thank you. Doctor X, could you go over the diagnosis of erythema nodosum?

speaker: doctor
text: What kind of procedures were done to address it?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, that's correct.

speaker: doctor
text: Were there any findings, Doctor X?

speaker: doctor
text: I see. Her report states something about a tibia and fibula fracture on her right leg before the erythema nodosum. Are these skin lesions due to the fracture?

speaker: patient
text: That's correct. The cuts in my skins are on both legs too. Not just the right.

speaker: doctor
text: Thank you. Did anything occur before the skin lesions?

speaker: doctor
text: Ma'am, I see you visited our clinic and the Dermatology several times, correct?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, that's correct. I had a rash that I wanted to get checked.

speaker: doctor
text: Doctor X, did you confirm with any tests?

speaker: doctor
text: Great. In the visits after, were there any other problems found?

speaker: doctor
text: Could you explain what it says?

speaker: doctor
text: The venous stasis could have been related to the fracture, right?

speaker: doctor
text: Her initial visit reports suspicion of I B D, sarcoid inflammatory arthropathy, and lupus. Why was that?

speaker: doctor
text: What lupus serologies were used?

speaker: doctor
text: How did her cardiolipin antibodies panel look?

speaker: doctor
text: I see. Was there anything else in the report?

speaker: doctor
text: That seems important because of the livedo pattern.

speaker: doctor
text: Why did she undergo a C T scan?

speaker: doctor
text: I see. The results came out normal, right?

speaker: doctor
text: Did you change some of you habits to help your bowels, ma'am?

speaker: patient
text: I tried my best to.

speaker: doctor
text: That's good. What was found Doctor X?

speaker: doctor
text: That gives the possibility of inflammatory bowel disease, right?

speaker: doctor
text: Were there any tests done to confirm this?

speaker: doctor
text: Nothing was seen microscopically?

speaker: doctor
text: That sounds important. That could be due to an allergic reaction or an emergence of Crohn Disease. I will have to discuss with Doctor Y from Gastroenterology to see the significance.

speaker: patient
text: Could I interrupt for a second? I don't think my B twelve and iron deficiency were looked at while I stayed in the United States.

speaker: doctor
text: Is that correct, Doctor X?

speaker: doctor
text: At least we are aware of it. What medication was provided during her first visit?

speaker: doctor
text: This may be a reason to her acne. Was she taken off this medication?

speaker: doctor
text: What was she places on after?

speaker: doctor
text: How were her inflammatory markers after taking it?

speaker: doctor
text: That is great. How did you like that medication, ma'am?

speaker: patient
text: My ankle would swell up and hurt. There were also some sensitive rashes on the skin of my legs.

speaker: doctor
text: I see. Is that stated on the report, Doctor X?

speaker: doctor
text: Did they find anything apparent?

speaker: doctor
text: What was the plan following that?

speaker: doctor
text: Was there any medication prescribed?

speaker: doctor
text: I see. Other than the fracture and jaw surgery, was there anything else?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, that's correct.

speaker: doctor
text: That's good. Our recent physical exam with you from last August showed changes in your venous stasis and diffuse periarticular ankle edema. Fortunately, we did not find any erythema nodosum, but the livedo patter was still present.

speaker: patient
text: I see. Did you find anything else?

speaker: doctor
text: We did find a heart murmur, so we will conduct an echocardiogram. Doctor X, could you confirm all the details form the workup, please?

speaker: doctor
text: Thank you for all that information. Does all this information and history seem to be correct, ma'am?

speaker: patient
text: Yes. Thank you for going over that in front of me.

speaker: doctor
text: No problem. I see you're here today regarding some mild but intense skin rashes. You mentioned that you thought it was erythema nodosum, correct?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, that's correct. I think it's on my ankles. I also feel some joint stiffness.

speaker: doctor
text: I will take note of that. You also mentioned something about a rash before. Did you have a rash that was sensitive to U V light, like sunlight?

speaker: patient
text: That's right. I had it twice when I was in Europe.

speaker: doctor
text: When did you notice the rashes?

speaker: patient
text: I was skiing, and my face started to swell up.

speaker: doctor
text: I see. Do you think it had to do anything with your acne?

speaker: patient
text: No. My acne was stable after I stopped taking that one medicine and started the other.

speaker: doctor
text: The prednisone and colchicine we mentioned earlier, correct?

speaker: patient
text: That's correct.

speaker: doctor
text: Is there anything else you would like to ask?

speaker: patient
text: I am trying to get pregnant and would like to know if the medication has any effects on pregnancy.

speaker: doctor
text: I'll discus that with you right now.

speaker: patient
text: Actually, could you provide me with a pamphlet? I need to go study for my psychology classes. I have a big test tomorrow.

speaker: doctor
text: Anyone sick in your family?

speaker: patient
text: Nope.

speaker: doctor
text: So, everyone is healthy?

speaker: patient
text: That's right.

speaker: doctor
text: Mister Sunil, your blood pressure is high, and I am noticing this from past two-three times you have been here. It's been constantly high, you are not taking it seriously.

speaker: patient
text: No, nothing like that Doctor! It's been well under control. I have been monitoring at home.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you noting your readings? Did you bring it with you?

speaker: patient
text: No. I did not get the readings with me but I assure you I am taking care and my B P is normal.

speaker: doctor
text: Well, it's up and I am little bothered by it.

speaker: doctor
text: What is your family medical history?

speaker: patient
text: My dad had colon cancer.

speaker: doctor
text: Did your dad pass from colon cancer?

speaker: patient
text: No. They caught it early. He passed away from old age. My mom passed away when she was in her nineties from a stroke.

speaker: doctor
text: I am sorry. Do you have any family history of any neurological disorders like, M S, Alzheimer's, Parkinson's or epilepsy?

speaker: patient
text: Other then my mom having a stroke, I know of nothing else.

speaker: doctor
text: Hello. I see you're here for a follow up. Did you get your blood work done?

speaker: patient
text: I did. Here are the results.

speaker: doctor
text: Let me take a look. Oh, wow. It looks like your blood sugar is high. Are you exercising every day?

speaker: patient
text: Not really. Is that bad?

speaker: doctor
text: You are at risk of developing type two diabetes.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you had ever had surgery?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I had my gallbladder removed a few years ago.

speaker: doctor
text: Thank you, what about any other parts of the body, like your eyes, ears, or nose?

speaker: patient
text: Oh yeah, I forgot. I had eye surgery too.

speaker: doctor
text: Thank you, think hard, any other surgeries you can remember?

speaker: patient
text: Let me look at my notes, um, it looks like I had a dilation and curettage done some time back, too.

speaker: doctor
text: I see. Thank you for sharing that with me.

speaker: doctor
text: Hi there! How are you doing?

speaker: patient
text: Um. I am feeing really strange.

speaker: doctor
text: Strange how?

speaker: patient
text: I took Ecstasy over the weekend and I feel weird still. My heart is racing. I feel agitated and have been having waves of sadness. I cannot shake this feeling.

speaker: doctor
text: When did you take the Ecstasy?

speaker: patient
text: On Saturday.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you live alone?

speaker: patient
text: I do. I lost my husband to prostate cancer last year.

speaker: doctor
text: Oh wow. I'm so deeply sorry for your loss. Losing a loved one is incredibly difficult. I lost my sister to cervical cancer two years ago. It was one of the hardest experiences of my life.

speaker: patient
text: I'm sorry for your loss as well. It helps to remember the positive memories you had with them.

speaker: doctor
text: Yes, definitely. How have you been doing otherwise?

speaker: patient
text: Not bad. I've been keeping myself busy with gardening.

speaker: doctor
text: Gardening is a great hobby.

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I enjoy it very much. It brings me a lot of peace.

speaker: doctor
text: And as your doctor I have to ask, but any history of alcohol or drug use?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Hello. How are you doing today?

speaker: patient
text: I feel depressed.

speaker: doctor
text: I'm sorry to hear that. What's been happening?

speaker: patient
text: My parents were fighting for a long time, and I think they're not together anymore.

speaker: doctor
text: That must be really hard. I'm sorry to hear that they're divorced. Who do you live with right now?

speaker: patient
text: I usually hop houses. I'll go to my dad's house the first half of the week and spend time with his family. Then, I'll go to my mom's house during the last half of the week.

speaker: doctor
text: That's nice. Now you can ask for more gifts during Christmas.

speaker: patient
text: You know what? I never thought about that. That's a really good idea.

speaker: doctor
text: What do you do for a living?

speaker: patient
text: I'm a real estate agent.

speaker: doctor
text: How long have you been working in the real estate business?

speaker: patient
text: Almost twenty years.

speaker: doctor
text: Wow. I know who to go to when I'm looking to buy a house.

speaker: patient
text: Happy to help.

speaker: doctor
text: So let's see here. Do you drink or smoke?

speaker: patient
text: I drink socially, but it's very infrequent.

speaker: doctor
text: And I have to ask, but any drug use?

speaker: patient
text: Nope. Not now, not ever.

speaker: doctor
text: Welcome back in, Miss A.

speaker: patient
text: Thank you, doctor.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you remember the information about your operation?

speaker: patient
text: No, not really. Can you remind me?

speaker: doctor
text: Sure, you had a lap band replacement in January of O nine, and you had a band adjustment.

speaker: patient
text: Thank you.

speaker: doctor
text: How are you feeling today?

speaker: patient
text: Well, I've been under a lot of stress lately, and I had problems with my adjustments before.

speaker: doctor
text: Has anything changed since the operation?

speaker: patient
text: Actually, doctor, I was in a car accident a couple weeks ago, and I'm having problems.

speaker: doctor
text: What symptoms are you experiencing?

speaker: patient
text: I don't feel full.

speaker: doctor
text: How is your appetite?

speaker: patient
text: I'm not really hungry, but I also don't feel full. When I get hungry at night I can't wait until the morning to eat. I get so hungry.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you eat anything when you feel like this?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I usually have a candy bar, and that helps some.

speaker: doctor
text: So, where do you live?

speaker: patient
text: Ah, I now live in an assisted nursing facility.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, and do you drink or smoke?

speaker: patient
text: No, neither.

speaker: doctor
text: Any specific medical traits in the family?

speaker: patient
text: What do you mean by that?

speaker: doctor
text: I meant does anyone in your family or extended family have any medical problems that they were treated for?

speaker: patient
text: I'm not aware of any such thing in my family.

speaker: doctor
text: Welcome in! I am Doctor Madison.

speaker: patient
text: Thank you. It's nice to meet you.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you married?

speaker: patient
text: Yes. We just got hitched last year.

speaker: doctor
text: Congratulations!

speaker: patient
text: Thank you.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you drink alcohol?

speaker: patient
text: No, I don't drink.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you smoke cigarettes?

speaker: patient
text: Yes. I know it's bad for me.

speaker: doctor
text: How much do you smoke per day?

speaker: patient
text: About a pack a day.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay. I have a lot of tools to help you quit smoking that we can discuss.

speaker: patient
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: We have you scheduled for a follow up and to have the staples removed in one week with Doctor X Y Z. Do you have your wound care instructions?

speaker: patient
text: Yes.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any questions?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: If you do have questions or concerns that may come up, please don't hesitate to call the office.

speaker: patient
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: If you develop a fever greater than one hundred and one point four, chills, nausea, vomiting, or continuing diarrhea please call the office. Also if your incision site becomes red, warm to the touch or has any drainage, call the office.

speaker: patient
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you had sinus issues before?

speaker: patient
text: I am not sure, maybe on and off.

speaker: doctor
text: Because this is more allergic.

speaker: patient
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: So, we call it allergic rhinitis.

speaker: patient
text: Is it different than sinus infection?

speaker: doctor
text: Yes, it's it is different.

speaker: patient
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: She has a rare case of thrombocytopenia. I'd like her to come in for a consult.

speaker: doctor
text: No, just the thrombocytopenia.

speaker: doctor
text: Hi there how are you?

speaker: patient
text: I am good no problem at all other than the usual.

speaker: doctor
text: And what is that?

speaker: patient
text: You know, some discomfort I have on my right side. I have been feeling that since I had a stroke five years back.

speaker: doctor
text: Right, right. We did an E M G right?

speaker: patient
text: Yes.

speaker: doctor
text: And none of the medications we tried are helping?

speaker: patient
text: No, I also saw a neurologist, but nothing is helping

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, and are you monitoring your sugar regularly?

speaker: patient
text: Oh yes, Everyday at least two to three times a day.

speaker: doctor
text: And how bout insulin dose?

speaker: patient
text: Oh, that I kind of adjust myself.

speaker: doctor
text: Well, I have rechecked all the symptoms and everything looks fine. I don't see anything out of order, but we will keep monitoring.

speaker: patient
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: And you are not smoking or drinking again are you?

speaker: patient
text: No, not since I had the stroke.

speaker: doctor
text: In the past you had a history of heavy usage of both alcohol and smoking, you need to be careful. You are seventy years old.

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I am taking care of it.

speaker: doctor
text: Alright take care then.

speaker: doctor
text: What is the strength of your Omeprazole?

speaker: patient
text: It is forty M G and I take it just once a day.

speaker: doctor
text: Any herbal medication?

speaker: patient
text: No I do not take anything like that.

speaker: doctor
text: So, to double check, you have a history of hay fever and asthma, correct?

speaker: patient
text: Yes. I was also recently diagnosed with cervical dysplasia. I found out shortly after my last O B G Y N visit.

speaker: doctor
text: And are you planning to follow up with your O B G Y N in the upcoming months?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, the next visit is scheduled and everything.

speaker: doctor
text: So, do you have any family history of arthritis?

speaker: patient
text: Fortunately, no, not that I know of.

speaker: doctor
text: So, as far as you know, no one has had a joint replacement?

speaker: patient
text: No, it doesn't ring any bells.

speaker: doctor
text: Please, tell me about your medical history.

speaker: patient
text: I've been dealing with depression and anxiety for some time now.

speaker: doctor
text: I'm sorry, that must be difficult.

speaker: patient
text: Thank you, it is, but I manage.

speaker: doctor
text: What about your joints? How do you move?

speaker: patient
text: Oh yes, I have arthritis as well. I also had sciatic pain a long time ago, and a herniated disk.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you ever had neurological symptoms, like headaches, blurry vision, or weakness?

speaker: patient
text: Actually yes, I have migraines when I'm having my period.

speaker: doctor
text: Thank you, and have you had any surgery in the past?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I had my appendix out.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any past history of psychiatric treatment of struggles?

speaker: patient
text: I had some extreme fatigue back in nineteen ninety one. I was in therapy for six years. They had me on Prozac. I took in for that whole six years while I was in therapy. When I started the Prozac, I had just started working again. The stress at work was overwhelming.

speaker: doctor
text: Was this the first time that you had feelings for fatigue and depression?

speaker: patient
text: No. I have always had a little sadness or depressed time in my life but it had been manageable before all the work stress started happening.

speaker: doctor
text: How are you feeling these days?

speaker: patient
text: I get somewhat sad from time to time but I don't dwell on things anymore.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you ever have thoughts of selfharm or suicidal thoughts?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: How many other children do you have?

speaker: doctor
text: How is everyone else doing?

speaker: doctor
text: Do you live here in Easton?

speaker: doctor
text: Good, do you have any pets?

speaker: doctor
text: What, no deer?

speaker: doctor
text: What grade are you in, young man?

speaker: patient
text: I'm in the second grade, doctor.

speaker: doctor
text: Good, how do you like P E? Are you able to play no problem?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I love P E. I don't have any problems there.

speaker: doctor
text: So let's start from the beginning.

speaker: patient
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: You're seventy nine years old, correct?

speaker: patient
text: Yes.

speaker: doctor
text: Right or left handed?

speaker: patient
text: Right.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you remember when you had your first fall?

speaker: patient
text: Hm about a year and a half ago I fell while trying to walk from my bed to the living room.

speaker: doctor
text: Did you feel lightheaded prior?

speaker: patient
text: Uh yeah I did have some lightheadedness and I was a bit confused. I was aware of my surroundings though. My legs just gave out and the next thing I knew I was on the floor.

speaker: doctor
text: I see. Did you lose consciousness?

speaker: patient
text: No, thank goodness.

speaker: patient
text: Yeah. I was good until my legs gave out on me July third of O eight.

speaker: doctor
text: Did you experience the same lightheadedness as before?

speaker: patient
text: Not this time.

speaker: patient
text: I was later diagnosed with pneumonia. The fall was blamed on the pneumonia.

speaker: doctor
text: Got it.

speaker: patient
text: To be on the safe side, I started using a walker from then on.

speaker: doctor
text: Did you need any type of walking assistance prior to your falls?

speaker: patient
text: Nope. I used to walk about two miles a day before all of this stuff started happening to me. This isn't even the end of it. My legs gave out on me again August O eight. No lightheadedness beforehand, but they did find that I had pneumonia again.

speaker: doctor
text: Did rehab help?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah. I was able to use my walker after that.

speaker: doctor
text: Did you return to your previous health?

speaker: patient
text: Uh not really, no. I had another fall in October O eight.

speaker: doctor
text: Did they diagnose you with pneumonia again?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah. I also had shingles.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you currently living at home?

speaker: patient
text: I'm living in a Chronic Rehab Unit. I can't use my walker anymore. I'm confined to a wheelchair.

speaker: doctor
text: I'm sorry to hear that.

speaker: patient
text: On top of that, I've noticed that my hands have been numb for the past three weeks.

speaker: doctor
text: Is it all of your fingers or only some?

speaker: patient
text: All.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you noticing any other symptoms along with the numbness in your fingers?

speaker: patient
text: Yes. I feel like I've lost quite a bit of muscle in my hands. They're also much weaker than before. My strength hasn't been the same since July O eight. It's definitely getting worse.

speaker: doctor
text: I see.

speaker: patient
text: I've had muscle twitching in my legs since August O eight.

speaker: doctor
text: Fasciculations?

speaker: patient
text: Yes. In my lower legs and thighs.

speaker: doctor
text: Any cramping or problems swallowing?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Any difficulty breathing?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Any constipation or diarrhea?

speaker: patient
text: Both actually. It tends to alternate.

speaker: doctor
text: But no loss of bowel or bladder control?

speaker: patient
text: No. I've noticed that my blood pressure has been out of whack. I also feel like I'm about to faint anytime I stand.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

speaker: patient
text: I don't think I have much feeling in my feet. They feel like sponges.

speaker: doctor
text: How long has that been going on?

speaker: patient
text: Uh nine months or so. I lost joint position sense in my feet around that time, too.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you still doing water aerobics?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I've been hitting the pool five days outta the week.

speaker: doctor
text: How're you feeling? Have you noticed any changes in energy and strength?

speaker: patient
text: I feel a bit stronger now compared to when I first started. I'm also way, way more energized.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any history of chronic pain?

speaker: patient
text: I got into a car accident a long time ago and I have always had neck pain.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay. Any other pain throughout the body?

speaker: patient
text: Sometimes I have back pain.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: How is your pain today?

speaker: patient
text: Eh it's been a rough few days that's for sure. The pain started almost instantly.

speaker: doctor
text: I'm sorry to hear that. Have you been taking anything for it?

speaker: patient
text: I actually saw a chiropractor the other day. My neck pain has been unbearable.

speaker: doctor
text: Is the pain localized to one area?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah.

speaker: doctor
text: And it hasn't radiated to any other part of your body?

speaker: patient
text: Nope.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you experiencing a pins and needles sensation at all?

speaker: patient
text: Not yet.

speaker: doctor
text: Any back pain?

speaker: patient
text: Oh yeah. I'd say it's even worse than my neck pain. The pain starts in my lower back and radiates down both legs.

speaker: doctor
text: Any pins and needles as a result of this back pain?

speaker: patient
text: No, no pins and needles.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you experiencing stiffness in your back?

speaker: patient
text: The stiffness seems to worsen when I exert myself during activities.

speaker: doctor
text: Has it impacted your sleep at all?

speaker: patient
text: Honestly, I haven't gotten much sleep since the accident. It's been so difficult to find a comfortable position to sleep in. I've never had back problems until now.

speaker: doctor
text: This accident sure did a number on you.

speaker: patient
text: No kidding.

speaker: doctor
text: You had mentioned experiencing stiffness during strenuous activity. Is it mostly during the day or does it progress into the night?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, it's mostly during the day.

speaker: doctor
text: I see.

speaker: patient
text: The pain does improve a bit when I lay flat or sit up in a chair.

speaker: doctor
text: But despite this, your activity continues to be restricted, correct?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, correct.

speaker: doctor
text: I meant to ask if you felt better after chiropractic treatment?

speaker: patient
text: A little bit, but not much.

speaker: doctor
text: And would you say your pain has overall gotten worse or remained the same?

speaker: patient
text: It's stayed more or less the same.

speaker: doctor
text: And to confirm, you didn't have neck or lower back problems prior to the accident?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah.

speaker: doctor
text: I have reviewed your x rays from your emergency room visit. I agree with Doctor Jones that your lungs show no signs of infection or decreased lung capacity.

speaker: patient
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: Hello, how are you doing? What brings you here?

speaker: patient
text: I think I have allergies. I used to live in Seattle. I had allergies there, but I think they're getting worse after moving here. You see, I'm twenty three and I am a white female. I was in Seattle, I thought that the weather there is not for me. That's why I plan to move on here, but my allergies are not leaving me here either.

speaker: doctor
text: What did you take for your allergies before?

speaker: patient
text: Claritin and Zyrtec.

speaker: doctor
text: How effective were they?

speaker: patient
text: They seemed to be working for some time, but now I feel like nothing is effective anymore.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you ever tried Allegra?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I tried that last summer and I've started it again like two weeks ago. But again, the story is the same. They work for some time and now it doesn't seem to be working anymore.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you tried sprays?

speaker: patient
text: I did use some over the counter ones. But I never got any prescribed nasal spray.

speaker: doctor
text: Any other medically related history that I should be aware of?

speaker: patient
text: I do have asthma if that counts.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you taking any medications for your asthma?

speaker: patient
text: Nope, nothing on the regular basis.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you think it is your asthma that is flaring up?

speaker: patient
text: I don't think so. I think, I still think it is just some allergies. I want to get tested.

speaker: doctor
text: Good afternoon, ma'am.

speaker: patient
text: Good afternoon doctor.

speaker: doctor
text: So, do you have any medical conditions I should know about.

speaker: patient
text: Actually, yes. I have a few. I have hyperthyroidism, and I've had gallbladder issues for some time now.

speaker: doctor
text: I see. How's your blood pressure?

speaker: patient
text: Oh, um, I have high blood pressure too.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you a smoker, sir?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I've been smoking about a pack, to about a pack and a half a day for more than forty years now.

speaker: doctor
text: What about alcohol, do you drink?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I drink a six pack of beer a day, doctor.

speaker: doctor
text: What about drugs? Do you use any illicit substances?

speaker: patient
text: No, I never used anything like that.

speaker: doctor
text: I'd like her to come see you for a consult tomorrow.

speaker: doctor
text: About five years now.

speaker: doctor
text: Not since moving here.

speaker: doctor
text: So, sir, are you married?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I'm married to my lovely wife.

speaker: doctor
text: That's great, so, what did you do for a living?

speaker: patient
text: I was a Pepsi Cola truck driver, but thankfully, I'm retired.

speaker: doctor
text: Congratulations on your retirement. What seems to be the problem today then?

speaker: patient
text: Thank you, it's nice to be done with that. The years took their toll though, I have a lot of pain in my back and knees.

speaker: doctor
text: Ah, yes, those years of sitting and lifting eventually catch up to everyone.

speaker: doctor
text: Tell me about your family medical history.

speaker: patient
text: The only thing that I know about is that my grandma has diabetes.

speaker: doctor
text: Hello, Mister G, how are you today?

speaker: patient
text: I am good doctor thank you for asking. I am here to talk to you about my will.

speaker: doctor
text: Yeah, nurse informed me. So, tell me how can I help you?

speaker: patient
text: As you know I have terminal cancer. I have decided I do not want to be resuscitated. I have appointed my daughter as my legal healthcare proxy and she respects my wish.

speaker: doctor
text: Tell me what I can do to make you comfortable?

speaker: patient
text: Honestly doctor you have done enough and I am so thankful for that. I just wish to spend my last days at home surrounded with loved ones. I have my nurse, she takes care of me. I think I am fine!

speaker: doctor
text: Alright my friend.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you smoke?

speaker: patient
text: Nope.

speaker: doctor
text: What about alcohol? Or any kind of drugs?

speaker: patient
text: Nope.

speaker: doctor
text: History of any illnesses, surgeries, or hospitalizations?

speaker: patient
text: I dislocated my wrist when I was a kid but that's all.

speaker: doctor
text: Any pain while peeing?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Any change in frequency or feeling the urgency to pee?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: And what about bladder control, any accidents?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Any history of syphilis or any other S T D?

speaker: patient
text: No, never.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: Is there any history of heart disease in your family?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, my dad and brother had heart vessel blockage type of disease in their forties.

speaker: doctor
text: If I'm understanding correctly, you sustained an elbow injury during a fight with some other kids in Juvenile Hall?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah. My left elbow is killing me.

speaker: doctor
text: How old are you?

speaker: patient
text: Seventeen.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you having pain anywhere else?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah. My left ankle also hurts.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you able to walk without difficulty?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah.

speaker: doctor
text: Any knee pain?

speaker: patient
text: Not right now, but I've had left knee pain in the past.

speaker: doctor
text: Did you pass out or hurt your neck in any way?

speaker: patient
text: I didn't pass out. I hit my head against the floor when one of the kids tried to pin me down.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have a headache, nausea, or blurry vision?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: And no chest or abdominal pain?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Were there any weapons like knives or guns used during the fight?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Hello. Before we begin your visit, I noticed some information missing. Could I verify the information with you?

speaker: patient
text: Of course.

speaker: doctor
text: Does your family have a history of any health related problems?

speaker: patient
text: Oh, yeah. A lot of my family have heart problems and cancer.

speaker: doctor
text: I see. Do you know what kind of cancer?

speaker: patient
text: I'm not completely sure, but my wife may know. She's here with me right now.

speaker: doctor
text: Great. I'll bring her in.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you know what type of cancer runs in his family?

speaker: doctor
text: Thank you. Sir, are there any other health related problems I should be aware of?

speaker: patient
text: High blood pressure and food allergies run in my family too.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay I am looking at you for multiple issues today. One of the biggest being swelling on your left leg. Can you tell me more about that?

speaker: patient
text: Yes sure. I got this swelling for almost three years now, and it has been worse for the past two to three months. Sometimes it gets better in the morning when I get up, but then throughout the day it begins to swell again.  Lately it is staying bigger, and it feel uncomfortable with it being so large.  The right leg also swells, but not nearly like the left leg.

speaker: doctor
text: How old are you, miss?

speaker: patient
text: I am forty four. My biggest problem is this pain in my left shoulder. I feel as if this low back pain is due to a poor mattress.

speaker: doctor
text: Did you hurt your shoulder?

speaker: patient
text: No, I don't remember hurting shoulder, but gradually I am losing some mobility.  It is hard for me to get my hands behind my back or behind my head.  I am losing strength in the left shoulder gradually for the last year.

speaker: doctor
text: Ok let's look at your labs.

speaker: patient
text: So far white counts are high. In April two thousand five Doctor X Y Z was asked to look at my high white count, but she thought it wasn't a problem and asked me to come for follow up.

speaker: doctor
text: Any other complaints?

speaker: patient
text: I have a lot of frequency with urination, and I get up to pee at night at least two to three times.   Also, I have gained weight, I think about twelve pounds since March.  Right now, I am two eighty four pounds.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay. So, I can see that your blood pressure is staying stable.  You do take Atenolol twelve point five M G per day and Lasix as needed.

speaker: patient
text: Yes, that's correct. It makes me pee so much. I do not take it.

speaker: doctor
text: How about chest pain or shortness of breath?

speaker: patient
text: No chest pain, but I am gradually feeling short of breath.

speaker: doctor
text: What work you do?

speaker: patient
text: I work for the city of Wichita as bus dispatcher. My work demands sitting a lot, and just really does not move around much.  But towards the end of the day my leg swells up.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay that's okay.

speaker: patient
text: I need cholesterol check right?

speaker: doctor
text: Yes, you do, but all the other labs are normal.

speaker: doctor
text: What do you do for living?

speaker: patient
text: I am an officer at United States Marine office, artillery repair specialist.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you drink alcohol?

speaker: patient
text: I use to drink socially but stopped two years back.

speaker: doctor
text: How about smoking and drugs?

speaker: patient
text: No not that.

speaker: doctor
text: How are you today?

speaker: patient
text: I am good.

speaker: doctor
text: What is your past medical history?

speaker: patient
text: I don't have any health problems. Not yet at least.

speaker: doctor
text: Let's keep try to keep it that way.

speaker: patient
text: Yes please.

speaker: doctor
text: Well, I am looking at your ultrasound report and honestly the only significant finding of this area is that it shows to be related to bone.

speaker: patient
text: Oh okay.

speaker: doctor
text: Tell me about your family. Did anyone have any medical issues?

speaker: patient
text: My father is alive. He is sixty nine right now. He did have some strokes in the past. My mom on the other hand died at the age of sixty two of many kinds of heart diseases.

speaker: doctor
text: What about your grandparents?

speaker: patient
text: My maternal grandfather he also had heart issues and he died of a heart attack. Both he and my maternal grandma had some heart diseases. Their heart use to beat pretty fast.

speaker: doctor
text: Hi there! What brings you back to see me so soon?

speaker: patient
text: Hi! I have had these sores in my mouth.

speaker: doctor
text: How long have you had the sores?

speaker: patient
text: They started about ten to twelve days ago.

speaker: doctor
text: We have been currently treating your rheumatoid arthritis with methotrexate. How much have you been taking?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, we have tried lots of different treatments and methotrexate has been working well.  I have been on it for ten years now. I have been taking about twenty or twenty five M G of per week.

speaker: doctor
text: Did we recently increase your dosage? I see in your chart that we have changed your dosage a few times.

speaker: patient
text: About a year ago we lowered the dosage for twenty five M G to twenty but my arthritis flared up so we went to twenty two point five.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you ever had any side effects from the methotrexate in the past?

speaker: patient
text: No. I don't think so.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you taking any other medications?

speaker: patient
text: I had a sinus infection and the doctor put me on an antibiotic. That was about two weeks ago.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you know what the antibiotic the doctor gave you?

speaker: patient
text: I don't remember the name of the antibiotic, but I know that I have taken antibiotics before and I didn't have a problem.

speaker: doctor
text: How long was your antibiotic course?

speaker: patient
text: It was three or four days long. I had to take it three times a day.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you ever had any allergic reactions to medications?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Any history of mouth sores?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you taking anything to help with the pain of the mouth sores?

speaker: patient
text: I took Aspirin a month ago. I started taking it again because my mouth was sore.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you had any other problems with your skin? Any new rashes?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Sorry to side track, but where is your accent from? My family is Cuban and my mom and you speak the same.

speaker: patient
text: What a surprise! I am Cuban. A proud fifty seven year old Cuban.

speaker: doctor
text: Hello, miss. How are you feeling today?

speaker: patient
text: Terrible. My allergies are killing me right now.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have a history of allergies?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I do. I had them all the time when I lived in Seattle, but they got a lot worse when I moved here. I am a strong German woman and I hate how something as little as allergies gets the best of me.

speaker: doctor
text: Why did you move here?

speaker: patient
text: I wanted to experience different cities since I'm only twenty three.

speaker: doctor
text: That sounds exciting. Back to your allergies now. Do you take any medication to relieve your symptoms?

speaker: patient
text: Here's a list of past and current medications I'm taking.

speaker: doctor
text: Thank you. Let me take a look. I see you took Claritin and Zyrtec in the past, correct? Did those help you?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, that's correct. They were working for a bit, but then they stopped working after a while.

speaker: doctor
text: I see. Your notes say you took Allegra after, correct?

speaker: patient
text: Correct. I tried out Allegra last summer, but I don't know if it was doing its job. I tried it again two weeks ago because my allergies were getting bad, but it still didn't work.

speaker: doctor
text: I see. Your notes state you've tried some nasal sprays, correct?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I did. I wanted to see if they would work.

speaker: doctor
text: Were you prescribed these nasal sprays?

speaker: patient
text: Nope. I bought them at my local pharmacy.

speaker: doctor
text: Sounds good. I'm looking at your medical history, and it sates here you have asthma too, correct?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I've had it for a long time, but it hasn't gotten worse.

speaker: doctor
text: I see. Do you think you need any medication to help alleviated your asthma?

speaker: patient
text: No. It doesn't bother me as much as my allergies.

speaker: doctor
text: How are you doing young man?

speaker: patient
text: I'm good. Thank you.

speaker: doctor
text: Let's see how your chest is doing.

speaker: patient
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: Chest measurements look nice. No issue there. The outline also looks great. Also, there is no hunchback?

speaker: doctor
text: I see here that Doctor-

speaker: patient
text: Yes, Doctor X referred me. My thyroid is an absolute mess. I have never been in so much pain in my seventy one years.

speaker: doctor
text: I'm so sorry to hear that. I hope we're able to get you the care that you need.

speaker: patient
text: I've been coughing up a storm. It's gotten to be way too enlarged.

speaker: doctor
text: It's good that you're here today to get the surgery rolling.

speaker: patient
text: I signed the paperwork and everything.

speaker: doctor
text: I'll go over the risk and benefits one more time. Any questions for me?

speaker: patient
text: When is the earliest I can get this done again?

speaker: doctor
text: Given your symptoms, I'd like to get you in in the next few days.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you allergic to any medications?

speaker: patient
text: No, I am not allergic to any drugs.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay. Are you sure?

speaker: patient
text: Yes.

speaker: doctor
text: I see here that you're allergic to grapefruit and peanuts. Do you happen to be allergic to any medications you've taken in the past?

speaker: patient
text: Nah, just allergic to grapefruit and peanuts.

speaker: doctor
text: Gotcha. Do you carry an Epi pen around with you?

speaker: patient
text: I try to bring it with me everywhere I go.

speaker: doctor
text: So, tell me about your family, any illness or anything that runs in the family.

speaker: patient
text: Um, not that I know of.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: Any medical issues in the past?

speaker: patient
text: No, I have a very clean history.

speaker: doctor
text: That's good for you. Any kind of surgery or hospitalization?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Let's talk a little bit about your family, okay?

speaker: doctor
text: Does anyone in your family had any medical issues?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, my parents died of cancer.

speaker: doctor
text: Which cancer? How old were they?

speaker: patient
text: I don't know which cancer they had, but my mother was forty two and dad was sixty two.

speaker: doctor
text: Who else is there in the family?

speaker: patient
text: Oh, I have a big family. I have four sisters, one brother and two half brothers. One of my half brother's has asthma.

speaker: doctor
text: So, tell me something, does asthma run in your family?

speaker: patient
text: No, I think I am the only one who has it. Even my parents were surprised when I developed it, as no one else has it.

speaker: doctor
text: Yeah, it happens.

speaker: doctor
text: Welcome in, sir. I am Doctor Gray.

speaker: patient
text: Thank you. It's nice to meet you.

speaker: doctor
text: What is your past medical history?

speaker: patient
text: I had surgery on my shoulder thirteen years ago and after the surgery I lost my sense of smell. I still can't smell. I also can't see very well in my right eye.

speaker: doctor
text: How old are you?

speaker: patient
text: I am seventy six.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you get headaches?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any nasal drainage?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you ever experience any weakness or numbness throughout or localized to an area of the body.

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you had any resent weight loss?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Do thyroid problems run in your family?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you taking any medicines?

speaker: patient
text: Just Tylenol for my pain.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: Good afternoon, sir. Did you see the nurse already?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I just saw her.

speaker: doctor
text: Great, you're seventy eight years old, correct?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I'm not as young as I used to be.

speaker: doctor
text: Who is? What seems to be the problem today, sir?

speaker: patient
text: I have right hand pain, and it's been there for a while now.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you having numbness sir?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, and I can't move it very well, either.

speaker: doctor
text: Which fingers are you having these symptoms in?

speaker: patient
text: Well, I told you it's all in the right hand, but it's in the index and middle fingers.

speaker: doctor
text: Are your fingers catching?

speaker: patient
text: What does that mean, doctor?

speaker: doctor
text: Are you having any problems extending your fingers?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, they seem to lock up when I try to extend my fingers.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you seen another doctor for this?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I had an E M G and it showed, um, carpal tunnel on both hands.

speaker: doctor
text: It's in both hands, but the right is worse than the left, correct?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, that's correct.

speaker: doctor
text: What treatments have you had for this?

speaker: patient
text: I only had an injection so far.

speaker: doctor
text: Did this help at all?

speaker: patient
text: Well, some, but it was really only temporary relief. Is there surgery for this?

speaker: doctor
text: Yes, I think you'd be a good candidate for surgery.

speaker: patient
text: What are the risks of infection from the surgery?

speaker: doctor
text: It's less than one percent. We use prophylactic antibiotics to control for infection the entire time.

speaker: patient
text: Even though it's on my hand, will I be asleep for this procedure?

speaker: doctor
text: Yes, you won't feel a thing.

speaker: patient
text: Okay, yes. I'd like to do the surgery.

speaker: doctor
text: Hi are you married?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I am.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have kids?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I had a son, but unfortunately, he died in a car accident. It was five years ago.

speaker: doctor
text: Where do you work?

speaker: patient
text: I work in a pharmaceutical company as a salesperson.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you smoke or drink or at any time tried any illicit drug?

speaker: patient
text: No, I've never smoked. I have tried a beer once, but I never liked it.

speaker: doctor
text: What about drugs?

speaker: patient
text: No, never did that.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you going to visit rehab?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, what choice do I have?

speaker: doctor
text: Yes, please do visit Mercy Manor for P T and Rehab.

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I will.

speaker: doctor
text: That will help your right side hip pain.

speaker: patient
text: I think so too.

speaker: doctor
text: Can you tell me about your Immunizations?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I had them all.

speaker: doctor
text: Good, looks like you are up to date.

speaker: doctor
text: Welcome back to the clinic. How are you feeling today?

speaker: patient
text: Thank you. I am doing better.

speaker: doctor
text: It looks like we are following up on your severe osteoarthritis in both knees. And you also have been experiencing some flexion contracture limitations.

speaker: patient
text: Um hum.

speaker: doctor
text: How is your physical therapy going?

speaker: patient
