text: It is going really well. She kicks my butt but it seems to be helping. Doing my exercises at home is really helping.

speaker: doctor
text: Were you not doing them in the beginning?

speaker: patient
text: No, I wasn't. She got on me to start doing them and I have definitely seen the difference.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you experienced any worsening of pain since you were last seen?

speaker: patient
text: Well, the right knee is worse than the left? It mostly hurts after physical therapy.

speaker: doctor
text: Can you describe what the pain feels like?

speaker: patient
text: It feels achy.

speaker: doctor
text: Is it a continuous pain, or?

speaker: patient
text: No. It is not all the time. Every once and a while. It feels stiff all the time.

speaker: doctor
text: Any weakness or instability?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Any burning sensations associated with the pain?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: How long have you been dealing with this?

speaker: patient
text: Several months.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you had any trouble sleeping?

speaker: patient
text: No. When I sit down or lie down at night there's no pain.

speaker: doctor
text: So, the pain is when you are weight bearing, right?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah. And it hurts when I move around. It makes it difficult to do things.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you noticed any pain with the cold weather change?

speaker: patient
text: No, I have not noticed anything.

speaker: doctor
text: I am just going to take a look here.

speaker: patient
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: I don't see any swelling or redness. And I don't feel any warmth coming from the area. Have you noticed any of these symptoms?

speaker: patient
text: Nope.

speaker: doctor
text: Any radiating pain through the knees here?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Any pain any where else in the body?

speaker: patient
text: No, just the knees.

speaker: doctor
text: So, no pain in the hips or back?

speaker: patient
text: Nope.

speaker: doctor
text: Hi, what is going on?

speaker: doctor
text: We see this a lot at A B C Medical Center. I am glad you came. You just saw Doctor H, right?

speaker: doctor
text: Okay. Where is she living? With you?

speaker: doctor
text: Ma'am, do you have headache or chest pain?

speaker: patient
text: What? What? Huh?

speaker: doctor
text: Ma'am. Do you have vision issues?

speaker: patient
text: What? I can see. Of course I can see.

speaker: doctor
text: Any shortness of breath?

speaker: doctor
text: Have your symptoms improved at all? Or have they worsened since this morning?

speaker: doctor
text: I think you have a muscular strain.

speaker: patient
text: Yeah.

speaker: doctor
text: So right side shoulder strain and maybe a little bit of nerve compression.

speaker: patient
text: Oh really!

speaker: doctor
text: Maybe. I will do further evaluation and treatment.

speaker: patient
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your daughter, ma'am?

speaker: doctor
text: Has she ever had surgery?

speaker: doctor
text: When was her last surgery?

speaker: doctor
text: How did she do following the second surgery?

speaker: doctor
text: So, what brings you in for a visit today?

speaker: patient
text: Well, I've been having some leg pain on the side of my legs.

speaker: doctor
text: How long have you had this pain?

speaker: patient
text: It's been several months at this point.

speaker: doctor
text: When is your pain the worst?

speaker: patient
text: Um, it's the worst at night, I have to take medicine for the pain.

speaker: doctor
text: What do you take?

speaker: doctor
text: Wow, that's a lot. Looks like you have some patch sensory loss in the L four to S one region. Are you going to the bathroom regularly?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, there's no problems there. I do have some loss of feeling in my big toe and calf though.

speaker: doctor
text: Well, he has improved clinically but would require acute care.

speaker: doctor
text: Good morning, ma'am. Can you confirm your age for me, please?

speaker: patient
text: Good morning, I'm sixty five years old, doctor.

speaker: doctor
text: How are you recovering from your operation?

speaker: patient
text: I'm doing okay. Can you remind me what operation I had?

speaker: doctor
text: Um, we did a left upper lobectomy for your stage I A non small cell lung cancer.

speaker: patient
text: Thank you, doctor.

speaker: doctor
text: Absolutely, do you have the results of your pelvic C T?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I have the report right here.

speaker: doctor
text: Thank you, so this shows an enlarging simple cyst of the left kidney.

speaker: patient
text: What can we do about this?

speaker: doctor
text: Well, that's why we did the barium swallow, which showed a small hiatal hernia with minimal reflux.

speaker: patient
text: Oh, yeah, I remember that.

speaker: doctor
text: So, I have your x rays from November twenty third two thousand nine here, we did an A P and lateral view, and they're normal.

speaker: patient
text: Oh, well that's good too.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you having any pain with swallowing food?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I get some chest pain, but I'd say it's pretty mild. Look at my calf, doctor, it's much bigger than the right one.

speaker: doctor
text: Chest pain is probably due to tertiary contractions with some delayed emptying. Is it tender?

speaker: patient
text: No, there's no real tenderness.

speaker: doctor
text: How long has this calf been enlarged?

speaker: patient
text: Um, it's been several months at this point.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you ever had D V T?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, um, in nineteen seventy five, and in nineteen eighty five.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you having any abnormal weight loss?

speaker: patient
text: No, everything is normal there, and I'm eating normally.

speaker: doctor
text: What about any cold or flu symptoms? Any fever or chills?

speaker: patient
text: No, that's all fine too.

speaker: doctor
text: Any new aches or pains?

speaker: patient
text: No, all my muscles feel pretty good.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you had a cough, or coughed up any blood.

speaker: patient
text: That's a negative, doctor.

speaker: doctor
text: What about shortness of breath while at rest or difficulty breathing with exercise?

speaker: patient
text: No, that's normal too. I'm breathing just fine.

speaker: doctor
text: Let's talk about your family's medical history.

speaker: patient
text: Hm, well both my father and my brother had colon cancer. My daughter was detected with breast cancer.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you remember what her age was?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, she was forty.

speaker: doctor
text: I see. Anything else?

speaker: patient
text: Well, I have a heart condition and high blood pressure. I also had a stroke.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay.

speaker: doctor
text: Any fever?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: No nausea and vomiting or black stool? Did you notice any blood in your stools?

speaker: patient
text: Nope, nothing like that.

speaker: doctor
text: Did you notice any blood in urine or painful urination?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, any chest pain?

speaker: patient
text: Um, no.

speaker: doctor
text: Any shortness of breath, cough or cold like symptoms?

speaker: patient
text: Nope.

speaker: doctor
text: No diabetes or thyroid problem, right?

speaker: patient
text: Absolutely not!

speaker: doctor
text: Looks like you have no history of C V A or stroke.

speaker: patient
text: Correct.

speaker: doctor
text: Everything else looks fine.

speaker: patient
text: Cool.

speaker: doctor
text: Your eyes, nose, and throat look good.

speaker: doctor
text: How are you doing miss? How are your sugar numbers coming along?

speaker: patient
text: I'm doing good. Thank you. Sugar has consistently been one hundred and thirty five or under it.

speaker: doctor
text: How are you checking it?

speaker: patient
text: I have a glucose monitor at home I'm using that only.

speaker: doctor
text: Nice. Did you eat anything in the morning today?

speaker: patient
text: No, I'm fasting for my test.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, let's see. We have an Accu Chek here in our office. I will do a quick sugar test for you, and this will be a fasting sugar test. It will be just a quick prick on your finger.

speaker: patient
text: Don't worry doctor. I'm used to poking my finger all the time.

speaker: doctor
text: Let's see what we got here. Your reading says one hundred and twenty. I will write it down for my record. Are you being active?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I'm exercising as a rule three times every week. I don't miss it.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you feel any tingling or numbness or any kind of cramps?

speaker: patient
text: Nope.

speaker: doctor
text: Any kind of blurry vision?

speaker: patient
text: Nope.

speaker: doctor
text: Any weight loss?

speaker: patient
text: Not that I notice.

speaker: doctor
text: How did your last visit go with the cardiologist?

speaker: patient
text: Good.

speaker: doctor
text: It looks like they diagnosed you with sick sinus syndrome. Do you have any questions about this new diagnosis?

speaker: patient
text: No, she explained everything to me. I'm planning to follow-up with her in the next two weeks.

speaker: doctor
text: Great. So it looks like your past medical history is the same? Nothing new other than the sick sinus syndrome.

speaker: doctor
text: So Mister J, where do you stay?

speaker: patient
text: Oh, I stay at a care facilit. It's very near to your clinic. Have you heard about this place called South Valley Care Center?

speaker: doctor
text: Oh yes, I have heard of it.

speaker: doctor
text: How are you Mister James?

speaker: patient
text: I have been better!

speaker: doctor
text: Oh, tell me what's going on with you?

speaker: patient
text: I have this leg pain on my left side.

speaker: doctor
text: Hm, left leg pain?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you ever had an allergic reaction to drugs you've taken in the past?

speaker: patient
text: More than once. I've reacted poorly to sulfa drugs, penicillin, and some mycins. I also think I'm allergic to contrast medium.

speaker: doctor
text: Hey, do you smoke cigarettes?

speaker: patient
text: Yes I do smoke. Do you?

speaker: doctor
text: Nope. Are you planning on quitting?

speaker: patient
text: No, I just smoke one pack per day, it's not bad.

speaker: doctor
text: Oh my God. No. It is bad. You should think about quitting.

speaker: patient
text: Okay I will think about it.

speaker: doctor
text: Where do you work?

speaker: patient
text: I work at local christmas tree farm.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you still working?

speaker: patient
text: Retired some time ago.

speaker: doctor
text: What was your profession?

speaker: patient
text: I used to work at a car repair shop called Champion Automotive Company.

speaker: doctor
text: Nice. How did you enjoy the work?

speaker: patient
text: I liked it a lot, but there came a time where I knew it was the end of the road for me. I'm really enjoying retirement.

speaker: doctor
text: I bet. I have cousin who owns a car repair shop. He's almost always busy.

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, it can be a lot sometimes.

speaker: doctor
text: Any smoking, drinking, or hard drugs?

speaker: patient
text: I can confidently say no to each one.

speaker: doctor
text: Great to hear.

speaker: doctor
text: Yes, I confirmed with his wife. He had a CABG done in ninety one. He has a history of radical prostate cancer for which he underwent a radical prostatectomy and nephrectomy.

speaker: doctor
text: Yes. He had lumbar surgery twice before. He suffered from lumbar stenosis many years ago in the sixties and seventies. He's actually due for another lumbar surgery with Doctor Y. He takes Percocet daily for his back pain.  He also has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you have any history of major surgeries?

speaker: patient
text: No. Nothing major.

speaker: doctor
text: Good morning, sir.

speaker: patient
text: Good morning, doctor.

speaker: doctor
text: Before we begin, have you ever had surgery?

speaker: patient
text: Yes, I had a vasectomy some time ago.

speaker: doctor
text: Okay, so let's go over your medications. I'd like you to take these to help your muscle spasms.

speaker: patient
text: Sounds good.

speaker: doctor
text: I've prescribed eight hundred milligrams of Ibuprofen to be taken every eight hours as needed along with Tylenol number three every six hours as needed.

speaker: patient
text: What does the number three stand for?

speaker: doctor
text: Tylenol number three is combined with Codeine.

speaker: patient
text: Okay, I see.

speaker: doctor
text: And finally, I'm prescribing Methocarbamol seven fifty milligrams which needs to be taken four times a day for maximum relief. Do you have any questions for me?

speaker: patient
text: No, I think you answered them all.

speaker: doctor
text: How are you doing today, sir?

speaker: patient
text: Honestly, I'm pretty sick today. I've got a lot going on.

speaker: doctor
text: How long have you been feeling this way?

speaker: patient
text: Well, it's been off and on for about a month now.

speaker: doctor
text: Has it been getting worse recently?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, it has over the last couple weeks.

speaker: doctor
text: What are your symptoms?

speaker: patient
text: Well, I'm coughing up this yellow phlegm. It feels like everything is in my chest.

speaker: doctor
text: What medications have you been taking for this?

speaker: patient
text: I've been taking Allegra D sometimes, but I'm almost out. I need a refill.

speaker: doctor
text: What other problems are you having?

speaker: patient
text: My foot keeps breaking out.

speaker: doctor
text: Has this improved at all?

speaker: patient
text: Well, it was for a while, but now it's really bad again.

speaker: doctor
text: Have you been diagnosed with any conditions before?

speaker: patient
text: I had, um, tinea pedis before.

speaker: doctor
text: How was this treated?

speaker: patient
text: They gave me Nizoral cream.

speaker: doctor
text: It has been getting warmer recently, I don't think that this isn't necessarily a coincidence that you're having these symptoms now.

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I work in the flint and it's really hot and humid down there.

speaker: doctor
text: What else are you dealing with, sir?

speaker: patient
text: I have this wart on my right middle finger, are you able to freeze it off?

speaker: doctor
text: Have you ever done that before?

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, you have done it before, and it went away.

speaker: doctor
text: If we've done it before, we can do it again.

speaker: patient
text: Cool, can we do blood work, too? I want to check on my prostate.

speaker: doctor
text: Well, that's called P S A.

speaker: patient
text: Can I have that done? I'm concerned. I am fifty after all.

speaker: doctor
text: Sure, we can check your cholesterol too. I know you have history of it being high.

speaker: patient
text: You know, I've been working on that. I quit smoking for a while, but I got back into it.

speaker: doctor
text: That's good, it's really hard to quit.

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I tried chewing tobacco, but it's not the same.

speaker: doctor
text: Be sure to keep trying to quit smoking.

speaker: doctor
text: Hi, how's it going?

speaker: patient
text: Not too bad, can't complain.

speaker: doctor
text: It looks like the weather's been warming up, which is nice.

speaker: patient
text: Yeah, I can't wait to spend some time with my kids this afternoon.

speaker: doctor
text: Aw, how many kids do you have?

speaker: patient
text: Two.

speaker: doctor
text: And are you single, dating, married?

speaker: patient
text: I've been married to my wife for about ten years now.

speaker: doctor
text: Congratulations! That's a decade, my friend.

speaker: patient
text: Hah, it sure is.

speaker: doctor
text: Are you from the area?

speaker: patient
text: I was actually born in Oklahoma.

speaker: doctor
text: How long-

speaker: patient
text: Moved up here in O seven.

speaker: doctor
text: Awesome. I moved here in O nine, so two years after you.

speaker: patient
text: No way! How funny. Where from?

speaker: doctor
text: I'm originally from Kentucky. And I have to do the routine ask, but any drinking, smoking, or illicit drug use?

speaker: patient
text: No to all of the above.

speaker: doctor
text: Got it.

speaker: doctor
text: Looks like the nurse came in and asked you everything. Ah, she has everything documented here, but I will ask one more time. So, tell me, where do you live?

speaker: patient
text: Oh, it's a senior citizen house. They have many nursing aids there.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you smoke?

speaker: patient
text: No.

speaker: doctor
text: Do you work?

speaker: patient
text: Ah, right now I can't because of this disability, but I used to work as the security guard.
